PAGE: 1
HEADING: STIEBEL

Stiebel, Salomon Friedrich (1792-1868), German (Hessen-Nassau) physician, zoolo-
gist and botanist; from 1855 hospital physician in Frankfurt; member of the Collegium
medicum 1828; from 1845 physician at a children's hospital; zoological director of the
Senckenbergische Naturforschende Gesellschaft. (<em>Stiebel</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: BM 5: 2020; De Toni 1: cxix, 2: cxi; PR ed. 1: 9931.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Brit. Mus. cat. print. books 230: 309. 1964; Bonplandia 2: 254. 1854, 4:
	350, 38. 1850.
Knoblauch, A., Ber. Senckenb. naturf. Ges. Frankfurt 59-60. 1919 (b. 20 Apr 1792, d.
	20 Mai 1868; philantropist-physician).

13.106. <em>Die Grundformen der Infusorien in den Heilquellen</em> nebst allgemeinen Bemerkungen
über die Entwickelung derselben ... Erstes Heft. Gallionella ferruginea. Conferva filifor-
mis sulphurata. Ueber die Keimpünktchen und deren Bedeutung in der organischen
Entwickelungsgeschichte ... Frankfurt am Main (Verlag von Carl Jügel) 1841. Qu. (in
twos). (<em>Grundf. Infus. Heilquell.</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: 16-23 Mai 1841 (Hinrichs; Flora rd. 9 Mar-28 Nov 1841), p. [1]-22, <em>1 pl</em>. (uncol.
	lith.). <em>Copy</em>: FH.

Stiefelhagen, Heinz (<em>fl</em>. 1911), German (Alsatian) botanist. (<em>Stiefelh</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: STR.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: BL 2: 171; MW p. 473

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Lack, H.W. &amp; C.-O. v. Sydow, Willdenowia 14: 440. 1984 (letter to Halácsy in
	Dörffler coll., UPS-UB.

13.107. <em>Systematische und pflanzengeographische Studien zur Kenntniss der Gattung Scrophularia</em>.
Vorarbeiten zu einer Monographie ... Leipzig (Wilhelm Engelmann) 1910. Oct. 

<em>Publ</em>.: 22 Mar, 9 Aug 1910 (in journal), cover-t.p., p. [i, recto of 406], [406]-496, <em>pl. 4.
	Copy</em>: HH. – Reprinted and to be cited from Bot. Jahrb. 44 (2-4): [406]-408. 22 Mar
	1910, 409-496, <em>pl. 4.</em> 9 Aug 1910.

Stiehler, August Wilhelm (1797-1878), German (Prussian-Saxony) lawyer and
paleobotanist; magistrate at Wernigerode, later in Quedlinburg. (<em>Stiehler</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Collections of fossils at Univ. Halle.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: ADB 36: 184-185 (H. Pröhle); Andrews p. 336; Barnhart
3: 330 (b. 6 Aug 1797, d. Mai 1878); Biol.-Dokum. 17: 8981; BM 5: 2020; CSP 5: 832, 8:
1018; Herder p. 353; LS 25880; PR 8972-8974, ed. 1: 9933; Quenstedt p. 415.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Brit. Mus. gen. cat. print. books 230: 326. 1964.

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Stiehleria</em> R. Daber (1953).

13.108. <em>Beiträge zur Kenntniss der vorweltlichen Flora des Kreidegebirges im Harze</em> ... Erster

	5(3-4): 71-80, <em>pl. 12-15.</em> Oct 1857-Feb 1858.

<em>Publ</em>.: Mai 1860 (Bot. Zeit. 8 Jun 1860; Festgabe 18 Mai 1860), p. [1]-12, <em>1 pl</em>. Reprint

Stillingfleet, Benjamin (1702-1771), British botanist, private tutor and author; B.A.
Trinity Coll., Oxford 1723. (<em>Stillingfleet</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Backer p. 551; Barnhart 3: 331 (d. 15 Dec 1771); BB p.
289; BM 5: 2021, 8: 1251; Bossert p. 384; Desmond p. 585; DNB 54: 373-375 (18: 1260-
1262); Frank 3 (Anh.): 100; Henrey 2: 110, 111-112, 116, 304, 538, 742; Herder p. 23,
236, 277; Jackson p. 33, 111, 213, 417, 419; PR 5418, 5425, 5477, 8977-8978, ed. 1:
5998-5999, 6012, 6066, 9934-9935; Rehder 1: 222; SO see index authors p. 51; Tucker 1:
669, 2: xxxvi, 3: 295.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Allen, D.E., Naturalist in Britain 43, 49. 1976.
Allibone, S.A., Crit. dict. Engl. lit. 2: 2260-2261. 1878.
Anon., Brit. Mus. gen. cat. print. books 230: 403-404. 1964; Cat. gén. livr. impr. Bibl.
	natl. 178: 593-595. 1950.
Armytage, G.J., Obituary prior to 1800, London 1901, p. 16.
Blackwood, J., Country Life 163: 832. 1978 (portr.).
Blunt, W., The compleat naturalist 149, 213. 1971.
Coxe, W., ed., Literary life and select works of Benjamin Stillingfleet. London 1811, 2
	vols. (1: 19, 256 p., 2: 7, 651 p.).
Druce, G.C., Fl. Berkshire cxliii. 1897.
Freeman, R.B., Brit. nat. hist. books 329-330. 1980.
Fussell, G.E., More old English farming books 41-44, 49, 63. 1948.
Jackson, B.D., J. Bot. 62: 361. 1924 (ex D.C. Tovey, Letters Thomas Gray, 2, 1904).
Milner, J.D., Cat. portr. Kew 99. 1906.
Smith-Dampier, J.L., East Anglian Worthies 179. 1949 (originator of the term Blue
	Stocking).
Walter, J.H.F., Trans. Norf. Norw. Natural. Soc. 9: 655. 1914 (on Stillingfleet and W.
	Hudson).

13.112. <em>Miscellaneous tracts</em> relating to natural history, husbandry, and physic. Translated
from the Latin, with notes by Benj. Stillingfleet ... London (printed and sold by R. and
J. Dodsley, ...) 1759. Oct. (<em>Misc. tracts</em>).

<em>Ed</em>. [<em>1</em>]: 1759, p. [i]-xxx, [xxxii], [1]-230. <em>Copy</em>: KU. – See SO 1319 and HU 573 for
	contents and notes. "The first fundamental treatise on the principles of Linnaeus
	published in England, and the era of the establishment of Linnaean botany in
	England". Contains on p. 202-218 <em>Observations on grasses</em> by B. Stillingfleet; on p. 1-30

HEADING: STIRTON

	C. Linnaeus, <em>An oration concerning travelling in one's own country</em> [orig.: <em>Orig. peregrinat.</em>

<em>Ed. 2</em>: 1762, p. [i]-xxxi, [xxxii], [1]-391, <em>pl. 1-11. Copies</em>: G, KU, MO, NY. – <em>Miscellaneous
	tracts ... physick</em>. To which is added the <em>Calendar of flora</em>. By Benj. Stillingfleet. The
	second edition, corrected, and augmented with additional notes throughout, part-

	London (printed and sold by R. and J. Dodsley, ...) 1762. Oct. SO 1320. – Contains
	e.g. <em>The calendar of flora</em>, Swedish and English, made in the year 1755 on p. 229-337,

	tracts ... the third edition". London (id.) 1775. Oct. Main contents as in ed. 2.

	... the fourth edition". London (id.) 1791. Oct. – SO 1322, 1904. Main contents as in
	ed. 2.

	London 1762, and in Stillingfleet, Literary life 2, 1811.

Stirling, James (1852-1909), Australian geologist and botanist; land officer at Omeo,
Victoria 1878; died in Riverside, California. (<em>J. Stirling</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Material at B (partly destr.), BM (bryo.), KIEL (phan.), MEL,
determined by F. v. Mueller. – Some <em>letters</em> at G.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 331; BB p. 289; BL 1: 74, 75, 320; Bossert p.
384 (d. 25 Jun 1909); CSP 11: 501, 12: 705, 18: 966-967; Desmond p. 586 (b. 9 Jan
1852); HR (bibl.); Rehder 5: 825; Urban-Berl. 314.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Ferguson, J.A., Bibl. Australia 3: 64, 65. 1951, 7: 442-443. 1969.
Maiden, J.H., Rep. Australas. Ass. Adv. Sci. 13: 234. 1911 (bibl.).
Mueller, F. v., Vict. Natural. 6: 166-167. 1890 (brief note; <em>Helichrysum Stirlingi</em>).
Robert, W.C.H., Contr. bibl. Australia ed. 2. 3: 295. 1970.
Willis, J., Vict. Natural. 87: 145. 1970, 66: 126. 1949 (coll. in Australian Alps).

<sm>NOTE</sm>: Sir James Stirling (1791-1865) was the first lieutenant-governor of W. Australia,
honored in botanical eponymy because he "advanced the study of Western Australian
Plants (J.H. Maiden, J. West. Austral. nat. Hist. Soc. 6: 25-26. 1909). – James Stirling
(1836-1916) collected mosses in Kent and owned a bryophyte herbarium which is at
Tunbridge Wells Museum (Desmond p. 586, see also Bryologist 21: 96. 1919 and Proc.
R. Soc. London ser. A. 93: xli-xlii). – John Stirling Stirling (1832-1900), Lieut.-Col.,
Royal Artillery, U.K., published <em>Notes on the flora of Stirlingshire</em> with R. Kidston (q.v.),
10 papers in Trans. Stirling nat. Hist. Arch. Soc. 1890/91-1899/1900 (see BL 2: 312).
His herbarium is at STIU (on loan from STI; further material in LIV and NMW (see
D.H. Kent &amp; D.E. Allen, Brit. Irish herb. 251. 1984).

13.114. <em>The cryptogamia of the Australian Alps</em>. Part i. ... Royal Society of Victoria ...
1885. (<em>Crypt. Austral. Alps</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: 9 Dec 1885 (date on cover), cover-t.p., p. [1]-8. <em>Copy</em>: PH.

Stirton, James (1833-1917), Scottish physician and cryptogamist; MD Edinburgh
1858; lecturer on gynecology Royal Infirmary; Glasgow 1879-1889; professor of gyne-
cology Glasgow 1889-ca. 1904. (<em>Stirt</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: GLAM (2000 lich., 7000 mosses); further material at BM (smal-

PAGE: 4
HEADING: STIRTON

ler part of orig. lichen herb.; dupl. mosses, lich.), BRI, CHR, DBN, E, GL, NMW,
OXF, WELT.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 331 (d. 14 Jan 1917); BB p. 289; BM 5:
2022; Clokie p. 249; CSP 8: 1020, 11: 502, 12: 705, 18: 967; Desmond 586; GR 381;
Hawksworth p. 186; IDC 340, 517; IH 1 (ed. 6): 365, (ed. 7): 99, 343; Kelly p. 219;
Lenley p. 388; LS 25895-25934 (lich.); Morren ed. 10, p. 78; SBC p. 133.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Boyd, D.A., Glasgow Natural. 8(4): 142-144. 1920 (obit.).
Bridson, G.D.R. et al., Nat. hist. mss. res. Brit. Isl. 84.21, 157.6. 1980.
Dixon, H.N., J. Bot. 61: 10-17. Jan, 46-52. Feb, 69-75. Mar 1923 ("Dr. Stirton's new
	British mosses revised").
Doidge, E., Bothalia 5: 1020. 1950 (bibl. S. Afr. lich.).
Gyelnik, V.K., Ann. hist.-nat. Mus. natl. Hung., Bot. 31: 57. 1938.
Hawksworth, D.L. &amp; M.R.D. Seaward, Lichenol. Brit. Isl. 23, 155, 199. 1977 (bibl.).
Jones, G., Glasgow Natural. 20: 54, 57. 1980 (lichen herbarium divided over GLAM
	and BM).
Laundon, J.R., Lichenologist 11: 17. 1979 (coll.).
Rogers, R.W., Austrobaileya 1(5): 502-510. 1982 (typification Australian lichens).
Sayre, G., Bryologist 80: 518. 1977 (coll. mosses).
Trail, J.W.H., Proc. Linn. Soc. London 129: 71-75. 1917 (obit., bibl.).
Urban, I., Symb. ant. 1: 160. 1898 (Challenger exp. lichens see J. Linn. Soc. Lond. 14:
	369-372. 1875).

<sm>COMPOSITE</sm> <sm>WORKS</sm>: (1) <em>Cryptogamic flora, in</em> Edward Richard Alston, <em>Notes on the fauna and
flora of the West of Scotland</em>, Glasgow 1876.

lists, <em>A contribution towards a complete list of the fauna and flora of Clydesdale</em> ... Glasgow 1876.

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Stirtonia</em> A.L. Smith (1926); <em>Stirtonia</em> R. Brown (1900).

Stizenberger, Ernst (1827-1895), German (Baden) physician and lichenologist;
studied medicine at Freiburg i. Br. and Zürich, state exam. med. 1850; Dr. med. Frei-
burg 1851; practicing phycisian at Konstanz 1851-1895; from 1852 also inspector of the
pharmacies in S. Baden; active politician and musician. (<em>Stizenb</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: ZT; duplicates B (mainly destr.), H, L, M, OXF, WRSL.
<em>Exsiccatae</em>: (1) With A. Braun and L. Rabenhorst, <em>Characeen Europas</em> fasc. 1-5, 121 nos.,
1857-1878. For further details see index under A. Braun (TL-2/1: 307) and L. Raben-
horst (exs. 10). – Flora 39: 223-224. 14 Apr 1856 (announcement; identifications by A.
Braun); A. Braun et al., Bot. Zeit. 14: 230-232. 1856 (description), Schlechtendal,
D.F.L. von, Bot. Zeit. 15: 726-728. 1857 (rev. fasc. 1), Fürnrohr, A.E., Flora 41: 42-45.
1858 (id.), 42: 669-672. 1819 (id. fasc. 2), Anon., Bot. Zeit. 17: 383-384. 1859 (rev. fasc.

PAGE: 6
HEADING: STIZENBERGER

2). – Fasc. 5 publ. before 21 Jun 1878 (Bot. Zeit. 21 Jun 1878). Additional sets: see IH 2:
726.
(2) With J.B. Jack and L. Leiner, <em>Kryptogamen Badens</em>, 1857-1880 nos. 1-1000, 21 fasc. –
For further details see under J.B. Jack (TL-2/2: 394 and IH 2: 305). – Schlechtendal,
D.F.L. von, Bot. Zeit. 18: 134-136. 13 Apr 1860 (rev. fasc. 1-4), 19: 44. 8 Feb 1861 (rev.
7-8), 19: 303-304. 11 Oct 1861 (rev. 9-10), 21: 8. 2 Jan 1863 (rev. 12), 22: 351-352. 12
Nov 1864 (rev. 13-14), 22: 415. 30 Dec 1864 (rev. 15-16), Bary, A. de, Bot. Zeit. 28: 775-
776. 2 Dec 1870 (rev. 18-19), Anon., Bot Zeit. 38: 624. 3 Sep 1880 (ann. 20-21, nos. 901-
1000). – <em>Alphabetisches Verzeichniss nebst Standortangabe</em>: W. Baur, Mitt. badisch. bot. Ver.
87-89: 301-326. 1891. See also Lagerheim (1889).
<em>Letters</em> to W.G. Farlow at FH, to D.F.L. von Schlechtendal at HAL; 932 letters in W.
Nylander's correspondence at H-UB (plus 365 from N. to S.); other letters at G.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: ADB 54: 534-535 (E. Wunschmann); Ainsworth p. 336;
Barnhart 3:332 (b. 13 Jun 1887, d. 27 Sep 1895); Biol.-Dokum. 17: 8996; BJI 1: 56; BM
5: 2022-2023; Clokie p. 249; CSP 5: 835, 8: 1020, 11: 502-503, 18: 967-968; De Toni 1:
cxix, 2: cxi; DTS 1: 292; Frank 3 (Anh.): 100; GR p. 49, <em>pl</em>. [<em>17</em>], cat. p. 72; Hawksworth

Stocker, Otto (1888-1979), German (Baden) plant physiologist and ecologist; Dr. phil.
Freiburg i. Br. 1923; scientific assistant at the Techn. Hochschule Karlsruhe 1913-1914;
high school teacher at Bremerhaven 1915-1934; professor of botany and director of the
Botanical Institute and Garden in Darmstadt 1934-1959; in retirement still actively
travelling and publishing. (<em>Stocker</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 332 (b. 17 Dec 1888); BFM 1713, 3291;
Biol.-Dokum. 17: 8998-8999; BJI 2: 171; Bossert p. 384; DTS 1: 293; GR p. 141-142; LS
suppl. 26778; Moebius p. 257, 259.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Hedwigia 74: (141). 1934 (app. Darmstadt), 75: (72). 1935 (id.); Österr.
	bot. Z. 83: 160. 1934 (app. Darmstadt).
Degener, H.A.L., Wer ist's ed. 10. 1559. 1935.
Evenari, M. &amp; O.L. Lange, Flora 168: 5-11. 1979 (tribute 90th birthday; portr.).
Lüttge, U., Ber. deut. bot. Ges. 92: 1-6. 1979 (90th birthday; sketch of life and work;
	portr.).
Ziegler, H., Ber. deut. bot. Ges. 81: 558, 565. 1970.
Ziegler, H. et al., Ber. deut. bot. Ges. 95: 375-386. 1982 (obit., bibl., portr.).

<sm>COMPOSITE</sm> <sm>WORKS</sm>: <em>Die Aegyptisch-Arabische Wüste, in</em> G. Karsten and H. Schenck, ed.,
<em>Vegetationsbilder</em> ser. 17, 5/6, Jena 1926, ser. 18, I. Jena 1927.

<sm>FESTSCHRIFT</sm>: Ber. deut. bot. Ges. 92. 1979.

Stockmans, François (1904-x), Belgian botanist; "aide-naturaliste"; later director of
the palaeontological department of the Brussels Museum of natural history and Labor-
atory director at the Institut royal des Sciences naturelles de Belgique; professor at the
Université de Bruxelles. (<em>Stockmans</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Section de Paléobotanique, Institut royal des Sciences naturelles,
Bruxelles. – Some herbarium material at BR.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Andrews p. 336; Biol.-Dokum. 17: 9000; BM 8: 1257;
Roon p. 108; TL-2/9074.

Anon., Brit. Mus. gen. cat. print. books 230: 656. 1964; Index biogr., Acad. R. Belgique
	244. 1964 (b. 13 Sep 1904).

Verdoorn, F., ed., Chron. bot. 1: 91. 1935, 2: 33, 83, 381. 1936, 5: 526. 1939, 6: 119.

Stockmayer, Siegfried (1868-1933), Austrian physician and botanist (algologist); Dr.
med. Wien 1892; district physician in Frankenfels and subsequently municipal physician
in Unter-Waltersdorf 1893-1909; from 1913 practicing physician at Stammersdorf nr.
Wien. (<em>Stockmayer</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: W. – Contributed to <em>Kryptogamae exsiccatae editae a Museo palatino
Vindobonensi</em>, sets e.g. in B, E, LE and W. – <em>Letters</em> at G.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 332; Biol.-Dokum. 17: 9000; Bossert p. 384;
CSP 18: 970; De Toni 4: liv; LS 25968; Nordstedt p. 30, suppl. 15; Tucker 3: 296.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Keissler, K., Verh. zool.-bot. Ges. Wien 85: 149-157. 1935 (obit., portr., bibl.,
	b. 8 Aug 1868, d. 20 Mar 1933).
Koster, J.Th., Taxon 18: 558. 1969 (types algae at B; if so now mainly destr.).
Prescott, G.W., Bibl. Desmidiac. univ. 481. 1984.

<sm>COMPOSITE</sm> <sm>WORKS</sm>: (1) <em>Charophyta, in</em> I.S. Poetsch &amp; K.B. Schiedermayr, <em>Nachträge, Syste-
matische Aufzählung der im Erzherzogthume Oesterreich ob der Enns bisher beobachteten samenlosen
Pflanzen</em> ... Wien 1894, p. 60-61 (Bot. Centralbl. 30 Oct 1864), TL-2/8095.
(2) <em>Algae, in</em> G. Beck, <em>Flora von Südbosnien</em> 1(4): 7-10. 1890, Ann. Naturh. Hofmus., Wien
4(4): 345-348. 1890.
(3) I. Classe, <em>Algen, in Nachträge</em> zur systematischen <em>Aufzählung der im Herzogthum Österreich
ob der Ems bisher beobachteten samenlosen Pflanzen</em> (Kryptogamen) p. 23-59. 1894.
(4) <em>Algae, in</em> H. von Handel-Mazetti, <em>Ergebnisse einer botanischen Reise in das Pontische Rand-
gebirge</em> im Sandschak Trapezunt, Ann. k.k. Naturh. Hofmuseum, Wien 23, 1909.

HEADING: STÖRCK

	cited from Österr. bot. Z. 59: 183-186. 1909. – Proposed to accept J.B. De Toni, Syll.

Stockwell, [William] Palmer (1898-1950), American botanist, MS (Bot.) Univ.
Arizona 1932; Dr. phil. Stanford 1940; technical assistant Carnegie Institution of Was-
hington at Stanford 1932-1935; with Inst. Forest Genetics, Calif. Forest &amp; Range Exp.
Sta. until 1950, director from 1940. (<em>Stockw</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: CAS, DS and UC; further material at C, DPU. – <em>Field notes</em> at

Störck, Anton [Freiherr] von (1731-1803), German (Württemberg) physician and
pharmacologist in Vienna; Dr. med. 1757; from 1760 private physician to the emperor;
1766 dean at the Vienna Medical Faculty, rector of the University 1768; later director
of the Medical Faculty and of the medical studies at the University; "Freiherr" 1777.
(<em>Störck</em>).

ib. 1911, full professor 1916-1942; Dr. Sci. h.c. Oberlin 1955; worked at Buitenzorg

Stoliczka, Ferdinand (1838-1874), Moravian palaeontologist, geologist and zoologist;
with the Geologische Reichsanstalt Wien 1861-1862; in the Geological Survey of India
1862-1874. (<em>Stoliczka</em>).

Stolle, Emil (1868-1940), German (Oberlausitz) botanist (bryologist and
lichenologist); gardener in various places; from 1919 merchant (vegetables) (from 1921-
ca. 1934 as street vendor) in Dresden. (<em>Stolle</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: DR (Sphagnum herb.; extant), WBM (herb. Röll); some lichens
at M, bryophytes at B (mainly destr.), and L. – Stolle acquired the <em>Hepaticae</em> from the
estate of L. Rabenhorst.
<em>Exsiccatae</em> (1) with A. Schade and Riehmer, <em>Lichenes saxonici exsiccati</em>, 1924-1935, Dec. 1-
56. Sets at BM, DR, FH, M. – Schedae in mss.
(2) with A. Schade, <em>Hepaticae saxonicae exsiccatae</em>, 1923-1936 (1937?). Dec. 1-29. Sets at
FH, L. – Schedae in mss.
(3) with A. Schade, <em>Sphagna saxonica</em> Dec. 1, 1923, nos. 1-10.

13.178. <em>Die Psilophyten</em>. i. Alter und Reihenfolge der Psilophyten in den Devonfloren. ii.

Serodiagnostik. Hannover (Druck von Wilh. Riemschneider) 1925. Oct. 

<em>Publ</em>.: 1925 (ÖbZ for Jun-Sep 1925), cover-t.p., p. 39-76. <em>Copy</em>: B. – Reprinted and to be
	cited from Jahresber. Niedersächs. geol. Ver. Hannover 18: 39-96. 1925. – Engler, in
	his review (1926), commenting on Serodiagnostics: "Vorderhand hat die Wissenschaft
	das Stadium der morphologischen Systeme noch nicht überwunden und es ist ver-
	früht, zu glauben, dass man sie bereits durch ein einziges, vollkommen natürliches
	System zu ersetzen fähig sei, welches das Ziel alles Strebens ist. Durch grosse Worte,
	Voreiligkeit und Übertreibung wird man es nicht schneller, sondern nur langsamer
	erreichen, da der Wiederabbau des zu Vielen und nicht Stabilen Zeit und Kraft
	kosten werden".
<em>Ref</em>.: Engler, A., Bot. Jahrb. 60 (Lit.): 61-65. 1 Apr 1926 (rev.).
	Gothan, W., Z. f. Bot. 18: 522-523. 1926 (rev.).
	Mez, C., Bot. Echo 1: 67-69. 1925 (rev.).

Stolz, Adolf [Ferdinand] (1871-1917), South-Africa-born (son of a Moravian brother)
German missionary and botanical collector; merchant at Neuwied a. Rh. and Wriezen
1885-1897; merchant in the service of the mission of the Moravian Brethern (Herrnhuter
Mission) in Nyassaland (German East Africa; h.t. Malawi) charged with the develop-
ment of plantations 1898-1914; from 1914-1917 in Germany, ultimately in the mission's
hospital for tropical diseases at Tübingen. (<em>Stolz</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: B (first set destr. but many duplicates extant); other material at
A, B, BP, BR, C, E, F, G, GH, GRO, HBG, JE, K, L, LD, LE, M, MO, MTJB, NY, P,
PH, PR, PRE, S, SAM, STU, U, UPS, US, W, WAG, WRSL, Z. – The duplicates
were distributed from B but also by Otto Weigel (see e.g. Herbarium 48: 460. 1919, 66:
179. 1923). – A copy of a hectographed map and list of collecting localities is at B; see
also Harms 1918.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: IH 1 (ed. 6): 365, (ed. 7): 343, 2: (files); Urban-Berl. p.
315, 401.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Harms, H. et al., Notizbl. k. bot. Gart. Mus. Berlin 7(66): 281-288. 1918 (obit.
	by Direction of Moravian Brethern and by Harms, b. 17 Jan 1871, d. 25/26 Dec
	1917).

White, A. &amp; B.L. Sloane, The Stapelieae ed. I. 137. 1933, ed. 2. 844. 1937.

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Stolzia</em> Schlechter (1915).

Stomps, Theodoor Jan (1885-1973), Dutch botanist (cytologist and geneticist); Dr.
phil. Amsterdam 1910; student of Hugo de Vries; extraordinary professor of cytology
1910, idem cytology and systematics 1913; ordinary professor of botany 1919-1946; dir-
ector of the Amsterdam Botanical Garden 1923-1946; from 1946 in retirement. (<em>Stomps</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: AMD; further material at L. – <em>Letters</em> at G.

Stone, Witmer (1866-1939), American naturalist (ornithologist and botanist); B.A.
Univ. Pennsylvania 1887, MA 1891, Dr. Sci. h.c. 1913; conservator of the ornithological
section of the Academy of natural sciences, Philadelphia 1891, executive curator of its
Museum 1918-1925 and director 1925-1928; from 1928 emeritus director; collected
widely in N. and S. America; co-founder of the Philadelphia Botanical Club, 1891.
(<em>Stone</em>).

	1912) at his home. This agrees well with the date 26 Jan 1912 given by TBC.

	"volume I" and "volume II".
	<em>1</em>: [i], 25-550.
	<em>2</em>: [i], [551]-828, [829], <em>pl. 1-129.</em>
	<em>Note</em>: this issue of the flora, lacking the t.p. and p. 3-21 of of the Annual Report, with
	two different t.p.'s instead is dated 1911. It is not clear whether this came out (or
	whether vol. 1 came out) before or after the journal issue. In view of Pennell's
	personal account (he was present at the handing out of early copies on 12 Feb
	1912), it seems best to consider this issue for the time being as having been pub-
	lished in 1912.

	plants of southern New Jersey/Witmer Stone ... Quarterman Publications, Inc.
	Boston", ISBN 0-88000-009-0, see Taxon 22: 467-468. 1973. Contains on p. [iv] a

	preface with information on Stone by E.M. Woodford.

Stoneman, Bertha [M.] (1866-1943), American-born botanist; Dr. sci. Cornell Univ.
1896, settled in South Africa 1897; in charge of the Botany Dept. of the Huguenot
College for Women, Wellington, Cape Prov. 1897-1921; president id. 1921-1933; from
1933 in retirement at Bainskloof. (<em>Stoneman</em>).

Stopes, Marie [Charlotte Carmichael] (1880-1958), British paleobotanist, pioneer
of birth control, sex education and emancipation of women; Dr. phil. München 1904;
Dr. sci. London Univ. 1905; asst. lecturer in palaeobotany, Manchester University
1904-1909; lecturer ib. 1909-1913; lecturer at University College London 1914-1920;
from 1920 turning her attention mainly to birth control; opened "The mothers' clinic"
in London 1921; married Reginald Ruggles Gates 1911 (annulled 1916), Humphrey
Verdon Roe, 1918. (<em>Stopes</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: BM; further material at NY.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Andrews p. 336-337; Barnhart 3: 335 (b. 15 Oct 1880);
Biol.-Dokum. 17: 9020; BJI 2: 172-173; BM 8: 1259; Bossert p. 385; Desmond p. 588;
DNB suppl. 7: 930-931; LS 41768; Plesch p. 417; SO 895; TL-2/11.820; Tucker 1: 670,
2: xxxvi, 3: 296.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Adam, Corinna, New Statesman 78: 177-178. 8 Aug 1969 (reassessment: disap-
	pointed prophetess).
Andrews, H.N., The fossil hunters 14, 138-142, 211. 1980 (personal recoll.; portr.).
Anon., Biography Index 5: 690. 1961, 6: 565. 1964, 8: 654. 1970, 10: 730. 1976, 11: 751.
	1979 (q.v. for further biographical references); Bot. Centralbl. 96: 576. 1904 (app.
	asst. lecturer Manchester), 110: 352. 1909 (app. regular lecturer on paleobotany ib.),
	123: 240. 1913 (appointed to the new lectureship in fossil botany at Univ. Coll.
	London); Brit. med. J. 5101: 920-921. 11 Oct 1958 (obit.); Brit. Mus. gen. cat. print.
	books 230: 987-994. 1964; Hedwigia 54: (126). 1913 ("Ordinarius" at the chair of
	paleobotany, Univ. London); Nat. Nov. 26: 597. 1904 (junior professor, Manchester),
	31: 241. 1909 (lecturer ib.); New Scientist 88: 177. 1980 (portr., biogr. sketch); The
	Lancet 1958(2): 804-805 (obit.); The New York Times 3 Oct 1958 (d.; portr.); Who's

Strachey, Richard (1817-1908), British colonial administrator, geophysicist and natu-
ralist; with Bombay Engineers 1836, with Bengal Engineers 1839; collected in Punch,
Kashmir, and Gharwal Kumaon, 1846-1849; in various military and administrative
positions until 1871; stationed in England 1871-1876; retired as Lieutenant-general.
(<em>Strachey</em>).

M, OXF, P (collections made jointly with James Edward Winterbottom 1803-1804), W,
YU. – Geological collections in the India Museum, London.

HEADING: STRASBURGER

Schube, Th., Ber. deut. bot. Ges. 15: (41)-(43). 1897 (obit., bibl.).

Strasburger, Eduard Adolf (1844-1912), Polish-born (of German descent) German
botanist; studied at Paris 1861-1862, Warsaw 1862-1864, Bonn 1864, Jena (with N.
Pringsheim) 1864-1866; Dr. phil. Jena 1866; habil. Warsaw 1867; lecturer ib. 1867-
1869; extraordinary professor of botany at Jena 1869-1871, full professor 1871-1880;
professor of botany at Bonn 1880-1912; founder of modern plant cytology. (<em>Strasb</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Early pteridological and European collections in WA (2500);
duplicates at LE. – Library left to Bot. Inst. Bonn. <em>Correspondence</em> see Holzmann (1967),
p. 5-6. Other letters at G, UPS-UB.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Ainsworth p. 121-122, 283, 320, 347; Backer p. 662;
Barnhart 3: 338 (b. 1 Feb 1844, d. 19 Mai 1912); BFM 3287; Biol.-Dokum. 17: 9039-
9040; BJI 1: 56, 2: 173; BM 5: 2033-2034; Bossert p. 386; CSP 8: 1030, 11: 514-515, 18:
997; De Toni 1: cxx, 2: cxii, 4: lv; DSB 13: 87-90 (G. Robinson); Frank 3 (Anh.): 101;
GR 730-731; Herder p. 123, 272, 273, 294; Jackson p. 74, 75, 78, 93, 99, 108, 120, 129,
149, 490; LS 26014-26018, 39708, suppl. 26919-26922; Moebius p. 457 [index]; Morren
ed. 2, p. 11, ed. 10, p. 8; MW p.474; NI 1901-1903; Plesch p. 417; PR 8998-8999;
Quenstedt p. 418; Rehder 5: 827; TL-2/see indexes; TR 1384-1386; Tucker 1: 671, 3:
297.

<sm>COMPOSITE</sm> <sm>WORKS</sm>: (1) Editor (with W. Pfeffer), Jahrb. wiss. Bot. 27-50, 1895-1912.
(2) Editor, with Wilhelm Benecke, <em>Zellen- und Gewebelehre Morphologie und Entwicklungsge-
schichte</em>, i: <em>Botanischer Teil</em>, Leipzig (Druck und Verlag von B.G. Teubner) 1913, vii, 338
p. (Kultur der Gegenwart, Teil 3, Abt. 4, Band 2, I. Botanischer Teil).

<sm>THESIS</sm>: "<em>Asplenium bulbiferum</em>, ein Beitrag zur Entwicklungsgeschichte des Farnblattes mit
besonderer Berücksichtigung der Spaltöffnungen und des Chlorophylls" [Jena 1866,
unpublished], main results published in Jahrb. wiss. Bot. 5: 297-342. 1867, a publication
which served as "Habilitationsschrift" for Warsaw.

<sm>NOTE</sm>: Main general bibliography (also including all items published in Polish):
Hryniewiecki (1938); an important addition to this biography is the study by B.
Holzmann (1967) based on numerous original sources such as the correspondence re-
ceived by Strasburger held by the Strasburger family and letters by Strasburger to K.
von Goebel with the Baierische Akademie der Wissenschaften, München.

<sm>HANDWRITING</sm>: Hryniewiecki, B., Prof. Dr. Edward Strasburger, Warsawa 1938, p. 61;
Burdet, H., Candollea 33: 415-416. 1978; Bot. Gaz. 54: 72. 1912.

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Strasburgeria</em> Baillon (1876) probably honors this author.

<sm>POSTAGE</sm> <sm>STAMPS</sm>: Poland 3 zl. (1973) yv. 2127.

HEADING: STRASBURGER

13.237. <em>Lehrbuch der Botanik</em> für Hochschulen ... Jena (Verlag von Gustav Fischer) 1894.
Oct. (<em>Lehrb. Bot.</em>).

<em>Title</em>: also called, unofficially, and never on the title-pages: "Bonner Handbuch" (the
	original authors were all professor or lecturer (Privatdozent) at the University of
	Bonn) and "Viermännerbuch". This Lehrbuch, with its 32 editions, has had a pro-
	found influence on the teaching of botany in the Germanic language part of cont-
	inental Europe in the twentieth century.
<em>Authorship</em>: original authors: E. Strasburger, Fritz Noll (1858-1908, see TL-2/3: 763),
	[Johann] Heinrich [Rudolph] Schenck (1860-1929) (TL-2/5: 130-133), and Andreas
	Franz Wilhelm Schimper (1856-1901) (TL-2/5: 160-163). The authorship for the
	various sections in the subsequent editions was:
	<em>Einleitung und Morphologie</em>: eds. i-ii, 1894-1911: E. Strasburger; eds. 12-26, 1913-1954:
	Hans [Johannes Theodor Gustav Ernst] Fitting (1877-?); eds. 27-31, 1958-1978:
	Dietrich von Denffer.
	<em>Physiologie</em>: eds. 1-9, 1894-1908: Fritz Noll; eds. 10-16, 1909-1923: Ludwig Jost (1865-
	1947), eds. 17-21, 1928-1939: Hermann Sierp (1885-1958); eds. 22-30, 1944-1971:
	Walter Schumacher, ed. 31, 1978: Hubert Ziegler.
	<em>Niedere Pflanzen</em>: eds. 1-16, 1895-1923: Heinrich Schenck; eds. 17-28, 1928-1962:
	Richard Harder (1888-?); eds. 29-31, 1967-1978: Karl Mägdefrau (1907-x).
	<em>Samenpflanzen</em>: eds. 1-5, 1894-1901: A.F.W. Schimper; eds. 6-19, 1904-1936: Georg

PAGE: 37
HEADING: STRASBURGER(LEHRB.)

	Karsten (1863-1937); eds. 20-29, 1939-1967: Franz Firbas (1902-1964); eds. 30-31,
	1971-1978: Friedrich Ehrendorfer (1927-x).
	<em>Pflanzengeographie</em>: eds. 20-29, 1939-1967: Franz Firbas; eds. 30-31, 1971-1978: Fried-
	rich Ehrendorfer.
<em>Ed</em>. [<em>1</em>]: Oct 1894 (p. [iii]: Jul 1894; Bot. Zeit. 1 Dec 1894; Bot. Centralbl. 14 Nov 1894;
	ÖbZ for Oct 1894; Hedwigia Dec 1894; Nat. Nov. Oct(2) 1894), rev. by H. de Vries;

Strasser, Pius (1843-1927), Austrian priest and botanist (lichenologist, mycologist);
chaplain at St. Peter in der Au 1867-1868; id. Markt Aschbach 1869-1873; professor at
the gymnasium of the Stift Seitenstetten 1873-1885; priest at Waidhofen a.d. Ybbs 1885-
1919; in retirement at Seitenstetten 1919-1927. (<em>Strass</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: W. – Other material at C, CUP, E, LD, M, STU, WRSL. –
Contributed to Kryptogamae exsiccatae, Mus. Palat. Vindb.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: AG 5(1): 603; Barnhart 3: 338 (b. 27 Dec 1843, d. 9 Nov
1927); Bossert p. 386; DTS 1: 404; GR, cat. p. 72; Hirsch p. 289; IH 2: (files); Kelly p.
219; LS 26019-26023, 39709-39710, suppl. 26923-26927; Tucker 1: 671.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Österr. bot. Z. 76: 330. 1927 (d.).
Keissler, K., Verh. zool.-bot. Ges., Wien 78: 1-4. 1928 (obit., portr., bibl.).

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Strasseria</em> G. Bresadola et P.A. Saccardo ex P. Strasser (1902); <em>Strasseriopsis</em>
B.C. Sutton et T. Kobayashi (1970).

<sm>NOTE</sm>: Main publications in Verh. zool.-bot. Ges. Wien (no reprints with independent
pagination seen by us):
(1) <em>Zur Flechtenflora Niederösterreichs</em>, 39(Abh.): 327-372. Late Sep 1889.
(2) <em>Pilzflora des Sonntagberges</em> (Nieder-Oesterreich):
	1: <em>in</em> Verh. 50 (Abh.): 190-196. 25 Mai 1900.
	2: <em>in</em> 50 (Abh.): 293-301. 25 Jul 1900.
	3: <em>in</em> 50 (Abh.): 359-372. 24 Aug 1900.
	4: <em>in</em> 51 (Abh.): 412-425. 18 Aug 1901.
	<em>Nachtr. 1, in</em> 51 (Abh.): 640-645. 29 Nov 1901.
	<em>Nachtr. 2, in</em> 52 (Abh.): 429-437. 25 Sep 1902.
	<em>Nachtr. 3, in</em> 55 (Abh.): 600-621. 30 Dec 1905.
	<em>Nachtr. 4, in</em> 57 (Abh.): 299-320. 30 Aug 1907, 321-340. 14 Dec 1907.
	<em>Nachtr. 5, in</em> 60 (Abh.): 303-304. 15 Jul 1910, 305-335. 20 Oct 1910, 464-477. 30 Dec
	1910.
	<em>Nachtr. 6, in</em> 65 (Abh.): 79-104. 1 Mar 1915, 159-164. 30 Apr 1915, 208-224. 30 Apr
	1915, 225-227. 15 Jul 1915.
	<em>Nachtr. 7, in</em> 68 (Abh.): 97-123. 10 Jun 1918, 69 (Abh.): 355-384. 31 Dec 1919, 385. 31
	Mar 1920.

Stratingh, Gozewinus Acker (1804-1876), Dutch geologist, archeologist and botanist;
Dr. med. Groningen 1828; Dr. phil. h.c. ib. 1850; dedicated himself (after a brief period
as practicing physician) entirely to the natural sciences, working as a private scientist.
(<em>Stratingh</em>).

PAGE: 41
HEADING: STRATTON

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown; the Stratingh herbarium at GRO was made by
Sibrandus(?) E. Stratingh (<em>fl</em>. 1856-1857).

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: BL 2: 431, 720; NNBW 3: 1206-1208; Oudemans 2(2):
147; Rehder 3: 827; TL-2/2291.

Breure, A.S.H.&amp; J.G. de Bruijn, eds., Leven en werken van J.G.S. van Breda 51, 234,
	270, 277, 279, 415. 1979.

13.249. <em>Initia florae groninganae</em>, of proeve van eene naamlijst der planten, welke in de
provincie Groningen gevonden worden. Uitgegeven door het Genootschap ter bevorder-
ing der natuurlijke historie te Groningen. Groningen (by J. Oomkens, ...) 1825. Oct. (<em>Init. fl. groning.</em>).

Stratman, Mary Agatha, sister (1894-?), American nun and botanist; sister of the
Immaculate Heart, Hollywood Calif; Dr. phil. Cath. Univ. America 1935; chairman
Dept. biology Immaculate Heart College, Los Angeles from 1935. (<em>Stratman</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 338.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Amer. men sci. ed. 7: 1725. 1944 (b. 30 Nov 1894).

13.250. <em>A key to the Pteridophyta, the Gymnospermae and the Monocotyledonae of the State of
California</em> ... A dissertation submitted to the Faculty of the Graduate School of Arts and
Sciences of the Catholic University of America in partial fulfillment of the requirements
for the degree of doctor of philosophy. Washington, D.C. (The Catholic University of
America) 1935. Oct. (<em>Key Pterid. Gymnosp. Monocot. Calif.</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: 1935 (USDA rd 11 Mar 1936), p. [i]-viii, 1-133. <em>Copies</em>: HH, NY, USDA. – The
	Catholic University of America, Biological Series no. 19.

Stratton, Frederic (1840-1916), British botanist at Newport, Isle of Wight, clerk to the
Board of Guardians ib. 1863-1903; practicing solicitor 1863-1914. (<em>Stratton</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Material at ABD, BM, CGE, DOR, E, FRS, K, MANCH,
NMW, OXF, PSCB, WAR (see Kent &amp; Allen 1984).

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 338 (b. 16 Nov 1840, d. 5 Dec 1916); BB p.
291; BL 2: 244, 720; BM 5: 2034; Bossert p. 386; Clokie p. 250; CSP 8: 1031, 11:515, 18:
999; Desmond p. 589; Rehder 1: 535; Tucker 1: 671.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Bot. Soc. Exch. Club Brit. Isl. Rep. 4(5): 468-469. 1917 (obit.).
Britten, J., J. Bot. 55: 20-22. 1917 (obit., portr.).
Jackson, B.D., Proc. Linn. Soc. 129: 66-67. 1917.
Kent, D.H., Brit. herb. 80. 1957 (coll.).
Kent, D.H. &amp; D.E. Allen, Brit. Irish herb. 252. 1984 (coll.).

<sm>COMPOSITE</sm> <sm>WORKS</sm>: (1) Contributed to A.G. More, <em>Suppl. fl. vect.</em> 1871, TL-2/6291.
(2) <em>Flowering plants and ferns and their allies, in</em> F. Morey, ed., A guide to the natural
history of the Isle of Wight 126-199. 1909. – See also: <em>Isle of Wight plants</em>, J. Bot. 51: 285-
294. 1913, 54: 232-233, 291. 1916 and his popular <em>Wild flowers of Isle of Wight</em>. 1900.

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Strattonia</em> Ciferri (1954) was named for Robert Stratton (1883-?), American

PAGE: 42
HEADING: STRATTON

mycologist, author of <em>The Fimetariales of Ohio</em>, Ohio Biol. Surv. 3(2) [Bull. 12]. 1921.

Straus, Adolf Paul Carl (1901-x), German (Berlin) palaeobotanist and mycologist;
Dr. phil. Göttingen 1929; managing clerk 1930-1941; owner of the bookprinting shop
1941, publisher 1954; collaborator Berlin-Dahlem (Bot. Mus.) 1963-1964; lecturer
paläontology Freie Univ. Berlin 1964. (<em>Straus</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Geol.-paläont. Inst. Göttingen (Pliocene pl.), B (extant, fungi,
lichens, fossil pl.), Deut. Akad. Wiss., Arbeitsstelle Paläobotanik (fossil pl.).

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Andrews p. 337 (refs. to pubis. with new taxa); Biol.-
Dokum. 17: 9046-9047; Bossert p. 386; GR p. 143; Roon p. 109; Zep.-Tim. p. 106.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Berl. Morgenpost 13 Apr 1979, p. 1 ("Ein Privatgelehrter" brief sketch,
	portr.).
Straus, A., Personal comm. senior author 1957 (on coll.).
Gothan, W., Deut. Akad. Wiss., Berlin, Vortr. Schr. 42: 17. 1951.

Strausbaugh, Perry Daniel (1886-1965), American botanist; Dr. phil. Univ. Chicago
1920 as student of J.M. Coulter; school teacher in Danville, Ohio 1909-1910, at Wooster
College 1911-1913 (prep. school), instructor in biology ib. 1913-1915, asst. prof. 1915-
1918, 1920-1921, professor of botany 1921-1923; head of department of botany West
Virginia University 1923-1948 (1942-1945 in the armed services); emeritus prof. ib.
1948-1965. (<em>Strausb</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: WVA. – Other material at C, DPU, L, NY.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 338 (b. 21 Mar 1886); BFM 1608; BL 1:
221/320; Bossert p. 386.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Amer. men sci. eds. 4-10, 1927-1961; Brit. Mus. gen. cat. print. books
	231: 391-392. 1961; Castanea 30: 244. 1965 (obit. not.); West Virginia biol. Newslet-
	ter 11: 1-10. 1965.
Core, E.L., Bull. Torrey bot. Club 93(2): 138-140. 1966 (obit., portr., partial bibl.).
Core, E.L. et al., Bibl. West Virginia Plant Life 40-41. 1962.
Frodin, D.G., Guide standard floras world no. 148. 1984.
Lowden, M.D., Taxon, Index pers. names vols. 1-30. 708. 1984.
Verdoorn, F., ed., Chron. bot. 1: 304. 1935, 2: 358. 1936, 3: 324. 1937, 5: 524. 1939.

Appalach.</em>).

Strauss, Friedrich Karl Joseph, Freiherr von (1787-1855), German (Bavarian)
botanist, magistrate and "Regierungsrath", general secretary to the prefect of the de-
partment of Aschaffenburg 1810-1817; "Regierungsrath" (government councillor) of
the Obermain district 1817-1832, id. of the Oberdonau district 1832-1837, id. Isar dis-
trict 1837-1838, from 1838, from 1838 in similar governmental functions in the govern-
ments of Schwaben and Neuburg 1838-1840 and Unterfranken and Aschaflenburg

PAGE: 43
HEADING: STRAUSS, TH.

1840-1847; ultimately ordinary state councillor of the kingdom of Bavaria; Dr. phil. h.c.
Würzburg 1852. (<em>F. Strauss</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: M.

Strauss, Heinrich [Christian] (1850-1922), German (Hannoverian) gardener and
bibliographer; worked in nurseries in Hamburg and Berlin 1865-1873; gardener at the
Berlin Botanical Garden 1873-1921, ultimately as "Obergartenmeister". (<em>Strauss</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: B (garden plants; mainly destr.); some duplicates in A.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 338 (b. 12 Nov 1850, d. 21 Mai 1922); BL 2:
173; Hortus 3: 1205; Urban-Berl. p. 401; Zander ed. 10, p. 722, ed. 11, p. 789, 823.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Verh. bot. Ver. Brandenburg 64: 208, 244. 1922 (d.).
Harms, H., Monatschr. Kakteenk. 32: 110. 1922; Ber. deut. bot. Ges. 40: (97)-(99).
	1922 (obit.).

<sm>COMPOSITE</sm> <sm>WORKS</sm>: (1) Indexes, <em>Bot. Jahrb.</em> vols. 1-25 (1902), 26-30 (902), 31-35 (1905).
(2) Indexes, <em>Ber. deut. bot. Ges.</em> vols. 1-37; general index for vols. 1-25.
(3) Many of the indexes to Engler's <em>Pflanzenreich</em>, up to 1922, were made by Strauss.
(4) Contributed to <em>Gartenflora</em> 59-68, 1910-1919.

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: See H. Harms (1922), p. (99).

Strauss, Theodor (1859-1911), German (Thuringian) merchant and plant collector;
representative of an English export firm in Iran ca. 1881-1911, ultimately also vice-
consul for England in Sultanabad. (<em>Th. Strauss</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: JE. – Duplicates A, B (extant), BP, E, K, W, WRSL, WU, Z. –

Strecker, Wilhelm (1858-1934), German (Prussian) agriculturist; Dr. phil. Göttingen
1884; lecturer ib. 1884-1888; in charge of the "Landeskultur-Spezialkommission" in
Witzenhausen 1890-1895; professor of agricultural technique Leipzig 1895-1927.

Strehler, Ludwig F. (<em>fl</em>. 1841), German (Bavarian) botanist and high school teacher

Streinz, Wenzel Matern (1792-1876), Bohemian-Austrian physician and botanist; Dr.
med. Praha 1817; regional physician at Bidschow 1818; id. at Beroun 1819; "Sanitäts-
Referent" at Linz 1828, subsequently "Protomedicus" for Upper-Austria and Salzburg;
from 1841-1856 "Gubernialrath und Landes-Protomedicus" in Linz. (<em>Streinz</em>).

Strempel, [Johannes] Carl Friedrich (1800-1872), German (Mecklenburg) physi-
cian and botanist; studied in Rostock and (1818-1822) Berlin; Dr. phil. Berlin 1822;
practicing physician in Schwerin ca. 1822-1825; from 1825 physician (from 1838 as
"Ober-Medizinalrath") in Rostock. (<em>Strempel</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown. – <em>Letters</em> to D.F.L. von Schlechtendal at HAL.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: ADB 36: 573-575 (Ad. Hofmeister); Barnhart 3: 339 (b.
20 Aug 1800); BM 5: 2035; Herder p. 271; IF p. 732; PR 9004, ed. 1: 9957; Zander ed.
10, p. 722, ed. 11, p. 823.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Blanck, A., Die mecklenb. Ärzte 151 f. 1874 (n.v.).
Meyer, D.E., Nova Hedwigia 35: 603-637. 1981 (on Strempel's dissertation and on
	<em>Botrychium matricariifolium</em>).

<sm>DEDICATION</sm>: Roeper, J., <em>Botanische Thesen</em>, Rostock 1872, dedicated to Strempel to com-
memorate the 50th anniversary of the publication of his thesis.

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Strempelia</em> A. Richard ex A.P. de Candolle (1830) and possibly the derived
<em>Slrempeliopsis</em> Bentham (1876).

13.259. <em>Filicum berolinensium synopsis</em>. Dissertatio inauguralis quam consensu et auctoritate
gratiosi medicorum ordinis in Universitate literaria berolinensi ad summos in medicina
et chirurgia honores rite impetrandos d. ii. m. Augusti a. mdcccxxii h.l.q.s. publice
defendet auctor Carol. Frider. Strempel megapolitanus ... Berolini [Berlin] (typis
Joannis Friderici Starckii) [1822]. Oct. (<em>Fil. berol. syn.</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: 2 Aug 1822, p. [1]-48, <em>1 pl</em>. (uncol. lith. auct., F. Guimpel sculps.). <em>Copies</em>: BR(2),
	G(2), HH, NY(2); IDC 7267 (<em>copy</em>: KVA, Stockholm). – <em>Vita</em> on p. 46-48.
<em>Ref</em>.: Anon., Flora 6(2): 731-732. 14 Dec 1823.

Strobl, Gabriel (1846-1925), Austrian botanist, zoologist and clergyman; educated in
the Benedictine monastery at Admont; ordained 1870; studied natural sciences at
Innsbruck as a student of A. Kerner 1872-1876; teacher at the Benedictine Gymnasium
of Seitenstetten 1876-1880; idem at the Gymnasium of Melk 1880-1886; from 1887 idem
at Admont. (<em>Strobl</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: GJO (p.p.; on loan from ADMONT), ADMONT, LI. – further

(destr.), WRSL. – The original herbarium of Strobl is owned by ADMONT; it consists

PAGE: 47
HEADING: STROBL

of a <em>Herbarium universale</em> (21.416 taxa) and a set <em>Flora von Italien</em> (3.432 taxa), both on

<em>Letters</em> at G and UPS-UB.

Stromeyer, Friedrich (1776-1835), German (Hannover) physician, botanist and
chemist; Dr. med. Göttingen 1800; lecturer (1802) and professor (1805, e.o.; 1807 ord.)
in the medical faculty of Göttingen, from 1817 officially for chemistry and pharmacy,
but from 1806 in charge of the chemical laboratory; general inspector of pharmacies in
the kingdom of Hannover; Hofrath 1817; son of Johann Friedrich Stromeyer. (<em>F.
Stromeyer</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 340 (confusion with Johann Friedrich S.);
BM 5: 2037; CSP 5: 861-863, 12: 709; Herder p. 24, 168; PR 9010 (b. 2 Aug 1776, d. 18
Aug 1835), ed. 1: 9965; Rehder 1: 298.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Breure, A.S.H. &amp; J.G. de Bruijn, eds., Leven en werken van J.G.S. van Breda
	62. 1979.
Herzog, C., Arch. Pharm. Apoth.-Ver. nördl. Teutschl. 63: 1-11. 1838 (obit., bibl.).
Lindemann, E., Bull. Soc. Imp. Natural. Moscou 61(1): 74. 1886 (err. as J.F.
	Stromeyer).
Lockemann, G. &amp; R.E. Oesper, J. Chem. Educ. 30(4): 202-204. 1953 (hist. chem. lab.
	instruct.).
Poggendorff, , Biogr.-lit. Handw.-Buch 2: 1031-1032. 1863 (b. 2 Aug 1776, d. 18 Aug
	1835).
Wulff, E., Intr. hist. pl. geogr. 1, 2, 3, 10, 12, 24. 1943.

Gottingae [Göttingen] (typis Henrici Dieterich] 1800. Qu. (<em>Hist. veg. geogr. spec.</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: 1800, p. [i-viii], [1]-80, [81-82, theses]. <em>Copies</em>: G, NY, PH, USDA, Wagenitz. –
	Pioneer account of plant geography, see Wulff (1943), preceded only by Willdenow,
	<em>Grundriss der Kräuterkunde</em> 1792.

13.290. <em>The American flora</em>, or history of plants and wild flowers; containing a systematic
and general description, natural history, chemical and medical properties of over six
thousand plants, accompanied with a circumstantial detail of the medicinal effects, and
of the diseases in which they have been most successfully employed ... New York (pub-
lished by Strong and Bidwell, ...) 1846. (<em>Amer. fl.</em>).

<em>Orig. ed.</em>: 1846-1850, 4 vols. <em>Copies</em>: HH, NY. – Vols. 2-4 have a different imprint.
	<em>1</em>: 1846, frontisp., engr. t.p., p. [i*-ii*], [i]-iv, 5-137, [138-139]. <em>50 pl</em>. (col. in HH
	copy).

	but this includes plates with 2 ills.). Imprint: New York (Published by Green &amp;
	Spencer).
	<em>3</em>: 1849, frontisp., engr. t.p., p. [i]-vi, 3-188, <em>46 pl</em>. (t.p.: <em>54 pl</em>.). <em>Imprint</em>: as vol. 2.

	Imprint</em>: as vols. 2 but address "by Bowery".
	<em>1</em> (<em>other issue</em>): 1847, p. [1]-137, [138], [i]-iv, frontisp. and <em>51 pl. Copy</em>: HU. – New York
	(published by Strong and Burdick).
	<em>1</em> (<em>other issue</em>): 1848, as above but <em>imprint</em>: New York (published by Green &amp; Spencer,
	140 Nassau Street) 1848.
<em>Other ed</em>.: 1855, 4 vols. <em>Copies</em>: HH, NY. – <em>The American flora</em>, ... properties, mode of
	culture, propagation, &amp;c. designed as a book of reference for botanists, physicians,

	B-S, HH, M.

Stuckert, Teodoro [Theodor] Juan Vicente (1852-1932), Swiss botanist and phar-
macist; studied pharmacy in Tucumán and Cordoba; practicing pharmacist in Cordoba
from 1885; professor of natural sciences at the Escuela Nacional de Agricultura,
Cordoba 1903-1905; Swiss consul at Cordoba 1906-1912; in Genève 1913. (<em>Stuck</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: CORD; other material at B (mainly destr.), BUC, C, DAO, G,
GOET, NY, S, SI. <em>Exsiccatae</em>: <em>Herbarium argentinum</em> at e.g. LIL, SI. Grasses, Cyperaceae
and Juncaceae in the series of exsiccatae edited by A. Kneucker and distributed by O.
Weigel. – <em>Letters</em> at G.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: AG 5(1): 355; Barnhart 3: 342 (b. 4 Sep 1852, d. 11 Jun
1932); BL 1: 232, 320; Bossert p. 387; CSP 18: 1019; Rehder 5: 829; Tucker 3: 297;
Urban-Berl. p. 401.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Allg. bot. Z. 9: 156. 1903 (prof. agr. coll. Argent. from 1 Jun 1903), 13: 216.
	1907 (vice consul for Switzerland at Cordoba); Index Amer. bot. lit. 4: 294. 1969;
	Hedwigia 53: (235). 1913 (lives in Geneva); Physis 11: 192-193. 1932.
Molfino, J.F., Anal. Soc. Ci. Argent. 114: 116-121. 1932, repr. in <em>Malv. argent.</em> p. 54-59.
	1932 (portr., bibl., obit.).
Wagenitz, G., Index coll. princ. herb. Gott. 162. 1982.
Wittrock, V.B., Acta Horti Berg. 3(3): 64. 1905.

<sm>NOTE</sm>: Stuckert was born in Basel, of German-Swiss parents, and is referred to in
Molfino's obituary of him still as "Swiss botanist". He was almost certainly given
German first names (Theodor Johann Vincent), however, we have no data on this.

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Stuckertia</em> O. Kuntze (1903); <em>Stuckertiella</em> Beauverd (1913).

... Buenos Aires. [1899]. Oct.

Studer-Steinhäuslin, Bernhard (1847-1910), Swiss botanist (mycologist) and
pharmacist at Bern; studied pharmacy at Bern and Wiesbaden; state examination phar-

PAGE: 57
HEADING: STUDT

macy 1872; in his father's pharmacy in Bern from 1872, from 1877-1907 co-owner with
Wilhelm Studer. (<em>Studer</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: BERN. – <em>Letters</em> at G.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 342 (d. 28 Mar 1910); BM 5: 2040; CSP 18:
1019-1020; Kelly p. 220; LS 26070-26082, 39732-39751.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Hedwigia 51: (88). 1911 (d.).

Fischer, Ed., Verh. schweiz. naturf. Ges. 1914(2): 17, 25.
Rytz, W., Mitt. naturf. Ges. Bern 5: 29. 1922 (family herb. at BERN).
Tschirch, A., Verh. schweiz. naturf. Ges. 93(1): 36-42. 1910 (obit., portr., bibl.).

<sm>NOTE</sm>: The Studer herbarium at Bern goes back to Samuel Emanuel Studer (1757-1834),
professor of theology at Bern; his son [Daniel] Friedrich [Gottlieb] Studer (1790-1856)
was a pharmacist at Bern and also botanically active; his younger son Bernhard Studer
(1794-1887) was a great Swiss geologist (Quenstedt p. 419). Friedrich Studer's son
Bernhard Friedrich (1820-1911) was also botanically active and the father of Bernhard
Studer-Steinhäuslin (1847-1910).

13.302. <em>Die wichtigsten Speisepilze</em> nach der Natur gemalt und beschrieben ... Bern
(Verlag von Schmid, Francke &amp; Co. ...) 1887. Oct. (<em>Wicht. Speisepilze</em>).

<em>Ed</em>. [<em>1</em>]: Aug 1887 (Bot. Centralbl. 12-16 Sep 1887; Nat. Nov. Aug(2) 1887), p. [1]-24,
	<em>11 pl</em>. (col.). <em>Copy</em>: Stevenson.
<em>Ed. 2</em>: Sep 1892 (ÖbZ for Oct 1892; Bot. Centralbl. 13 Oct 1892; Bot. Zeit. 4 Nov 1892;
	Nat. Nov. Oct(2) 1892), p. [1]-24, <em>11 pl</em>. (col.). <em>Copy</em>: FH.
<em>Ed. 3</em>: Aug 1905 (Bot. Centralbl. 3 Oct 1905; Nat. Nov. Sep(1) 1905). 24 p. <em>12 pl</em>.

Studt, Werner (1894-x), German (Hamburg) botanist; studied at Göttingen; on active
duty 1915; continued his studies in Kiel; state teacher's examination Hamburg 1922; Dr.
phil. Hamburg 1926. (<em>Studt</em>).

Stübel, [Moritz] Alphons (1835-1904), German (Saxonian) explorer, geologist and
plant collector; studied natural sciences at Leipzig University 1854-1855; for health
reasons to Egypt 1855-1858, in Italy 1858-1859; continued his studies in Heidelberg
1859-1860; Dr. phil. ib. 1860; travelled in Scotland 1862, in Madeira 1862-1863, Cape
Verde Isl. 1863; Madeira 1863-1865 making volcanological studies, e.g. on Santorin
1866, in the Colombian Andes 1868, until 1877 exploring S. and C. America; settled in
Dresden 1877, continuing his studies on shorter voyages. (<em>Stübel</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: B (3000, mainly destr.); other material at F (photos), L (Algae),
MEDEL.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 343 (b. 26 Jul 1835, d. 10 Nov 1904); BM 5:
2041; Quenstedt p. 420; Urban-Berl. p. 401.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Brit. Mus. gen. cat. print. books 232: 3-5. 1964; Cat. gén. livr. impr.

	sketch); Globus, Braunschweig 86: 383. 1904 (obit.); Hedwigia 44: [92]. 1905 (d.),
	63: (97). 1922 [erroneous report of death; refers to Oskar Stübel 1846-1921, not a

1871 at Braunschweig and 1871-1877 at Halle; pharmacist at Lüneburg 1883-1884;
chemist at a cement factory in Lüneburg 1884-1918. (<em>Stümcke</em>).

Stuhlmann, Franz [Ludwig] (1863-1928), German (Hamburg) zoologist and collec-
tor; with the German army in East Africa 1888; with Emin Pasja to Central Africa but
returned to the East coast 1891; in Europe 1892-1893; in various functions in East Africa
1893-1903; in the Dutch East Indies 1900-1901; director of the Biological-agricultural
institute at Amani 1903-1908; secretary of the Colonial institute at Hamburg 1909-1921;
director of an institute for world trade ib. 1921. (<em>Stuhlmann</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: B (mainly destr.); other material at BR, C, GRA, H, HBG, K,
KIEL, LE, MO, NH, NY, POM, WRSL.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Backer p. 554; Barnhart 3: 343 (b. 29 Oct 1863, d. 19
Nov 1928); BJI 1: 56, 2: 173; BM 5: 2041-2042; CSP 18: 1025; IH 1 (ed. 6): 365, (ed. 7):
343; LS 26086, 39753; Rehder 1: 493; SK 1: 512; Tucker 1: 672; Urban-Berl. p. 282,
291, 315, 401.

Stuntz, Stephen Conrad (1875-1918), American botanist and bibliographer; B.S.
Wisconsin 1899; assistant to library and herbarium Univ. Wisconsin 1895-1902; cata-

Stur, Dionys [Rudolf Josef] [Štur, Dionýz] (1827-1893), Slovak botanist, geologist
and paleobotanist; studied at Wien and Schemnitz; student of St. Endlicher with the
Geol. Reichsanstalt, Wien from 1850, Bergrath 1867, geologist-in-chief 1873-1877, from
1877-1885 assistant director, director 1885-1892; Cothenius medal Leopoldina 1890.
(<em>Stur</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: B (extant; in herb. zool.-bot. Ver. Wien); other material in MW.
– <em>Letters</em> at G and UPS-UB.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Andrews p. 337; Barnhart 3: 343 (b. 5 Apr 1827, d. 9
Oct 1893); BJI 1: 56; BM 5: 2042; Bossert p. 387; CSP 5: 875-876, 8: 1040-1042, 11:
527-528, 12: 710, 18: 1026 (bibl.); DTS 1: 293-294; Herder p. 319, 325, 353; Hortus 3:
1205; Jackson p. 182, 183, 186; Kanitz p. 226; Moebius p. 143: Morren ed. 10, p. 29, 31;
PR 9021-9023, 10642; Quenstedt p. 420; Rehder 5: 829; Saccardo 1: 159, 2: 104; WU
40: 208-211; Zander ed. 10, p. 722, ed. 11, p. 823.

	524, map. 1860. – For a special study on the methodological significance of this
	journal see Hendrych (1975); Stur was a forerunner of R. Wettstein, A. Engler, A.
	Bunge and A. Kerner in applying geographical consideration in the context of mor-
	phological criteria in delimiting taxa. For significant precursor publications see Stur,
	<em>Beobachtungen über den Einfluss der geognostischen Unterlage auf die Vertheilung der Pflanzen</em> in
	Verh. zool.-bot. Ver. 3 (Abh.): 43-50. 1853 and <em>Über den Einfluss des Bodens auf die
	Vertheilung der Pflanzen</em>, S.B. Akad. Wiss., Wien 20: 71-152, 349-421. 1856.

13.317. <em>Beiträge zur Monographie des Genus Draba</em> in den Karparten [sic]: Ungarns,
Galiziens, Siebenbürgens und des Banates nördlich der Donau ... [Österr. bot. Z. 11,
1861]. Oct. 

<em>Publ</em>.: Mai-Jul 1861 (in journal), p. [1]-46, <em>pl. 1-3. Copy</em>: G. – Reprinted and to be cited
	from Österr. bot. Z. 11: 137-154. Mai, 183-195. Jun, 209-224. Jul 1861.

Sturgis, William Codman (1886-1942), American cryptogamist; Dr. phil. Harvard
1889; vegetable pathologist at the Connecticut Agricultural Station 1891-1901; lecturer
Yale School of Forestry 1899-1901; professor and dean School of Forestry, Colorado
Springs 1904-1917; educational secretary Board of Missions, Prot. Episcopal Church,
New York 1917-1927; lecturer College of preachers, Washington, D.C. 1928-1931;
warden St. Martin's House, Bernardville, N.Y. 1934-1937. (<em>Sturgis</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: NY; other material at GH (Colorado phan.), L, NYS, OSC.
<em>Mycological notes and correspondence</em> at NY; <em>letters</em> to W.G. Farlow at FH.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 343 (b. 15 Nov 1862, d. 30 Sep 1942);
Bossert p. 387; CSP 18: 1027; Ewan ed. 1: 316-317, ed. 2: 215; GR p. 249; IH 1 (ed. 6):
365, (ed. 7): 343; Kelly p. 220; LS 26089-26129, 39755-39765, suppl. 26968-26974; NAF
ser. 2. 1(1): 171; Rehder 3: 193; Stevenson p. 1259; Tucker 1: 298.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Amer. men sci. eds. 1-6. 1906-1938; Index Amer. bot. lit. 1886-1966. 4:
	295-296. 1967; J. New York Bot. Gard. 25: 210. 1924 (donates mycol. herb.), 39: 144.
	1938 (myxomyc. herb. acquired), 40: 9. 1939 (myxomyc. herb.), 44: 76. 1943 (d.);
	Mycologia 30: 475. 1938 (Myxomyc. herb., 3000, acquired by NY); Nat. Nov. 26:
	253. 1904 (app. Colorado Springs); The New York Times 30 Sep 1942; Who's who
	Amer. 6-23. 1910-1945; Who's who New England 3: 1221. 1938; Who was who Amer.
	2: 518. 1950.
Hagelstein, R., Mycologia 36: 123-124. 1944 (obit., portr.).
Marquis, A.N., ed., Who's who in America 22: 2122. 1942, 23: 2067. 1945.
Rogers, D.P., Brief hist. mycol. N. Amer. ed. 2. 46. 1981.

Sturm, Jacob (1771-1848), German botanical artist and engraver at Nürnberg; one of
the founders of the Naturhistorische Gesellschaft Nürnberg; Dr. phil. h.c. Breslau 1846.
(<em>Sturm</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Herbarium no longer extant (inf. E. Bauer, Nürnberg). – Some
bryophytes at H. – A note in Bonplandia (8: 317. 1860) mentions the existence of a
herbarium of circa 10.000 phanerogams and many cryptogams at "Sturm's naturhistor-
isches Museum" in Nürnberg. This herbarium must have consisted of material brought
together by both Jacob and Wilhelm Georg Sturm; it was offered for sale in 1865 (see
e.g. E. Fournier 1865). – <em>Letters</em> at G and UPS-UB.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: ADB 37: 20-21 (E. Wunschmann); AG 2(1): 118; Ain-
sworth p. 71, 116; Backer p. 554; Barnhart 3: 343 (b. 21 Mar 1771, d. 28 Nov 1848);
Biol.-Dokum. 17: 9103; Blunt p. 221, 264; BM 5: 2042-2043; Bossert p. 387; CSP 5: 880,
12: 710; DTS 1: 294-295, xxiii; Frank 3 (Anh.): 101; GF p. 77; GR p. 143; Herder p.
189, 238, 245, 266; Hortus 3: 1205; Jackson p. 293; Kelly p. 220; LS 26131; MD p. 230-
234; Moebius p. 119; NT 1910 and see indexes; Nordstedt p. 30; PH 364, 567; PR 2124,
4253, 5902, 6649, 9026, 9069, ed. 1: 9979; Ratzeburg p. 475-476; Rehder 1: 375; SBC p.
133; Stevenson p. 1259; TL-1/793, 912, 913a, 969, 1106, 1275; TL-2/see indexes; Tucker
1: 14, 672.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Abh. naturh. Ges. Nürnberg 7: frontisp. portr. 1881; Bonplandia 8: 317.
	1860 (note on the Sturm nat. hist. mus. at Nürnberg; holds a herbarium of over
	10.000 plants), 10: 45. 1862 (death of J.H.C.F. Sturm); Bot. Zeit. 7: 127-128. 1849
	(d.); Entom. Zeit., Stettin 10(5): 162-167. 1849 (obit.); Flora 29: 223. 1846 (dr. phil.
	h.c. Breslau 1846), 31: 782. 1848 (d.); Neu. Nekrol. Deut. 26: 726-738 (biogr., bibl.).
Eisinger, F., Int. entom. Z. 13(14): 105-111. 1919 (biogr., bibl.).
Fournier, E., Bull. Soc. bot. France 12 (Bibl.): 240. 1865 (Sturm herb. put up for sale
	[probably combined herb. of Jac. and J.W. Sturm]).
Guédès, M., J. Soc. Bibl. nat. Hist. 9(1): 46-47. 1978 (format Deutschl. Fl. is octavo);
	Arch. nat. Hist. 11(2): 205. 1983 (see also MD p. 230-234).
Hilpert, J.W., Flora 32: 145-155. 1849 (obit., bibl.); Zum Andenken an Dr. Jacob
	Sturm, ... Rede Nürnberg 1849, frontisp., 24 p.
Hoppe, D.H., Flora 10 (Beil. 2): 30-32. 1827 (request for collaboration; state of project).
Ilg, W., Hoppea 42: 267. 1984 (dates of sending first fascicles).
Lack, H.W. &amp; C.-O. v. Sydow, Willdenowia 14: 441. 1984.
Müller, R.H.W. &amp; R. Zaunick, Friedrich Traugott Kützing 55, 67, 296. 1960.
Percheron, A., Bibl. entom. 1: 84. 1837.
Ruhland, W., <em>in</em> Handw.-Buch Naturw. 9: 843. 1913, ed. 2. 9: 758. 1934.
Sayre, G., Bryologist 80: 518. 1977 (bryo. H-Sol).
Schmid, G., Chamisso als Naturforscher no. 128, p. 173. 1942.
Schultes, J.A., Flora 5: 134. 1822 (visit to J. Sturm).
S.M., Rev. Magas. Zool., Paris ser. 2. 2: 135-137. 1850 (obit.).

HEADING: STURM

Spiess, E., Abh. naturf. Ges. Nürnberg 1891: 202-207 (biogr. not., bibl.; err. d. "28 Dec
	1848").
Sturm, J., Bericht über die naturhistorischen Kupferwerke, welche im Selbstverlage von
	Dr. Jacob Sturm ... erschienen sind, 4 p. 1853.
Wittrock, V.B., Acta Horti Berg. 3(2): 144. 1903.

<sm>COMPOSITE</sm> <sm>WORKS</sm>: (1) With D.H. Hoppe, <em>Caricologia germanica</em> 1826, see TL-2/3038.
(2) With C.G. Nees von Esenbeck and Christian Friedrich Hornschuch, <em>Bryologia germa-
nica</em> 1823-1831, see TL-2/6682 and MD p. 188-189.
(3) For a detailed list of Sturm's copper engravings in works by others see Flora 32: 152-
155. 1849. Major contributions were 20 plates to A.G. Roth, <em>Cat. bot., 18 pl.</em> to O.
Swartz, <em>Lich. amer.</em>, 46 plates to C.G. Nees von Esenbeck, <em>Syst. Pilz. Schwämm.</em> and 126
plates to C. v. Sternberg, <em>Fl. Vorwelt.</em>

<sm>NOTE</sm>: Jacob Sturm was the son of the Nürnberg engraver Johann Georg Sturm; Jacob's
sons Johann Heinrich Christian Friedrich (1805-1862) and Johann Wilhelm (1808-
1865) continued his work. J.W. Sturm, in particular, continued <em>Deutschlands Flora</em>.

<sm>HANDWRITING</sm>: Candollea 33: 417-418. 1978.

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Sturmia</em> Hoppe (1799). <em>Note</em>: <em>Sturmia</em> H.G.L. von Reichenbach (1826) may also
commemorate Jacob Sturm, but no derivation was given.

13.335. <em>Deutschlands Flora</em> in Abbildungen nach der Natur mit Beschreibungen ...
Nürnberg (gedruckt auf Kosten der Verfassers) [1796-] 1798-1862, 96, 31 and 36 Hefte
in 3 "Abtheilungen". Oct. (<em>Deutschl. Fl.</em>).

<em>Abtheilung i</em>: <em>Phanerogamische Gewächse</em>, 96 Hefte, nos. 1-74 of <em>16 plates</em> with text; 75/76 with
	<em>16 pl</em>., 77/78-95/96 with <em>24 pl</em>. The text was supplied by various authors; unsigned
	texts are attributed by us to J. Sturm. The Hefte were bound in 20 Bänchen, usually
	4/Band; these Bändchen each have p. [i-iv] preface matter followed by the plates with
	text, often also with the original covers of the Hefte. The plates are hand-coloured
	copper engravings by J. Sturm (Heft 1-43), by Sturm and his two sons (Heft 44-61)
	and by the two sons (Heft 62-96) (J.H.C.F. and J.W. Sturm). Data taken from
	original covers and texts.
<em>1</em>: 1796-1798, p. [i-iv].
	<em>Heft 1</em>: Nov 1796 (copy sent to Regensb. bot. Ges. 3 Dec 1796), <em>pl. 1-16</em>, text J. Sturm;
	contents: miscellaneous.
	<em>Heft 2</em>: 1798, <em>pl. 1-16</em>, text id.; contents id.
	<em>Heft 3</em>: Dec 1797 (p. 3 of cover: Dec 1797), text id.; contents id.
	<em>Heft 4</em>: 1798, <em>pl. 1-16</em>, text id.; contents id.
<em>2</em>: 1798-1800, p. [i-iv].
	<em>Heft</em> 5: 1798, <em>pl. 1-16</em>, text id.; contents id.
	<em>Heft 6</em>: 1799, <em>pl. 1-16</em> text by J. Sturm and D.H. Hoppe; contents: miscellaneous, 3
	species by Hoppe.
	<em>Heft 7</em>: 1799, <em>pl. 1-16</em>, text by J. Sturm; contents: miscellaneous.
	<em>Heft 8</em>: 1800, <em>pl. 1-16</em>, text id.; contents id.
<em>3</em>: 1801-1802, p. [i-iv].

	<em>Heft 19-20</em>: 4-10 Apr 1841 (Hinrichs). Fungi by A.K.J. Corda, p. 1-52, <em>pl. 1-16.</em>
	<em>Heft 27-28</em>: Sep 1848 (Flora 14 Oct 1848; Hinrichs 17 Oct 1848), Polypores (ctd) by
	F.W.T. Rostkovius, p. 1-48, <em>pl. 1-24.</em>
	<em>Heft 31-32</em>: Dec 1851, Agaricales by Adalbert C.F.H.C. Schnizlein (1780-1856), p. 1-
	48, <em>pl. 1-24</em> (Flora rev. 21 Mar 1852).
	<em>Heft 33-34</em>: Jan-Mar 1853, misc. fungi by Friedrich Karl Joseph, Freiherr von Strauss
	(1787-1855), p. 1-48, <em>pl. 33.1-33.12, 34.1-34.12</em> (Flora rev. 21 Apr 1853; ÖbW 10
	Aug 1853; Bot. Zeit. rev. 5 Aug 1853).
<em>Copies</em>: B (ii, iii, incompl.), B-S, G, HH, NY (orig. covers), Stevenson (iii), Teyler (ii);
	IDC 5583 (i).
<em>Note</em>(<em>1</em>): W. Junk (Rara 1) states that the entire work consists of 30 "Bändchen", in 163
	Hefte, 3751 pages and 2336 handcoloured plates. The work was also issued with black
	and white plates. Friedländer bought the remaining stock and sold copies with plates
	with original and later colouring.
<em>Note</em>(<em>2</em>): Tucker (1: 194) mentions a French edition, <em>Flore germanique</em>, 4 cahiers (1 vol.),
	Erlangen 1801-1802, with 64 col. pl.
<em>Second edition</em>: 1900-1907, 15 vols., with new text by various authors; issued in the series
	<em>Schriften des deutschen Lehrer-Vereins für Naturkunde</em> vols. 6-21, published by K.G. Lutz.
	Main t.p.'s: "J. Sturm's <em>Flora von Deutschland</em> in Abbildungen nach der Natur. Zweite,
	umgearbeitete Auflage ..." Stuttgart (Verlag von K.G. Lutz).
	<em>1</em>: 1906, p. [2]-192, <em>pl. 1-64.</em> By Ernst Hans Ludwig Krause (1859-1912). Plates col.
	liths. – Schriften vol. 191.
	<em>2</em>: 1900 (Bot. Centralbl. 20 Feb 1901; Nat. Nov. Feb(2) 1901), p. [2]-160, <em>pl. 1-64.</em> By

	<em>3</em>: 1900 (Bot. Centralbl. 17 Oct 1900; Nat. Nov. Feb(2) 1901), p. [2]-175, [176], <em>pl. 1-
	56.</em> By K.G. Lutz. – Schriften vol. 6.
	<em>4</em>: 1905, p. [2]-256, <em>pl. 1-64.</em> By E.H.L. Krause. – Schriften vol. 17.
	<em>5</em>: 1901, p. [2]-320, <em>pl. 1-64.</em> By E.H.L. Krause. – Schriften vol. 9.
	<em>6</em>: 1902, p. [2]-256, <em>pl. 1-64.</em> By E.H.L. Krause. – Schriften vol. 10.

Sturm, Johann Wilhelm (1808-1865), German botanist and botanical artist at
Nürnberg; son of Jacob Sturm. (<em>J. W. Sturm</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: See under Jacob Sturm; some European material at K and PH. –
<em>Letters</em> to D.F.L. von Schlechtendal at HAL, further letters at G.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 343 (b. 19 Jul 1808, d. 7 Jan 1865); Biol.-
Dokum. 17: 9103; BM 5: 2043; Bossert p. 387; CSP 5: 880; DTS 1: 295; GR p. 143;
Herder p. 326; IF p. 732; Jackson p. 374; JW 1: 452; NI 2: 270; PR 9026, 9027-9029, ed.
1: 9979, 9982; TL-1/1275; TL-2/1387, 11.440; see A.C.F.H.G. Schnizlein.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Bonplandia 6: 53. 1858 (cognomen Leopoldina Sturm II); Bot. Zeit. 23:
	35-36. 1865 (obit. not.); Flora 32: 222. 1849 (M.A. h.c. Gettysburg), 48: 29-30. 1865
	(obit. from Allg. Zeit., Beilage 13. Jan 1865); Österr. bot. Z. 15: 62, 89. 1865 (d.).
Schlechtendal, D.F.L. von, Bot. Zeit. 23: 296. 1865 (herbaria for sale).
Urban, I., Fl. bras. 1(1): 205-206. 1906.

<sm>COMPOSITE</sm> <sm>WORKS</sm>: (1) Continued Jacob Sturm's <em>Deutschlands Flora</em>, Abth. 1, Heft 93-96
and Abth. 3, Heft 31-36.
(2) <em>Ophioglossaceae, Marattiaceae, Osmundaceae, Schizaeaceae, Gleicheniaceae, Hymenophylleae</em>, in
<em>Flora brasiliensis</em> 1(2): 137-302, <em>pl. 9-19</em> (fasc. 23). 15 Jul 1859.

<sm>NOTE</sm>: (1) J.W. Sturm left an unpublished and unfinished <em>Nomenclator filicum</em> of which
some proof sheets had been printed (not seen by us), see e.g. Bonplandia 3: 37-38. 15
Feb 1855, W.J. Hooker, J. Bot. Kew Gard. Misc. 7: 60-62. 1855 (with reproduction of a
sample entry) and Bot. Zeit. 12: 873-876. 1854 and 13: 360. 1855.
(2) Sturm published a paper on "<em>Nymphaea semiaperta</em> Klinggräff, eine für Bayern neue
Pflanze, bei Nürnberg aufgefunden" in Abh. nat. Ges., Nürnberg 1: 143-149, [150], <em>pl.
3.</em> 1858, reprinted 7 p. Nürnberg s.d. (reprint n.v.).

13.336. <em>Verzeichniss der</em> Phanerogamen und Kryptogamen s.g. <em>Gefässpflanzen in der Umgeg-

Sturt, Charles (1795-1869), British soldier, administrator, explorer and plant collector;
in the British army 1813-1833 (from 1825-1833 in Australia); explored Southern
Australia 1828-1831; on sick leave in England 1832-1834; settled in New South Wales
1834; surveyor general to South Australia; explored central Australia 1844-1846;
colonial treasurer of South Australia 1846; colonial secretary id. 1849-1851; in retire-
ment on his farm near Adelaide from 1851; died in England. (<em>Sturt</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: K, incl. letters; papers, journals, maps and letters in Mitchell
Library and National Library of Australia; further material at BM (R. Brown's herb.)
and CGE.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 343; BB p. 293; Bossert p. 387; CSP 5: 880,
8: 1043; Desmond p. 592 (b. 28 Apr 1795, d. 16 Jun 1869); DNB 55: 136-138 (19: 136-
138); HR; IH 2: (files); Lasègue p. 499; Rehder 1: 501; TL-2/837; Tucker 3: 298.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., A fine field for botanizing (Cat. Exhib. 13th Int. bot. Congr.) 33. 1981;
	Proc. Linn. Soc. 1869-70: cx-cxii (obit.).
Beale, E., Sturt, the chipped idol, Sydney 1979, 270 p. (biogr. biofile).
Bridson, G.D.R. et al., Nat. hist. mss. res. Brit. Isl. 229.286, 274.4, 334.12, 350-19. 1980.

	no. 16394. 1969.

13.340. <em>Narrative of an expedition into Central Australia</em>, performed under the authority of

Sturtevant, Edward Lewis (1842-1898), American agriculturist and botanist, M.D.
Harvard 1866; running an experimental farm with his brother Thomas 1867-1882,
breeding Ayrshire cattle; director of the New York State Agricultural Experiment
Station at Geneva, N.Y. 1882-1887; private scientist at South Framingham 1887-1898.
(<em>Sturtev</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: MO. – <em>Library</em> of pre-Linnean works at MO (catalogue see J.C.
Bay 1896). – <em>Letters</em> at G, GH.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 344 (b. 23 Jan 1842, d. 30 Jul 1898); BL 1:

829; Tucker 1: 672, 3: 298; Zander ed. 10, p. 722, ed. 11, p. 823.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Bot. Centralbl. 33: 32. 1888 (retirement), 76: 144. 1898 (d.); Bot. Gaz.

Stuxberg, Anton Julius (1849-1902), Swedish zoologist and botanist; Dr. phil.
Uppsala 1875; director of the zoological department of the Göteborg Museum 1882;
accompanied A.E. Nordenskiöld on his Arctic journeys of 1875-1876 and 1878-1880
(Vega expedition). (<em>Stuxberg</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: GB.

Suckow, Georg Adolph (1751-1813), German (Thüringian of Mecklenburg paren-
tage) botanist and physician; Dr. med. Jena 1772; professor of natural sciences and
political economy ("Kameralwissenschaften") at the "Hohe Kameralschule", Univers-
ity of Heidelberg 1774; from 1781 at the College of Lautern; son of Lorenz Johann
Daniel Suckow (1722-1801). (<em>Suckow</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: ADB 37: 105-106 (Jännicke); AG 5(4): 171; Barnhart 3:
344; BM 5: 2045; Dryander 3: 12, 24, 557, 582, 598; Frank 3 (Anh.): 101; Herder p. 96,
142; Hortus 3: 1203; PR 9036-9039, ed. 1: 9988-9991; Quenstedt p. 421; Rehder 5: 829;
SO 323; Tucker 1: 672; Zander ed. 10, p. 722, ed. 11, p. 823.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Brit. Mus. gen. cat. print. books 273-274. 1964; Cat. gén. livr. impr.
	Bibl. natl. 180: 162-163. 1952.
Poggendorff, J.C., Biogr.-lit. Handw.-Buch 2: 1046-1047. 1863 (bibl., b. 28 Jan 1751, d.
	13 Mai 1813).

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: No etymology was given for <em>Succowia</em> Medikus (1792), but may honor G.A.
Suckow.

Suckow [Succow], Laurenz (later: Lorenz) Johann Daniel (1722-1801), German
(Mecklenburg) physicist and naturalist; Mag. phil. Jena 1746; lecturer at Jena, sub-
sequently high school teacher of mathematics in Hamburg, from 1756 professor of math-
ematics and physics at the University of Jena; "weimarischer Kammerrath", father of
Georg Adolph Suckow. (<em>L. Suckow</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: ADB 37: 105; Barnhart 3: 344 (b. 19 Feb 1722, d. 26
Aug 1801); PR 9040, ed. 1: 9992; Rehder 3: 51, 4: 95.

Chemnitius, F., Die Botaniker an der Universität Jena 13, 21. 1930.

Sudworth, George [Bishop] (1864-1927), American dendrologist; A.B. Univ. Mich-
igan 1885; instructor in botany Michigan Agric. College 1885-1886; botanist in the
United States Department of Agriculture, Division of Forestry 1886-1895; dendrologist
Bureau of Forestry 1895-1904; chief dendrologist 1904-1927. (<em>Sudw</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: US; further material at MICH.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 345 (b. 31 Aug 1864, d. 10 Mai 1927); BL 1:
159, 162, 320; BM 5: 2046; CSP 18: 1033; Ewan ed. 1: 317, ed. 2: 215; Hortus 3: 1205;
Kelly p. 220; LS 26141; NW p. 58; Rehder 1: 341, 5: 830; Tucker 1: 672-673, 2: xxxvii,
3: 298; Zander ed. 10, p. 722, ed. 11, p. 823-824.

Anon., Amer. men sci. ed. 4. 953. 1927; Cat. gén. livr. impr. Bibl. natl. 180: 210-212.
	1952; Index Amer. bot. lit. 1886-1966, 4: 298. 1967; J. Forestry 25: 511-512. 1927
	(obit.); J. Washington Acad. Sci. 17(13): 356. 1927 (d.; with USDA since 1888);

	Amer. 1-15, 1899-1929; Who was who Amer. 1: 1203. 1968.

Suessenguth, Karl (1893-1955), German (Unterfranken, Bavarian) botanist; student
of K. Goebel at München; on active service 1915-1918; Dr. phil. München 1919; habil.
ib. 1922; scientific assistant with Goebel 1919-1927; extraordinary professor of botany at
the University of München 1927-1955; interim director of the Botanical Institute,
München 1945-1948; curator of the Botanische Staatssammlung 1927-1955. (<em>Suess</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: M. – <em>Letters</em> at G.

GR p. 143; Hortus 3: 1205; IH (ed. 1): 65, (ed. 2): 84; Langman 726; LS suppl. 9708;

HEADING: SUESSENGUTH

Suhr, Johannes Nicolaus von (1792-1847), German/Danish (Danish Holstein) al-
gologist and soldier in the Danish army in Schleswig; from 1834 as captain; from 1842 in
Rendsburg. (<em>Suhr</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: B (main part; mainly destr.), KIEL (minor part; extant); other
material at C, HBG, L, LD, REG, W. <em>Original drawings and mss</em>.: KIEL. <em>Correspondence</em>
with Friedrich Heinrich Wilhelm Frölich (1769-1845) at KIEL (destr.?).
<em>Exsiccatae</em>: Mertens, Frölich &amp; von Suhr, <em>Hydrophytorum tarn indigenorum quam exoticorum
collectio, Sammlung von einheimischen und auswärtigen Hydrophyten</em> 1829; contributed also to
Threde, <em>Die Algen der Nordsee und die mit denselben vorkommenden Zoophyten</em> 1812. (Christ-
iansen (1936) mentions a set in the municipal library of Hamburg).

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 345 (b. 16 Oct 1792, d. 29 Mar 1847); Biol.-
Dokum. 17: 9116; Christiansen p. 320 [index]; CSP 5: 884; De Toni 1: cxxi; IH 2:
(files); KR p. 675; Nordstedt suppl. p. 15; PR (alph.); Urban-Berl. p. 269.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Bot. Zeit. 5: 560, 841-850. 1847 (detailed biogr.); Flora 30: 249. 1847
	(d.).
Fischer-Benzon, R.J.D. v., <em>in</em> P. Prahl, Krit. Fl. Schlesw.-Holst. 2(1): 57, Nachtr. 7.
	1889.
Hansen, A., Bot. Tidsskr. 69: 214. 1974.

Ilg, W., Hoppea 42: 98, 234, 344. 1984.

Koster, J.Th., Taxon 18: 558. 1969 (coll.).
Lowden, R.M., Taxon, Index pers. names 711. 1984.
Newton, L.M., Phycol. Bull. 1: 18. 1952 (material at Kiel and Berlin).

	including original drawings).

	remainder to B; details on coll.).

<sm>NOTE</sm>: (1) Suhr's nationality was Danish; he was a soldier in the Danish army, obtained
his military training in Rendsburg (Holstein) and Copenhagen and was born and died
on Danish territory.
(2) Suhr's main publications were all in journals: his <em>Beiträge zur Algenkunde</em> appeared <em>in</em>
Flora 19: 337-350, <em>pl. 3-4.</em> 14 Jun 1836, 22: 65-75. 7 Feb 1839, 23: 257-265. 7 Mai, 273-
282. 14 Mai, 289-304. 21 Mai 1840; <em>in</em> Ann. Sci. nat., Bot. ser. 2. 7: 171-176. 1837 and <em>in</em>
Nova Acta Leop. 18 (suppl. 1): 273-288, <em>pl. 1-3.</em> 1841 (IDC 6216), probably publ. late
1841 (Soc. géol. France rd 10-24 Jan 1842; rev. Flora 7 Apr 1842). – For further papers
see e.g. CSP.

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Suhria</em> J. Agardh ex Endlicher (1843).

Sukachev, Vladimir Nikolaevich (1880-1967), Russian botanist; associated with the
St. Petersburg Forest Institute from 1898; from 1944 director of the Forest Institute of
the Academy of Sciences U.S.S.R. at Moscow (later S.M. Kirov Forest Engineering
Academy). (<em>Sukachev</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: MHA and LE. – Other material at C, E, H, MW.

suppl. 337-338; Roon p. 109; TL-2/see C.G.O. Drude; Tucker 3: 298; Zander ed. 10, p.
722, ed. 11, p. 824.

Suksdorf, Wilhelm Nikolaus (1850-1932), German (Holstein) born American bota-
nist and plant collector; to the U.S.A. 1858; in Iowa 1858-1874; at the University of
California 1874-1876; from 1876-1932 at Bingen (White Salmon), Klickitat Co., Was-
hington; worked with Asa Gray at Harvard 1886-1888; sold exsiccatae and seeds.
(<em>Suksd</em>.).

PAGE: 86
HEADING: SUKSDORF

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: WS (30.000; see W.A. Weber, 1944); duplicates in many her-
baria, e.g. A, B (extant), BM, BR, BUF, C, CAS, CM, CORD, CUP, DBN, E, F, GH,
GOET, K, L, LD, M, MANCH, MICH, MIN, MO, MSC, NA, NY, NYS, ORE,
OSC, P, PH, US (2000), WRSL, WSP, WTU. – Suksdorf distributed his plants in sets,
called <em>Plants from Washington Territory</em>; <em>Flora of Washington, Columbia River and Mount
Paddo</em>; <em>Plants of the Cascade Mountains</em>. – <em>Manuscripts and correspondence</em> in Washington State
University Library; further <em>field notes</em> at US. – <em>Letters</em> at G, GH, UPS-UB.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 346 (b. 15 Sep 1850, d. 3 Oct 1932); BL 1:
220, 320; Bossert p. 388; CSP 18: 1035; Ewan ed. 1: 318, ed. 2: 215; Hortus 3: 1205; IH
1 (ed. 2): 36, (ed. 6): 365, (ed. 7): 343; Lenley p. 398 (also 360); NW p. 15-21, 58, 59;
PH 164, 209; Rehder 1: 326, 327; Tucker 1: 673, 3: 298; Urban-Berl. p. 402; Zander ed.
10, p. 722, ed. 11, p. 824.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Index Amer. bot. lit. 1886-1966. 4: 299. 1969; Science ser. 2. 76: 457-
	458. 1932 (obit. not.); Torreya 32(6): 170. 1932 (died, killed by a train); Washington
	State College Powwow 33(4): 12-14. 1953 (portr.).
Cooke, W.B. &amp; C.G. Shaw, Res. Stud. State Coll. Washington 20(4): 135-145. 1952,
	21(1): 3-56. 1953 (on S.'s fungus coll.).
Jones, G.N., Rhodora 34: 189-190. 1932 (on his Unters. Gatt. Amsinckia); Wash. hist.
	Quart. 24(2): 128-129. 1933 (obit.).
Jones, M.E., Contr. West. Bot. 18: 19. 1935 (obit. not.; "he was always a hopeless
	splitter").
Keck, D.D., Madroño 2: 103. 1933.
L., J.E., Spokane Spokesman Review, Sunday 8 Jul 1928, Mag. p. [4] ("botanist tells
	world of western plants").

	itin., localities, types, bibl.) (rev. by L. Constance, Madroño 8: 63-64. 1945).

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Suksdorfia</em> A. Gray (1880, <em>nom. cons.</em>); for specific epithet eponyms see S.J.
Preece (1955).

<sm>NOTE</sm>: (1) Published a series <em>Washingtonische Pflanzen, in</em> Bot. Monatschr. 16(11): 209-212.
Nov 1898, 16(12): 220-222. Dec 1898, 18(2): 26-27. Feb 1900, 18(5-6): 86-88. Jun 1900,
18(7): 97-99-Jul 1900, 18(9): 132-134. Sep 1900, 18(10): 153-156. Oct 1900, 19(6): 91-
93. Jun 1901 (in part reprinted with original pagination or no pagination at all, sets at
HH, US). A <em>second</em> part in this series was published in Allg. bot. Z. 12: 5-7, 26-27, 42, 43.
1903; for parts III and IV see <em>Werdenda</em>, below.
(2) <em>The Flora of Mount Adams</em>, Mazama 1(1): 68-97. 1896.
