Sullivan, David (1836-1895), Australian botanist and head master of the state school
at Moyston, Victoria. (<em>Sullivan</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: MEL. – Some material at B (mainly destr.), NMW.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: BB p. 293; BL 1: 75, 320; CSP 18: 1036; Desmond p.
592; HR (bibl., biogr. refs.); Rehder 5: 830; Urban-Berl. p. 315.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Proc. Linn. Soc. 1895-1896: 47. 1896 (obit. not.); Vict. Natural. 12(3):
	36. 1895 (obit.).
Maiden, J.H., Vict. Natural. 25: 113. 1908.
Willis, J.H., Vict. Natural. 66: 105, 123-124. 1949.

Sullivant, William Starling (1803-1873), American businessman and botanist
(bryologist); studied at Yale University, M.A. 1823; afterwards in charge of the family
property in Ohio; active as a surveyor and administrator as well as a private scientist.
(<em>Sull</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: FH (1739 Hepat., 16.200 Musci; presented 1874); other material
(mainly bryophytes) at BR, BUF, G, G-DC, GH (phan.), GRA, H, MO (incl. phan.),
MSC, NY (incl. phan.), OS (phan. Ohio; dupl. of exsicc.), PH (incl. phan.), US (incl.
phan.), W, WTU. Index to Sullivant's hepatic herbarium at FH: Sayre (1974), id. to
the moss herbarium (Sayre 1984). The types of the hepatics of the Wilkes exp. were lost
in the mails before Sullivant's death. – Unpublished <em>manuscripts</em> and <em>letters</em>, original draw-
ings for <em>Icones muscorum</em>, original sketches for Gray's <em>Manual</em>, ed. 2 (genera of musci and
hepatics) at FH; <em>letters</em> to S.O. Lindbergh at H-UB; other letters at G, GH, UPS-UB.
<em>Exsiccatae</em>: (1) <em>Musci alleghanienses</em> fasc. 1-2, nos. 1-292. 28 Jan 1846 ("1845"). Sets at B
(mainly destr.), BM, BR, E, FH, FR, G, H, HAL, L, LE, MICH, OXF, PC, W,
WELC, Z. – See Sayre (1971) for further details. First sets published 30 Jan 1846. For
schedae see <em>Musci alleghanienses</em> (1845) 1846, below.
(2) <em>Musci boreali-americani</em>, with Charles Léo Lesquereux (1806-1899), <em>ed. 1</em>, nos. 1-355,
Columbi Ohioensium. Feb 1857 ("1856"). Sets: BM, CM, COLO, DPU, FH, G, GRI,
H, MICH, NEU, NY, PC, W. For further details see Sayre (1981, 13) and below <em>Musc.
bor.–amer</em>. 1856 [i.e. 1857].
(3) Id. <em>ed. 2</em>, nos. 1-536, Apr 1866 ("1865"). Sets: B, BM, FH, H, MICH, PC. – For
further details see Sayre (1971).
(4) <em>Musci cubenses</em> (coll. Charles Wright 1856-1858), nos. 1-131, Columbus, Ohio 1861.
Sets: B (mainly destr.), FH, H. <em>Index</em>: W.S. Sullivant, Musci cubensis, Proc. Amer. Acad.
Arts Sci. 5: 273-290. 1861; some taxa descr. previously in id. 4: 275-282. 1859. For
further details see Sayre (1971). <em>Accompanying text</em>: <em>Musci cubensis wrightiani</em> 1861, see
below.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 346 (b. 15 Jan 1803, d. 30 Apr 1873); BM 5:
2047; Bossert p. 388; Clokie p. 250; CSP 5: 885-886, 8: 1045, 12: 711; DAB 18: 201 (by
W.R. Maxon); De Toni 1: cxxi, 2: cxiii; Frank 3 (Anh.): 101; Herder p. 208, 262, 267;
IH 1 (ed. 3): 42, (ed. 6): 363, (ed. 7): 343, 2: (files); Jackson p. 154, 359, 361, 404;
Lasègue p. 453; Lenley p. 398, 470; MD p. 230-234; ME 1: 232, 3: 662; MW p. 475;
NAF ser. 2. 3: 43-45; NI 1911-1912, 2153; PH 364; PR 1281, 9043-9047, ed. 1: 9994-
9995; Rehder 1: 313; SBC p. 133; SIA 7085; SK 4: cvii; TL-1/431, 1276-1280, 1317,
1319; TL-2/515, 2124, 4260 and see indexes; Tucker 1: 14, 673; Urban-Berl. p. 315.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Allibone, S.A., Crit. dict. Engl. lit. 2300-2301. 1878.

13.398. <em>A catalogue of plants</em>, native or naturalized, in the vicinity <em>of Columbus, Ohio</em> ...
Columbus, Ohio (Charles Scott, ...) 1840. Oct. (<em>Cat. pl. Columbus</em>).

<em>Publ</em>. 1840, p. [i]-iv, [5]-63. <em>Copies</em>: HH, PH, USGS.

13.399. <em>Musci alleghanienses</em>, sive enumeratio muscorum atque hepaticarum quos in
itinere a Marylandia usque ad Georgiani per tractus montium a.d. mdcccxliii decerpser-
unt Asa Gray et W.S. Sullivant (interjectis nonnullis aliunde collectis). Concinnavit et
exposuit W.S. Sullivant. Columbus, in Ohione. 1845. Oct. (<em>Musc. allegh.</em>).

[<em>Ed. 1</em>]: Dec 1845 or 1-7 Jan 1846 (see Sayre (1981) for extensive details; a copy was
	received by the Boston Soc. nat. Hist. at its session of 7 Jan 1846), p. [1]-72. <em>Copies</em>:
	GH (fide Sayre), NY, PH. – Sayre cites a letter by Sullivant to Gray 8 Jan 1846:
	"Received one copy of the Enumeratio by mail ... I consider it a villanous affair &amp;
	shall commit them to the flames on their arrival &amp; wish you to do the same with those
	[sic] in your possession ..." Various copies were even so distributed and remained
	intact. The edition has never been used as a source for the new names. Sayre pro-
	poses, on the basis of the author's intent to destroy the copies, that it was not effective-
	ly published.
[<em>Ed. 2</em>]: 18-22 Mar 1846 (see Sayre (1981); a copy of this edition was received by the
	Boston Soc. Nat. Hist. at its session of 18 Mar 1846), p. [1]-87, [88, colo.]. <em>Copies</em>: B-S,
	G, H, HH, NY, PH, Teyler; IDC 5755. 100 copies printed. Type same but re-
	arranged.
<em>Exsicccatae</em> accompanying the text: publ. 28 Jan 1846; for a description see Sayre (1981),
	p. 470 (2b) and see above under exsiccatae.
	<em>Review of exsiccatae and text</em> of ed. [1] by Asa Gray, Amer. J. Sci. ser. 2. 1: 70-81. 1-15
	Jan 1846 (err. on p. 312, Mar 1846). The review by Asa Gray contains citations of
	descriptions of 16 of the taxa from ed. [1], the names of which are therefore effectively
	published 1-15 Jan 1846; the two taxa corrected in the March issue (p. 312) were
	effectively published in the exsiccatae. <em>Other review</em> of the text of ed. [2] and the
	exsiccatae by Karl Müller, Bot. Zeit. 4: 807-811. 20 Nov 1846 ("verschwenderisch
	ausgestattet ...") [All sets were given, not sold, by Sullivant].

13.400. <em>Contributions to the bryology and hepaticology of North America</em> ... Part i ... Cambridge
(Metcalf and Company, ...) 1846. Qu. 

<em>Part i</em>: 1-20 Sep 1846 (in journal, see Sayre (1981); the reprint was probably published
	somewhat later: on 12 Nov 1846 Sullivant requests that 50 copies of the reprint be
	sent to him), p. [1]-12 (p. 3-12, also numbered 57-66), <em>pl. 1-5</em> (uncol. liths. auct.).
	<em>Copies</em>: B-S, G, H, MO, NY. – Reprinted and to be cited from Mem. Acad. Sci. Arts
	ser. 2. 3(1): 57-66, <em>pl. 1-5.</em> 1846.
<em>Part ii</em>: 6 Feb 1850 (in journal and as reprints, see Sayre (1981), cover-t.p., p. 13-20, <em>pl.
	1-5</em> (id.). <em>Copies</em>: B, GH, H, NY. – Reprinted with special cover and double pagination
	from Mem. Amer. Acad. Arts Sci. ser. 2. 4(1): [169]-176, <em>pl. 1-5.</em> 1849 [i.e. 1850]. –
	Title on reprint cover: "Contributions ... North America. By William S. Sullivant.
	Part ii ... 1849".

	<em>Copies</em>: G, HH, NY. – Preprinted from id. 3: 181-185. Nov-Dec 1855. New genus <em>Alsia</em>

13.403. <em>The musci and hepaticae of the United States</em> east of the Mississipi River. Contributed
to the second edition of Gray's Manual of botany, ... New York (George P. Putnam &amp;
Co.) 1856. Oct. (<em>Musc. hepat. U.S.</em>).

<em>First publ. of text</em>: circa 1 Sep 1856 (TL-2/2124) <em>in</em> A. Gray, <em>Manual</em> ed. 2. 607-702, <em>pl. 1-8.</em>
	 – Also included in ed. 2, revised editions of 1858 (n.v.) and 1859 as well as in ed. 4,
	1863 and ed. 4 revised (p. 607-743, <em>pl. 15-23</em>, 1865). Not included in other issues of
	Manual after 1865. – A section on Hepatics by L.M. Underwood was included in ed.
	6, 1890.
	<em>Note</em>: The new taxa date from circa 1 Sep 1856; references to <em>Musci boreali-americana</em>
	were premature: the book had not yet been published. For further details see Sayre
	(1981, 11).
<em>Reprint</em>: Oct 1856 (see Sayre (1981, 12), t.p. as given in heading), p. [i]-iv, [607(7)]-
	702(102), additions 103-105, [106], expl. pl. [731(107)]-737(113), index [107]-112
	sic, [1, h.t.], <em>pl. 1-8. Copies</em>: G, HH, MICH, NY, USDA; IDC 7624.
<em>Ref</em>.: Müller, K., Bot. Zeit. 15: 671-675, 690-693. 1857 (rev.).

13.404. <em>Musci boreali-americani</em>, quorum specimina exsiccata W.S. Sullivant et L. Les-

bor.-amer.</em>).

	americani</em>, sive specimina exsiccata muscorum in Americae rebuspublicis foederatis de-
	tectorum ... 1856, p. [i], [1-5] and exsiccatae. <em>Copies</em>: B, NY.

13.405. <em>Explorations and surveys for a railroad route from the Mississippi River to the Pacific
Ocean</em>. War Department. Route near the thirty-fifth parallel, explored by Lieutenant
A.W. Whipple, topographical engineer, in 1853 and 1854. <em>Report on the Botany of the
Expedition</em>. [p. 185: no. 5. <em>Description of the mosses and liverworts</em>. By W.S. Sullivant]. Was-
hington, D.C. 1856 [i.e. 1857]. Qu. (<em>Expl. railroad Mississippi Pacific, Descr. moss. liverw.</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: Aug 1857 (see Sayre (1981, 14) for a detailed discussion. The Sullivant reprints
	came out in Aug 1857), p. [i, t.p. as above], [185]-193, <em>pl. 1-10</em> (uncol. liths. W.S.
	Sullivant and A. Schrader). <em>Copies</em>: G, NY, U; IDC 5772 (in part). – Reprinted from
	<em>Expl. railroad Mississippi Pacific vol 4., part 2</em> (with above t.p.), paper no. 5. – Sayre
	recommends as an abbreviated title: Expl. Surv. railr. Pacific 4(2): 185-193 ("1856")
	1857. – Copies vary: sometimes as part of complete partial volume 4(2) and somet-
	imes as simple reprints with the Sullivant text only preceded by the 4(2) t.p.

13.406. <em>Characters of some new musci</em> collected by Charles Wright in the North Pacific
Exploring Expedition, under the command of Captain John Rodgers, U.S.N. By
William S. Sullivant and Leo Lesquereux. August 1859. Oct. (<em>Char. new musci</em>).

<em>Co-author</em>: Charles Léo Lesquereux (1806-1889).
<em>Publ</em>.: Aug 1859 (date on p. 1; possibly also only in September because the reprint of the
	paper by Asa Gray in the same volume came out in September; see Sayre (1981, 15)),
	p. [1]-7. <em>Copies</em>: G (with 17 pp. drawings), H, HH, NY. – Preprinted from Proc.
	Amer. Acad. Arts Sci. 4: 275-282. 1860. – The accompanying drawings, on <em>17 plates</em>
	were published by G. Sayre in D.P. Pfister, ed., Crypt. U.S. North Pacif. Expl. Exp.
	1853-1856, pl. 1-17 (with reproduction of mss. text on p. 127-161). 1978.

13.407. <em>United States Exploring Expedition</em>. During the years 1838, 1839, 1840, 1841, 1842.
Under the command of Charles Wilkes, U.S.N. <em>Botany. Musci.</em> By William S. Sullivant.
With twenty-six folio plates. Philadelphia (printed by C. Sherman &amp; Son) 1859. Fol. (<em>U.S. Expl. Exped., Musc.</em>).

PAGE: 91
HEADING: SULZBERGER

<em>Publ</em>.: 1-18 Mai 1860 (t.p. 1859; for details see Sayre (1981, 16), p. [1]-32, <em>pl. 1-26</em>
	(uncol. copp. author and A. Schrader). <em>Copies</em>: MO, NY. – "Unofficial" issue of part
	of volume 17 of the U.S. Exp. (Wilkes) series. The letterpress in this separate issue is
	set up in folio, in double columns to match the plates. – Hasskell 69.
<em>Official issue</em>: 1874 in <em>United States Exploring Expedition</em>. During the years 1838-1842, under
	the command of Charles Wilkes, U.S.N. vol. xvii. Botany I. Lower Cryptogamia ii.
	Phanerogamia of the Pacific Coast of North America. Philadelphia (printed by C.
	Sherman) 1862, 1875, on p. [3]-112, "Musci. By William S. Sullivant". – See also
	TL-2/239 and Haskell 68. <em>Copies</em>: LC, US.
<em>Plates official issue</em>: The Sullivant plates were not included in the official issue; "they are
	usually found only with the accompanying text issued by the author in 1859"
	(Haskell), or they may be bound with Haskell 72, the unofficial issue of the other 29
	plates of algae, lichenes, fungi and "botany" 1-17. The Sullivant plates are included
	in the 1969 facsimile.
<em>Facsimile ed</em>. 1971, US Exploring Expedition (Wilkes Expedition) volume xvii, Botany iii.
	Reprint 1971, Lehre (Verlag von J. Cramer), Hist. nat. class. 87(3), text on p. [3]-
	112 (text as in official issue 1874, Haskell 68) plates in separate atlas as Haskell 72 but
	in this case indeed with the plates of the musci. The atlas vol. 17, <em>Lower Cryptogamia</em> ...
	is dated 1862; users of this facsimile should realize that the plates were actually issued
	1-18 Mai 1860 with the "1859" unofficial issue treated above (Haskell 69). <em>Copies</em> of
	facsimile ed.: BR, FAS.
<em>Ref</em>.: Haskell, D.C., Bull. New York Publ. Library 45: 842-845. 1941.
	Sayre, G., Bryologist 84: 477-478. 1981.
	Stafleu, F.A., Taxon 21: 172. 1972.

13.408. <em>Musci cubenses wrightiani</em>, coll. 1856-1858, by William S. Sullivant. Extracted
from the Proceedings of the American Academy of Arts and Sciences, August 1861. Oct. (<em>Musc. cub. wright.</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: Sep 1860 (date on preprint: Aug 1859; see Sayre (1981, 9, 17) for the dating of
	this preprint), p. [i], 273-290. <em>Copies</em>: B, G, H, HH, NY(2). – Preprinted from Proc.
	Amer. Acad. Arts Sci. 5: 273-290. 1862.
<em>Ref</em>.: Urban, I., Symb. ant. 1: 160. 1898.

13.409. <em>Icones muscorum</em>, or figures and descriptions of most of those mosses peculiar to
Eastern North America which have not been heretofore figured ... Cambridge, Mass.
(Sever and Francis), London (Trübner &amp; Co.) 1864. Oct. (<em>Icon. Musc.</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: Oct 1864 (for details on date see Sayre (1981, 18) and TL-1/1279), p. [i]-viii, [1]-

Summerhayes, Victor Samuel (1897-1974), British botanist (orchidologist); B.Sc.
Univ. Coll. London 1920; travelled to Spitzbergen 1921; at the Royal Botanic Gardens,
Kew, in charge of the orchid herbarium 1924-1964. (<em>Summerh</em>.).

Sumstine, David [Ross] (1870-1965), American mycologist; M.S. Univ. Pittsburgh

Supprian, Karl [Wilhelm] (1871-1917), German (Silesian) botanist; studied natural
sciences at München and Berlin; Dr. phil. Berlin 1894 as student of A. Engler; teacher at
the Reform-Realgymnasium, Altona 1900; active promotor of gymnastics; on active
service 1914-1917; fell at Villers-devant-la-Thour. (<em>Supprian</em>).

Surian, Joseph Donat (x-1691), French physician-pharmacist at Marseille; travelled
in the West Indies 1689-1690 by Royal Command, accompanied by Charles Plumier.
(<em>Surian</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: P. – Surian accompanied Plumier to the West Indies in 1689-
1690. During the trip Plumier made the drawings and the descriptions, whereas Surian
made the collections. The extensive herbarium in book-form (10 volumes) came to
hands of the Jussieu family and is now at P (herbier historique). It contains a great
many plants that are referable to Plumier species and is for that reason an important,
although hitherto hardly used, source of information. The Surian herbarium was used
by both Adanson and A.L. Jussieu, and is repeatedly quoted by the former author. The

PAGE: 95
HEADING: SURINGAR

Surian names are, however, manuscript names and were never published by Surian
himself. – See also Clokie. Further material at BM-SL, OXF, P-JU.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Backer p. 567; Barnhart 3: 348; Clokie p. 251; IH 1 (ed.
6): 365, (ed. 7): 344, 2: (files); Lasègue p. 316, 487; PR alph.; Rehder 1: 334; TL-
1/1281-1282; see C. Plumier; TL-2/see C. Plumier.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Fries, Th.M., Bref Skrifv. Linné 1(2): 75. 1908.
Hulth, J.M., Bref Skrifv. Linné 2(1): 127. 1916.
Lacroix, A., Figures de savants 3: 53, 4: 159. 1938.
D-P-s, <em>in</em> J.Fr. Michaud, Biogr. univ. 40: 452-453. 1854ff. (facs. 1969).
Schumann, K., Monatschr. Kakteenk. 14(5): 78. 1904.
Stafleu, F.A., <em>in</em> N.J. Jacquin, Select. stirp. amer. hist., facs. ed. New York 1971, p. F-21,
	22.
Urban, I., Symb. ant. 1: 124, 130, 160-161. 1898, 3: 133. 1902.

<sm>COMPOSITE</sm> <sm>WORKS</sm>: <em>Insignium et rariorum plantarum semina</em>, ex insulis americanis recentes
allata, offeruntur &amp; communicantur à Josepho Donato de Surian, ... in Nicolas
Lémery, <em>Traité universel des drogues simples</em> ... Paris 1698, p. [i-vi] [a list of vernacular
names].

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Suriana</em> Linnaeus (1753).

Suringar, Gerard Conrad Bernard (1802-1874), German (Lingen/Hannover)-born
Dutch physician; Dr. med. Leiden 1824; studied in Gent, Liège, Paris and Berlin 1824-
1826; Dr. chirurg. Leiden 1826; practicing physician at Leiden 1826-1830; professor of
anatomy at the Athenaeum, Amsterdam 1830-1831 (from 1831-1843 honorary) profes-
sor of medicine at the Clinical School Amsterdam 1831-1843; professor of medicine
Leiden 1843-1872. (<em>G. Suringar</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: BM 5: 2050; Herder p. 123; NNBW 3: 1213-1215
(Simon Thomas); PR 9048, ed. 1: 9996; Rehder 1: 109.

Daniels, C.E., <em>in</em> A. Hirsch et al., eds., Biogr. Lex. hervorr. Ärzte ed. 3. 5: 477-478. 1962.
L.Hn., Dic. encycl. Sci. méd. 13: 575-576. 1884.
Suringar, P.H., Ned. Tijdschr. Geneesk. ser. 2. 10(2): 66-93. 1874 (obit., bibl.).

Suringar, Willem Frederik Reinier (1832-1898), Dutch botanist; Dr. phil. Leiden
1857; extraordinary professor of botany University of Leiden 1857-1862, regular profes-
sor of botany, successor to W.H. de Vriese 1862-1898; from 1871-1898 director of the
Rijksherbarium as successor to F.A.W. Miquel; Dr. phil. h.c. Univ. München 1872;
travelled in Suriname, [British] Guyana, Trinidad and the Netherlands Antilles 1884-
1885. (<em>Suringar</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: L; some further material at B (mainly destr.), H, K, MO, W,
WAG. – Suringar's private herbarium was considerable; it contained e.g. the herbarium

PAGE: 96
HEADING: SURINGAR

of F.T. Kützing and the type herbarium of W.D. Koch's <em>Synopsis</em>. Most parts of the
herbarium were ultimately given to L; even so Koster (1936) states that some of
Suringar's types of algae are [still] missing. Most original <em>drawings</em> for S.'s algological
works are also at L. <em>Letters</em> to W.G. Farlow at FH; to D.F.L. von Schlechtendal at HAL;
other letters at G, UPS-UB.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Ainsworth p. 61; Backer p. 568; Barnhart 3: 348 (b. 28
Dec 1832, d. 12 Jul 1898); BL 2: 428, 429, 721; BM 5: 2050; Bossert p. 389; CSP 5: 888,
8: 1046, 11: 530, 12: 711, 18: 1039-1040; De Toni 1: ciii, cxiii, cxvi, cxxi, 4: lv; DSB 13:
154-155 (P.W. v.d. Pas); Herder p. 29, 68, 123, 133, 245, 254; IH 1 (ed. 2): 70, (ed. 6):
365, (ed. 7): 344, 2: (files); Jackson p. 324, 383, 441, 480, 507; JW 1: 449, 451, 2: 201, 3:
370, 5: 253; LS 23612; Morren ed. 2, p. 28, ed. 10, p. 90; MW p. 476; NI 1913-1914;
Nordstedt p. 30; NNBW 10: 990-995; Oudemans 2(2): 256-257, 259; PR 9049-9053;
Rehder 5: 830-831; SK 4: cvii; TL-1/877, see W.D.J. Koch; TL-2/2460, 6125, see
W.D.J. Koch, F.T. Kützing, K.M. Schumann; Tucker 1: 673-674, 3: 299; Urban-Berl.
p. 402.

	134. 1858 (app. Leiden), 10: 215. 1862 (regular prof. Leiden after de Vriese's death);
	Bot. Not. 1888: 208, 1899: 48; Bot. Monatschr. 16: 156: 1898 (d.); Bot. Zeit. 16: 68.

Veendorp, H. &amp; L.G.M. Baas-Becking, Hortus acad. lugd.-bat. 150, 164, 167, 168, 170-
	177. 1938.
Verdoorn, F., ed., Chron. bot. 1: 221. 1935.
Vries, H. de, Ber. deut. bot. Ges. 17: (104), (220)-(224). 1899 (obit.); Eigen Haard
	1897(44): 724-727 (on his 40 years professorship).
Vuyck, L., Ned. kruidk. Arch. ser. 3. 1: i-x. 1899 (obit., portr.).
Wachter, W.H., Ned. kruidk. Arch. 55: 61-68. 1947 (on S. and the Ned. bot. Ver.).
Winkler Prins, A., ed., Geill. encycl. 14: 83-84. 1887.
Witte, H., Tijdschr. Tuinbouw 4: 1-5. 1899 (obit., portr.).
Wittrock, V.B., Acta Horti Berg. 3(3): 169. 1905.

<sm>COMPOSITE</sm> <sm>WORKS</sm>: (1) Co-editor <em>Nederlands kruidkundig archief</em> 4(3)-12(4), 1857-1898.
(2) Published part 3 of F.A.W. Miquel, <em>Ill. fl. Archip. Ind.</em>, 1871, TL-2/6125.

PAGE: 97
HEADING: SURINGAR

(3) Contributed to A.L. van Hasselt, <em>Bijdr. Fl. Midd. Sumatra</em> 1884, TL-2/2460, see below
<em>Rafflesia Hasseltii</em> (1880).
(4) Editor, <em>Catalogue des Broméliacées</em> cultivées au Jardin botanique de l'Université à
Leide. (2e édition, revue et augmentée). Ier janvier 1894. Leide, Imprimerie de A.W.
Sijthoff, p. [i-iv], [1]-68. <em>Copy</em>: M.

<sm>NOTE</sm>: (1) Among Suringar's students at Leiden were Martinus Willem Beijerinck (1851-
1931), Jacob Gijsbert Boerlage (1849-1950), Jacob van Breda de Haan (1866-1917),
William Burck (1848-1910), Melchior Treub (1851-1910), Hugo de Vries (1848-1935).
(2) Suringar married Sara Valckenier in 1862; their son Jan added his mother's name to
that of his father's: Jan Valckenier Suringar (1864-1932), also a botanist, treated by us
under Valckenier.
(3) No bibliography of Suringar's numerous publications is known to us; for this reason
our treatment of Suringar is somewhat more extensive than usual in TL-2. CSP lists the
majority of S.'s publications in journals.

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Suringaria</em> Pierre (1886); <em>Suringaria</em> H. Kylin (1940).

13.419. Dissertatio botanica inauguralis continens <em>Observationes phycologicas in floram
batavam</em>, quas, annuente summo numine, ex auctoritate rectoris magnifici Frederici
Kaiser, ... et nobilissimae Facultatis disciplinarum mathematicarum et physicarum de-
creto, pro gradu doctoratus, summisque in mathesi et philosophia naturali honoribus ac
privilegiis in Academia lugduno-batava, rite ac legitime consequendis, defendet Willem
Frederik Reinier Suringar, Leovardensis. A.D. iii m. Martis a. mdccclvii. Hora ii-iii.
Leovardiae [Leeuwarden] (G.T.N. Suringar) [1857]. Oct. (in 4-s). (<em>Observ. phycol. fl.
batav.</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: 3 Mar 1857 (date of defense thesis; Ned. Staatscourant 6 Mai 1857 (legal deposit),
	p. [i*-x*], [i]-xiv, [xv-xvi], [1]-75, [77-79, index], <em>pl. 1-4</em> (col. or uncol. liths. auct.)
	with text, [1-4, theses]. <em>Copies</em>: B, BR, FAS, FH, G, KNAW, NY, U, USDA. – Title
	on cover: <em>Observationes phytologicae in floram batavam</em>. – The thesis was based on a text
	submitted as an answer to a prize question of Leiden University; Suringar obtained
	the prize and used the text as the basis of his thesis. – The copies at B, FH and
	KNAW have coloured plates. (The uncoloured copies sold at Hfl. 2. =, coloured Hfl.
	3. =).
<em>Commercial edition</em>: 1857, p. [i*-vi*], [i]-xiv, [xv-xvi], [1]-75, [77-79, index], <em>pl. 1-4</em> (col.
	liths.). <em>Copies</em>: PH, US. – Lacks the Dissertation t.p., and has a t.p. <em>Observationes
	phytologicae in Floram batavam</em> ... Leovardiae [Leeuwarden] (G.T.N. Suringar) 1857.

13.420. Blikken in het leven der natuur. 4. <em>Het leven der natuur</em>, door Dr. W.F.R. Suringar.
Leeuwarden (G.T.N. Suringar) 1857. Oct. (<em>Leven nat</em>.).

<em>Publ</em>.: before 19 Sep 1857 (Ned. Staatscourant, legal deposit, 19 Sep 1857), cover-t.p., p.
	[145]-192. <em>Copy</em>: FAS. – Of importance only for an understanding of S.'s background.
	Part of no. 4 of 8 volumes of the series "Blikken in het leven der natuur, tot bevorder-
	ing van natuurkennis onder alle standen" edited by J. Bosscha Jr., R.S. Tjaden
	Modderman and W.F.R. Suringar.

13.438. <em>Melocacti novi</em> ex insulis Archipelago indici-occidentalis neerlandicis Curaçao,
Aruba et Bonaire ... Amsterdam (Johannes Müller) 1885. Oct. 

<em>Publ</em>.: late Dec 1885, or, more probably early 1886 (texxt submitted 19 Dec 1885; t.p.
	preprint 1885), cover-t.p., p. [1]-13. <em>Copies</em>: BR, HH, PH, U. – Preprinted or re-
	printed from Versl. Meded. Kon. Akad. Wet., Afd. Natuurk. ser. 3. 2: [183]-195.
	1886. – A brief preliminary report (no new taxa) was publ. 20-31 Dec 1885 in Kon.
	Akad. Wet. Amsterdam. Afd. Natuurk. Zitting van 19 Dec 1885, p. [1]-2 (<em>copy</em>: BR).
<em>Ref</em>.: Urban, I., Symb. ant. 1: 161-162. 1898 (q.v. for this and subsequent publications
	on Melocactus).

<em>Copies</em>: B, BR, U.

Suter, Johann Rudolf (1766-1827), Swiss botanist; studied in Göttingen 1785-1787;
Dr. phil. ib. 1787; studied medicine at Mainz 1791-1793 and Göttingen 1794-1795; Dr.
med. 1794; practicing physician in Zofingen 1795; member of the council of the Helvet-
ian republic 1798-1801; practicing physician and private scientist in Bern 1801-1804; id.
Zofingen 1811-1820; professor of philosophy and Greek, Bern 1820-1827. (<em>Suter</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 348 (b. 29 Mar 1766, d. 24 Feb 1827); BM
5: 2051; Herder p. 181; Hortus 3: 1205; PR 9055, ed. 1: 9999; Rehder 1: 433; SO 778a,
add. 778b; Tucker 1: 674; Zander ed. 10, p. 722, ed. 11, p. 824.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Attinger, V. et al., eds., Dict. hist. biogr. Suisse 6: 437. 1932.
Bossart, C., Schweiz. Ärzte Naturf. 19. Jahrh. 14-15. 1979.
Fischer, Ed., Verh. Schweiz. naturf. Ges. 1914(2): 8, 26.
Mittler, O. &amp; G. Boner, Biogr. Lex. Aargaus 767. 1958.
Usteri, P., Verh. allg. Schweiz. Ges. Naturw. 13: 131-144. 1827 (obit.).

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Sutera</em> A.W. Roth (1807). <em>Note</em>: <em>Suteria</em> A.P. de Candolle (1830) may also
honor J.R. Suter, but no etymology was given.

13.449. <em>Helvetiens Flora</em> worinn alle im Hallerischen Werke enthaltenen und seither
neuentdeckten schweizer Pflanzen nach Linné's Methode aufgestellt sind ... Zürich
(bey Orell, Fuessli und Comp.) 1802. Duod. (<em>Helvet. Fl</em>.).

<em>Ed</em>. [<em>1</em>]: 1802, 2 vols. <em>Copies</em>: B, BR, M, NY. – Other t.p.: <em>Flora helvetica</em> exhibens plantas
	Helvetiae indigenas Hallerianas, et omnes quae nuper detectae sunt ordine Lin-
	naeano". – Lists species of Haller, A. von, Hist. stirp. helv. 1768, TL-2/2311.
	<em>1</em>: 1802, p. [ii-iii], [1]-345.

HEADING: SUTHERLAND

	<em>2</em>: 1802 (p. lxiii: 6 Dec 1801), p. [ii]-lxiii, [1]-416, [1-16, index, err.].
<em>Ed. 2</em>: 1822, 2 vols. <em>Copies</em>: B, G, NY, PH, US. "<em>Helvetiens flora</em> enthaltend die phanero-
	gamischen Gewächse Helvetiens. Zuerst bearbeitet von Joh. Rudolf Suter ... ver-
	mehrt herausgegeben von Joh. Hegetschweiler ..." Zürich (bey Orell, Füssli und
	Compagnie ...) 1822. Duod. – Other t.p. "<em>Flora helvetica</em> exhibens plantas Helvetiae
	phanerogamas. Editionem primam curavit Joh. Rudolf Suter ... alteram edidit et

<em>Ref</em>.: Anon., Flora 6(2): 737-750. 21 Dec 1823 (rev.).

Sutherland, James (c. 1639-1719), British botanist; professor of botany, Edinburgh
1695-1706; King's botanist for Scotland 1699; director of the Royal Botanical Garden,
Edinburgh 1699-1714. (<em>Sutherland</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Not traced. Material sent to J. Petiver in BM-Sloane and to W.
Sherard in OXF.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: AG 6(2): 724; Barnhart 3: 349; BB p. 293; BM 5: 2051;
Desmond p. 592 (d. 24 Jun 1719); Dryander 3: 101; Henrey 13, 197-198, 199 note;
Herder p. 41, 150; Jackson p. 411; PR 9056, ed. 1: 10.000; Rehder 1: 52; TL-2/see A.
Buddle; Tucker 1: 674.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Hatfield, M. et al., Brit. Gardeners 272-273. 1980.
Bridson, G.D.R. et al., Nat. hist. mss. res. Brit. Isl. 138.32, 224.99. 1980.
Dandy, J.E., The Sloane herbarium 218-219. 1958.
Fletcher, H.R., Roy. Bot. Gard. Edinburgh 7-18. 1970.
Kent, D.H. &amp; D.E. Allen, Brit. Irish herb. 253. 1984 (coll.).
Richardson, R., Extracts lit. sci. corr. 27. 1835. Sutherland, J. 836

<sm>HANDWRITING</sm>: Dandy, J.E., The Sloane herbarium, facs. no. 2. 1958.

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Sutherlandia</em> J.F. Gmelin (1791, (<em>nom. rej</em>.); <em>Sutherlandia</em> R. Brown ex W. Aiton
et W.T. Aiton (1812, <em>nom. cons</em>.).

Oct. (<em>Hort. med. edinb</em>.).

<em>Other ed</em>.: 1692, Edinburgh (Andrew Anderson) n.v.

Sutherland, William (1832-1920), British gardener, at Kew 1856-1860, later at
Minto, Roxburghshire. (<em>W. Sutherland</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: NMW. – For <em>Plantae rariores abredonenses</em> see W.J. Hooker, J. Bot.
Kew Gard. Misc. 9: 311-312. 1857.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Desmond p. 593 (d. 12 Feb 1920); Jackson p. 408.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Gard. Chron. 1920(1): 110 (obit. not.).
Kent, D.H. &amp; D.E. Allen, Brit. Irish herb. 253. 1984 (coll.).

Blackwood and Sons) 1871. Oct. (<em>Handb. hardy fl</em>.).

<em>Publ</em>.: 1871 (Flora 18 Aug 1871; Bot. Zeit. 14 Jul 1871), p. [i]-lxvi, [1]-321. <em>Copies</em>: B,
	BR, HH, NY.

PAGE: 104
HEADING: SUZA

Suza, Jindrich (1890-1951), Moravian (later Czechoslovakian) botanist (lichenologist,
phytogeographer), assistant at the botanical Department of Masaryk University at Brno
1921-1934; later professor of botany at Praha; Dr. phil. Brno 1924. (<em>Suza</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: BRNU, BRNM, P, PRC. – Other material at BPI, BR, C, DAO,
DS, DUKE, DS, GB, GH, M.
<em>Exsiccatae</em>: (1) <em>Lichenes bohemoslovakiae exsiccati</em>, fasc. 1-10, nos. 1-300, 1926-1935. – Sets at
FH, GB, LD, M, MSC, S, UPS, W.
(2) (posthumously): <em>Reliquiae Suzaianae e Museo nationali Pragensi</em> anno 1966 distributae,
nos. 1-100. Sets: H, LD.

<sm>NOTE</sm>: We are indebted to O. Almborn and P. Isoviita for providing details for the Suza
entry.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Ainsworth p. 186; Biol.-Dokum. 17: 9127; BJI 2: 174;
BM 8: 1273; Bossert p. 389; Futak-Domin p. 572-575; GR p. 667, <em>pl</em>. [<em>113</em>], cat. p. 72;
Hirsch p. 292; IH (ed. 6): 365, (ed. 7): 344, 2: 389; Klásterský p. 179 (q.v. for further
sec. refs.); LS suppl. 27067-27096; SBC p. 133.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Encykl. kl. slov. 5: 656. 1981; Preslia 9: 96. 1930.
Boros, A., Rev. bryol. lichénol. 22: 325. 1953 (d. 19 Nov 1951).
Domin, K., Preslia 18-19: 22-36. 1940 (biogr. sketch, bibl.).
Fott, B., Preslia 25: 90-93. 1953 (obit., portr., addl. bibl.).
Kunc, J., Koly zemreli 262. 1962.
Laundon, J.R., Lichenologist 11: 17. 1979 (herb. lich. PRM).
Pax, F., Bibl. schles. Bot. 7, 15. 1929.
Sayre, G., Mem. New York Bot. Gard. 19(1): 166. 1969 (exsicc).
Verdoorn, F., ed., Chron. bot. 1: 351. 1935, 2: 34, 107, 109, 111. 1936, 3: 27, 91. 1937,
	4: 187. 1938.

Svedelius, Nils [Eberhard] (1873-1960), Swedish botanist (algologist); Dr. phil.
Uppsala 1901 as a student of F.R. Kjellman; Regnellian curator Riksmuseum Stockh-
olm 1901-1902; lecturer at Uppsala 1902-1914; professor of botany 1914-1938, director
of the Botanical Museum 1928-1938; visited Ceylon, Singapore and Buitenzorg 1902-
1903; director of the Hortus Linnaeanus, Uppsala 1920-1930; of Uppsala Univ. Bot.
Trädg. 1928-1938. (<em>Sved</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: UPS; other material at C, E, NY. – <em>Exsiccatae</em>: contributed to S.
Lundell and J.A. Nannfeldt: <em>Fungi exsiccati suecici praesertim upsalienses</em>, fasc. 1-30, nos. 1-
1500, 1934-1947, for Schedae see TL-2/5105. – <em>Letters</em> at G.

Svenson, Henry Knute [Knut] (1897-x), Swedish-born American botanist; Dr. phil.
Harvard Univ. 1928; assistant Arnold Arb. 1920; instructor in biology, Union College
1922-1925; asst. prof. biology 1925-1927; asst. Gray herbarium 1928-1929; asst. curator
Brooklyn Bot. Gard. 1930-1936, curator herbarium 1936-1946; curator and chairman
Dept. Forestry and General Botany, Amer. Mus. nat. hist. 1946-1952; botanist U.S.
Geol. Survey 1954-1966. (<em>Svens</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: BKL; further material at AKAD, B (mainly destr.), CAS, DBN,
F, FARM, GH, K, L, MICH, MO, MSC, NY, NYS, S, TENN, UC, US.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 350 (b. 13 Jan 1897); BJI 2: 175; BL 1: 109,
320; Bossert p. 389; Hirsch p. 292; Hortus 3: 1205; IH 1 (ed. 7): 344, 2: (files); Langman
p. 726-727; Lenley p. 398; MW p. 477, suppl. 341-342; PH 33, 209, 558; SIA 226 (HI
107); TL-2/781.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Acosta-Solis, M., Natural. Viaj. Ci. Ecuador 67-68, 124. 1968 (work in
	Ecuador).
Anon., Amer. men sci. eds. 4-11. 1927-1967; Brooklyn Bot. Gard. Rec. 19(5): 240. 1930;

Svensson, Harry Gustaf (1894-1959), Swedish botanist; Dr. phil. Uppsala 1925; lec-
turer at the University of Uppsala 1925-1932; high school teacher at Karlstad 1932-
1943; at Uppsala from 1944. (<em>H.G. Svens</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 350 (b. 6 Feb 1894); Hirsch p. 292; TL-
2/12.079.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Hedwigia 66: (120). 1926 (lecturer Uppsala).

Swainson, William (1789-1855), British naturalist and explorer; with the British
colonial army in Malta and Sicily 1807-1815; from 1815 on privately active; in Brazil
with Henry Koster 1816-1819; working on his – mainly zoologial – collections in
England 1818-1840; emigrated to New Zealand 1840; engaged by the Tasmanian and
Victorian administrations to report on timber trees 1851-1853. (<em>Swainson</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: K (Brazil), LIV (Mediterr.; few from W. Ind. and Brazil); fur-
ther material at CGE (Sicily), FI (New Zeal.), GH, LIV, PH, WELT. <em>Letters</em> at BM,
LINN. – Manuscripts at Mitchell Libr. (Sydney), Natl. Libr. Canberra, Dominion
Museum (Wellington). Drawings of New Zealand trees at K. – Further information on
mss. in HR.

Swallow, George Clinton (1817-1899), American geologist; AM Bowdoin 1846; Dr.
med. Maryland Med. Coll. 1867; LL.D. Univ. Missouri 1873; principal at Bowdoin
1843-1849; id. at Hampden, Me. 1849-1851; professor of geology and mineralogy, Univ.
Missouri 1851-1853 and 1870-1882; state geologist for Missouri 1856-1861, for Kansas
1866-1867; engaged in mining operations in Montana 1867-1870; professor of agricul-
ture Univ. Missouri, dean ib. 1872 as well as professor of botany in the medical school;
editor of the Daily Independent at Helena, Mont. 1882-1888; state inspector of mines
1888-1890. (<em>Swallow</em>).

<sm>COMPOSITE</sm> <sm>WORKS</sm>: (1) Contributed 10.281 entries on miscellaneous phanerogams to
E.R. Farr, J.A. Leussink and F.A. Stafleu, <em>Index nominum genericorum</em>. 1979.
(2) <em>Burseraceae, in</em> A.A. Pulle, ed., <em>Fl. Suriname</em> 3(2): 204-251. Feb 1951.
(3) <em>De veredeling van den Oliepalm, in</em> S.J. Wellensieck, ed., Grondslagen der Algemeene
Plantenveredeling ed. 2, 1947, p. 348-381.
(4) <em>Burseraceae</em> [of Guiana], <em>in</em> B. Maguire et al., Plant explorations in Guiana in 1944,
chiefly to the Tafelberg and the Kaieteur Plateau VI. Bull. Torrey bot. Club 75: 644. 6
Dec 1948.

13.522. <em>Over de flora van Urk en Schokland</em> ... Verslagen en Mededelingen no. 1, Commissie
voor het botanisch onderzoek van de Zuiderzee en omgeving. [Amsterdam (Druk de
Bussy) ...]. 

<em>Publ</em>.: 1 Mar 1930 (in journal), p. [i, iii], 425-457. <em>Copies</em>: FAS, U. – Reprinted and to be
	cited from Ned. kruidk. Arch. 39(3): [425]-457. 1930. – See also his Verslag van een
	excursie naar Urk en Schokland op 11, 12, 13 en 14 Juni 1927 door Swart, Reitsma
	en Eyma gehouden, Ned. kruidk. Arch. 37(1): [49]-54. 30 Apr 1928.

13.523. <em>Novitates Burseracearum</em> ... Société botanique néerlandaise [1942]. Oct. 

<em>Publ</em>.: Dec 1942, cover p. [i*-ii*], [189]-210. – Reprinted and to be cited from Rec.
	Trav. bot. néerl. 39: [189]-210. 1942.
<em>Other issue</em>: in combined reprint with <em>Monogr. Protium</em>, 1942, see below.
<em>Novitates II</em>: Acta bot. néerl. 1(2): 244-249. Jul 1952.

13.524. <em>A monograph of the genus Protium</em> and some allied genera (Burseraceae). Proef-
schrift ter verkrijging van den graad van doctor in de wis- en natuurkunde aan de
Rijksuniversiteit te Utrecht, op gezag van den Rector magnificus ... te verdedigen tegen
de bedenkingen van de Faculteit der Wis- en Natuurkunde op Maandag 23 November
1942 te 15 uur ... Gouda (Drukkerij Koch en Knuttel) 1942. Oct. (<em>Monogr. Protium</em>).

<em>Thesis issue</em>: 23 Nov 1942, p. [i]-iv, [v-vi], [211]-446. <em>Copies</em>: FAS, HH, MICH, U. –
	Preprinted from Rec. Trav. bot. néerl. 39: 211-246. Dec 1942.
<em>Regular reprint</em>: Dec 1942, in combination with <em>Novitates Burseracearum</em> reprinted from Rec.
	Trav. bot. néerl. 39: [189]-200 [Novitates], [211]-446 [Monograph]. Dec 1942.
	<em>Copies</em>: FAS, G.
<em>Other issue</em>: as Meded. Bot. Mus. Herb. Utrecht 90, 1942.
<em>Addenda</em>: <em>A new Protium from Suriname</em>, Rec. Trav. bot. néerl. 42: 70. Dec 1950.

Swartz, Olof [Peter] (1760-1818), Swedish botanist; Dr. med. Uppsala 1785; curator

PAGE: 117
HEADING: SWARTZ

and professor at the "Bergianska trädgårdsskolan 1791; curator of the natural history
cabinet of the Swedish Academy of Sciences 1806; permanent secretary of the Swedish
Academy of Sciences 1811-1818; professor of botany at the "Chirurgiska skolan" (now
Karol. Inst.) Stockholm 1813; travelled in Sweden 1779-1783, 1800, 1807; visited
Boston 1783, travelled in the West Indies and N.E. South America 1784-1786; worked
in London 1786-1787; F.M.L.S. 1791; in charge of the Hortus botanicus bergianus
1791-1818. (<em>Sw</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: The Swartz herbarium constitutes, with the Alströmer and
Montin herbaria, the basis of the general herbarium of the Riksmuseum in Stockholm
(S). Swartz's herbarium and library were acquired by the Swedish Academy of Sciences
in 1819. The West-Indian collections (1784-1786) at S, however, are not complete.
Other material is at B (Willdenow, extant), BM, BR, C, CGE, E, FI, G, G-DC, H,
HAL, IJ, K, LAU, LD, LE, LINN, LIV, LW, M, NY, P, PC, PH, S, SBT, UPS, W. –
Swartz was very liberal with his specimens and Swartz types will be found for instance
in BM and LD. <em>Correspondence</em>: Library Sv.-Akad., Stockholm (p.p.), Brinkmanska
Arkivet and Riksarkivet. Letters to J. Banks and J. Dryander in the British Library; to
C.P. Thunberg at Uppsala; to C.H. Mertens at HU; other letters at G.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: AG 3: 594; Backer p. 568; Barnhart 3: 351; BM 5: 2056;
Bossert p. 390; Bret. p. 276; CSP 5: 896-897; Dawson p. 798-800; Dryander 3: 88, 168,
188, 222, 242, 247, 249, 254, 277, 282, 300, 301, 305, 320; DSB 13: 177-178 (G.
Eriksson); Frank 3 (Anh.): 102; GF p. 77; GR p. 482-483, <em>pl</em>. [<em>39</em>], cat. p. 72;
Hawksworth p. 186; Hegi 4(2): 733; Herder p. 148, 196, 226, 267, 271, 277; Hortus 3:
1205; IF 732-733; IH 1 (ed. 2): 114, (ed. 3): 146, (ed. 6): 365, (ed. 7): 344, 2: (files);
Kelly p. 221; KR p. 573, 677-683 (b. 21 Sep 1760, d. 19 Sep 1818) (main bibl.);
Krempelh. 1: 613; Langman p. 727-728; Lasègue p. 584 [index]; LS 26163-26171;
Moebius p. 129; MW p. 477, suppl. p. 342; NI 1915-1919; Plesch p. 418; PR 775, 5529,
5658, 9061-9071, 10707, ed. 1: 6167, 6324, 10003-10016, 11232, 11827; Rehder 5: 831;
RS p. 144; SBC p. 133; SK 4: ccxiv; SO 44, 597, 1317; Sotheby 724; Stevenson p. 1259;
SY p. 11, 14, 17, 30, 48, 59, 112, 150, 359, 368; TL-1/947, 1283-1285, see index; TL-
2/350, 517, 2801, 3004, 3826, 4528, 11.084 and see indexes; Tucker 1: 674-675; Urban-
Berl. p. 315, 402, 415; Zander ed. 10, p. 722, ed. 11, p. 824.

<sm>COMPOSITE</sm> <sm>WORKS</sm>: (1) Swartz provided the text for Johan August Pfeiffer, ed., <em>Magasin
för blomster-älskare</em> och idkare af trädgårds-skötsel, Häft 1-12. Stockholm (... C. Delén)
1803-1809, Qu., <em>36 pl</em>. with text. – See KR p. 573 and Junk, Cat. 214 (1979), no. 242
and p. 76.
(2) <em>On the genera of Orchideae in</em> C.D.E. Koenig, ed., <em>Tracts bot</em>. 1805 (TL-2/3826) [trans-
lation of <em>Afhandling om Orchidernes slägter</em>, Sv. Vet.-Akad. Handl. 1800: 115-138 and
chart], and <em>Genera and species of the natural order of the Orchideae, in</em> id. [translation of
<em>Orchidernes slägter och arter upställde</em>, ib. 1800: 202-254, <em>pl. 3</em>]. (See KR p. 679, no. 679). –
Latin version: <em>Genera et species Orchidearum, in</em> Schrader, Neu. J. Bot. 1(1): 1-108, <em>pl. 1</em>.
Jun 1805. – See below (1805).
(3) Liljeblad, S., <em>Ulkast Sv. fl</em>. (TL-2/4528), ed. 3, 1816, was edited by J.H. Wallman,
with the assistance for the cryptogams by i.a. O. Swartz.
(4) Text for <em>Svensk botanik</em>, vols. 5-8 (nos. 1-6), 1805-1819, see under J.W. Palmstruch,
TL-2/7247.

<sm>NAME</sm>: Swartz spelt his name in various ways: Swartz, Svartz, Swarts, or Swarz, also in
titles of publications (see KR p. 677).

<sm>HANDWRITING</sm>: Webbia 32(1): 37. 1977, Candollea 33: 419-420. 1978; <em>in</em> S. Savage, Cat.
Linn. herb. 1945, fig. 33.

HEADING: SWARTZ

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Schwartzia</em> [sic] Vellozo (1825); <em>Swartzia</em> Schreber (1791, <em>nom. cons</em>.); <em>Swartzia</em>
S.E. Bridel (1801). <em>Note</em>: <em>Swartsia</em> J.F. Gmelin (1791) probably also commemorates O.
Swartz.

Mauritz Frumerie.

13.525. <em>Methodus muscorum</em> illustrata. Quam indulgente exper. Facult. medic. Upsal.
Praeside viro nobilissimo Carolo a Linné [fil.], ... in Auditorio Gustaviano majori, ad
diem xiv April. 1781. Proponit Olof Swartz, ... Upsaliae [Uppsala] (apud Joh. Edman,
...) [1781]. Qu. (<em>Meth. musc</em>.).

<em>Publ</em>.: 14 Apr 1781 or a few days earlier, p. [1]-38, [39, expl. pl.], <em>pl. 1-2</em> (uncol. copp.
	J.D. Lundmark). <em>Copies</em>: FH, H, HH, HU, NY; IDC 6186. – Defended under Lin-
	naeus filius but written by Swartz.
<em>Reprint</em> (<em>1</em>): <em>in</em> Acta med. Sv. 1: 150-204, <em>pl. 13-15</em>. 1783. <em>Copy</em>: H.
<em>Reprint</em> (<em>2</em>): <em>in</em> Caroli Linnaei <em>Amoenitates Academicae</em> (ed. J.C.D. Schreber) 10: 69-122,
	<em>pl. 4-5</em>. 1790.
<em>Reprint</em> (<em>3</em>): <em>in</em> C.F. Ludwig, ed., <em>Delectus opusculorum</em> ad scientiam naturalem spec-
	tantium 1: 340-381, <em>pl. 4-5</em>. 1790. "XI Caroli a Linne c.f. et Olof Schwarz [sic]
	Methodus muscorum illustrata ..."

13.526. <em>Nova genera &amp; species plantarum</em> seu <em>Prodromus</em> descriptionum vegetabilium max-
imam partem incognitorum quae sub itinere in Indiam occidentalem annis 1783-87
digessit Olof Swartz. M.D. Holmiae [Stockholm], Upsaliae [Uppsala], &amp; Aboae [Åbo]
(in bibliopoliis acad. M. Swederi) 1788. Oct. (<em>Prodr</em>.).

<em>Publ</em>.: 20 Jun-29 Jul 1788 (see Stearn 1980 for a summary of data), p. [i]-x, [1]-152,
	[153-158, ind.]. <em>Copies</em>: B-S, FH, G, HH, KU, LD, M, MICH, NY(2), PH, US(2);
	IDC 5756. – The names of plants marked with an asterisk are based on specimens in
	the Banksian herbarium. The other names are based on Swartz's own material. The
	Roman numbers after the generic names refer to the Linnaean natural orders as
	published later [sic] by Giseke in Linné's Praelectiones (1792). The numbers between
	the specific name and the diagnosis refer to related species in Murray, Syst. veg. ed.
	14. 1784, see also ICBN 63.2 (example of typification of Swartz taxa). Swartz made
	use of an unpublished Linnaeus fil. manuscript when writing the <em>Prodromus</em>. The
	Index kewensis cites, for this reason, e.g. <em>Thrinax</em> Linnaeus f. ex O. Swartz; however,
	there is no justification in the printed text for any other way of citing but as <em>Thrinax</em>
	Sw. – For further details see Stearn (1980).
<em>Facsimile ed</em>.: 1962, p. [i*-iv*], [i]-x, [1]-152, [153-158]. <em>Copies</em>: B, BR, FAS, LD. –
	Historiae naturalis classica tomus xxv, J. Cramer (Weinheim).

13.527. IX. <em>The botanical history of the Canella alba</em> ... [Trans. Linn. Soc. 1, 1791]. Qu. 

<em>Publ</em>.: 13 Aug 1791, <em>in</em> Trans. Linn. Soc. 1: 96-102, <em>pl. 8</em>. 1791, errata ib. 2: 356. 1 Mai
	1794 (tearsheet copy: HH).

13.528. <em>Observationes botanicae</em> quibus plantae Indiae occidentalis aliaeque Systematis ve-
getabilium ed. xiv illustrantur earumque characteres passim emendantur ... Erlangae
(sumtu Jo. Jacobi Palmii) 1791. Oct. (<em>Observ. bot</em>.).

<em>Publ</em>.: Mai-Jul 1791 (TL-1; see Stearn 1980), p. [i-viii], [1]-424, <em>pl. 1-11</em> (uncol. copp.
	auth.). <em>Copies</em>: B-S, BR, H, HH, LD, M, MICH, MO, NY, PH, Stevenson, U, US(2),
	USDA; IDC 5757.

13.529. <em>Icones plantarum</em> incognitarum quas in India occidentali detexit atque delineavit
O. Swartz ... Fasciculus i. Erlangae (sumtibus Joannis Jacobi Palm) 1794-1800, 2 sect-
ions. Fol. (<em>Icon. pl</em>.).

<em>Sect. 1</em>: Apr-Mai 1794 (letter Schreber to Usteri, Ann. Bot. 11: 125-126. 1794), p. [1]-8,
	[1-2], <em>pl. 1-6</em> (coll. copp.).
<em>Sect. 2</em>: 1801, <em>pl. 7-13</em> (id.).
<em>Sect. 3</em>: never published, planned to contain <em>pl. 14-25</em>, as listed in text Sect. 1.
<em>Copies</em>: B, BR, G, HU, MICH, NY, PH, USDA; IDC 5738. – Fasc. 1 of a work which
	was scheduled to contain circa 200 plates. I. Urban acquired 71 of the unpublished

PAGE: 120
HEADING: SWARTZ

	originals; they were sold by Urban to C.A.M. Lindman in 1922 and are at Stockholm
	in the library of the Sv. Vet.-Akad. For further details see Stearn (1965, 1980), Kiger
	(1976), Urban (1898).
<em>Ref</em>.: Kiger, R.W., Bull. Torrey bot. Club 103(2): 80-83. 1976 (on the unpublished
	drawings).
	Stearn, W.T., Baileya 5: 197. 1957; Taxon 29: 8. 1980.
	Urban, I., Symb. ant. 1: 164-165. 1898 (on "Sw. Ic. ined.").

13.530. <em>Tal, Om natural-historiens uphof</em> och framsteg i Sverige; hållet för Kongl.
Vetenskaps-Akademien vid praesidii nedläggande den 8 Sept 1790 ... Stockholm
(Tryckt hos Anders Zetterberg) 1794. Oct. (<em>Tal nat</em>.-<em>hist. uphof</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: 1794, p. [1-48]. <em>Copy</em>: KU.

13.531. Olavi Swartz ... <em>Flora Indiae occidentalis</em> aucta atque illustrata sive descriptiones
plantarum in prodromo recensitarum ... Erlangae (sumtu Jo. Jacobi Palmii) [tome 1;
also: Londini apud Benj. White et filium], 3 vols. 1797-1806. Oct. (<em>Fl. Ind. occid</em>.).

<em>1</em>: Nov 1797 (TL-1; Stearn 1980), p. [i]-viii, [1]-640, <em>pl. 1-15</em> (uncol. copp.).
<em>2</em>(<em>1</em>): Jan-Jun 1798 (id.), p. [i], [641]-928.
<em>2</em>(<em>2</em>): late (prob. Oct) 1800 (id.), p. [i, t.p. vol. 2], 929-1230 [2 p. err.], [1, note: plates
	will be publ. with vol. 3].
<em>2</em>(<em>1, 2</em>) <em>plates</em>: issued with vol. 3. Oct 1806, <em>pl. 16-29</em>.
<em>3</em>: Oct 1806 (id.), p. [i], [1231]-2018, [i]-x, index.
<em>Copies</em>: B-S, BR, FH, G, H, HH, LD, M, NY, PH, U, US(2), USDA; IDC 487.
<em>Note</em>: Garay (1974) suggests that vol. 3 may have been published in three parts: 1233-
	1566, 1567-2018, and index. A number of orchid names in vol. 3 are referred to with
	indication of correct pagination in Schrader, Neu. J. Bot. 1: 1-108. Mar 1805. Willde-
	now, Sp. pl. 4(1), 1805 also refers to orchid names with the correct page number in
	the Flora. Garay concludes that it is highly probable that vol. 3, p. 1231-1566 were
	published in 1804. – Sayre (SY p. 30) dates vol. 3. 11 Oct 1806. It may well be that
	the date 1806 refers only to the complete vol. 3; there is, however, no independent
	proof beyond the indications given by Garay, of a publication in parts. Almborn (in
	litt.) also agrees that "there is nothing to support such a hypothesis".
<em>Ref</em>.: Hitchcock, A.S., Contr. U.S. natl. Herb. 12: 114-127. 1908 (types).
	Urban, I., Symb. ant. 1: 165-166. 1898.

13.532. Olai Swartz ... <em>Dispositio systematica muscorum frondosorum Sueciae</em>. Adjectis de-
scriptionibus et iconibus novarum specierum. Erlangae (Apud Joannem Jacobum Palm)
1798. Oct. (<em>Disp. musc. Suec</em>.).

<em>Publ</em>.: 1798 (t.p.), p. [1]-112, <em>pl. 1-9</em> (col. copp. Jac. Sturm). <em>Copies</em>: B-S, BR, FH, G, H,
	HH, NY, PH; IDC 5005. – English translation of preface (by P.M. Echel) in Bryolo-
	gist 83(2): 279-280. 1980.
<em>Preliminary publ</em>.: <em>Systematisk upställning af Svenska Löfmossorna</em>, Sv. Vet.-Akad. Handl.
	1795: 223-273. – See also his <em>Musci in Suecia nunc primum reperti ac descripti</em>, Upsala Soc.
	Sci. nov. Act. 4: 239-244 [244-251, 36 "Lichen" species]. 1784.
<em>Rev</em>.: Schrader, H., J. Bot. 1800(1): 119-124; note by Swartz on p. 398-400.

13.533. <em>Genera et species orchidearum</em> systematice coordinatarum ... 1805. Oct. 

<em>Publ</em>.: Jun 1805 (in journal), p. [i], [1]-108, <em>pl. 1</em> (uncol. copp.). <em>Copies</em>: H, HH. –
	Reprinted and to be cited from H.A. Schrader, Neu. J. Bot. 1(1): 1-108, <em>pl. 1</em>. 1805.

	arrangement, in Tracts relative to Botany, London 1805: 91-120, 121-138, see above
	under Composite works.

HEADING: SWEDERUS

13.535. <em>Lichenes americani</em> quos partim in Flora Indiae occidentalis descripsit, partim e
regionibus diversis Americae obtinuit D.O. Swartz, ... iconibusque coloratis illustravit
J. Sturm. Fasc. I mus. Norimbergae [Nürnberg] (apud Jacob Sturm) 1811. Oct. †. (<em>Lich.
amer</em>.).

<em>Publ</em>.: 1811, p. [i-iv], [1]-25, [27, index], <em>pl. 1-18</em> (col. copp. Jacob Sturm). <em>Copies</em>: B-S,
	FH, G, H, HH, KU, NY; IDC 5311. – Swartz intended to publish three fascicles.

13.536. <em>Summa vegetabilium Scandinaviae</em> systematice coordinatorum ... Holmiae [Stockh-
olm] (Typis Caroli Delén) 1814. Oct. (<em>Summa veg. Scand</em>.).

<em>Publ</em>.: 1814, p. [i-iii], [1]-71, [72, err.]. <em>Copies</em>: NY, USDA. – Swartz is not mentioned as
	author, neither on the t.p. nor elsewhere and hence is not cited by Krok. The work,
	however, is generally ascribed to Swartz (Almborn).

13.537. <em>Adnotationes botanicae</em>, quas reliquit Olavus Swartz, ... Post mortem auctoris col-
lectae, examinatae, in ordinem systematicum redactae atque notis e praefatione in-
structae a Johanne Em. Wikström. Accedit biographia Swartzii, auctoribus C. Sprengel
et C.A. Agardh. Adjectis effigiae Swartzii, delineatione monumenti ejus sepulcralis
atque duabus tabulis botanicis ... Holmiae [Stockholm] (Excudebant P.A. Nordstedt &amp;
Filii) 1829. Oct. (<em>Adnot. bot</em>.).

<em>Editor</em>: Johan Emanuel Wikström (1789-1856).
<em>Publ</em>.: 1829 (p. xi: 25 Mai 1829), frontisp. portr., p. [i]-lxxiv, other portr. Sw., [1]-188,
	<em>pl. 1-3</em> (uncol. copp. auct.). <em>Copies</em>: B-S, BR, H, HH, LD, M, NY, Peterson, US,
	USDA. – It is clear from the preface that Wikström was indeed only the editor and
	that the diagnoses of new taxa are all by Swartz; i.e. all new taxa are to be attributed
	to Swartz. – Wikström provided a biography and bibliography of Swartz on p. xxx-
	lxxiv and added texts of biographical notices by C.A. Agardh and K.P.J. Sprengel
	(see <em>Biofile</em>).

Swayne, George (1746-1827), British botanist and clergyman; vicar at Pucklechurch,
Glos. 1772; rector at Dyrham 1806. (<em>Swayne</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: For exsiccatae <em>Gramina pascua</em> see below.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 351; BB p. 294; BM 5: 2056; Dawson p. 595
(d. 24 Oct 1827); Dryander 3: 213; Henrey 3: 124-125 (no. 1399); Herder p. 394; HU
2(1): clxxxiii, no. 713; Jackson p. 239; Plesch p. 418-419; PR 9072, ed. 1: 10017; Rehder
3: 357, 369; SO add. 742a; Sotheby 725.

Riddelsdell, H.J., Fl. Gloucestershire cxvi. 1948.
White, J.W., Fl. Bristol 65-66. 1912.

13.538. <em>Gramina pascua</em>: or, a collection of specimens of the common pasture grasses,
arranged in the order of their flowering, and accompanied with their Linnaean and
English names, as likewise with familiar descriptions and remarks ... Bristol (printed for
the author, by S. Bonner, ... and sold by W. Richardson ... London) 1790. Fol. (<em>Gram.
pascua</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: 1790, 12 leaves, unsigned and unpaged plus errata slip and <em>6 plates</em> with, in all 19
	specimens of grasses pasted down with labels (with Latin and English name and a
	number). <em>Copies</em>: BRISTM, HU, K, NY, USDA. – For a detailed description see HU
	713; see also Henrey 1399.

Sweet, Robert (1783-1835), British horticulturist, botanist and ornithologist; nursery-
man at Stockwell 1810-1815, Fulham 1815-1819, Chelsea 1819-1826. (<em>Sweet</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Cultivated plants at CGE and MW. – <em>Letters</em> at G and K. – The
56 original water-colours by E.D. Smith for S.'s <em>Flora australasica</em> are at BM.

13.548. <em>Flora australasica</em>; or, a selection of handsome, or curious plants, natives of New
Holland, and the South Sea Islands; containing coloured figures and descriptions of
some of the choicest [sic] species most proper for the conservatory or greenhouse, and
many of which will endure the cold of our climate, in the open air, with a very little
protection; with magnified dissections of their most essential parts, their names, de-
scriptions, &amp; a full account of the best method of cultivation and propagation. The
greater part are handsome evergreen shrubs, and many produce sweet-scented flowers;
and as they are generally of free growth, and easily managed, they may be considered as
the most desirable plants for cultivation ... London (James Ridgway, ...) 1827-1828.
Qu. †. (<em>Fl. australas</em>.).

<em>Publ</em>.: 1 Jun 1827-1 Jul 1828 (in 14 parts, shown by the dates on the plates), p. [i-iv], <em>56
	pl</em>. with text (handcol. copp. E.D. Smith). <em>Copies</em>: BR, G, HH, NY, PH, USDA; IDC

Swingle, Walter Tennyson (1871-1952), American botanist; M.Sc. State Agr. Coll.
Kansas 1896; Dr. sci. h.c. 1922; with the United States Department of Agriculture 1891-
1941; in 1895-1896 and 1898 studying at the Universities of Bonn (with E. Strasburger)
and Leipzig (with Pfeffer); specialist on <em>Citrus</em>. (<em>Swingle</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: BPI (fungi), KSU, NY, US. – <em>Exsiccatae</em>, with W.A. Kellerman:
<em>Kansas fungi</em>, fasc. 1-2, nos. 1-50. 1889, see under Kellerman and IH 2: 350. – <em>Letters</em> to
W.G. Farlow at FH.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Backer p. 662; Barnhart 3: 352 (b. 8 Jan 1871, d. 19 Jan
1952); BM 5: 2060, 8: 1279; Bossert p. 391; CSP 18: 1052; De Toni 4: lv; Hortus 3: 1205;
IH 2: 350; Kelly p. 221; Langman p. 728; Lenley p. 399; LS 26176-26187, 39798; MW
p. 478, suppl. p. 342; NW p. 59; PH 26; Rehder 5: 832; SIA 221, 223; SO 2460a;
Stevenson p. 1259; TL-2/10.303, see W.A. Kellerman; Tucker 1: 675-676, 779, 3: 300-
301; Urban-Berl. p. 282; Zander ed. 10, p. 722, ed. 11, p. 824.

Swinhoe, Robert (1836-1877), British botanist, plant collector and ornithologist; in the
consular service at Hongkong 1854, to Amoy 1855, vice-consul Taiwan 1860-1862,
consul Amoy 1865-1871; visited Hainan 1868; consul at Ningpo 1871-1873. (<em>Swinhoe</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: BM, K. – <em>Letters</em> at K.

Desmond p. 596 (b. 1 Sep 1876); MW p. 478; Rehder 5: 832; Tucker 1: 676.

Sydow, Hans (1879-1946), German (Berlin) amateur mycologist; son of Paul Sydow;
bank employee in Berlin from 1899-1937 (from 1904 with the Dresdner Bank); collected
in Costa Rica 1924-1925, Venezuela 1927-1928, Ecuador 1937-1938. (<em>Syd</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: S (mycol. herb. acquired 1919); private herbarium assembled by
Sydow after 1919 destroyed 22 Nov 1943; some material in US, W (through Petrak). –
Some <em>letters</em> at G.

<sm>COMPOSITE</sm> <sm>WORKS</sm>: (1) Founder and editor of the <em>Annales mycologici</em> 1903-1948, vols. 1-42.
(2) H. Sydow published many papers and books together with his father P. Sydow.
Their joint publications (84 nos.) are all listed by Petrak (1948).
(3) With P. Sydow and E.J. Butler: <em>Fungi Indiae orientalis</em>, parts 1-5 in Annales mycologici
4: 424-445. 31 Oct 1906, 5: 485-515. 31 Dec 1907, 9: 372-421. 10 Aug 1911, 10: 243-280.
10 Jun 1912, 4: 117-120. 28 Mai 1916.
(4) With F. Petrak, <em>Gatt. Pyrenomyc</em>. 1927, see TL-2/7785 (IDC 746 (240-246)).
(5) For further papers published with F. Theissen, F. Petrak, E. Werdermann, W.
McRae, J.H. Mitten, R.N. Tandon and Sultan Ahmad, see Petrak (1948, p. 24-25).
(6) With P. Sydow, <em>Contribution à l'étude des champignons parasites de Colombie, in</em> O.
Fuhrman &amp; E. Mayor, <em>Voy. expl. Sci. Colombie</em>, Mém. Soc. neuch. Sci. nat. 51: [432]-441.
1912.

<sm>HANDWRITING</sm>: Candollea 33: 421-422. 1978.

Sydow, Paul (1851-1925), German (Pommeranian) botanist (cryptogamist), biblio-
grapher and schoolmaster at Berlin. (<em>P. Syd</em>.).

PAGE: 133
HEADING: SYDOW

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: The part of P. Sydow's mycological collections incorporated in
H. Sydow's herbarium is now at S (acquired in 1919), bryophytes at GOET, H and S,
lichens at WRSL. Other material at PAD. Plants from Pommerania at W. The "Laub-
moosherbarium" of Sydow was offered for sale in combination with that of Wilms in
Herbarium 52: 15. 1920. – <em>Letters</em> to W.G. Farlow at FH; other letters at G and UPS-
UB.
<em>Exsiccatae</em>: (<em>1</em>) <em>Uredineen</em>. fasc. 1-57, nos. 1-2850, 1888-1924. For full details, including a
list of published references and reviews see Stevenson (1971, p. 415-426). <em>Collectors</em>: H.
and P. Sydow, F. Bubak, P. Dietel, J. Eriksson, Ed. Fischer, P. Hennings, O. Jaap, A.
Kmet, G. Lagesheim, P. Magnus, A. Mori, O. Pazschke, C.B. Plowright and others; for
N. American collectors see Stevenson (1971). <em>Sets</em>: B (extant), BPI, BUC, CINC,
COLO, DAOM, DBN, FH, H, HAL, HBG, ILL, ISC, K, KSC, M, MICH, MIN,
MSC, NEB, NY, OC, OS, PRE, PREM, PUR, RUTPP, S, SOLH, TRTC, UC, UPS,
W, WIS, WRSL.
(2) <em>Ustilagineen</em>, fasc. 1-13, nos. 1-500, 1894-1915. For extensive details (including a list
of published references and reviews) see Stevenson (1971, p. 430-434). <em>Sets</em>: BM, BPI, C,
DAOM, FH, GRO, H, HBG, HCIO, IARI, ILL, KSC, L, M, MICH, MSC, NEB,
NY, PRE, RUTPP, S, SOLH, TRTC, UPS, W, WIS, WRSL.
(3) <em>Phycomyceten et Protomyceten</em>, fasc. 1-9, nos. 1-350, 1898-1916. For full details (dates, list
of published references and reviews) see Stevenson (1971, p. 435-437). <em>Sets</em>: BM, BPI,
COLO, DAOM, FH, H, HBG, ILL, K, NY, PC, RUTPP, SOLH, TRTC, UPS, WSP.
(4) With E.F.A.W. Migula and L.J. Wahlstedt: <em>Characeae exsiccatae</em>, fasc. 1-6, nos. 1-150,
1892-1901. For details see IH 2: 537 (sets) and Sayre (1969).

Zopf), cent. 1-49, nos. 1-4900, 1880-1899 ("marchica": Mark Brandenburg, Preussen).

13.600. <em>Taschenbuch der wichtigeren essbaren und giftigen Pilze Deutschlands</em>, Österreichs und
der Schweiz, nebst allgemeinen für den Pilzfreund nützlichen Bemerkungen ... Heidel-

	Taschenbücher I.

Sylvén, Nils Olof Waldemar (1880-1969), Swedish botanist; Dr. phil. Uppsala 1906;
assistant at the Hortus Bergianus, Stockholm 1906-1907; id. with the Forestry Research
Institute 1907-1909; lecturer at the Forestry College 1909-1917 in charge of the depart-
ment of texture and oil plants, later of pasture plants of the Svalöv plant-breeding
station 1918-1938; head of the Institute for breeding Forest trees, Ekebo, Svalöv 1938-
1949; professor h.c. 1940; at Lund from 1950. (<em>Sylvén</em>).

Sylvie, Éouard (1670-1739). Fictitious French naturalist and clergyman; abbot at
Lyon; visited Santo Domingo 1701-1703, explored the Caribbean sea, visited South
America 1704, doubled Cape Horn, explored Chile and Peru; returned to France 1710.
(<em>Sylvie</em>).

<sm>NOTE</sm>: Wholly fictitious, but evidently inspired by the life story of Louis Feuillée (1660-
1732), appearing in Appleton's Cyclopaedia of American Biography 6: 15. 1889, but see
J.H. Barnhart, J. New York Botanical Garden 20: 178-179. 1919. One of the, equally
non-existent titles of this profilic ghost is said to be "Explications de l'herbier et des
collections rapportées d'Amérique par l'Abbé Édouard Sylvie" (3 vols. Paris 1711-
1713).

Syme, John Thomas Irvine Boswell (afterwards Boswell-Syme) (1822-1888), British
botanist; curator Botanical Society, Edinburgh; from 1851 in London; lecturer at
Charing Cross (1854-1867) and Westminster (1855-1867) Hospitals ; at the Free Church
College, Edinburgh 1868. (<em>Syme</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: BM, MANCH; further material at BEL, C, CGE, E, FI, GL,
GOET (bryo.), K, L, LIV, MANCH, NA, NMW, OXF, WARMS. – <em>Letters</em> at G.

<sm>NOTE</sm>: Often treated as Boswell or Boswell-Syme.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 1: 226 (Boswell); BB p. 295; BL 1: 224, 721;
BM 5: 2066; Clokie p. 251; Desmond p. 78 (sub Boswell, b. 1 Dec 1822, d. 31 Jan 1888);
Henrey 2: 143; Hortus 3: 1205; IH 2: 88; Jackson p. 237; Rehder 2: 109; Urban-Berl. p.
323; Zander ed. 10, p. 722, ed. 11, p. 824.

	botany).

Szabó, Zoltan von (1882-1944), Hungarian botanist; Dr. phil. Breslau 1905, student of
F. Pax; habil. Budapest 1958; lecturer at the R. Veterinary College, Budapest 1908-

Szafer, Wladyslaw (1886-1970), Polish botanist; Dr. phil. Lwów 1909; studied at
Vienna 1910-1911, München 1911-1912; botanical assistant at the School of Forestry,
Lwów (Lemberg); army bacteriologist 1914-1917; professor of botany and director of
the botanical garden at the University of Kraków 1917-1960, later also at Institute of
Botany of the Polish Academy of Scienes, Kraków. (<em>Szafer</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: KRA, KRAM; other material at C, CERN, GB, NMW. <em>Exsic-
catae</em>: <em>Plantae Poloniae exsiccatae</em>, ser. 2, cent. 1-5, 1930-1957 with B. Pawlowski (series 1 by
M. Raciborski). – <em>Letters</em> at G.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: AG 5(2): 346; Barnhart 3: 354 (b. 23 Jul 1886); BFM
1477, 1694, 1695; BJI 2: 175; BM 8: 1282; Bossert p. 391; Futak-Domin p. 579-580;
Hortus 3: 293; LS suppl. 27266; Tucker 3: 301.

Täckholm, Vivi, née Laurent (1898-1978), Swedish botanist; studied at Stockholm
College; worked in the United States 1921-1923, in Sweden as journalist and editor
1923-1926; married G.V. Täckholm 1926 and joined her husband at the Botany
Department of the Egyptian University (h.t. Cairo University) 1926-1929, continuing
her husband's work from 1933; in Sweden 1929-1933 and 1939-1946; with Bot. Dept.
Univ. Cairo 1946-1947; with the University of Alexandria 1947-1948; professor of
botany at the Faculty of Science, Univ. Cairo 1948-1978; in Sweden March-May 1978.
(<em>Täckh</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: CAI and CAIH. – Some lichens at M; other material at BR, LD.
– <em>Letters</em> at G, LD.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Bossert p. 392; IH 1 (ed. 1): 34, (ed. 2): 38, (ed. 3): 41,
(ed. 5): 34, (ed. 6): 45; Zander ed. 11, p. 824.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Bot. Not. 1968: 457; Egyptian bot. Soc. Yearb. 3: i-iv. 1974; Gard.
	Chron. 183(23): 5. 1978; Optima Newsletter 7: 18. 1978 (d.).
Boulos, L., Bot. Not. 1972: 281-282 (portr., dedic); Taeckholmia 9: 5-8. 1978 (obit.,
	bibl.); Egypt. J. Bot. 21: 155-160. 1978 (1980) (obit., bibl.).

Tärnström, [Ternström], Christopher (1703-1746), Swedish teacher, clergyman and
botanist; student at Uppsala 1724; teacher at Östhammar 1739; id. at Vaxholm 1741;
Dr. phil. Uppsala 1746; chaplain in the Swedish East-Indian Company 1745; died at
Pulo Condor (nr Cambodja) 1746. (<em>Tärnström</em>).

A.W. Grape (1918).

Tafalla, Juan José (1755(?)-1811), Spanish botanist; pharmacist in Navarra; with
Ruiz and Pavon on their expedition to Peru; professor of botany at Lima from 1788.
(<em>Tafalla</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: See H. Ruiz and J. Pavon; main collections (in those of Ruiz and
Pavon) at MA; some material at B-Willd., FI, K.

Bot., Ohio State Univ. 1931-1932, graduate assistant 1932-1933, chief assistant 1933-
1934, instructor 1934-1951, professor of botany 1951-1977. (<em>Taft</em>).

Takeda, Hisayoshi (1883-1972), Japanese botanist; graduated from Engineering
Department, King's College, London 1912; instructor at Taihoku Univ., Kyushu Univ.,
King's College, Kyoto Univ., after 1945 agricultural adviser to the Natural Resources
Bureau, Japan. (<em>Takeda</em>).

Takhtajan, Armen Leonovich (1910-x), Soviet (Armenian) botanist; graduated
Tbilisi 1932; professor at Erevan Univ. 1938-1948; director of the Botanical Institute of
the Armenian Academy of Sciences 1944-1948; professor at Leningrad University 1949-
1961; Dept. head Komarov Botanical Institute from 1954; president of the International
Association for Plant Taxonomy 1975-1981. (<em>Takht</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: ERE, LE. – Other material at C, E.

MW suppl. p. 349.

	1980).

	birthday).

Talbot, William Alexander (1847-1917), Irish botanist; in the Indian Forest Service
1876 in the Bombay Presidency; conservator of Forests, Bombay 1901-1909; in Switzer-
land from 1911. (<em>Talbot</em>).

13.695. <em>The genetics of the genus Linum</em> ... 's Gravenhage (Martinus Nijhoff) 1928. Oct.

Tamsalu [né Tomson], Aleksander (1891-1960), Estonian botanist and agronomist;
elementary school teacher at Laiksaare 1910-1912; at St. Petersburg Institute of Agricul-
ture 1912-1921, during WW I with the Petrograd Railroad Committee; with the
Estonian Dept. of Agriculture 1921-1925; at a farm in Saaremaa 1925-1927; lecturer
Köljala Agricultural School 1927-1931; teacher at Leisi, Kuressaare and Poltsarnaa,
associated with Th. Lippmaa and the Department of Agriculture 1932-1944; in exile in
Germany 1944-1949; in the United States 1949-1953; to Canada 1953, ultimately 1955-
1959, ecologist at the Royal Botanical Gardens, Hamilton, Canada. (<em>Tamsalu</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: HAM.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Lord, J.B., Aleksander Tamsalu 1891-1960, a botanist in exile. Hamilton,
	Ontario (biogr., bibl., portr., b. 28 Apr 1891, d. 5 Feb 1960).

Tanaka, Tyôzaburô (1885-?), Japanese botanist; studied at Tokyo University, grad.
1910; Dr. agr. Tokyo 1932; lecturer Ueda Sericultural College 1912; botanist and trans-
lator USDA 1915; lecturer in horticulture Kyushu Imperial Univ. 1923; professor at
Miyazahi Agr. College 1925; professor of horticulture and economic botany Taihoku
Univ. from 1929; specialist on <em>Citrus</em>. (<em>Tanaka</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: TAI. – Other material at BR, E, PH, US. – <em>Letters</em> at G.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: BJI 2: 176; Bossert p. 393 (b. 3 Nov 1885); Hortus 3:
1205; Lenley p. 400; LS suppl. 27379-27390; MW p. 487-490 (bibl.), suppl. p. 351-352;
Rehder 3: 368; Roon p. 112; SK 1: 517; Stevenson p. 1259; Tucker 3: 302.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Address book Jap. bot. 43. 1951; Index Amer. bot. lit. 1886-1966, 4:
	317-318. 1969.

Japanese Diet and House of Peers (1890); director of the Japan Forestry Association;
secretary to the departments of Agriculture and Commerce and Home affairs. (<em>Y.
Tanaka</em>).

Tanfani, Enrico (1848-1892), Italian botanist; studied at Pisa and Firenze; in various
functions at the Ministry of Agriculture, Roma; from 1892 assistant at the Botanical
department of the Firenze institute of higher studies and assistant at the Botanical
Museum, Firenze. (<em>Tanfani</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: FI.

soil science at the Agricultural Institute, Odessa. (<em>Tanfiljew</em>).

Tansley, Arthur George (1871-1955), British botanist and ecologist; studied at Cam-
bridge; lecturer University College, London 1893-1906; lecturer in botany, Cambridge
1906-1923; Sherardian professor of botany, Oxford 1927-1937; founder of the British
Ecological Society; knighted 1950. (<em>Tansley</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: CGE, OXF. – <em>Letters</em> at G.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 360 (b. 15 Aug 1871); BJI 2: 176; BL 2: 114,
224, 257, 271, 721-722; BM 5: 2071, 8: 1285; Bossert p. 394 (d. 25 Nov 1955); Desmond
p. 598-599; DNB 1951-1960: 953-954; GR p. 416; Hirsch p. 295; IH 2(4): 563; Nor-
dstedt suppl. p. 4; TL 2/see C.J. Schröter; Tucker 1: 779, 3: 304.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Allen, D.E., The naturalist in Britain 242, 243, 261, 265. 1976; Bot. Centralbl.
	104: 224. 1907 (app. Cambridge); Brit. Mus. gen. cat. print. books 234: 665-667.
	1964; Bull. misc. Inf. Kew 1929: 135. (app. Oxford); Anon., Gard. Chron. 1927 (no.
	2123): 182 (obit., portr.); J. Bot. 76: 61-63. 1938 (announcement of a new British
	Flora); New Phytologist 55(2): 145-146. 1956 (obit., portr.); Österr. bot. Z. 57: 175.
	1907 (app. Cambridge); Who's who (London) 1908-1956; Who was who (London) 5:
	1067. 1951-1960 (d. 25 Nov 1955).

Tardent, Charles (<em>fl</em>. 1841), Swiss naturalist. (<em>Tardent</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown. – <em>Letters</em> at G.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: BM 5: 2072; Hortus 3: 1205; LS 26301; PR 9097, ed. 1:
10046; Rehder 1: 361; TR 1399.

<sm>NOTE</sm>: Henri Alexis Tardent (1854-1929), Swiss (canton de Vaud) scientist and journal-
ist; spent some time in a "Swiss agricultural colony in Southern Russia" before emigrat-
ing to Queensland, Australia where he established a winery at Roma, and subsequently
became director of an experimental state farm. Tardent published mainly on agricul-
tural botany and forestry as well as on many topics outside botany. (See HR and Kelly
p. 225). The possible relationship to Charles Tardent is not known to us.

13.731. <em>Essai sur l'histoire naturelle de la Bessarabie</em>, ... Lausanne (Imprimerie et Librairie
de Marc Ducloux) 1841. Duod. (<em>Essai hist. nat. Bessarabie</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: 1841, p. [1]-88. <em>Copy</em>: G. – On p. 27-88: "<em>Catalogue des plantes qui croissent</em> naturelle-
	ment <em>en Bessarabie</em> et aux environs d'Odessa".

HEADING: TARDIEU-BLOT

Tardieu-Blot, Marie-Laure (1902-x), French botanist (pteridologist); originally
trained as a pharmacist (Faculté de Paris 1926); Dr. sci. 1933; Dr. méd. 1934; high
school teacher in Tonkin 1926; director of the laboratory for biological analyses Hanoi
hospital, 1928; with the Laboratoire de Phanérogamie, Muséum d'Histoire naturelle,
Paris from 1932; assistant 1933, sous-directeur 1942; director Laboratoire de Botanique
phanérogamique tropicale, École des Hautes Études, Paris 1967; hon. director 1971.
(<em>Tardieu-Blot</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: P. – <em>Letters</em> at G.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: BJI 2: 176; BL 1: 125, 320; Bossert p. 394; Hortus 3:
1205; IF suppl. 3: 218, suppl. 4: 343-345; IH 1 (ed. 1): 75, (ed. 2): 94, (ed. 3): 119, (ed.
4): 131, (ed. 5): 139, (ed. 6): 207, (ed. 7): 213; MW p. 491, suppl. 354; Roon p. 112; TL-
2/4275; Zander ed. 10, p. 723, ed. 11, p. 825.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Cat. gén. livr. impr. Bibl. natl. 182: 632-634. 1954.

Targioni Tozzetti, Adolfo (1823-1902), Italian entomologist, physician and botanist;
professor of botany and materia medica at the Firenze hospital 1855 (1856?); professor
of botany and zoology at the Institute of higher studies (later: University) of Firenze;
grandson of O. Targioni Tozzetti. (<em>Ad. Targioni</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: FI. <em>Letters</em> G.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: AG 2(1): 128; Barnhart 3: 360 (b. 13 Feb 1823, d. 18
Sep 1902); BM 5: 2072; Bossert p. 394; CSP 5: 912, 8: 1059; 11: 553, 12: 720-721, 19: 26-
27; GR p. 539; Herder p. 76; LS 23765, 26302-26304; PR 9098; Rehder 5: 835; Sac-
cardo 1: 160-161 (b. 13 Feb 1823), 2: 105; Tucker 1: 679.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Bonplandia 4: 99. 1856 (succeeds his uncle Antonio at the Firenze
	hospital); Brit. Mus. gen. cat. print. books 234: 779-780. 1964; Encicl. ital. 269. 1937;
	Entom. mon. mag. 39: 20. 1903 (obit. not.); Flora 39: 287. 1856 (succeeds his uncle,
	sic, as prof. botany and materia medica, hospital Firenze); J. Bot. 31: 160. 1893 (err.
	death notice, 13 Nov 1893 was T.'s 70th birthday); Österr. bot. W. 6: 135. 1850 (app.
	Firenze succeeding his uncle Antonio); Nat. Nov. 24: 560. 1902 (d. 16 Sep 1902);
	Trans. Entom. Soc. London, Proc. 1902: lix-lx. 1903.
Bargagli, P., Bull. Soc. entom. ital. 34: 113-117, 199-233. 1902 (obit., bibl.).
Bridson, G.D.R. et al., Nat. hist. mss. res. brit. Isl. 273.18. 1980 (err. "Alfredo").
Howard, L.O., History of applied entomology 250-252. 1930 (Smiths. misc. coll. 84)
Trotter, A., Marcellia 1: 131. 1902 (obit. not.).

<sm>NOTE</sm>: The relationship between the botanical (zoological) members of the Targioni
Tozzetti family is: <em>grandfather</em>. Giovanni (1712-1783), <em>father</em>: Ottaviano (1755-1829), <em>son</em>:
Antonio (1785-1856), <em>nephew</em> of Antonio and grandson of Ottaviano: Adolfo (1823-
1902).

Targioni Tozetti, Giovanni (né Targioni) (1712-1783), Italian (Firenze) physician
and naturalist; Dr. med. Pisa 1734; practiced medicine in Firenze 1734-1783; promoted
prophylactic inoculation against smallpox; director of the Magliabechi Library 1739;
associate of P.A. Micheli; director of the Firenze medico-botanical garden from 1737-
1749; travelled widely espcially in Tuscany; father of Ottaviano Targioni Tozzetii. (<em>G.
Targioni</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: FI. – <em>Letters</em> at G.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Ainsworth p. 54, 149-150, 299, 311; Barnhart 3: 360 (b.

Rodolico; bibl. sources); GR p. 539; HA 2: 274-275, 556; Herder p. 61, 76; Jackson p.
438; Kelly p. 225; LS 26305-26308; NI alph. and see index; PR 9101-9104, 6803, ed. 1:
10050-10054, 6915-6916; Quenstedt p. 423; Rehder 5: 835; Saccardo 1: 160, 2: 105; SO
2521a, b; TL-1/843; TL-2/5475, 5974, 5975; Tucker 1: 679.

Targioni Tozzetti, Ottaviano (1755-1829), Italian (Firenze) botanist and physician;
professor of botany at the Firenze Spedale Santa Maria Nuova until 1807; professor of
botany and director of the botanical garden, the University of Pisa 1807-1829; son of
Giovanni Targioni Tozzetti. (<em>O. Targioni</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: FI. – <em>Letters</em> at G.

Tarnavschi, Ion [Teofil] (1904-x), Roumanian botanist and palynologist; studied at
Cernauti (Czernowitz) with M. Gusuleac 1924-1928; technician at the Cernauti Botan-
ical Institute 1928-1939; studied at Grenoble 1932-1933 with R. de Litardière; Dr. phil.
Cernauti 1935; assistant at the Botanical Institute, Bucarest 1939, subsequently as pro-
fessor of botany; director of the botanical garden 1952-1975. (<em>Tarnavschi</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: BUC, CERN. – <em>Letters</em> at G.

Taschenberg, Ernst Ludwig (1818-1898), German (Prussian Saxony) botanist and
entomologist; studied in Berlin and Leipzig ; assistant teacher at the Francke'schen
Stiftungen Halle and from 1845-1847 associated with the Zoological Museum ib.; high
school teacher at Seesen and Zahna 1847-1855; from 1855 again in Halle as inspector of
the Zoological Museum and extraordinary professor of zoology at the university.
(<em>Taschenb</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 361 (b. 10 Jan 1818, d. 19 Jan 1898); BM 5:
2073, 8: 1286; CSP 5: 914, 8: 1060, 11: 554, 19: 30; Herder p. 376, 394; LS 26310; PH
939; PR 9114-9115, ed. 1: 10067-10069; Rehder 5: 836; Tucker 1: 679.

	books 235: 2-3. 1964; Entom. News 9: 80. 1898 (d.); Cat. gén. livr. impr. Bibl. natl.

Taschner, Christian Friedrich (1817-?), German (Thuringian) physician and

<em>Ref</em>.: Pritzel, G.A., Bot. Zeit. 1: 278. 21 Apr 1843 (rev.).

Tassi, Attilio (1820-1905), Italian (Tuscany) botanist; studied at Pisa; assistant with
the chair of natural history (G. Savi) at Pisa 1839-1850; Laur. Sci. nat. Pisa 1842;
director of the Botanical Garden Lucia 1850-1860; director of the Botanical Garden and
professor of botany at the University of Siena 1860-1905; took part, on the Tuscan side,
in the battle of Curtatone and Montanara 1848. (<em>A. Tassi</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: SIENA. – <em>Letters</em> at G.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 361 (b. 25 Dec 1820, d. 19 Mai 1905); BL 2:
403, 722; BM 5: 2075-2076; Bossert p. 394; CSP 5: 914, 12: 721; De Toni 1: cxxii;
Herder p. 123, 180; Jackson p. 48, 405; LS 25311-26312; Morren ed. 2, p. 27, ed. 10, p.
87; MW p. 491; Rehder 5: 836; Saccardo 1: 161; Tucker 1: 679.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Bot. Not. 1906: 45-46 (d.); Bull. Soc. bot. France 52: 368. 1905;
	Hedwigia 45: (38). 1906 (d.); Nuova Notarisia 16: 127. 1904 (1905) (d.).

Tassi, Flaminio (1851-?), Italian (Tuscany) botanist; with the chair of botany of the
University of Siena from 1880; director of the Siena botanic garden 1905-1906, id.,
acting, of the garden at Cagliari 1910; son of A. Tassi. (<em>Tassi</em>).

Tate, George (1805-1871), British linen draper, postmaster, paleobotanist and geolo-
gist at Alnwick; longtime secretary of the Alnwick mechanic's scientific institution and of
the Berwickshire naturalist's club. (<em>G. Tate</em>).

Tate, George Henry Hamilton (1894-1953), British-born American zoologist and
collector; field assistant at the American Museum of Natural History, New York from
1922-1931; American citizen 1927; M.A. Columbia Univ. 1931; asst. curator mammals
1931-1942, assoc. curator 1942-1946, curator 1946-1953; Dr. Sci. Univ. Montreal 1937;
made 42 collecting expeditions in the tropics, made substantial botanical collections in
South America. (<em>G.H. Tate</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: NY (orig.), US (orig. Venezuela, Ecuador); further material at B
(mainly destr.), DPU, G, K, US. – <em>Field notes</em> at NY.

Tate, Ralph (1840-1901), British naturalist; science teacher at the Trade and Mining
School Belfast; assistant curator of the Geological Society, London 1864-1867; visited
Venezuela and Nicaragua 1867 as a mining expert; director of mining schools in Bristol,
Darlington and Redcar ca. 1868-1874; Elder professor of Natural Science, Adelaide
University 1875-1901; nephew of George Tate (1805-1866). (<em>Tate</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: AD (Australia), BEL, BM (N. Ireland, Shetland, Nicaragua),

Tatnall, Edward (1818-1898), American farmer, industrialist and botanist at Wil-
mington, Delaware; pioneer fruitcanner and match-maker. (<em>Tatnall</em>).
