Taubenhaus, Jacob Joseph (1884-1937), American (Israeli-Palestine-born) phyto-
pathologist and mycologist; studied at Cornell University (B.S. 1908, M.S. 1909) and
the University of Pennsylvania; Dr. phil. 1913; assistant plant pathologist Delaware
Agric. Expt. Station 1913-1916; assoc. id. 1916-1924; chief Div. Plant Pathology, Texas
Agric. Expt. Station 1924-1937. (<em>Taubenhaus</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown. – <em>Letters</em> to W.F. Farlow at FH.

<sm>NOTE</sm>: Taubenhaus himself stated to Hirsch (p. 296) that he was born in 1885.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 362 (b. 20 Oct 1884, sic, d. 13 Dec 1937);
Bossert p. 395; Hirsch p. 296; Kelly p. 225; LS 39856, suppl. 1446, 5562-5565, 7824,
27418-27455; PH 567, 617; Stevenson p. 1259.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Acheson, S.H. et al., eds., Texian who's who 1, 454. 1937.
Anon., Amer. men sci. eds. 3-5, 1921-1933; Expt. Sta. Record 78(2): 288. Feb 1938
	(obit. not.); Index Amer. bot. litt. 1886-1966, 4: 120-122. 1969 (bibl.); Phytopat-
	hology 28: 305. 1938 (obit. not.); Torreya 38(2): 50. 1938 (d.); Who's who Amer. 12-
	18, 1922-1935; Who was who Amer. 1 (1897-1942): 1217. 1968.

	1885, sic; d. 13 Dec 1937; portr.), 271, 559. 1938.

Taubert, Paul [Hermann Wilhelm] (1862-1897), German (Berlin) botanist; Dr.
phil. Berlin 1889 (student of I. Urban); travelled and collected in Cyrenaica (1887);
associated with the Berlin Botanical Museum 1889-1895 (1893-1895 as scientific
assistant); in 1896 in Brazil, ultimately at Manaos. (<em>Taub</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Brazilian collections sold after T.'s death to the administration of
Alto Amazonas in Manáos (now unknown); the European herbarium went to the
Braunsberg Lyceum (fide Urban 1906); the main set of the Mediterranean collections is
at G (dupl. B, mainly destr., P). The types of the new taxa described in his Berlin period
and some algae and musci are (only partly extant) in B; other material at E (Libya,
Malta), K (Libya) and MO. – <em>Letters</em> at G and UPS-UB.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Backer p. 662; Barnhart 3: 362 (b. 12 Aug 1862, d. 1 Jan
1897); BFM 254, 255; Biol.-Dokum. 17: 9178-9179; BJI 1: 57; BL 1: 32, 320; BM 5:
2077; CSP 19: 35; Hortus 3: 1205; IF p. 733; Langman p. 730; LS 26366; MW p. 493;
Rehder 5: 837; TL-2/11.480; Urban-Berl. p. 269, 315, 402; Zander ed. 10, p. 723, ed.
11, p. 825; Zep.-Tim. p. 107.

PAGE: 180
HEADING: TAUBERT

Tausch, Ignaz Friedrich (1793-1848), Bohemian botanist; studied philosophy,
natural sciences and medicine at the University of Prague; extraordinary professor of
economic and technical botany 1816, associated with the garden of Joseph von Canal.
(<em>Tausch</em>).

PAGE: 183
HEADING: TAUSCH

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: PR (Czech herb.), PRC; further material BUC, CGE, LE, LZ
(destr.), PH, REG, W (p.p. series of exsicc). – The Hortus Canalius was mainly based
on plants from the garden of count Joseph Malabaila von Canal (1745-1826). This
garden was at the time a center of botanical activity at which courses in botany were
taught by such men as F.W. Schmidt (1791-1796), J.C. Mikan (1796-1801), Joh.
Nowodworsky (1801-1811), J.E. Pohl (1811-1815), I.F. Tausch (1815-1826).
<em>Exsiccatae</em>(<em>1</em>) <em>Herbarium florae Bohemiae universale</em>. Sets at BUC, CGE, LE, PRC, W
(Tausch, Flora 16(1): 281-286. 1833 discusses material in cent. 1, 1832; for a catalogue
see J. Ott, <em>Cat. fl. Böhm</em>. 1851, TL-2/7137; see also Herbarium 15: 132. 1910, 2050 nos.).
(2) <em>Dendrotheca bohemica</em> (see Tausch, Flora 17(2), Intell.-Bl. 2: 17-18. 1834, complete
with 212 species. Set at W.
(3) <em>Dendrotheca exoto-bohemica</em> (see I.F. Tausch, Flora 21: 713-724, 729-740, 745-755.
1838. (Herbarium 6: 47. 1908 mentions 4 Lief., 308 species; Tausch, Flora 17(2), Intell.-
Bl. 2: 18-20. 1834 lists contents Lief. 1-3, 1833-1834; 21(1) Intell.-Bl. 11-12. 1838 on
fasc. 5; Flora 28: 254-255. 1845 on fasc. 6).
(4) <em>Agrostotheca bohemica</em> (see Herbarium 15: 132. 1910, 256 species; Tausch, Flora 16(1)
Intell.-Bl. 1: 2. 1833, 17(2) Intell.-Bl. 2: 20-21. 1834, complete with 256 nos.
(5) <em>Plantae selectae florae bohemicae</em> (see Flora 16(1) Intell.-Bl. 1: 2. 1833 (fasc. 2 publ.),
16(1): 128. 1833 (lists cont.), 17(2): 444-447. 1834; Tausch, Flora 17(2), Intell.-Bl. 2:
21-22. 1834, 3 fasc. publ.; lists contents fasc. 3; Flora 14 Mar 1839: fasc. 4).
(6) <em>Collectio Hieraciorum et Salicum sudetorum</em> (see Herbarium 15: 132. 1910: 60 species).
<em>Letters</em> at G, UPS-UB.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: AG 1: 34-35, 4: 274, 5(1): 686; Backer p. 662; Barnhart
3: 362; Biol.-Dokum. 17: 9179-9182 (lists all publ. in Flora); BM 5: 2077; CSP 5: 917-
918 (bibl.); DTS 1: 296-297; Frank 3 (Anh.): 102; Futak-Domin p. 601-604 (impt.
bibl.); GF p. 77; Hegi 6(2): 1242; Herder p. 192; Hortus 3: 1205; IF p. 733; IH 1 (ed.
6): 364, (ed. 7): 344; Jackson p. 416; Kanitz 87 (no. 132); Klásterský p. 184 (b. 29 Jan
1793, d. 8 Sep 1848); Langman p. 730; Lasègue p. 332, 333; Maiwald p. 181, 284
(index); MW p. 493; NI 1936; PR 6870, 9125-9126, ed. 1: 10076-10077; Rehder 5: 837;
RS p. 144; TL-1/1290; TL-2/7138; TR 1400; Tucker 1: 680; WU 43: 138-139; Zander
ed. 10, p. 723, ed. 11, p. 825.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Bonplandia 1: 241. 1853; Bot. Zeit. 7: 640. 1849 (herb. Tausch bought
	by Kosteletzky for PR); Flora 3(2): 638. 1820 (collected Salix in Riesengebirge);
	Ottuv slovník naucný 25: 128-129. 1906; Preslia 50(2): 110. 1978 (biogr. sketch).
Candolle, Alph. de, Phytographie 453. 1880.
Fiek, E., Fl. Schlesien 116. 1881.

	UB).

Tavel, Catherine von (1898-x), Swiss mycologist and gardener; studied horticulture at

Tavel, [Rudolf] Franz von (1863-1941), Swiss mycologist; studied in Genève, Bern
and Strassburg; Dr. phil. Strassburg 1886 (with A. de Bary); in Münster with Brefeld;

PAGE: 186
HEADING: TAVEL

appointed extraordinary professor of bacteriology at the University of Bern 1892; habil.
Zürich 1892; lecturer ETH Zürich 1892-1895; curator at the Botanical Museum of the
ETH Zürich 1895; from ca. 1908 active in the Salvation Army and studying ferns.
(<em>Tavel</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: BERN; further material at E. – <em>Letters</em> at G.

Taylor, George (1904-x), British botanist; studied at Edinburgh University; B.Sc.
1926; with RBG Edinburgh 1927-1928; with Botany Department British Museum
(Natural History) London 1928-1956, asst. keeper 1928-1950, keeper 1950-1956; direc-
tor of the Royal Botanic Gardens, Kew 1956-1971; in retirement at Dunbar, Scotland;
collected in East Africa 1927-1928 and 1934-1935, in the Himalayas (Tibet, Bhutan and
Sikkim) 1938; president of the International Association of Plant Taxonomy 1969-1972;
knighted 1962. (<em>G. Tayl</em>.).

Taylor, Joseph (ca. 1762-1844), British naturalist; author of Newington Butts, Surrey.
(<em>Jos. Tayl</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 363; BB p. 297; BM 5: 2078; Desmond p.
601; Jackson p. 36; Rehder 5: 837; Tucker 1: 680.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Allibone, S.A., Crit. dict. Engl. lit. 3: 2358. 1878 (d. 24 Sep 1844, aged 82).
Anon., Brit. Mus. gen. cat. print. books 235: 539-540. 1964.
Freeman, R.B., Brit. nat. hist. books 337-338. 1980.

13.810a. <em>Arbores mirabiles</em>: or, description of the most remarkable trees, plants, and
shrubs, in all parts of the world ... taken from the journals of eminent travellers, his-
torians, and naturalists ... London (printed by and for W. Darton, ...) 1812. Duod. (<em>Arbor. mirab</em>.).

<em>Publ</em>.: 1812, frontisp., p. [i], [1]-192, [193-200, index], <em>5 pl. Copy</em>: NY. – Jackson p. 36
	"The fable of the Upas tree here appears in its pristine glory".
<em>Later ed</em>.: as, The wonders of trees, plants and shrubs ... [1823], n.v.

Taylor, Norman (1883-1967), British-born American botanist and botanical explorer;
to U.S.A. 1889; studied at Cornell University 1900-1902; with Zoological Park, New
York 1903-1904; with New York Botanical Garden 1904-1911; curator at the Brooklyn
Botanic Garden 1911-1929; director Cinchona Prod. Inst. 1937-1950. (<em>N. Tayl</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: NY; material at B (mainly destr.), BKL, F, NY. – <em>Correspondence</em>
at NY; field notes NY, US. – Other <em>letters</em> at G.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 364 (b. 18 Mai 1883); BL 1: 91, 201, 203,
321; BM 5: 2079; Bossert p. 395; Hirsch p. 296; Hortus 3: 1205; IH 2: (files) and p. 580;
Lenley p. 401-408 [sic]; NW p. 59; PH 450; Plesch p. 423; TL-2/781, 791, 5665; Tucker
2: xxxvii, 3: 304; Urban-Berl. p. 402; Zander ed. 10, p. 723, ed. 11, p. 825 (d. 9 Nov
1967).

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Amer. men sci. eds. 2-9, 1910-1955; Gard. Chron. Amer. 53: 9. 1949
	(portr.); Index Amer. bot. lit. 1886-1966, 4: 325-326. 1969; The New York Times 9
	Nov 1967, p. 47; Who's who Amer. 20-35, 1938-1969; Who was who Amer. 5: 714.
	1973.
Chardon, C.E., Natural. Amer. Lat. 1: 199-201, <em>pl. 15</em>. 1949.
Frodin, D.G., Guide standard floras world no. 143. 1984.
House, H.H., New York State Museum Bull. 328, 1942 (bibl., Bot. New York State,
	many entries).
Pennell, F.W., Bartonia 22: 27. 1943.
Verdoorn, F., ed., Chron. bot. 3: 303, 320. 1937, 4: 82, 258. 1938.
Zanoni, T.A., Moscosoa 3: 62-82. 1984 (expeditions T. on Española).

<sm>COMPOSITE</sm> <sm>WORKS</sm>: (1) NAF, <em>Zannichelliaceae</em> (17(1): 13-27), <em>Zosteraceae</em> (17(1): 29-30),
<em>Cymodoceaceae</em> (17(1): 31-32), <em>Naiadaceae</em> (17(1): 33-35), <em>Lilaeaceae</em> (17(1): 37), all 30 Jun
1909.
(2) Editor, F.S., Mathews, <em>Field Book Amer. wild fl</em>. ed. 4, 1955, see TL-2/5665.
(3) Editor, <em>Torreya</em> 1911-1921.
(4) Associate editor, <em>Ecology</em> 1920-1929.

<sm>NOTE</sm>: Outside our period: <em>Plant drugs that changed the world</em>, London (George Allen &amp;
Unwin Ltd.) [1966]. <em>Copy</em>: G.

	Torreya 12: 229-242. 1912. – Contr. 4 Brooklyn Bot. Gard.

Taylor, Thomas (1786-1848), India-born Irish botanist; M.D. Trinity College, Dublin
1814; physician in ordinary to Sir Patrick Dun's Hospital in Dublin 1814-1820; professor
of botany and natural history at the Royal Cork Scientific Institution 1820-1830; in
retirement at Dunkerron, County Kerry from 1830-1840; physician to the Union Work
House at Kenman 1840-1847. (<em>Tayl</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: FH; also in BM (acq. with herb. Wilson). – Other material at
DBN, E, K, M, OXF, TCI, WRSL. – <em>Letters</em> K, TCD.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: BB p. 297; BL 2: 280, 722; BM 5: 2079; Clokie p. 252;
CSP 5: 923-924; Desmond p. 601; DNB 19: 470-471; GR p. 753, cat. p. 72 (b. 1775);
Hawksworth p. 186; Herder p. 21, 261, 264; Kelly p. 225; Lenley p. 408; LS 26380-

p. 133; TL-1/546; TL-2/2964, 2967, 2989, 5183.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Allan, M., The Hookers of Kew 65, 70, 72, 74-75. 1967.

Taylor, Thomas (1820-1910), Scottish-born American mycologist, chemist and micro-
scopist; chief of the division of microscopy, USDA 1871-1895. (<em>T. Tayl</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: BPI. – <em>Letters</em> to W.G. Farlow at FH.

Taylor, Thomas Mayne Cunninghame (1904-1983), South African-born botanist;
M.S. Univ. Wisconsin 1927; Dr. phil. Univ. Toronto 1930; on the staff of the Depart-
ment of botany, University of Toronto 1927-1946; professor of botany at the University
of British Columbia 1946-1968; after 1968 living near Victoria. (<em>T.M.C. Tayl</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: TRT, 1946-1968 at UBC, later coll. at V. – Duplicates at CAN,
DAO, GB, GH, MT, MTJB, MTMG, NY, QFA, US.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 364 (b. 7 Jul 1904); BL 1: 142, 321; Hortus
3: 1205; PH 209; Roon p. 113.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Amer. men sci. eds. 5-11. 1933-1967.

Verdoorn, F., ed., Chron. bot. 2: 97. 1936, 6: 45. 1941.

<sm>NOTE</sm>: Publication outside our period e.g., <em>Pacific Northwest ferns and their allies</em>, Toronto

Taylor, William Randolph (1895-x), American algologist; Dr. phil. Univ. Pennsyl-
vania 1920; at Woods Hole Laboratory 1917-1920; instructor of botany at the Univers-

HEADING: W.R. TAYLOR

ity of Pennsylvania 1920-1930; professor of botany at the University of Michigan 1930-

LA, LD, MO, NY, PC, PENN, PH, USC. – Field notes at MICH; much archival
material at SIA.

Tchihatcheff, Pierre de [Chikhachef Petr Aleksandrovich; Tschihatcheff] (1812-
1890), Russian-born traveller, geographer and botanist of Bohemian descent; travelled
in the Altai, Asia minor (1848-1858), Egypt, Algeria, Tunisia and Spain; resigned his
diplomatic functions in 1844; resident in Paris from which he made his various trips.
(<em>Tchihatcheff</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: P (through Soc. bot. France); other material at LE. – <em>Letters</em> at
G, UPS-UB.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: AG 6(2): 679; Andrews p. 338-339; Backer p. 574;
Barnhart 3: 365 (d. 1 Oct 1890); BM 5: 2079-2080, 8: 1290; Bossert p. 396; CSP 5: 926,
8: 1065, 11: 559, 13: 234; Herder p. 61; Jackson p. 378, 379; Morren ed. 10, p. 84; MW
p. 493; Plesch p. 423; PR 9127; Quenstedt p. 425; Rehder 5: 837; Sotheby 735; TL-2/see
E. Fenzl, H.R. Goeppert, 2185; TR 1403-1405; Tucker 1: 680.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Bonplandia 6(2): 53. 1858 (cogn. Leopoldina J.G. Gmelin), 8: 112. 1860
	(donated a church and a library to the farmers of his possessions Simenny, Kowrow,
	Wladimir); Bot. Zeit. 1: 302-303, 320. 1843 (Altai journey); Brit. Mus. gen. cat. print:
	books 38: 328-330. 1966; Bull. Soc. bot. France 5: 312. 1858 (8th trip to Asia minor),
	16: 357. 1869 (herb. T. in herb. Soc. bot. Fr.); Cat. gén. livr. impr. Bibl. natl. 183:
	565-570. 1955; Encycl. brit. ed. 11. 26: 475. 1911; Leopoldina 26: 215. 1890; Nat.
	Nov. 12: 470. 1890 (d.); Nature 43: 19-20. 1891 (obit.); Österr. bot. Z. 8: 408. 1858
	(returned from 10 yrs in Asia minor), 41: 40. 1891 (d.); Proc. R. Geogr. Soc. ser. 2.
	12: 765. 1890 (obit.).
Boissier, E., Fl. Orient. 1: xix-xx. 1867.
Cosson, E., Comp. fl. atl. 1: 93. 1881.

	662-664. 1891 (obit.).

Techet, Karl [Carl] (1877-1919), Austrian botanist and high school teacher; student
with R. Wettstein in Wien 1899-1903; botanical assistant at the Triest Zoological
Station 1903-1905; later teacher at Triest, Kufstein and Prossnitz; from 1914 in Wien.
(<em>Techet</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

Tedin, Hans (1860-1930), Swedish geneticist and plant breeder; Dr. phil. Lund 1891;
with the Svalöv plant breeding institute of the Swedish Seed Association from 1891.
(<em>Tedin</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: LD. – Some material from Norway at E.

Teesdale, Robert (ca. 1740-1804), British gardener and botanist at Castle Howard,
Yorkshire; later junior partner in Minier, Mason and Teesdale, seedsmen, London.
(<em>Teesd</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Some material at YRK, LINN, LIV. – "Herbarium sold in sale
of W.T. Aiton's effects by Foster and Son, ... 4 Sep 1851" (Desmond).

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 365; BB p. 297; CSP 5: 927; Dawson p. 805;
Desmond p. 602 (d. 25 Dec 1904); Dryander 3: 138; GR p. 416; Hegi 4(1): 72; LS
26406-26407; PR alph.; Rehder 1: 396; SO add. 754f; Tucker 1: 681.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Baker, J.G., Bot. Trans. Yorksh. Natural. Union 1: 198, 199. 1891.
Blackwell, E.M., Naturalist 877: 54. 1961.
Crackles, E., Naturalist, Yorks. 901: 37-47. Apr-Jun 1967 (plant records by T.).
Kent, D.H., Brit. herb. 81. 1957.
Kent, D.H. &amp; D.E. Allen, Brit. Irish herb. 255-256. 1984 (coll.).
Robinson, J.F., Flora East Riding Yorkshire 11, 13. 1902.
Smith, J.E., Trans. Linn. Soc. 11: 283-287. 1815 (observation on the genus Teesdalia).
Wilkinson, H.J., Ann. Rep. Counc. Yorksh. Philos. Soc. 1906: 53. 1907.

<sm>NOTE</sm>: <em>Plantae Eboracenses</em>: or, a catalogue of the more rare plants which grow wild in the
neighbourhood of Castle Howard, ... disposed according to the Linnean System, <em>in</em>
Trans. Linn. Soc. 2: 103-125. 1 Mai 1794; <em>A supplement to the Plantae Eboracenses</em> ... ib. 5:
36-95. 18 Feb 1800.

<sm>COMPOSITE</sm> <sm>WORKS</sm>: Contributed to J. Sowerby &amp; J.E. Smith, Engl. bot. 202, 2046, 2517.

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Teesdalia</em> R. Brown (1812); <em>Teesdaliopsis</em> Rothmaler (1940).

Tehon, Leo Roy (1895-1954), American phytopathologist and botanist; M.A. Univ.
Illinois 1920; Dr. phil. id. 1934; student of F.L. Stevenson; assistant in botany, Univ. of
Wyoming 1915-1916; id. Univ. Illiniois 1916-1917, 1924-1925; botany teacher Arsenal
Technical School Indianapolis, Indiana 1917-1918; asst. plant pathologist USDA 1919-
1920, 1921-1922; with Mount Arbor Nurseries, Shenandoa, Iowa 1920-1921; botanist in
charge of the Botanical Section, Illinois State Natural History Survey 1921-1954; re-
search professor in plant pathology Univ. Illinois 1947-1954. (<em>Tehon</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: ILLS.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 365 (b. 21 Jun 1895, d. 17 Oct 1954); BL 1:
174, 321; Hawksworth p. 186; Hirsch p. 296; IH 1 (ed. 1): 98, (ed. 2): 124, (ed. 7): 344;
Kelly p. 225, 258; LS 27486-27502; MW p. 493; Stevenson p. 1259.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Amer. men sci. eds. 3-8, 1921-1949; Index Amer. bot. lit. 1886-1966: 4:
	329-330. 1969; Science 120: 751. 1954(d.); The New York Times 18 Oct 1954; Who's
	who Amer. 17-28. 1932-1955; Who was who Amer 3: 845. 1960.

Teichert, Julius (x-1873), German (Prussian) high school teacher and botanist; con-
rector at the gymnasium at Freienwalde a. Oder. (<em>Teichert</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

Teichmeyer, Hermann Friedrich (1685-1744), German (Hannoverian) physician,
physicist and botanist; professor of experimental physics Jena 1717; extraordinary pro-
fessor of medicine 1719, from 1727 in ordinary professor of botany, surgery and ana-
tomy; physician in ordinary, Weimar. (<em>Teichmeyer</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

Teijsmann [Teysmann], Johannes Elias (1809-1882), Dutch botanist; to Java as
gardener 1830; curator of the Buitenzorg (h.t. Bogor) botanic gardens 1831-1869;
honorary inspector of cultures from 1858; botanical explorer of the Indonesian archi-
pelago. (<em>Teijsm</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: BO. – Other material at A, B (mainly destr.), BR, C, CAL, FH,
FI, H, K, L, MEL, MICH, P, PC, PNH, SI, U, W. <em>Letters</em> to Miquel at U; further
letters at G.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Backer p. 579; Barnhart 3: 365 (d. 22 Jun 1882); BL 1:
108, 321; BM 1: 164, 5: 2081; Bossert p. 397; CSP 5: 927-928, 8: 1066, 11: 561; Herder
p. 164, 275, 336; Hortus 3: 1205; IH 1 (ed. 6): 365, (ed. 7): 344, 2: (files); Jackson p.
452; JW 1: 449, 2: 202, 3: 372, 4: 410; Moebius p. 421; Morren ed. 2, p. 38; MW p. 493,
suppl. p. 358; NI alph.; PR 9133-9134, 9870; Rehder 5: 841; RS p. 144; SK 1: 521-526
(major treatment; itin. coll., bibl.), 4: (many entries); TL-1/1293; TL-2/see S. Bin-
nendijk; Tucker 1: 14, 146, 681, 3: 305; Urban-Berl. p. 315, 403; Zander ed. 10, p. 723,
ed. 11, p. 825.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Bonplandia 4: 226. 1856, 5: 171. 1857; Flora 42: 191. 1859 (cotton tree
	cultivation), 47: 413. 1864 (decoration); Tijdschr. Ned.-Indië ser. 2. 11(2): 153-155.
	1882 (obit.).
Gorkom, K.W. van, Eigen Haard 1882: 431-435 (obit., portr.).

	Batavia 1880, 17 p. (repr. from Tijdschr. Maatsch. Nijverh. Landb. Ned.-Ind. 40:

	portr.).

Wittrock, V.B., Acta Hort. Berg. 3(3): 173, <em>pl. 144.</em> 1905 (portr.).

PAGE: 202
HEADING: TEIJSMANN

<sm>NAME</sm>: We use the spelling Teijsmann following the note by van Steenis and van Steenis-
Kruseman (Fl. males. ser. I. 5: cccxxvi. 1958, based on a statement by A.J.G.H. Koster-
mans) that Teijsmann himself always spelled his name with Dutch "ij" rather than with
"y". We can confirm this on the basis of Teijsmann's numerous letters to F.A.W.
Miquel, at Utrecht, in which Teijsmann consistently signs himself this way. The pub-
lishers of his papers were often less consistent; the spelling Teysmann occurs frequently,
e.g. in some of his numerous papers published in the "Natuurkundig Tijdschrift voor
Nederlandsch-Indië; not as frequently though as "Teijsmann".

<sm>TRAVEL</sm> <sm>REPORTS</sm> (see also SK 1: 521-526. 1950):
(1) <em>Uitreksel uit een dagverhaal eener reis door Midden- Java</em>, Nat. Tijdschr. Ned. Indië 8:
[195]-294. 1855 (the trip took place in 1853 rather than 1854 as stated on p. 195).
(2) <em>Uitreksel uit het dagverhaal eener reis door Oost- Java</em>, Karimon Java en Bali Baleling, ib.
11: [111]-206. 1856.
(3) <em>Dagverhaal eener botanische reis over de westkust van Sumatra</em>, ib. 14: 249-376. 1857;
<em>Botanische Reise durch das westliche Sumatra</em>, Bonplandia 6: 176-187. 1 Jun, 202-212. 15 Jun,
253-263. 15 Jul, 278-287. 1 Aug 1858, with notes by J.K. Hasskarl.
(4) <em>Botanische reis over Banka</em> ... see below, no. 13.869. (1859).
(5) <em>Verslag</em> van den honorair-inspecteur van kultures J.E. Teysmann, <em>over de</em> door Z.Ed.
in 1860 gedane <em>reize in de Molukken</em>, Nat. Tijdschr. Ned.-Ind. 23: [290]-369. 1861. – <em>Reise
nach den Molukken</em> (transl. J.K. Hasskarl), Bonplandia 10: 111-139. 1 Mai 1862. – French
transl. J. Bot. néerl. 1: 297-344. 1861.
(6) <em>Aanteekeningen uit het dagboek mijner reis over Bangka</em>, van Juni 1869 tot en met Januari
1870, ... Nat. Tijdschr. Ned.-Indië 32: [31]-100. 1873.
(7) <em>Verslag eener botanische reis naar Bangka</em>, Riouw en Liengga van 10 Mei tot en met 9
December 1872, ib. 34: [225]-296. 1874; see also Tijdschr. Nijverh. Landb. Ned. Ind.
16: 248-269. 1871 for a report on a trip to Bangka Aug 1870-Apr 1871.

Samauw, Alor, Solor, Floris en Soemba, Nat. Tijdschr. Ned.-Ind. 34: 348-517. 1874.

Loudon, Nat. Tijdschr. Ned. Ind. 25: 149-209. 1863.

Teiling, Einar [Johan Sigurd] (1888-1974), Swedish botanist (algologist) and high
school teacher; fil. lic. Stockholm 1917; Dr. phil. h.c. Lund 1950; biology (1908) and
geography teacher in Stockholm 1912-1919; head teacher in biology and geography at
Strängnäs Normal School 1919, id. at Växjö (Training College) 1931, Linköping (id.)
1937; from 1960 in retirement in Lund. (<em>Teiling</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: UPSV. – <em>Letters</em> at G.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 365; Bossert p. 396; KR p. 698-699 (b. 21
Mar 1888); Roon p. 113.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Vem är det 1949: 993.
Bourelly, P., Rev. algol. ser. 3. 11(3-4): 205-208. 1976 (obit.).
Fries, R.E., ed., Short hist. bot. Sweden 77. 1950.
Prescott, G.W., Bibl. Desmid. univ. 497-499. 1984.
Thomasson, K., Sv. bot. Tidskr. 69: 191-197. 1975 (obit., portr., bibl.).

<sm>NOTE</sm>: Main publication outside our period: <em>The desmid genus Staurodesmus</em>, Ark. Bot. ser.
2. 6: 467-629. 1967.

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Teilingia</em> P. Bourrelly (1964).

Tempère, Joannes Albert [Jean Clodius] (1847-1926), French diatomologist.
(<em>Temp</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: AWH; other material (sometimes probably sets of preparations
as listed below): MANCH, MPU, MT, NMW, PC, PH, TALE.
<em>Preparations</em>: (<em>1</em>) <em>Diatomées du monde entier</em> (with H. Peragallo), 625 slides, 25 sets, 1889-
1895, sets at AWH, BM, PC, PH.

Pantocsek (1891).
(3) <em>Genres des Diatomées</em>, 150 slides, 6 sets, 1888-1910, set at BM.
(4) <em>Champignons de France</em>, 250 slides, 10 sets, 1892-1893, set at BM. – With E. Dutertre. –
See Herbarium 1: 161, 180.
(5) <em>Les algues de France</em> en préparations microscopiques (with Dupray), set announced
Bot. Zeit. 46: 128. 1888. (17 series of 12 preparations each; 204 sp.).
<em>Letters</em> to W.G. Farlow (6) at FH.

Tengström, Johan Magnus af (1793-1856), Finnish botanist; Dr. phil. Åbo 1815, Dr.
med. ib. 1817; museum inspector Åbo 1818, "adjunkt" (assoc. prof.) 1828 and from
1842 professor of zoology and botany Helsinki. (<em>Tengstr</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: H. – Correspondence at H-UB.

	1981.

	1828-1890. 368-369. 1891.

continuation.

<sm>NOTE</sm>: For the botanical publications of Tengström's son Johan Martin Jakob af Ten-
gström (1821-1890) see Saelan p. 496-497. Biogr. in Finsk biogr. handb. 2: 2186-2187.
	1903.

HEADING: TENNENT

<em>Publ</em>.: 17 Jun 1846, p. [1]-24. <em>Copies</em>: G, H, NSUB, NY.

Tengwall, Tor Ake ("Åke") (1892-1946), Swedish botanist; Dr. phil. Uppsala 1920;
continued his study at the University of Utrecht; with the Java Sugar Experiment
Station, Pasoeroean, Java 1921-1926; asst. director Rubber Expt. Station, Buitenzorg
(Bogor) Java, 1926-1931; in charge of the Agriculture Service of "Bergcultures" in Java
1931-1933; subsequently director of an agricultural institute in Turkey; director of re-
search Firestone Plantation Co., Liberia; ultimately adviser to the Rubber Division of
the Board for the Netherlands Indies, Suriname and Curaçao at New York. (<em>Tengwall</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Some material at BO, DPU, E, GB, K, L, PAS.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 367; BJI 2: 176; BL 2: 529, 532, 722; GR p.
501-502; Hirsch p. 297; Kleppa p. 238; KR p. 699 (b. 8 Mai 1892); LS suppl. 27521-
27525; SK 1: 518; Stevenson p. 1259; Tucker 3: 305.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Cat. gen. livr. impr. Bibl. nat. 184: 23. 1957; Vakbl. Biol. 26(2): 26.
	1946 (obit. not.).
Arwidsson, T. &amp; G.R. Cedergren, Generalregister Svensk botanisk Tidskrift 1-20 (1907-
	1926): 36, 64. 1932.
Peterson, B., Generalregister Svensk botanisk Tidskrift 21-40 (1927-1946): 38. 1949.

13.895. <em>Die Vegetation des Sarekgebietes</em> Erste Abteilung. Akademische Abhandlung welche
zur Erlangung der Doktorwürde mit Erlaubnis der mathematisch-
naturwissenschaftlichen Sektion der weitberühmten Philosophischen Fakultät zu
Uppsala am 28. Maj 1920 10 Uhr ... verteidigt wird ... Stockholm (Druck von Cen-
traltryckeriet) 1920. Oct. (<em>Veg. Sarekgeb.</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: 18 Mai 1920 (see p. [436]), p. [i], [269]-435, [436], <em>pl. 10-11</em>, maps. <em>Copies</em>: BR,
	FH, H, HH, M, MO, NY. – Preprinted or reprinted as "Sonderabdruck" of A.
	Hamberg, Naturw. Unters. Sarekgeb. Schwed.-Lappland 3 (Botanik), Lief. 4.
<em>Part 2</em>: 15-30 Jun 1925 (printed 15 Jun 1925), cover-t.p., p. [703]-774, idem 3 (Botanik),
	Lief. 8. <em>Copy</em>: B-S, H, HH, LD, PH.
<em>See also</em> his <em>Die Gefässpflanzen des Sarekgebietes</em>, in idem 3 (Botanik), Lief. 7: 627-674. 25-28
Feb 1925, and <em>Nachtrag zur Flechtenflora des Sarek-Gebietes</em>, ib. p. [694]-702.

Tennent, James Emerson (1804-1869), British (Belfast-born) politician and admini-
strator; educated at Trinity College Dublin; called to the Bar (never practiced) at
Lincoln's Inn 1831; M.P. for Belfast 1832, 1835, 1837, 1842-1845, for Lisburn 1851-
1852; secretary to the India Board 1841-1845, civil secretary to the government of
Ceylon 1845-1850; secretary to the Poor-Law Board 1850-1852, knighted 1867.
(<em>Tennent</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: BM 5: 2083-2084; DNB 19: 545-546; PR 9140; Rehder
5: 838; Tucker 1: 682, 3: 306.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Allibone, S.A., Crit. dict. Engl. lit. 3: 2370-2371. 1878 (bibl.).
Anon., Brit. Mus. gen. cat. print. books 61: 414-415. 1960 (under Emerson); Cat. gén.
	livr. impr. Bibl. natl. 184: 43-44. 1957.
Boase, F., Mod. Engl. Biogr. 3: 912. 1965.

Tenore, Michele (1780-1861), Italian botanist at Naples (Napoli); director of the
botanical garden and professor of botany 1809 [1810]-1860. (<em>Ten</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: NAP; further material in AWH, B-Willd., BASSA, BM, BR, C,
CGE, DWC, E, FI, G, G-DC, H, K, M, MPU, OXF, P, PH, REG, UPS (Thunb.). –
The collections at FI contain many duplicates of Tenore types with the handwriting of
the author (inf. C.H. Steinberg). <em>Letters</em> at G and UPS-UB.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: AG 2(1): 280, 5(1): 680, 6(2): 999; Backer p. 576;
Barnhart 3: 367 (b. 5 Mai 1780, d. 19 Jul 1861); Biol.-Dokum. 17: 9197; BL 2: 340, 341,
345, 348, 349, 722; BM 5: 2084-2085; Bossert p. 396; Clokie p. 252; CSP 5: 932-934, 8:
1067; Frank 3 (Anh.): 102; GF p. 77; GR p. 540; Hegi 5(2): 1094; Herder p. 480
[index]; Hortus 3: 1205; IF p. 733, suppl. 1: 132, IH 1 (ed. 2): 86, (ed. 3): 108; Jackson
p. 22, 136, 145, 201, 319, 320, 435, 507; Langman p. 731; Lasègue p. 585 (index); LS
26420-26422; MW p. 494; NI 1939; PH 364; PR 9141-9170, ed. 1: 3994, 6678, 10091-

723, ed. 11, p. 825.

Tenore, Vincenzo (1825-1886), Italian botanist, nephew of M. Tenore; professor of
botany at the veterinary school of Naples; honorary lecturer in botany at the University
ib. (<em>V. Ten.</em>).

1886), 2: 106.

Teodoresco [Teodorescu], Emanoil [Emmanuel] Constantin (1866-1949),
Rumanian botanist (algologist, phytosociologist, plant physiologist); Dr. phil. Paris
1899; professor of plant physiology at the Faculty of Sciences of Bucarest University.
(<em>Teodor</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: BUC; further material at W. – <em>Letters</em> at G.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 367 (b. 10 Mai 1866); Hortus 3: 297; LS
39866, suppl. 27531-27532; Nordstedt suppl. p. 15; Rehder 5: 839.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Dictionar enciclopedic Român 4: 638-639. 1966.
Combes, R., C.R. Séanc. Acad. Sci. Paris 228: 1897-1899. 1949 (obit.).
Koster, J.T., Taxon 18: 558. 1969 (alg. BUC).
Prescott, G.W., Bibl. desmid. univ. 499. 1984.

HEADING: TEODORESCO

	Natura, Biol., Bucuresti 18(3): 3-11. 1966 (100th anniv. birth).

	scientific work, portr.).

	Herbarium algologicum Romaniae at BUC).
Verdoorn, F., ed., Chron. bot. 2: 260. 1936, 3: 226. 1937.

<sm>FESTSCHRIFT</sm>: Colin, H. et al., <em>Hommage au professeur E.C. Teodoresco</em>, Bucuresti 1937, p.
[1]-240, [241-242], portr. (on p. 29-33: L. Dufour on T. and the Laboratoire de biologie
végétale de Fontainebleau; no further biogr. papers).

<sm>NOTE</sm>: Teodoresco spelled his name this way in all of his publications consulted by us;
The Festschrift of 1937 was also dedicated to "E.C. Teodoresco". However, the bio-
grapher of Teodoresco, N. Salageanu, (1960) uses the spelling Teodorescu and repro-
duces a signature from T. which most likely ends in "u". In view of the use of "Teodo-
resco" in his publications we use this as the preferred spelling for bibliographical
purposes.

Tepper, Johann Gottlieb Otto (1841-1923), German (Prussian/Posen)-born
Australian entomologist, botanist and numismatist; to Adelaide, S. Australia 1847;
worked as a shearer and teacher until 1883; natural history collector Adelaide Museum
(S. Austral. Mus.) 1883; entomologist ib. 1888-1910; ultimately Government Entomolo-
gist. (<em>Tepper</em>).

Terraciano, Achille (1862-1917), Italian botanist; son [?] of Nicola Terraciano; assist-
ant at the Orto botanico di Napoli 1885-1886; curator at the Istituto botanico, Roma
1886-1893; collected in Eritrea 1892-1893; teacher at the R. Scuola Tecnica, Padova,
and at the R. Istituto Tecnico, Caserta 1894-1896; lecturer botany Napoli 1896; assist-
ant at the Orto botanico 1896-1906; extraordinary profesor of botany at the University
of Sassari 1906-1917. (<em>A. Terrac</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: NAP and FT (Eritrea); mycological type specimens also at RO;
other material at E, GDOR, GE, PH. – Other material at B (mainly destr.). – <em>Letters</em> at
G, UPS-UB.

57, 2: 176; BL 1: 34, 321, 2: 341, 358, 390, 410, 414, 722; BM 5: 2068; Bossert p. 397;

p. 494; Rehder 5: 840; Saccardo 1: 162, cron. p. xxxiv; Tucker 1: 682-683, 2: xxxvii, 3:
306; Urban-Berl. p. 402; Zander ed. 10, p. 723, ed. 11, p. 825.

PAGE: 226
HEADING: TERRACIANO

13.983. <em>Per la priorità delle mie Gagearum novarum diagnoses</em> [Palermo] (Tipografia Priulla)
1904. Oct. 

<em>Publ</em>.: 31 Dec 1904 (date of journal publication given on p. 7; p. 7 text closed 15 Nov
	1904), p. [1]-7. <em>Copies</em>: G(3), M. – Reprinted and to be cited from Boll. Soc. Ortic.
	mut. Succ. Palermo 2(4): 59-61. 31 Dec 1904. – Written against A. Pascher, <em>Uebersicht
	über die Arten der Gattung Gagea</em>, Lotos 52(5): 109-131. Nov 1904; see TL-2/7419; see
	also Pascher, Beih. Bot. Centralbl. 20(ii): 76. 1906.
<em>Note</em>: AG (3: 74) notes that the Berlin material was first sent to Terraciano and later to
	Pascher. The Terraciano work is solid; it came out on 30 Sep 1904; the Pascher work
	"betrays everywhere the speed with which it was compiled" came out in Nov 1914,
	but the separates were distributed as preprints before the journal issue. Ascherson and
	Graebner state categorically that Terraciano has indeed priority. He also contributed
	to their own treatment of <em>Gagea</em>.

13.984. <em>Le Gagea della flora portoghese</em> ... (Extr. do Bol. da Soc. Brot., vol. xx, 1903. Oct. 

<em>Publ</em>.: Jan-Jun 1905 (date on p. 7; journal vol. dated 1903 came out Jan-Jun 1905), p.
	[1]-7. <em>Copy</em>: G. – Reprinted and to be cited from Bol. Soc. Brot. 20: 200-205. 1903
	(1905).

13.985. <em>Revisione monographica delle specie di Gagea della flora spagnola</em> ... Palermo
(Tipografia Priulla ...) 1905. Oct. (<em>Revis. Gagea fl. spagn.</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: Nov 1905 (p. 3: I Oct 1905; p. 62: printing finished at Palermo 30 Oct 1905), p.
	[1]-65. <em>Copies</em>: G(3), M. – Text originally published Boll. Soc. Arag. Ci. nat. 4: 188-
	254. 1905 (printing finished 30 Sep 1905). Terraciano, however, did not accept this
	publication because the Spanish editor had neglected to bring about his corrections in
	the proofs and republished the text himself. (ICBN 34. 1, (a), does not apply).

Teschner, Hans (1894-x), German (Schleswig-Holstein) botanist; educated in Breslau
and Berlin; on active service 1915-1916; studied natural sciences at the Friedrich-
Wilhelms-Universität, Berlin; Dr. phil. ib. 1931. (<em>Teschner</em>).

Entwicklungsgeschichte und Anatomie der Blüte von Erica und ihre systematische Bedeutung</em>, ...
Berlin (Dr. Emil Ebering, ...) s.d., p. [1]-38, [39-48]. <em>Copy</em>: B.

Tessendorff, [Konrad] Ferdinand (1879-1924), German (Prussian) botanist and
high school teacher; state teacher's examination Berlin 1905; assistant teacher at the
Hohenzollernschule, Berlin-Schöneberg 1906; "Oberlehrer", from 1920 "Ober-
studiendirector", at the Helmholtz-Realgymnasium, ib. 1907-1924; on active service
1917-1918; associate of Paul Graebner; librarian of the Botanischer Verein der Mark
Brandenburg 1910-1924; associated with the Botanisches Museum, Berlin-Dahlem.
(<em>Tessend</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: B (mainly destr.); further material at G. – <em>Letters</em> at G, UPS-UB.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: AG 5(2): 74; Backer p. 577; Barnhart 3: 368 (b. 1 Dec
1879, d. 18 Jun 1924); Urban-Berl. p. 402.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Hedwigia 65: (195). 1925 (d.); Verh. bot. Ver. Brandenburg 66: [iii],
	129. 1924 (d.).
Schulze, G.M., Verh. bot. Ver. Brandenburg 76: 64-69. 1936 (obit., bibl.).

1573. 1910.

Teuscher, Heinrich [Henry] (1891-1984), German gardener and
botanist (dendrologist, orchidologist); student gardener at Berlin-Dahlem until 1914; on
active service 1914-1918; landscape architect Hamburg 1918; gardener Berlin-Dahlem
1919-1921; to the United States 1922 (naturalized U.S. citizen 1932); with the Arnold
Arboretum 1922-1923; botanist in charge Morton Arboretum 1923-1926; with Boyce
Thompson Arboretum 1926-1932; with New York Botanical Garden 1932-1936; curator
Botanical Garden Montreal 1936-1972. (<em>Teusch</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: A, B (mainly destr.), MT (herb. material and orchid phot.). –
<em>Letters</em> at G.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 369 (b. 29 Mai 1891, curr. vitae until 1932);
Bossert p. 397; Hirsch p. 298; Hortus 3: 1205; Langman p. 733; Lenley p. 408; MW p.
494-495; PH 33; TL-2/11.977-11.978; Tucker 3: 306; Zander ed. 10, p. 723, ed. 11, p.
825.

	333-335. 1969.
Apel, J., Gärtn.-bot. Brief. 38: 1097-1098. 1972 (curr. vit.).

G.W.D., Bull. Amer. Orchid Soc. 31: 392-393. 1962 (retirement; portr.).

Thaer, [Konrad Wilhelm] Albrecht (1828-1906), German (Prussian) botanist and
agronomist; Dr. phil. Berlin 1851; in England 1851-1853; manager of the estates Ruders-
dorf and Börnicke 1853-1859; with his father at the estate (1859-1866) and agricultural
college at Möglin (1859-1861); habil. Berlin 1861; professor (e.o.) of agronomy at Berlin
University 1866-1871; regular professor of agronomy at the agricultural faculty of the
Ludwigs-University, Giessen 1871. (<em>Thaer</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Möglin collections (? herb. material) donated by him 1871 to the
Berlin agricultural museum.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 369 (b. 6 Aug 1828); Moebius p. 388; Rat-
zeburg p. 480-481.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Science ser. 2. 25: 78. 1907 (d. 14 Dec 1907).
Schindlmayr, A., Pioniere des Ackers 145. 1959.

<sm>NOTE</sm>: Grandson of Albrccht Daniel Thaer (1752-1828), founder of Möglin Agricultural
College (1805/1806-1861), and son of Albrecht Philipp Thaer (1794-1863), director of
the College 1828-1861. – Biogr. of A.D. Thaer, by F.H.W. Körte (1776-1846), <em>Albrecht
Thaer</em>: sein Leben und Wirken, als Arzt und Landwirth: aus Thaer's Werken und lite-

HEADING: THAL

rarischem Nachlasse, Leipzig (F.A. Brockhaus) 1839, xii, 416 p., <em>copy</em>: MO. – See also

Thal, Johannes (1542/43-1583), German (Erfurt) botanist and physician in Nord-
hausen. (<em>Thal</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: ADB 37: 642-643 (E. Jacobs); AG 6(2): 494; Ainsworth

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Thalia</em> Linnaeus (1753) and <em>Thalianthus</em> Klotzsch ex Koernicke (1862) were

Thaler, Aurelius Ant. (1796-1843), Moravian botanist and Augustine monk; professor
of philosophy at Brno [Brünn] from 1820. (<em>Thaler</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown (see Pluskal 1856); some material at BRNM.

	Herbar wird noch in dem Augustinerkloster zu Altbrünn aufbewahrt").

Tharp, Benjamin Carroll (1885-1964), American botanist; Univ. Texas AM 1915;
Dr. phil. 1925; botanist and plant physiologist with the Texas Department of Agricul-
ture 1915-1917; associate professor of biology Sam Houston State Teachers College
1917-1919; instructor in botany Univ. Texas 1919-1920, asst. professor ib. 1920-1925,
associate professor ib. 1925-1933; professor of botany 1933-1956; emeritus id. from 1956.
(<em>Tharp</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: TEX (incl. field notes); other material at BR, BUT, DPU, DS,
E, ILL, MICH, NY, NYS, OKLA, PH, SMU, UNL, US (2940), WS, WTU. – <em>Letters</em>
at G, PH, US (SIA).

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: BJI 2: 176; BL 1: 217, 321; Hirsch p. 298; Hortus 3:
1205; IH (ed. 1): 5, (ed. 2): 18, (ed. 3): 19, (ed. 4): 20, (ed. 5): 9, (ed. 7): 344; Langman
p. 733; LS suppl. 27577; PH 209; SIA 227 (HI 107); Stevenson p. 1209; Tucker 3: 306.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Amer. men sci. eds. 4-11, 1927-1967; Index Amer. bot. lit. 1886-1966, 4:
	335-336. 1969; Who's who Amer. 26-33. 1950-1965; Who was who Amer. 4: 934.
	1961-1968 (b. 16 Nov 1885, d. 29 Nov 1964).

Verdoorn, F., ed., Chron. bot. 6: 462. 1941.
Whaley, W.G., Bull. Torrey bot. Club 92: 489-492. 1965 (obit., bibl.).

Thaxter, Roland (1858-1932), American mycologist; A.B. Harvard 1882; Dr. phil. ib.
1888; assistant to W.G. Farlow 1886-1888; with Connecticut Experiment Station 1888-
1891; assistant professor Harvard (with W.G. Farlow) 1891-1901, full professor 1901-
1919; in retirement at Harvard 1919-1932; travelled in Chile 1905-1906. (<em>Thaxt</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: FH. – Other material at B (250 slides, prob. destr.), BM, CUP,

HEADING: THAXTER

cent. 7-10). Sets at BPI, CINC, CUP, DAOM, DPU, F, FH, ILL, LPS, MICH, NY,
OSC, PAC, PUR, SOLH, TRTC, TUR, UC, UPS, W, WIS. –<em>Correspondence, original
drawings</em> and <em>paintings</em>: at FH (see Taxon 31: 607. 1982). Other letters at G, US (SIA).

Thayer, Emma, née Homan (1842-1908), American artist, educated at Rutgers Univ-
ersity and the National Academy of Design; in Colorado from 1882; married George A.
Graves 1860 (d. 1864), Elmer A. Thayer 1877. (<em>Thayer</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Ewan ed. 1: p. 320, ed. 2: 218; NI 1947n, na; Rehder 1:

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Thayeria</em> Copeland (1906) honors Alfred Thayer, a professor at the University
of Texas, U.S.A.

Thays, Carlos [baptized Charles] (1849-1934), French-born Argentinian botanist, en-
gineer and gardener; founder and director of the Jardin botanico municipal de Buenos
Aires 1892-1917. (<em>Thays</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

<em>Publ</em>.: 1910, p. [1]-180, 2 maps. <em>Copy</em>: G.

Thedenius, Knut Fredrik (1814-1894), Swedish botanist, entomologist, pharmacist
and teacher; pharmacist's examination Stockholm 1840; pharmacist ib. 1843-1858,
teacher for natural sciences at Stockholm's Gymnasium from 1844 (temporary), 1852
(regular) and as "lektor" 1859-1886; from 1880-1888 lecturer at a state high school in
Stockholm. (<em>Thed</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: UPS (general and Swedish herb.), S (Södermanland and

PAGE: 237
HEADING: THEDENIUS

Uppland herb; through C.G.H. Thedenius). – Other material at C, DPU, E, F, GB, H,
KIEL, L, LD, M, MW, TO, WRSL. – <em>Exsiccatae</em>: <em>Musci Sveciae exsiccati</em> fasc. 5-6 (nos.
101-150), for details see S.J. Lindgren, TL-2/3: 48. Sets at B (destr.), LD, S, WRSL. –
<em>Letters</em> (30) in S.O. Lindberg's correspondence in H-UB; other letters at G.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 370 (b. 12 Nov 1814, d. 4 Mar 1894); BL 2:
524, 545, 547, 723; BM 5: 2088-2089, 8: 1297; Bossert p. 398; Frank 3 (Anh.): 102; GR
p. 502; Herder p. 19, 165; Jackson p. 339; KR p. 700-702 (main bibl.); Langman p. 733;
LS 26489-26490; Morren ed. 2, p. 31, ed. 10, p. 103; PR 162, 9176-9182, ed. 1: 10146-
10147, 11812; Rehder 5: 842; SBC p. 133; SO 853; TL-1/947, see Sillén, O.L.; TL-2/see
S.J. Lindgren; Urban-Berl. p. 315.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon, Bot. Centralbl. 58: 32. 1894 (d.); Bot. Jahrb. 18 (Beibl. 45): 39. 1894
	(d.); Bot. Not. 1842(5): 95, 175 (bot. trip to Norway), 1886: 150 (retirement), 1894:
	134 (part of herb. to S. through C.G.H. Thedenius); Generalregister Bot. Not. 1839-
	1938: 76. 1939; Österr. bot. Z. 44: 200. 1894 (d.).
Högrell, B., Bot. Hist. 1: 270-271. 1886 (biogr. notes, bibl.).
Levertin, A. et al., eds., Sv. Apotekarhistoria 1: 101-106. 1910-1918.

Weimarck, G., Bot. Not. 133: 417-418. 1980 (ed. Bot. Not. 1852-1856).
Wittrock, V.B., Acta Horti Berg. 3(2): 73. 1903, 3(3): 55, <em>pl. 102.</em> 1905 (portr.).

<sm>COMPOSITE</sm> <sm>WORKS</sm>: (1) Editor, <em>Botaniska Notiser</em> 1852-1856 ("Nya Botaniska Notiser")
(also 1850(5-6; 7 p.p. with C.F. Nyman) and 1851 (10-12)).
(2) For <em>Svensk skol-botanik</em> 1852, a text based in part on a text by N.J. Andersson, see KR
p. 700-701, no. 4.

<sm>NOTE</sm>: Thedenius' nephew, Carl Gustav Hugo Thedenius (1843-1929), pharmacist at
Göteborg, was also botanically active (see KR p. 699-700). His collections are at GB
with duplicates in E, F and PH; travelled in Scandinavia 1836, 1840, 1842, 1865, 1867.

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Thedenia</em> Schimper (1852). <em>Note</em>: <em>Thedenia</em> E.M. Fries (1842) may also honor
this author but no derivation was given.

Theel, Jakob Gustaf Gösta (1846-1885), Swedish botanist; Dr. phil. Uppsala 1872;
ultimately at the Swedish state archives. (<em>Theel</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 370; BM 5: 2089; Jackson p. 332; KR p. 702
(b. 18 Oct 1846, d. 2 Aug 1885).

<sm>NOTE</sm>: (1) Theel's brother, Johan Hjalmar Theel (b. 1848), a zoologist at Stockholm
(curator Evertebrata Stockholm Riksmus. 1892-1916), published some minor papers on
botany; see KR p. 702.
(2) For Johannes Theel (b. 16 Oct 1877, d. 6 Jul 1935), teacher of mathematics and
physics at the Berlin "Graue Kloster" Gymnasium, an active floristic botanist, see E.
Pritzel, Verh. bot. Ver. Brandenburg 76: 70-72. 1936 (portr., obit.).

iska gradens erhållande, till offentlig granskning framställes ... å Botaniska lärosalen

Scapania</em>).

Théis, Alexandre [Étienne Guillaume, baron] de (1765-1842), French author and
administrator; maire Laon 1808-1814; prefect of the dept. Corrèze 1830, ultimately
dépt. Haute-Vienne. (<em>Théis</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

Theissen [Theiszen], Ferdinand (1877-1919), German clergyman and mycologist;
Novit. S.J. 1897; stationed in São Leopoldo, Brazil 1902-1908; studied theology at Val-
kenburg and Innsbruck 1909-1912; ordained 1911; studied natural sciences in
Innsbruck 1913-1914; teacher at the Feldkirch gymnasium Stella matutina 1914-1919;
died in the Vorarlberg Alps while collecting lichens. (<em>Theiss</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: FH. – Further material in B (mainly destr.), W. – <em>Exsiccatae</em>: (1)
<em>Decades fungorum brasiliensium</em> cent. 1-4 (nos. 1-300, appendix nos. 1-15); 1910-1912 for

PAGE: 240
HEADING: THEISSEN

full details see J. Stevenson (1971). – Sets: B (mainly destr.), BPI, FH, HBG, K, LIL, S,
SOLH.
(2) See J. Rick, (TL-2/4: 780) for Theissen's share in the <em>Fungi austro-americani</em>.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: AG 12(2): 185, 12(3): 202; Barnhart 3: 371 (b. 27 Jul
1877, d. 5 Sep 1919); BM 5: 2090; GR p. 49, cat. p. 72; Hawksworth p. 186; Hegi 6(2):
1262; Kelly p. 225-226; LS 39896-39910, suppl. 27611-27646; MW p. 495; Stevenson p.
1260; Urban-Berl. 283.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Hedwigia 62 (Beibl.): (83). 1920 (d., accident on bot. excursion nr
	Feldkirch); Index Amer. bot. lit. 1886-1966, 4: 338-339. 1969; Österr. bot. Z. 68: 292.
	1919 (d. Heimspitze, in a mountain accident).
Doidge, E., Bothalia 5: 1022. 1950 (S. Afr. fungi).
Lloyd, C.G., Mycol. notes 1029-1030. 1921 (obit. not.).
Lowden, R.M., Taxon, Index pers. names vols. 1-30. 1985.
Murr, J., Neue Übers. Farn- Blütenpfl. Vorarlberg xxii. 1923.
Stevenson, J., Beih. Nova Hedwigia 36: 444-447. 1971 (details on Decades fungorum
	brasiliensium).
Sydow, H., Ann. mycol. 17: 134-139. 1919 (obit., bibl.).

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Theissenia</em> A. Maublanc (1914); <em>Theissenula</em> H. Sydow et P. Sydow (1914).

14.044. <em>Perisporiales riograndenses</em> ... Ex ephemeride Brotéria ... S. Fiel 1910. Oct.

<em>Note</em>: Theissen also published <em>Polyporaceae austro-brasilienses imprimis Rio Grandenses</em>, Wien

	Wien 83: [213]-250, <em>pl. 1-7.</em> 1927. The paper was read 15 Dec 1910. Volume 83 of the
	Denkschriften was published only in 1927, even though vol. 84 came out in 1911.

14.046. <em>Polyporaceae austro-brasilienses</em> imprimis Rio Grandenses ... Wien (aus der
Kaiserlich-königlichen Hof- und Staatsdruckerei ...) 1911. Qu. (<em>Polyp. austro-bras.</em>).

HEADING: THELLUNG

Thellumg, Albert (1881-1928), Swiss botanist; assistant at the Botanical Museum of the
University of Zürich 1904-1905; Dr. phil. ib. 1905; at Montpellier with Ch. Flahault in
1904 and 1906; habil. Univ. Zürich 1909; again assistant in Zürich 1906-1928, from
1921 with the professor's title. (<em>Thell</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Z; other material at BAS, MPU. – <em>Letters</em> at UPS-UB.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: AG 4: 304-305, 5(1): 74, 5(4): 57; Backer p. 656, 662;
Barnhart 3: 371 (b. 12 Mai 1881, d. 26 Jun 1928). BFM p. 320-321 [index]; Biol.-
Dokum. 17: 9217-9218; BJI 2: 176; BL 2: 722 [index]; BM 5: 2090, 8: 1297; Bossert p.
398; Christiansen p. 320 [index]; DTS 6(4): 201; Futak-Domin p. 609; Hegi 4(1): 51,
219, 5(2): 1504, 6(2): 1313; Hirsch p. 298; Hortus 3: 1205; IH 1 (ed. 6): 365, (ed. 7):
344; Langman p. 733-734; LS suppl. 27647-27680; MW p. 495; PFC 2(2): xxviii, 3(2):
xii; SO 3522; TL-2/200, 2571, 6619, 10.710, 10.714 and see indexes; Tucker 3: 306;
Zander ed. 10, p. 723, ed. 11, p. 825.

<em>Ref</em>.: Wernham, H.F., J. Bot. 50: 140-141. Apr 1912 (rev.).

Theobald, Gottfried Ludwig (1810-1869), German (Hessen) botanist, geologist and
teacher; studied theology in Marburg and Halle 1927-1931; pastor at Hanau 1831-1839,
private teacher at Montpellier 1839-1843; high school teacher for natural sciences and
geography at Hanau 1843-1850; suspended for political reasons 1850 (dismissed 1854),
teacher at Genève 1852-1854 and pastor of its German protestant community; from
1854 natural history teacher at the county school at Chur, Graubünden. (<em>Theobald</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: CHUR; further material at B (mainly destr.), G, KIEL, M
(lichens), WRSL. – <em>Letters</em> at G.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: ADB 37: 679-680; AG 3: 86 (uncle of Wilhelm Pfeffer);

part 1, p. [1]-80, was announced by Flora (21 Mar 1847), part 2, p. 81-160 came out in
1849.

Therese, Charlotte Marianne Augusta, Prinzessin von Bayern (1850-1925),
German (Bavarian) princess; travelled in the Mediterranean region 1875-1876, in
Scandinavia 1881, in Russia 1882, in S.E. Europe 1883, via Spain to Brasilia 1888, in
the Balkan Peninsula 1890, in N. America and Mexico 1893, in S. America 1898, col-
lecting natural history material; Dr. phil. h.c. München 1897. (<em>Therese</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: M; further material TUR-V. – <em>Letters</em> at G, UPS-UB.

Thériot, [Marie Hypolite] Irénée (1859-1947), French bryologist and schoolteacher;
École normale sup. St. Cloud exam. 1883; teacher in the Dépt. Sarthe 1883-1888; direc-
tor of the "école primaire supérieure" at Le Havre 1888-1920; in retirement at
Fontaine-la-Mallet 1920-1947. (<em>Thér</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: PC (26.000 musci), P. – Other material at DBN, E, H-BR, LS,
SI, W, WRSL. Thériot's phanerogamic herbarium was acquired by Charbonnel. <em>Exsic-
catae</em>: <em>Musci Novae-Caledoniae exsiccati</em>, fasc. 1-8, nos. 1-209, Le Havre 1908-1929, for de-
tails see G. Sayre (1971). Sets at B (mainly destr.), FH, MANCH, PC. – Collected by
Isidore Franc (1879-1969) at Nouméa. – <em>Letters</em> to F. Renauld at PC, to Brotherus (146)
in H-UB. Other letters at G and NY.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 371 (b. 21 Dec 1859, d. 25 Mar 1947); BJI
2: 177; BM 5: 2092-2093, 8: 1298; CSP 19: 70-71; IH 1 (ed. 6): 365, (ed. 7): 344; Kleppa
p. 147, 151; Lenley p. 490; MW p. 495; Rehder 2: 103; SBC p. 133; TL-2/10.288, see
LH. Monguillon; Tucker 1: 684; Urban-Berl. p. 315.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Cat. gén. livr. impr. Bibl. natl. 185: 921-924. 1959; Hedwigia 64: (71).
	1923 (retirement); Index Amer. bot. lit. 1886-1966, 4: 339-340. 1969; Rev. bryol.
	48(2): 32. 1921 (retirement); Rev. bryol. lichénol. 16: 131. 1947 (d.).
Bizot, Bryologist 55(2): 85-87. 1952 (obit.).
Debray, M., Rev. bryol. lichénol. 17: 5-6. 1948 (tribute, portr.).
Lamy, D., Occ. Pap. Farlow herb. 16: 124-125, 126. 1981 (corr. with F. Renauld).
Le Gallo, C., Natural. canad. 78(6): 170-175. 1951 (biogr. sketch).
Looser, G., Rev. Univ. Chil. 37: 221-243. 1952 (biogr., bibl., list sp. Chilean mosses).
Porter, C.E., Rev. Chil. Hist. nat. 39: 24-27. 1935 (biogr. sketch, portr.).
Potier de la Varde, R., Rev. bryol. lichénol. 17(1-4): 7-14. 1948 (obit., bibl.).
Sayre, G., Mem. New York Bot. Gard. 19(2): 263-264. 1971 (exsicc); Bryologist 80:
	519. 1977.

Theron, Johannes Jacobus (1905-x), South African botanist; at Potchefstroom Univ-
ersity 1930-1935; Humboldt Stipendium for study in Germany 1935-1936; Dr. phil.
Berlin 1936; lecturer at Potchefstroom 1936-1939; id., later head of the biology depart-
ment Pretoria University 1939-1969; in retirement in Ellisvar District. (<em>Theron</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: PRU, PU. – Other material at BM, DPU.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Andrews p. 339.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon. Brit. Mus. cat. gen. print. books 237: 186. 1964.
Gunn, M. &amp; L.E. Codd, Bot. expl. S. Afr. 343. 1981 (b. 26 Feb 1905).
Verdoorn, F., ed., Chron. bot. 2: 395. 1936, 5: 508. 1939.

14.147. <em>Anatomisch-systematische Untersuchungen der Laubblätter südafrikanischer Aristida-Arten</em>.

chen Fakultät der Friedrich-Wilhelms-Universität zu Berlin ... Potsdam (gedruckt bei

Therry, Jean Joseph [né Terri] (1833-1888), French merchant and banker, self-

Thihaudin, Gaston Louis (1727-1776), fictitious French explorer and botanist, said to
have been sent to Cuba, Chile and Peru by Louis XVI in 1776 to collect medicinal
plants that could be naturalized in France. (<em>Thibaudin</em>).

PAGE: 257
HEADING: THIÉBAUT-DE-BERNEAUD

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Non-existent.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Barnhart, J.H., J. New York Bot. Gard. 20: 179. 1919.
Conde, J.A., Hist. bot. Cuba 52. 1958.
Wilson, J.G. &amp; J. Fiske, Appleton's Cyclopaedia of American biography 6: 75-76. 1889.

<sm>NOTE</sm>: One of the most ingeniously depicted fictitious botanists featured in Appleton's
Cyclopaedia of American Biography, 6: 75-76. 1889 (see Barnhart 1919). Thibaudin
was said to have "landed in Concepcion early in February, 1777, journeyed for months
through the pampas [sic] and the mountains, and formed a rich herbarium". On his
return in France in 1785 "he was elected a corresponding member of the Academy of
Sciences"; his works included e.g. "Descriptions des plantes recueillir [sic] dans un
voyage au Pérou et au Chili", 2 vols., Paris 1786 and a "Prodrome de la flore du Chili
avec un herbier explicatif 4 vols., 1788. – Conde (1958) accepted these fictitious
authors uncritically, even added some minor details, and in this case changed the name
to "C.A. Thibaudt".

Thiébaut, Charles (1837-1884), French naval officer (capitaine de frégate), collector
of algae on his voyages e.g. to Madagascar and Mexico; published also on French
atlantic vegetation. (<em>C. Thiébaut</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: P, PC; further material at BUC, KIEL, MANCH, W. – <em>Letters</em> at
G and UPS-UB.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 372 (d. 28 Apr 1884); BL 2: 148, 723;
Morren ed. 10, p. 60.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Rev. bot. Bull. mens. Soc. Franç, bot. 3: 285. 1884-1885 (d.); Table art.
	orig. Bull. Soc. bot. France 222.
Duchartre, Bull. Soc. bot. France 31: 223. 1884.
Lack, H.W. &amp; C.-O. von Sydow, Wildenowia 14: 441. 1984 (letters to K. Keck).
Leon, N., Bibl. bot.-mexic. 360. 1895.
Sayre, G., Mem. New York Bot. Gard. 19(3): 404. 1975.

Thiébaut, Jean (x-1953), French botanist; student of the flora of Lebanon and Syria.

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: P.

Thiébaut-de-Berneaud, Arsenne [Arsène] (1777-1850), French agronomist, botanist
and author; officer in the republican army; librarian at the Bibliothèque Mazarine from
1808; from 1849 as "Conservatoir-adjoint"; secretary of the Société Linnéenne de Paris.
(<em>Thiébaut-de-Berneaud</em>).

Thiel, [C.E.] Hugo (1839-1918), German (Rheinland/Prussian) horticulturist and
botanist; studied at the Agricultural College Poppelsdorf and the University of Bonn;
Dr. phil. Bonn 1865; lecturer at these institutions 1865-1869; professor of agriculture at
the Darmstadt Polytechnic 1869; on active service in the Franco-Prussian war 1870-
1872; professor of agriculture at the Technical University of München 1872; general
secretary of the "Kgl. Preuss. Landesökonomiekollegium" 1873 and counsel to (later
director of) the Prussian ministry of agriculture, forestry and state domains; member of
the Prussian Diet and the German parliament 1873-1876; founder, with Althoff, of the
"Landhauskolonie Dahlem"; retirement from 1911. (<em>Thiel</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 372 (b. 2 Jun 1839, d. 13 Jan 1918); BM 5:
2093; Hortus 3: 1205; PR 9212 (see also p. 574).

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Hedwigia 60: (178). 1918 (d.).
Beyrodt, O. and S. Braun, Gartenflora 67: 1, 33-38 (funeral oration, portr.).
Degener, H.A.L, Wer ist's ed. 7. 1704. 1914, ed. 8. 1789. 1922 (d. 15 Jan 1918).
Möller, L., Deut. Gart.-Zeit. 18: 535. 1903 (portr.).

11. Copy</em>: PH.

Thielens, Armand (1833-1878), Belgian botanist and malacologist; studied at Liège,
Brussels and Bonn; industrialist at Tirlemont. (<em>Thielens</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: LG; other material at BR (1500 dupl. private coll.), AWH,
BUG, C, CGE, DBN, E, GOET, MW (2020), US.
<em>Exsiccatae</em>: with A. DeVos, <em>Kickxia belgica</em>, cent. 1-4, 1865-1868, see below for prospectus;
sets e.g. at BR, GOET, LG. – In addition to this series of exsiccatae Thielens offered
many sets of plants collected by others for sale as is clear from his undated pamphlets
<em>Collections de plantes</em> (doubles) provenant de divers herbiers et mises en vente" (5 series;
copies at G) and his <em>Liste de plantes de Belgique</em> offertes en échange, Tirlemont 1863 (no.
1)(p. [1]-8, <em>copy</em>: G). – <em>Letters</em> at G.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: BL 2: 34, 36, 40, 723; BM 5: 2093; Bossert p. 398 (b. 3

271-272, 303; PR 9213; Rehder 5: 843; Tucker 1: 684-685.

HEADING: THIELENS

Thienemann, [Friedrich August] Ludwig (1793-1858), German (Saxony) ornith-
ologist, physician, librarian and traveller; Dr. med. Leipzig 1820; travelled in Iceland
and Norway 1820-1821; lecturer Univ. Leipzig 1822; assistant curator Natural History
Cabinet Dresden 1825-1831; librarian in Dresden 1839-1842; from 1842 active as
private scientist.
(<em>L. Thienem.</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: LZ (destr.). – A <em>Herbarium florae arcticae</em> is mentioned by Flora
(43: 128. 1860): a handwritten list had been submitted under this title with the note that
the respective plants were for sale (see also Bonplandia 6: 65. 1858, Flora 41: 16. 1858
and Bot. Zeit. 16: 19. 1858: arctic cryptogams for sale).

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: ADB 38: 1; BM 5: 2094; CSP 5: 952-953; Herder p. 245,
412; LS 26545; PR ed. 1: 10186; Rehder 1: 353.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Bonplandia 1: 223. 1853, 3: 35. 1855 (cogn. Leop. Olavius), 6: 53, 65,
	295. 1858; Bot. Zeit. 16: 264. 1858 (obit. not.); Brit. Mus. gen. cat. print. books 237:
	301-302. 1964; Österr. bot. Z. 8: 342. 1858 (d.); Flora 8: 464. 1825 (app. "Zweiter
	Inspektor an der königlichen Naturaliensammlung", Dresden).
Gersdorf, Rcpert. deut. ausl. Lit., Leipzig 16(4): 64. 1858 (obit. not.).

HEADING: THIJSSE

Michaud, J.Fr., Biogr. univ. 41: 355. 1970 (repr.).

	meetings of German ornithologists).

<sm>NOTE</sm>: August Thienemann (1882-1960), the founder of modern limnology, was a
German (Thüringian) hydrobiologist and limnologist who studied at Greifswald,
Innsbruck and Heidelberg; Dr. phil. Greifswald 1905; director of the biology depart-
ment for fresh water fishery of the University of Münster 1907-1917, associate professor
ib. 1909; on active service 1914-1916; director of the Biological Station ("Hydrologische
Anstalt") of the Kaiser-Wilhelm-Gesellschaft (now Max Planck Gesellschaft) 1917-1957;
in addition ordinary professor at Kiel 1924, founder of the International Association of
theoretical and applied Limnology 1922; in charge of the "Deutsche limnologische
Sunda Expedition" 1928-1929. See e.g. his <em>Erinnerungen und Tagebuchblätter eines Biologen</em>,
Stuttgart, v, 499 p., with a bibliography, and Plesse, W. &amp; D. Rux, Biogr. bedeut. Biol.
338-343. 1977.

14.181. <em>Reise im Norden Europas, vorzüglich in Island</em>, in den Jahren 1820 bis 1821 ...
Leipzig (bei Carl Heinrich Reclam) 1827. Oct. 2 vols. †. (<em>Reise N. Eur.</em>).

<em>1</em>: 1824, p. [i]-viii, [1]-160, [i]-vi, 22 pl. (zoological: mammals).
<em>2</em>: 1827, p. [i]-xiv, 1-410, <em>5 pl</em>., map. (mainly zoological but with many botanical notes).
<em>Copies</em>: HH, NSUB, Österr. Nat.-Bibl.

14.182. <em>Über ein neues Geschlecht von Schneepflanzen</em>, Chionyphe, Schneegewebe, ...[Nova
Acta Leop. 1839]. Qu. 

<em>Publ</em>.: 1839 (in journal; read 17 Dec 1837; Flora rd 4 Mai 1840; Soc. géol. France rd by
	13 Jan 1840), p. [19]-26, <em>pl. 2</em> (col. lith. auct.). <em>Copy</em>: G. – Reprinted and to be cited
	from Nova Acta Leop. 19(1): [19]-26. 1839.

Thijsse, Jacobus Pieter (1863-1945), Dutch naturalist and schoolteacher at Amster-
dam 1883-1890; at De Burg, Texel 1890-1892; director of a school in Amsterdam 1892-
1901; teacher at the Amsterdam municipal teachers college 1901-1921; high school
teacher at the Kennemer Lyceum, Bloemendaal 1921-1930; from 1930 in retirement;
Dr. phil. h.c. Amsterdam 1922; pioneer conservationist and popularizer of natural his-
tory in the Netherlands. (<em>Thijsse</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: L.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Backer p. 582 (detailed biogr. sketch); Barnhart 3: 373
(b. 25 Jul 1863); BFM 1418; BL 2: 423, 428; JW 1: 449, 2: 202, 3: 372, 4: 410 (q.v. for
further biogr. refs.); TL-2/406, 8392 (err. "Thysse"), see E. Heimans; Tucker 1: 685.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Grote Winkler Prins 18, 437-438. 1974 (biogr., bibl., d. 8 Jun 1945);
	Natura 34: 181. 1935 (portr.); Persoonlijkheden in het Koninkrijk der Nederlanden
	1466. 1938 (portr.); Wie is dat 1: 258. 1931, 2: 324. 1932, 3: 375. 1935.

	11-15. 1949.

Verwey, J., Ardea 34: 270-276. 1946 (obit.).
Westhoff, V., Natuur en Landschap 19(2): 68-80. 1965 (biogr., evaluation, tribute,
	portr.).

2/2: 137-138).
(2) Founder (1895) and longtime editor of <em>De Levende Natuur</em>.

Thiriart, T.Fr. (<em>fl</em>. 1806), German printer and supervisor of the secondary school

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

Thiselton-Dyer, William Turner (1843-1928), British botanist; B.A. Oxford 1867,
B.Sc. London 1880; professor of natural history, Royal Agricultural College, Cirencester
1868-1870; professor of botany, Royal College of Science, Dublin 1870-1872; id. Royal
Horticultural Society London 1872, private secretary and editorial assistant to J.D.
Hooker 1872; assistant director Royal Botanic Gardens, Kew 1875-1885; director ib.
1885-1905; in retirement at Witcombe, Gloucestershire; knighted 1899. (<em>Dyer</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: K (including manuscripts, correspondence and field notes; other
material at DBN, OXF. – <em>Letters</em> e.g. at AK, FH, G, NY, US (SIA).

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Ainsworth p. 230; Andrews p. 339; Backer p. 187, 582;
Barnhart 1: 489 (sub Dyer); BJI 2: 177; BL 1: 54, 63, 118, 321, 2: 244, 256, 339, 723;
Blunt p. 183, 186; Bossert p. 398 (b. 28 Jul 1843, d. 23 Dec 1928); Bret. p. 823; Clokie p.
160; CSP 7: 588, 9: 767-768, 12: 728, 19: 79-80; Desmond p. 605; De Toni 1: cxxii; DNB
1922-1930: 830-832; DSB 13: 341-344 (G.L. Geison); Ewan ed. 2: 114; Hortus 3: 1192;
Langman p. 734; Lenley p. 409; Morren ed. 2, p. 24, ed. 10, p. 70; MW p. 495-496; PH
164, 567; Quenstedt p. 428; Rehder 5: 247; SIA 189, 221; TL-1/484, 496, 537; TL-
2/268, 1290, 1814, 2448, 2627, 2981, 3006, 3218, 7055, 9954; Tucker 1: 685, 3: 307;
Zander ed. 10, p. 655, ed. 11, p. 745.

White, A. &amp; B.L. Sloane, Stapelieae ed. 2, p. 12, 113-114, 847, 1086. 1937 (portr.).

<sm>COMPOSITE</sm> <sm>WORKS</sm>: (1) Founder, and during his directorship q.q. editor, of <em>Bull. misc. Inf.,
Kew</em> (Kew Bulletin) 1887-1905 (18 vols.).
(2) Editor, [Curtis's] <em>Botanical Magazine</em> 1905-1906; TL-2/1290.
(3) Assisted A.W. Bennett with the translation of J. v. Sachs, <em>Lehrb. Bot.</em> as <em>Text-book of
botany</em>, ed. 1, 1875, see TL-2/9954.
(4) Editor, W.J. Hooker, <em>Icon. pl. pl. 2401-2800</em>, see TL-2/3006.
(5) Editor, B.D. Jackson, <em>Index kewensis</em>, suppl. 2(1, 2), 1904, 1905; TL-2/3218.
(6) Contributed to J.D. Hooker, <em>Fl. Brit. Ind.</em> 1(2): 246-258. Jan 1874 (<em>Portulaceae,
Tamariscineae, Elatineae, Hypericineae</em>,), 279-317 (<em>Ternstroemiaceae, Dipterocarpaceae</em>). Jan
1874, 5(15): 655-658. (<em>Cycadaceae</em>). Dec 1888; TL-2/2981.
(7) Thiselton-Dyer revived the <em>Flora capensis</em>, started by Harvey and Sonder (TL-
2/2448), but interrupted 1865. W.T.T. took responsibility for the <em>Flora</em> from 1891 on-
wards and under his editorial guidance vols. 4-7 appeared between 1895 and 1925; the
supplement to 5(2), by A.W. Hill, came out in 1933 (see Bull. misc. Inf. Kew 1933: 367-
368). W.T.T. contributed no treatments of his own.
(8) Editor, D. Oliver, <em>Fl. trop. Afr.</em> vols. 4-6(1), 1902-1913. W.T.T. contributed addenda
to 4(1), 4(2) and 5; see TL-2/7055.
(9) Co-author with Henry Trimen (senior author). <em>Fl. Middlesex</em> 1869, see under H.
Trimen.
(10) <em>Introduction</em>, to W.J. Bean, <em>The Royal Botanic Gardens, Kew</em>, historical and descriptive,
1908.

<sm>NAME</sm>: Thiselton-Dyer was frequently called (and addressed) "Dyer" and is occasionally
so listed in indexes. G.L. Geison (DSB) states that he "derived his name from his pat-
ernal grandfather, William Matthew Thiselton, a printer and barrister who took the
additional name Dyer by royal license in 1840". We follow the <em>Draft index of author
abbreviations</em> ... Kew (1980) with respect to the use of "Dyer" as abbreviation. Rendle

PAGE: 266
HEADING: THISELTON-DYER

(1929), who also uses "Dyer" in the obituary, notes that the hyphen in Thiselton-Dyer
"was assumed about 1891".

<sm>NOTE</sm>: (1) Thiselton-Dyer's view of the importance of "Kew" was expressed by him to
M. Grant Duff (Notes from a diary 1881-1886, 2: 21) on 1 March 1885: "I often think,
and have no doubt often said, that we at Kew feel individually the weight of the Empire
as a whole, more even than they do in Downing Street". (J. Bot. 41: 61. 1903).
(2) Harriet Ann Thiselton-Dyer (1854-1945), eldest daughter of J.D. Hooker married
W.T.T. in 1877, two years after his appointment as assistant director of Kew. Lady
Thiselton-Dyer was a botanical artist who contributed ca. 90 drawings to the <em>Botanical
Magazine</em> between 1878 and 1906 (mostly 1878, 1879). Her work on the Magazine was
continued by her cousin, Matilda Smith.
(3) W.T.T.'s brother the Rev. Thomas Firminger Thiselton-Dyer (b. 1848) published
<em>The folk-lore of plants</em>, London (Chatto &amp; Windus) 1889, American issue New York (D.
Appleton and Companion) 1889, publ. Mar-Apr 1889, p. [i-vii], [1]-328 (<em>copies</em>: HH,
MO, NY) (reissued 1894), critically reviewed by J. Britten, J. Bot. 27: 122-124. 1889
(note by Britten ib. 30: 224. 1892: "The latter gentleman [T.F.T.] is well known as an
indefatigable rather than a competent compiler ..." – The book was reissued in fac-
simile 1968 by Singing Tree Press, Detroit, Mich., U.S.A.; <em>copy</em>: NY. – Also: <em>English folk-
lore</em>, London (Hardwicke &amp; Bogue) 1878, p. [i]-viii, [1]-290. <em>Copy</em>: HH.

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Dyera</em> J.D. Hooker (1882); <em>Dyerella</em> F. Heim (1892); <em>Dyerocycas</em> Nakai (1943);
<em>Dyerophytum</em> O. Kuntze (1891). <em>Note</em>: <em>Thiseltonia</em> Hemsley (1905) honors G.H. Thiselton-
Dyer who collected plants in West Australia.

Thoday, David (1883-1964), British botanist; studied at Cambridge; demonstrator in
botany ib. 1909-1911; lecturer in plant physiology, Manchester Univ. 1911-1918; profes-
sor of botany, Cape Town (Bolus chair of botany) 1918-1922; id. Bangor 1923-1949;
professor of plant physiology Alexandria Univ. 1950-1954; visiting professor Univ. Leeds
1951-1952. (<em>Thoday</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Some S. African material in GRA, SAM, STE.

<sm>NOTE</sm>: Thoday's wife Mary Gladys Thoday, née Sykes, c. 1884-1943, was an active plant
physiologist, see Nature 152: 406. 1943.

1883, d. 30 Mar 1964).

Thorn, Charles (1872-1956), American mycologist and microbiologist; at Lake Forest
College, Illinois 1895-1897, A.M. ib. 1897; instructor in biology Missouri State Univ.
1897-1899; Dr. phil. ib. 1899; instructor in botany ib. 1899-1901, assistant professor of
botany ib. 1901-1902; assistant in mycology Cornell University 1902-1904; mycologist
with USDA for cheese investigation at Storrs, Connecticut 1904-1913; mycologist in
charge of the USDA microbiological laboratory, Washington 1913-1927; mycologist in
charge of the Division of Soil microbiology ib. 1927-1942 (from 1934 in the Bureau of
Plant Industry). (<em>Thom</em>).

Thomas, Cyrus (1825-1910), American ethnologist, entomologist, plant collector and
Lutheran minister; co-founder of the Illinois Natural History Society 1858; member of
F.V. Hayden's Survey in Colorado and New Mexico 1869-1873; teacher at Carbondale
1873-1875; state entomologist of Illinois from 1874-1876; ultimately dedicating himself
to ethnology in the U.S. Bureau of Ethnology. (<em>C. Thomas</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: US. – <em>Letters</em> and mss. at SIA.

Thomas [Abraham Louis] Emmanuel [Emanuel] (1788-1859), Swiss plant collec-
tor, plant dealer and forester at Bex [Vaud]. (<em>Em. Thomas</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: G (bought Feb 1893). – Further material at B (mainly), BM,
BR, E, E-GL, FI, GOET, H, JE, K, LAU, LE, LZ (destr.), MW, NA, OXF, PC, TCD,
W. – The Bex herbarium was with Thomas's son Jean-Louis at Bex in 1880 (fide Alph.
de Candolle, Phytogr. 1880); it was put up for sale in 1887 (BSbF 34 (bibl.): 191-192.
1887). Part of it was bought from Henri Thomas at Bex in Feb 1893 by the Herbier
Boissier, now G. – <em>Letters</em> at G, UPS-UB.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: AG 2(1): 97, 4: 211, 5(1): 759; Backer p. 662; Barnhart

HEADING: EM. THOMAS

<sm>HANDWRITING</sm>: Candollea 33: 427-428. 1978.

<sm>NOTE</sm>: Emmanuel Thomas was the son of Abram [Abraham] Thomas (1740-1822),
grandson of Pierre Thomas (<em>fl</em>. 1750) and brother of Louis Thomas (1784-1823) and
Philippe Thomas (x-1831), all Swiss botanists. Abram Thomas accompanied A. v.
Haller on some of his mountain trips. Jean-Louis Thomas (1834-1886), son of
Emmanuel continued his father's botanical activities.

<sm>NAME</sm>: Emmanuel Thomas used both the spelling Emanuel and Emmanuel on the
catalogues.

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Thomasia</em> J. Gay (1821) honors Pierre Thomas, 18th century amateur Swiss
botanist and his son Abram Thomas (1740-1822), Swiss botanist.

suiss.</em>).

<em>1818 ed</em>.: 1818, p. [1]-38. <em>Copies</em>: G, PH.

Thomas, Friedrich August Wilhelm (1840-1918), German (Thüringian) botanist,
cecidiologist and high school teacher; studied natural sciences at Jena University with A.
Braun and M.J. Schleiden; Dr. phil. Berlin 1863 as student of N. Pringsheim; teacher at
the Gymnasium Gleichense at Ohrdruf (Thuringia) 1863-1905. (<em>F. Thomas</em>).

Thommen, Edouard (1880-1961), Swiss philologist and botanist; studied languages at
Basel, Paris, Oxford and Göttingen; Dr. phil. Göttingen 1903; stenographer with the
Swiss federal government 1903-1906; the Office international du Travail at Basel 1906-
1920; with the Bureau international du Travail Genève 1920-1940, from 1940 dedicat-
ing himself mainly to Swiss floristic botany. (<em>Thommen</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: BAS; further material at G. – <em>Letters</em> at G.

557, 566, 584, 723; MW suppl. 360; NI 1948, 3: 64; TL-2/522, 1838.

Thompson, Arnold (1876-1959), British bryologist and teacher (Sphagnaceae);
studied at London University and Tübingen (1902-1903), teacher Bootham School
York 1903-1906 and at King Edward VII School, Sheffield 1906-1936; in retirement at
Skipton; secretary British Bryological Society 1936-1947, president 1948-1949. (<em>Arn.
Thomps.</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: BM.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Desmond p. 606 (b. 15 Jun 1876, d. 27 Jan 1959).

Sayre, G., Bryologist 80: 519. 1977 (coll. BM).
Scott, L.I., Naturalist 879: 158-159. 1961 (biogr. sketch).

Thompson, Charles Henry (1870-1931), American botanist; M.S. Univ. Kansas
1898; instructor in botany, Shaw School of Botany, St. Louis 1893-1895; bot. asst.
Missouri Botanical Garden 1895-1896; instructor at the University of Missouri 1896-
1897; in charge of the department of succulent plants Missouri Botanical Garden from
1904; from 1915 assistant botanist, assistant professor of horticulture and professor of
horticulture at Massachusetts College. (<em>C.H. Thomps.</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: KANU (orig. Lemnaceae coll.); other material at B (mainly

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 376 (b. 23 Jun 1870, d. 23 Jan 1931); BM 5:
2096; CSP 19: 94; Hortus 3: 1205; Langman p. 735; LS suppl. 10048; Rehder 2: 589;
Stevenson p. 1260; Tucker 1: 686, 3: 307; Urban-Berl. p. 403.

secretary of the Watson Botanical Exchange Club 1900-1904, 1920-1934. (<em>H.S.

Thompson, John Vaughan (1779-1847), British surgeon, zoologist and botanist;
studied surgery at Edinburgh 1797-1798; assistant surgeon with the Prince of Wales's
Fencibles 1799, in Gibraltar 1799, in the West Indies and Guiana 1799-1809, from 1803
as full surgeon; to Madagascar and Mauritius 1812-1816; district medical inspector at
Cork 1816-1835; in charge of the convict medical department at Sydney 1835-1847.
(<em>J.V. Thomps.</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: BM; further material at M (lichens), MO (Madagascar).

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 377; BB p. 298; BM 5: 2097; CSP 5: 958-
959; Desmond p. 607; DNB 19: 698-699; Hortus 3: 1205; Jackson p. 249; PR 9228;
Rehder 1: 255, 396; Tucker 1: 685.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Brit. Mus. gen. cat. print. books 238: 126. 1964; Newsletter Soc. Hist.
	nat. Hist. 18: 6. 1983 (letters Natl. Archives).
Baker, J.G., Nat. Hist. Trans. Northumberland 14(1): 82. 1902.
Bridson, G.D.R. et al., Nat. hist. mss. res. Brit. Isl. 255.47, 255.141. 1980.
Britten, J.G., J. Bot. 50: 169-171. 1912 (b. 19 Nov 1779, d. 21 Jan 1847).
Praeger, R.L., Some Irish naturalists 165-166. 1949.
Vaughan, R.E., Proc. R. Soc. Arts Sci. Mauritius 1(3): 241-248. 1953.

<sm>NOTE</sm>: J.V. Thompson was the author of the anonymous <em>A catalogue of the exotic plants
cultivated in the Mauritius</em> ... Mauritius (printed by Baron &amp; Souvignec ...) Nov 1816,
Qu., 31 p. for which see Vaughan (1953). A second edition was issued in 1822 (n.v.).

Thorns, Hermann [Friedrich Maria] (1859-1931), German (Mecklenburg) pharma-
cist and botanist; trained at pharmacies at Woldegk, Giessen and Koblenz; state phar-
maceutical examination Jena 1884; Dr. phil. Erlangen 1886; pharmacist at Jena 1887-
1889; in charge of a chemical factory in Berlin 1889-1893; editor of the Apotheker-
Zeitung 1893; habil. Berlin for pharmaceutical chemistry 1895, professor's title 1896;
director of the Institute of Pharmaceutical Chemistry of Berlin University 1902-1929;
ordinary professor of pharmaceutical chemistry 1920, visited the United States and
Japan 1923; Dr. med. h.c. Würzburg 1929; founder of the Deutsche Pharmazeutische
Gesellschaft; botanically active as phytochemist. (<em>H. Thorns</em>).

Thomson, Paul William (1892-1957), Estonian botanist and quaternary geologist;
teacher at a gymnasium in Dorpat 1921-1932; lecturer in geology and paleontology at
the University of Dorpat 1928-1939, also connected with the Experiment Station of the
Estonian peat-bog association at Tooma nr Vägera; from 1941-1945 director of the
Geological-palaeontological Institute at Tosen; geologist with the Amt für Bodenfor-
schung Krefeld from 1947. (<em>P.W. Thomson</em>).

Thomson, Thomas (1817-1878), British physician and botanist; MD Glasgow 1839;
student of W.J. Hooker; surgeon in the Bengal army 1839; superintendent, Botanic
Garden, Calcutta 1854-1861; travelled in the W. Himalayas and Tibet 1847-1851 (with
J.D. Hooker 1849). (<em>Th. Thomson</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: K (see also J.D. Hooker); further material at B (mainly destr.),
BAS, BM, BR, C, CAL, E, F, FI, GH, GOET, H, K, L, LE, M, MH, NY, OXF, P, PH,
S, UW, WU. – <em>Mss</em>. and <em>letters</em> at K, other letters at G. – <em>Exsiccatae</em> (with J.D. Hooker
(1817-1911), <em>Herbarium Indiae orientalis</em>, col. 1847-1851, see J.D. Hooker.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Backer p. 583; Barnhart 3: 379; BB p. 300; BM 5: 2100;
Bossert p. 399; Clokie p. 253; CSP 5: 976, 8: 1080; Desmond p. 609 (b. 4 Dec 1817, d. 18
Apr 1878); DNB 56: 272-273 (19: 752-753); Frank 3 (Anh.): 103; GR p. 417; Herder p.
61, 209, 307, 314, 322; Hortus 3: 1205; IH 1 (ed. 6): 365; Jackson p. 388; MW p. 496;
PR (alph.) 4203; Rehder 5: 845-846; TL-1/525; TL-2/2972, 2981, see J.D. Hooker;
Tucker 1: 687; Urban-Berl. p. 315, 403; Zander ed. 10, p. 723, ed. 11, p. 765.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Bonplandia 2: 190. 1854 (app. Calcutta), 3: 35. 1855 (cogn. Leopoldina
	Hamilton), 9: 184. 1861 (in London); Bot. Not. 1879: 31 (d.); Brit. Mus. gen. cat.

Thornier, Franz (1863-1928), Austrian botanist; studied natural sciences in Vienna
and Berlin; scientist of private means in Dresden 1887-1902, in Vienna 1903-1920, in
Prague (Smichov) 1920-1928; travelled in the Belgian Congo 1896 and 1909. (<em>Thonner</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: BR; some further material in B (mainly destr.), K, W.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 379; BFM 2307; BJI 2: 177; BL 1: 17, 321;
BM 5: 2101, 8: 1304; Rehder 5: 846; Tucker 2: xxxvii; Urban-Berl. p. 403; Zander ed.
10, p. 723.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Degener, H.A.L., Wer ist's eds. 5-9, 1911-1928.

	biogr., bibl., commentary), see below.
Schmid, B. &amp; C. Thesing, Biologen-kalender 1: 325. 1914 (b. 11 Mar 1863).
Želízko, J.V., Mitt. Anthropol. Ges. Wien 1928: 238 (obit.).
