Thonning, Peter (1775-1848), Danish botanist; studied medicine and natural sciences
at Copenhagen; on a botanical expedition to Danish Guinea [now in Ghana] with O.
Haaslund Smith 1799-1803 studying natural resources and dye plants; after 1807 in
various functions, from 1829 co-director of the Royal Natural History Museum.
(<em>Thonn</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: C (1027 sheets extant); main set destroyed 1807; other material
at BM, BR, FI, G-DC, K, LE, MO, P, P-JU, S. – Copenhagen collection (with that of
Isert, q.v.) available on microfiche IDC 2203 (see F.N. Hepper 1976); for a description
of the material see C.F. Schumacher, Beskr. Guin. pl. 1827).

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Backer p. 583; Hortus 3: 1205; Lasègue p. 316, 345, 414,
504; PR 8599, ed. 1: 9464; TL-1/1208; TL-2/11.360 and see P.E. Isert and H.C.F.
Schumacher; Zander ed. 11, p. 825.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Christensen, C., Dansk Bot. Hist. 1: 117, 195, 223. 1924.
Hepper, F.N., The West African herbaria of Isert and Thonning. A taxonomic revision
	and index to the IDC microfiche, Kew 1976, 227 p. (portr., biogr. sketch, full details
	on coll.).
Hornemann, J., Nat. Tidskr. 1: 585. 1837.
Junghans, J., Bot. Tidsskr. 57: 310-355. 1961, 58: 82-122. 1962 (on collections at C).
Lowden, R.M., Taxon, Index pers. names vols. 1-30. 731. 1985.
Vallot, J, Bull. Soc. bot. France 29: 193-194. 1882.
Warming, E., Bot. Tidsskr. 12: 110. 1880 (bibl., b. 9 Oct 1775, d. 29 Jan 1848).

PAGE: 291
HEADING: THOREL

<sm>COMPOSITE</sm> <sm>WORKS</sm>: See Warming (1800, p. 100) for Thonning's share in publishing some
of M. Vahl's works.

<sm>HANDWRITING</sm>: Bot. Tidsskr. 57: 313. 1961.

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Thonningia</em> Vahl (1810).

Thore, Jean (1762-1823), French physician and naturalist; army physician in S.
France from 1792, later practicing physician at Dax; from 1815 some time school
teacher at Saint-Vincent, ultimately again at Dax. (<em>Thore</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown; some material at FI, P-JU; a single specimen ment-
ioned by Lindemann (1886; now MW). – <em>Letters</em> at G.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: AG 2(1): 229, 5(2): 62; Barnhart 3: 380 (b. 3 Oct 1762,
d. 27 Apr 1823); BL 2: 169, 723; BM 5: 2101; CSP 5: 982; De Toni 1: cxxii; Frank 3
(Anh.): 103; GR p. 353; Herder p. 175; LS 26613; PR 9233-9234, ed. 1: 10207; Rehder
1: 406; Stevenson p. 1260; Zander ed. 10, p. 724, ed. 11, p. 826.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Cat. gén. livr. impr. Bibl. natl. 188: 294. 1962.
Aparisi-Serres, Bull. Soc. Borda 1940: 17-32 (rev. Bull. Soc. franç. Hist. méd. 34: 95.
	1940).
Lindemann, E. v., Bull. Soc. imp. Natural. Moscou 61: 76. 1886 (one specimen in his
	herb.).

Quérard, J.M., La France littéraire 9: 452. s.d.

	(André Brossier) 1812, 15 p. (from Bull. Polymath. Mus. Instr. publ. Bordeaux 4-5,

(1913); <em>Thoreites</em> Massalongo (1850); <em>Thorella</em> J. Briquet (1914); <em>Thorella</em> B. Gaillon
(1833); <em>Thoreochloa</em> J. Holub (1963).

14.278. <em>Essai d'une Chloris</em> du Département des Landes, à Dax (chez Seize, ...) 1803-An
ix. Oct. (<em>Essai Chloris</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: 1803, p. [i*-iv*], [i]-xliv, [5]-516. <em>Copies</em>: B-S, G, HH, M, NY(2), USDA.

Thorel, Clovis (1833-1911), French physician, botanist and plant collector; Dr. med.
1861; colonial physician in Indochina 1861; exploring the area 1866-1868; at Paris
1868-1870; Dr. med. Paris 1870; from then on practicing physician in Paris. (<em>Thorel</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: P, PC (herbarium and manuscripts with descriptions of over
4000 species, see Gagnepain 1911); further material at A, C, E, NY.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 380 (b. 28 Apr 1833, d. 11 Sep 1911); Bret.
p. 835; MW p. 496; Rehder 1: 469; Tucker 1: 688.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Bull. Soc. bot. France 58: 479. 1911 (d.); Cat. gén. livr. impr. Bibl. natl.
	188: 306. 1902; Flora 52: 431. 1869 (on Indochina exped.).
Carnoy, H., ed., Dict. biogr. membr. soc. sav. 135-137. 1896.
Gagnepain, F., Bull. Soc. bot. France 58: 523-528. 1911 (main biogr. account, portr.,,
	bibl., list of collections and manuscripts); Fl. gén. Indochina vol. prélim. 48. 1944.
Kerr, A., J. Thail. Res. Soc. Nat. Hist. suppl. 12(1): 14-15. 1939.

<sm>COMPOSITE</sm> <sm>WORKS</sm>: <em>Agriculture et horticulture de l'Indo-Chine, in</em> F. Gamier, <em>Voyage
d'Exploration en Indo-Chine</em> 2: 335-491. <em>pl. 2.</em> 1873.

HEADING: THOREL

(1920, <em>nom. cons.</em>); <em>Thorelia</em> H.F. Hance (1877, <em>nom. rej.</em>); <em>Thoreliella</em> Wu (1957).

14.279. Faculté de médecine de Paris. Thèse pour le doctorat en médecine présentée et

Thorenaar, Adriaan (1894-1977), Dutch forest officer, silviculturist and soil scientist;
entered the Dutch East Indies Forest Service 1919; in E. Java 1919-1920; 1920-1925 at
Palembang; at Buitenzorg 1925-1937, from 1934 as teacher at the Buitenzorg [Bogor]
Agricultural School; from 1937 at Poerworedja; ultimately at Voorburg nr The Hague;
Dr. phil. Wageningen 1926. (<em>Thorenaar</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: BO, BZF; some further material at U.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: SK 1: 527 (coll., bibl.); Tucker 3: 308.

Stern, W.L., Taxon 27: 236. 1978 (wood coll. BZFw).

Thormeyer, Paul (1878-?), German (Anhalt) botanist and high school teacher;
studied mathematics and natural sciences in Göttingen (1901-1903), Halle (1903-1904),
and again Göttingen (1904-1906); state teachers examination Göttingen 1906; teacher
at Hannover from 1906; Dr. phil. Göttingen 1910; student of G.A. Peter. (<em>Thormeyer</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

Thornber, John James (1872-1962), American botanist; AM Univ. Nebraska 1901;
from 1901-1943 professor of botany at the University of Arizona, Tucson; botanist
(1901-1921) and director of the Univ. Arizona Experiment Station 1921-1928; from
1928 botanist ib. (<em>Thornb</em>.).

14.283. <em>New Illustration of the sexual system</em> of Carolus von Linnaeus: comprehending an
elucidation of the several parts of the fructification; a prize dissertation on the sexes of
plants; a full explanation of the classes, and orders, of the sexual system; and the Temple
of Flora, or garden of nature, being picturesque, botanical, coloured plates, of select
plants, illustrative of the same, with descriptions ... Shall Britons, in the field
unconquer'd still, the better laurel lose? – In finer arts and public works shall they to

PAGE: 294
HEADING: THORNTON

Gallia yield? .. Thomson. By Robert John Thornton, ... London (printed, for the pub-
lisher, by T. Bensley, ...) 1807. Broadsheet. (<em>New ill. sex. syst.</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: For a summary of the contents see Soulsby 772. Part I is "A new illustration of the
	sexual system of Linnaeus", part 2 a collection of 26 portraits and 91 botanical plates,
	part 3 "The temple of Flora". This <em>Temple of Flora</em> contains 31 coloured engraved
	plates. No two copies are alike because the plates were engraved by various processes,
	the impressions taken from them printed in colour and finished by hand, and altered
	in several instances thus producing various "states". See Grigson and Buchanan
	(1951), SO 772, NI 1955 and R. King for further details. – Copies vary considerably.
	<em>Copies</em>: BR, K, NY, Teyler.
<em>Contemporary reissue of Temple of Flora</em>: London 1812, frontisp., p. [i-xvii], <em>30 pl</em>. with text.
	<em>Copy</em>: NY. – NI 1955 mentions a quarto edition, London 1810, the so-called Lottery
	edition.
<em>Modern reissue of Temple of Flora</em>: R. King, <em>The Temple of Flora</em> Robert Thornton. Introd-
	uction by Ronald King, New York Graphic Society, Boston 1981. Reproduced from
	the copy at K. ISBN 0-812-1128-5. – Another reprint was publ. 1952, London
	(Collins), with notes by H. Buchanan; reissued 1972.
<em>Ref</em>.: Cardew, F.M.G., J.R. Hort. Soc. 72: 281-285, 450-453. 1947.
	Grigson, G. &amp; H. Buchanan, Thornton's Temple of Flora, London 1951.
Perkins, Gard. Chon. ser. 3. 16: 89, 154, 276-278. 1894.

14.284. <em>Botanical extracts</em>: or philosophy of botany ... London (printed by T. Bensley, ...)
1810, 2 vols. Fol. (<em>Bot. extr.</em>).

<em>1</em>: 1810, p. [1]-308.
<em>2</em>: 1810, p. [i], 309-574, <em>81 pl</em>.
<em>Copy</em>: B. – NI mentions <em>21 pl</em>. for the Botanical abstracts, followed by a number ["75-
	80"] of <em>Elementary botanical plates</em> which are regarded as vol. 3 of <em>The Philosophy of botany</em>
	(see below). The fourth volume is then the above mentioned <em>New ill. sex. syst.</em> 1799-
	1810. MO has a copy with the same title pages as the B copy, but with a different
	pagination (also mentioned by Tucker 3: 308 and described in Bot. Zeit. 18: 227-228.
	1860) and with the plates in a separate volume (see below).
	<em>1</em>: [i*-iii*], [i]-xi, [xiii], 1-308, <em>2 pl</em>.
	<em>2</em>: [i], 309-625.
<em>Note</em>: We record here only the existence of a few copies encountered by us. We were not
	in a position to enter further into this bibliographer's nightmare and refer to the same
	special studies as listed under <em>New ill. sex. syst.</em>

14.285. <em>Elementary botanical plates</em>, Illustrative of the science of botany: adapted to Lee's
introduction to botany; – Rose's introduction to botany; – ... but more particularly
intended to illustrate Botanical abstracts; or the philosophy of botany ... London
(printed by T. Bensley, ...) (<em>Elem. bot. pl.</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: can be regarded as vol. 3 of <em>Botanical extracts</em>, 1810, frontisp., p. [1]-6, [7], <em>1 pl</em>., i-
	ix, <em>100 pl. Copy</em>: MO. – Freemann (1980) mentions 160 pl., 17 portr.
<em>Text</em>: see above <em>Botanical extracts</em>, MO-copy.
<em>Note</em>: We suspect that this book and its associated titles shows the same feature as the
	<em>Temple of Flora</em> and associated material; copies are probably all different and consist of
	different sets of plates occurring under various titles.

14.286. <em>A new family herbal</em>: or popular account of the natures and properties of the
various plants used in medicine, diet, and the arts. By Robert John Thornton, M.D. ...
The plants drawn from nature, by Henderson: are engraved on wood, by Thomas
Bewick. London (printed for Richard Phillips, ...) 1810. Oct. (<em>New fam. herbal</em>).

Thory, Claude Antoine (1759-1827), French polygraph, horticulturist and botanist,
especially rhodologist; studied at the Collège de Lisieux; counsel at the French
Parliament; clerk at the "Chambre criminelle" of the Paris court of justice; after 1789
dedicating himself to the natural sciences and literature, especially botany. (<em>Thory</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Some of the Malmaison roses are at P. – Thory was the author of
the text of Redouté's <em>Les Roses</em>. – Beaumont (1828) mentions the existence of a
"complete herbarium of plants and shrubs of France".

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 381 (b. 26 Mai 1759); BM 5: 2104; Bossert
p. 400; CSP 5: 983; Herder p. 342; Hortus 3: 1205; Jackson p. 142; MW p. 496; NI
1958; Plesch p. 433; PR 9244-9247, 7455, ed. 1: 8413, 10219-10221; Rehder 5: 846;
Sotheby 746; TL-1/1044, 1295-1297; Tucker 1: 688; Zander ed. 10, p. 724, ed. 11, p.
826.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Cat. gén. livr. impr. Bibl. natl. 188: 485-487. 1962.
Beaumont, D., <em>in</em> P.J. Redouté, Les Roses, ed. 3. 1: i-vi. 1828.
MacPhail, I., ed., Cat. Redout. 25-26, 75, 103-104, 104-105. 1963.
Quérard, J.M., La France littéraire 9: 455-457. s.d.
Wright, R.L., Gardener's tribute 158-160, 184, 1949.
Z. <em>in</em> J.Fr. Michaud, Biogr. univ. 41: 434. 1854f (facs. ed. 1970).

<sm>COMPOSITE</sm> <sm>WORKS</sm>: <em>Les Roses</em>, par P.J. Redouté, Thory author of text, ed. 1, 1817-1824;
ed. 2, 1824-1826, "décrites par C.A. Thorry [sic; Thory had nothing to do with this
edition], ed. 3, 1828-1829, with biographical note of Thory by D. Beaumont. – See TL-
2/8748, 8749, 8751. – Ed. 3 contains the publication, posthumously, of an additional
<em>Traité du Rosier</em>, by Thory.

14.293. <em>Rosa Redutea</em> seu descriptio novae speciaei generis Rosae, dicata Petro Josepho

colebat anno 1813; cum figura aenea picta. Parisiis (apud Dam Hérissant Le Doux, ...)

14.295. <em>Prodrome de la monographie</em> des espèces et variétés connues <em>du genre Rosier</em>, divisées
selon leur ordre naturel, avec la synonymie, les noms vulgaires, un tableau synoptique,
et deux planches gravées en couleur. Ouvrage utile aux botanistes-cultivateurs pour
l'arrangement méthodique de ces arbrisseaux dans les grandes collections, et aux
pépiniéristes pour répondre au demandes qui leur seraient faites ... à Paris (chez Pierre
Dufart, ...) 1820. Duod. (<em>Prodr. monogr. Rosier</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: 7 Oct 1820 (BF), p. [i-iii], [1]-190, <em>pl. 1-2</em> (col. copp. H.J. Redouté). <em>Copies</em>: B-S,
	BR, HH, NY; IDC 5764.
<em>Ref</em>.: Sprengel, K.P.J., Neu. Entdeck. 3: 249-253. 1822 (rev.).

14.296. <em>Monographie</em> ou histoire naturelle <em>du genre Groseillier</em>, contenant la description,
l'histoire, la culture et les usages de toutes les groseilles connues, avec 24 planches
coloriées ... à Paris (chez P. Dufart, ...) 1829. Oct. (<em>Monogr. Groseillier</em>).

	uncol.] liths. L.A. &amp; A.M. Caneva). <em>Copies</em>: B, BR, G(2), HH, NY.

Thouin, André (1747-1824), French horticulturist and botanist; succeeded his father as
head gardener of the Jardin des Plantes, Paris 1764-1824; from 1806 [1793?] as "Profes-
seur de culture"; travelled in Auvergne 1780; in the Netherlands, Vlaanderen 1794-
1795, in Italy 1796-1797. (<em>Thouin</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: MPU (via J. Cambessèdes); further material at C, H (Steven, 2
drawings), LINN, MA, P, P-JU, SBT. – <em>Letters</em> to J. Banks at BM, to J.E. Smith at
LINN, to C.H. Mertens at the Hunt Institute; for letters to van Marum see Lefebvre &amp;
de Bruyn (1976), further letters at G.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: AG 5(1): 117; Backer p. 583; Barnhart 3: 381 (b. 10 Feb

<sm>NOTE</sm>: Jean Thouin (1756-1827), brother of André succeeded him as chief gardener at
the Mus. Hist. nat. Paris; André Thouin had succeeded his father Jean André Thouin
(1745-1768) in that function. An elder brother of André Thouin: Gabriel Thouin (1747-
1829) was the author of <em>Plans raisonnés de toutes les espèces de jardins</em>, Paris 1819 (ed. 3,
1828).

Thouvenin, Maurice [-François] (1857-?), French pharmacist and botanist; pharma-
cist Ist class Nancy 1884; Aggr. Ecol. sup. Pharmacie Paris 1884; Dr. Sci. nat. Paris
1890; chef des travaux pratiques École supérieure de pharmacie Nancy ca. 1884; teach-
ing at the École de médecine et de pharmacie Besançon ca. 1890. (<em>Thouvenin</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

Thozet, Anthelme (1826-1878), French-born Australian plant collector and gardener;
with the Sydney Botanic Gardens 1856-1858; to the Port Curtis goldfields, Queensland
1858; later cultivating economic plants on his property "Muellerville" at Rockhampton,
Queensland. (<em>Thozet</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: MEL; other material at K, M (lich.), P.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Backer p. 583; Barnhart 3: 381; BB p. 301; BM 5: 2105;
CSP 8: 1084; Desmond p. 611 (d. 31 Mai 1878); HR (bibl.); PR 9250; Rehder 5: 846.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Bull. Soc. bot. France 25 (bibl.): 191. 1879 (d.); Cat. gén. livr. impr.
	Bibl. natl. 188: 641-642. 1962; J. Bot. 16: 320. 1878 (d.).

Threlkeld, Caleb (1676-1728), British clergyman (dissenting minister) and botanist;
studied at the University of Glasgow 1696; minister at Kirk Oswald, Cumberland 1698-
1712, MD Edinburgh (1713); settled in Dublin 1713 as practicing physician. (<em>Threlkeld</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 381; BB p. 301; BL 2: 285-286, 723; BM 5:

1: 10227; Rehder 1: 394; Sotheby 749-750; Tucker 1: 689.

14.305. <em>Synopsis stirpium hibernicarum</em> alphabetice dispositarum, sive commentatio de
plantis indigenis praesertim Dublinensibus instituta. Being a short treatise of native
plants, especially such as grow spontaneously in the vicinity of Dublin; with their Latin,
English, and Irish names; and an abridgement of their vertues. With several new disco-
verys. With an appendix of observations made upon plants. By Dr. Molyneux, ... The

Thümen [-Gräfendorf], Felix [Karl Albert Ernst Joachim baron] von (1839-1892),
German (Saxonian) mycologist and phytopathologist; for a short time officer in the
Prussian army, subsequently administrating his property Gräfendorf nr Jüterborg,
Silesia, but turning more and more to botany as a full time occupation; from 1876
"Adjunct" at the Klosterneuburg (Niederösterreich) Experiment Station for viniculture
and fruit-growing nr. Wien. (<em>Thuem</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Thümen offered his herbarium for sale in Jun 1883; we are not
certain how it was disposed of; Hawksworth cites "PAD?" as a possible location of the
herbarium. Series of <em>exsiccatae</em>:
(<em>1</em>) <em>Mycotheca universalis</em>, cent. 1-23, nos. 1-2300, 1875-1884, for full details see Stevenson
(1971, p. 449-459). <em>Sets</em>: B (mainly destr.), BM, BPI, BR, BUC, C, CAS, DAOM, DBN,
DPU, ER, FH, FR, G, GRA, H, HBG, IA, ILL, ISC, K, KIEL, KSC, LE, LG, LPS,
M, MICH, MIN, MPU, NHES, NY, OXF, PAD, PAV, PC, PRC, PREM, RUTPP, S,
SOLH, STR, TLA, TO, UPS, W, WRSL. For index (1879) and for diagnoses of new
taxa (1876-1881), see below. Announcement by Thümen: Grevillea 3: 32. 1874. A copy
of Thümen's pamphlet describing the project (p. [1-2], dated Bayreuth Jul 1874), is at
G. – See also D. Pfister, Mycotaxon 23: 85. 1985.
(2) <em>Herbarium mycologicum oeconomicum</em>, fasc. 1-15, nos. 1-750, 1873-1880; for full details see
J. Stevenson) 1971, p. 460-463). <em>Sets</em>: B (extant), BPI, FR, GOET, GFW, ILL, K, LG,
MPU, NEB, PAV, S, UPS, W, WRSL. – See D. Pfister, Mycotaxon 23: 61. 1985.
(3) <em>Fungorum exoticorum decades</em>, dec. 1-5, nos. 1-50. 1879-1882. Sets at B (mainly destr.),
BPI, H, LG, UPS. – For diagnoses see Fungorum novorum exoticorum, Rev. mycol. 1:
9-11. 1879, 2: 36-38, 1880. – For details J. Stevenson (1971, p. 464-465).
(4) <em>Fungi austriaci exsiccati</em>, cent. 1-13, nos. 1-1300, 1871-1875. Sets at B (extant), BM,
BPI, FH, H, K, LG, PAD, S, UPS, W, WRSL.
(5) <em>Die Pilze der Gartengewächse und der landwirtschaftlichen Culturgewächse</em> in getrockneten
Exemplaren mit Abbildungen der Sporen, 50 species, 1872-1882. – See Herbarium 1:
132. 1910.
(6) <em>Die Pilze der Obstbäume</em> in getrockneten Exemplaren, mit Abbildungen der Sporen, 25
species, 1874-1880. – See Herbarium 1: 132. 1910.
(7) LG mentions <em>Les champignons de la vigne, Les champignons de grande culture, Choix de
Gasteromycètes</em>.
<em>Letters</em> to D.F.L. von Schlechtendal, at HAL, to W.G. Farlow at FH; further letters at G,
UPS-UB.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 381 (b. 6 Feb 1839, d. 13 Oct 1892); BM 5:

114 (bibl.); DTS 1: 299, 3: liii; Frank 3 (Anh.): 103; GR p. 50, cat. p. 72; Hawksworth
p. 186; Herder p. 73, 89, 245, 246, 247; IH 1 (ed. 6): 365, (ed. 7): 344; Jackson p. 167,
168, 170, 508; Kelly p. 226-227; Lenley p. 410; LS 3258, 26621-26765; Maiwald p. 92,

HEADING: THÜMEN

Urban-Berl. 283.

<sm>COMPOSITE</sm> <sm>WORKS</sm>: (1) D.N.F. Dietrich, <em>Forstflora</em>, ed. 6, Dresden 1885-1887, xix, 146 p.,

Thuillier, Jean Louis (1757-1822), French botanist and gardener at various gardens
in Paris, ultimately at the garden of the Collège Charlemagne. (<em>Thuill</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: G (through Delessert); some further material at P. – <em>Letters</em> at G.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: AG 2(1): 289, 4: 757; Backer p. 662; Barnhart 3: 382 (b.
22 Apr 1757, d. 18 Dec 1822); BM 5: 2108; Dryander 3: 142; Frank 3 (Anh.): 103; GR

PAGE: 306
HEADING: THUILLIER

p. 353; Hegi 4(2): 1034; Herder p. 175; Hortus 3: 1205; Kelly p. 226; Lasègue p. 72-73,
101, 296, 502; LS 26767; PR 9256, ed. 1: 2500, 10230; Rehder 1: 406; SO add. 742b,
add. 742c; TL-1/1298; TL-2/see J.P.B. Delessert; Tucker 1: 689; Zander ed. 10, p. 724,
ed. 11, p. 826.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Candolle, A.P. de, Mém. souvenirs 139. 1862.
Hoefer, ed., Nouv. biogr. gén. 45: 313-314. 1870.
Lacroix, A., Figures de savants 4: 140. 1938.
M.-R.-T., <em>in</em> J.Fr. Michaud, Biogr. univ. 41: 482-483. 1854f (facs. ed. 1970) (b. 22 Apr
	1757, d. 22 Nov 1822).
Sayre, G., Bryologist 80: 519. 1977 (mosses at G).

14.336. <em>Flore des environs de Paris</em>, ou distribution méthodique des plantes qui y croissent
naturellement, exécutée d'après le systême de Linnaeus, avec l'indication du temps de la
floraison de chaque plante, de la couleuer de ses fleurs, &amp; des lieux où l'on trouve les
espèces qui sont moins communes ... à Paris (chez la veuve Desaint, ...) 1790. Duod. (<em>Fl. env. Paris</em>).

<em>Ed</em>. [<em>1</em>]: 1790, p. [i*], [i]-viii, [1]-359, [360, err.]. <em>Copies</em>: B, G, HH, MICH, NY, USDA;
	IDC 6476.
<em>Ed. 2</em>: 24 Jun 1799 (Gazette nationale 28 Jun, 17 Jul 1799 fide M. Breistroffer through
	M. Kerguélen in lit.), p. [i]-xlviii, [1]-550. <em>Copies</em>: B, G, HH, KU, NY, USDA. – <em>La
	flore</em> ... naturellement, faite d'après le systême de Linnée: avec le nom et la description
	de chacune en latin et en françois; l'indication de leur lieu natal, de leur durée, du
	temps de leur floraison, de la couleur de leurs fleurs, et la citation des auteurs qui les
	ont mieux décrites ou en ont donné les meilleurs figures ... Nouvelle édition: revue,
	corrigée et considérablement augmentée. À Paris (chez l'auteur, ... H.L. Perronneau
	...) an VII. Oct.
<em>Reissue of ed. 2</em>: 1824, p. [i]-xlviii, [1]-550. <em>Copies</em>: HH, NY. – Title as ed. 2, Paris (chez
	Compère, ...) 1824. Oct.

14.337. <em>Le vade-mecum du botaniste voyageur</em> aux environs de Paris, à l'usage des personnes
qui ont la flore de J.-L. Thuillier: contenant la carte botanique portative de E.-P.
Ventenat; l'etymologie des genres publiés par cet auteur dans son Tableau du Règne
végétal, en 4 volumes, avec des planches; la floraison des plantes des environs de Paris,
les lieux généraux et particuliers où elles se trouvent; une carte topographique dressée
exprès pour guider le botaniste vers les endroits indiqués; et, pour la facilité des re-
cherches, six tables, dont une á sept colonnes. Redigé par C. [citoyen] D*** [Deshayes],
editeur de la carte botanique de la méthode naturelle de Jussieu, dressée d'après le
Tableau du Règne végétal de E.P. Ventenat ... Paris (Baudoin, ...) Floréal an xi
(1803). Duod. (<em>Vade-mecum bot. voy.</em>).

<em>Author</em>: Pierre Marie Deshayes (see Barnhart 1: 446; PR 2182 attributes the text to G.P.
	Deshayes).
<em>Publ</em>.: 21 Apr-20 Mai 1803 (Floréal an 3), p. [i]-xii, chart, [xiii], [1]-426, [427, err.].
	<em>Copies</em>: BR, USDA.
<em>Other issue</em>: 1807, chart [iii]-xii, [xiii], [1]-426, [427, err.]. <em>Copies</em>: B-S, HH. – À Paris
	(chez Pillot jeune, ...) 1807. Duod.
(<em>Le botaniste voyageur</em> aux ...).

Thunberg, Carl Peter (1743-1828), Swedish botanist; studied natural sciences and
medicine with e.g. Carl Linnaeus at Uppsala; Dr. phil. ib. 1767; Dr. med. ib. 1772 (in
absentia); studying in Amsterdam and Paris 1770-1772; at the Cape of Good Hope
1772-1775, to Java 1775; in Japan 1775-1776; again on Java 1776-1777; on Ceylon
1777-1778; in Holland 1778; back in Sweden 1779; appointed botanical demonstrator
Uppsala 1777 (under Linnaeus f.); extraordinary professor 1781, full professor of botany
and medicine at Uppsala, succeeding Linnaeus f. 1784-1828. (<em>Thunb</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: UPS (kept separate; available on IDC microfiche 1036; index
IDC 5184). Thunberg gave his entire herbarium to Uppsala University in 1785. By that
time it contained all the collections made during his travels as well as material received
from some of his colleagues such as the Forsters. After 1785 Thunberg continued to
insert material received by him in the "Thunberg herbarium" which was therefore for

PAGE: 307
HEADING: THUNBERG

the rest of his lifetime the official herbarium of the University. The most important set of
duplicates is now at S, through the herbaria of Alströmer and Montin. Other duplicates
are at B (extant; in the Willdenow herb.), BM (through Banks and from the sale of the
Lambert herbarium who obtained his Thunberg set with the Pallas collection), E, FI,
FR, G (in the Delessert herbarium which incorporates the Burman herbarium, probably
also a very important set), GB, GOET, H, JE, KIEL, L, LD (through the Acharius and
Retzius herbaria), LE (in the Ledebour herbarium), LINN (Linnaeus received direct
shipments of plants from the Cape), LIV, M, MEL (in the Lehmann herbarium),
MPU, MW, OXF, P, P-JU, PH, S, SBT (in the Bergius herbarium), U, W. – Juel
(1918) provides a list of all plants collected by Thunberg outside Sweden and of the
plants described or cited in Thunberg's botanical publications with reference to the
specimens in the Thunberg herbarium. – <em>Letters</em> received by Thunberg at Uppsala Univ-
ersity Library, A-HJO available on IDC microfiche 7646; letters to <em>Banks</em> at BM, to J.E.
Smith at LINN; to C.H. Mertens at HU, other letters at G. A mss. <em>Flora capensis</em>, pre-
1782, is at BM.

<sm>MAIN</sm> <sm>COLLECTORS</sm> represented in the Thunberg herbarium:
<em>Afzelius, Adam</em> (1750-1837), (TL-2/1:11-13), plants collected in England and Scotland
	(incl. Kew and Oxford bot. gardens) and a considerable set of his plants from Sierra
	Leone.
<em>Ahlquist, Abraham</em> (1794-1844), plants from Runsten, Öland.
<em>Agardh, Carl Adolph</em> (1785-1859), (TL-2/1: 13-18), a few plants from his earlier years.
<em>Alströmer, Clas</em> (1736-1794), (TL-2/1: 38-39), plants from Spain.
<em>Aspegren, Georg Casten</em> (1791-1828), (TL-2/1: 78), plants from Blekinge.
<em>Aublet, Jean Baptiste Christophe Fusée</em> (1720-1778), (TL-2/1: 79-80), some 60-80 plants
	from French Guiana.
<em>Banks, Joseph</em> (1743-1820), (TL-2/1: 115-118), many specimens collected by Banks and
	Solander on Cook's first voyage, mainly from Tahiti (Otaheite), New Zealand (Nova
	Cambria), Australia (Nova Hollandia).
<em>Bartram, John</em> (1699-1777), (TL-2/1: 131-132).
<em>Bartram, William</em> (1739-1823), (TL-2/1: 132-135), a few specimens labelled "Bartram"
	may have been collected either by John B. or by his son William. Thunberg may have
	obtained these specimens from J. Banks.
<em>Bauer, Ferdinand Lukas</em> (1760-1826), (TL-2/1: 145-146), plants from Norfolk Island, rd
	from J.E. Smith.
<em>Bellardi, Carlo Antonio Lodovico</em> (1741-1826), (TL-2/1: 169-170), plants from Piedmont.
<em>Bergius, Peter Jonas</em> (1730-1790), (TL-2/1: 190-191), plants labelled "ex herbario Bergii"
	may have been collected by Bergius himself in Sweden, or by other botanists represen-
	ted in B.'s herbarium.
<em>Bladh, Peter Johan</em> (1746-1816), plants collected around Canton, near Macao and some
	algae "e mari chinensi".
<em>Bonsdorff, Gabriel von</em> (1762-1831), Finnish plants.
<em>Bosc, Louis Auguste Guillaume</em> (Bosc d'Antic") (1759-1828), (TL-2/1: 287-288), some
	plants from the Carolinas.
<em>Brass, William</em> (x-1783), plants from Cape Coast Castle, Gold Coast.
<em>Broberg</em> (gardener at Uppsala in the 18th century), plants from the Paris and Kew
	botanical gardens.
<em>Brown, Robert</em> (1773-1858), (TL-2/1: 364-369), a considerable set of plants from Australia
	(Port Lincoln, Port Jackson, et al.) and Tasmania ("Ins. v. Diemen").
<em>Browne, Patrick</em> (1720-1790), (TL-2/1:371-372), duplicates from his Jamaican herbarium.
<em>Buek, Johannes Nicolaus</em> (1736-1812), (TL-2/1: 399, note) plants cultivated in his garden
	at Hamburg.
<em>Burman, Nicolaas Laurens</em>, Sr. (1733-1793), ((TL-2/1:416-417). Some material from the
	Cape from "Burmann". This may stem from both N.L. Burman Sr. and Jr. Plants
	labelled "Ex herbario Burmann" may be of various origin (P. Hermann, Oldenland,
	Hartog, Tryon, Kleinhoff, Garcin; European correspondents of the Burmans) which
	is difficult to establish.
<em>Burman, Nicolaas Laurens</em> Jr. (1782-1826), see above: some Cape material may stem from
	S. African plants grown in his garden at Loenen a.d. Vecht, Netherlands.
<em>Cavanilles, Antoine José</em> (1745-1804), (TL-2/1: 471-474), specimens from the Madrid and

PAGE: 308
HEADING: THUNBERG

	Paris botanical gardens, and from his own collecting trips in Spain. Thunberg also
	received Peruvian specimens from Cavanilles; they may stem from Dombey or from
	Ruiz and Pavon.
<em>Collinson, Peter</em> (1694-1768), (TL-2/1: 528), specimens labelled "Collins(on) ex America
	boreali" are probably duplicates from the Linnaean herbarium; the location of
	Collinson's original herbarium is not known.
<em>Commerson, Philibert</em> (1727-1773), (TL-2/1: 532-533), a considerable set of plants e.g.
	from Magelhaes, Tahiti ("Otahiti", or "Otaheite"), Mauritius ("Ile de France"),
	Réunion (Ile Bourbon).
<em>Dryander, Jonas Carlsson</em> (1748-1810), (TL-2/1: 686-687), plants from e.g. Kew Gardens
	and specimens from the L.J. Montin herbarium.
<em>Ehrhart, Friedrich</em> (1742-1795), (TL-2/1: 731-734), plants from the Harz (Hercynia)
	region and from Ehrhart's Hannover garden.
<em>Fahlberg, Samuel</em> (1758-1834), (TL-2/1: 811), West Indian plants.
<em>Fontana, Felice</em> (1730-1805), Italian naturalist at Florence; Italian plants collected or at
	any rate sent by him; some Mediterranean algae.
<em>Forselles, Jacob Hemic af</em> (1785-1855), Swedish mining engineer in the Sala (Väs-
	tmanland) silver mines; plants "in Finlandiae littoribus".
<em>Forsskål, Pehr</em> (1732-1763), (TL-2/1: 855-857), small set, annotated by Thunberg with
	references to the Flora aegyptiaco-arabica.
<em>Forsström, Johan Eric</em> (1775-1824), (TL-2/1: 857), plants from Lapland, Finmark and the
	West Indies (Forsström sent plants directly to Uppsala University as well as to the
	Swedish Academy of Sciences. After his death his collections went to Gustaf Johan
	Billberg (1772-1844) (TL-2/1: 215), with whom he had arranged that the collections
	of the first of them to die would go to the other. Part of the Billberg collection went
	through G.J. Billberg's children to BM.
<em>Forster, Johan Reinhold</em> (1729-1798) and <em>Forster, Johan Georg Adam</em> (1754-1794) (TL-2/1:
	859-861 and 857-859), a considerable number of plants from Cook's second voyage
	(1772-1775); see H.O. Juel, Sv. Linné-Sällsk. Årsskr. 7: 68-82. 1924 for a discussion of
	the importance of Thunberg's set of Forster plants. – A number of sheets in the
	Thunberg herbarium carry the annotation "Forster, Botany Bay". This Bay, in
	Australia, was an important collecting area of Banks and Solander on Cook's <em>first</em>
	voyage; the Forsters did not visit this region.
<em>Freyreiss, Georg Wilhelm</em> (1789-1825), (TL-2/1: 877-878), important set of plants collected
	in the Rio de Janeiro region and in Minas Geraes ("Villa Rica", now Ouro Preto).
	Freyreiss was employed 1815-1818 by Lorentz Westin (q.v.), which explains why
	most Freyreiss plants in the Thunberg herbarium carry both names. – Freyreiss's
	plants were described in <em>Plantarum brasiliensium</em> dec. 1, 2, 1817, 1818.
<em>Gåsevadsholm</em>. The garden of Clas Alströmer (q.v.) at Gåsevadsholm, south of Göteborg,
	Sweden. Some plants so labelled are in the Thunberg herbarium.
<em>Gedner, Christopher Eliasson</em> (1729-1773), Swedish physician (M.D. Berlin 1755, id.
	Uppsala 1758), government physician in Värmland (1764-1773), at least one plant "e
	Roslagia Sueciae" in the Thunberg herbarium.
<em>Gestrin, Samuel</em> (1764-1815), Swedish teacher at Gävle who owned a natural history
	cabinet. Some specimens "in alpibus genitidis" collected by Gestrin; it is not certain
	that these plants were indeed collected by S. Gestrin.
<em>Gouan, Antoine</em> (1733-1821), (TL-2/1: 975-976), a small number of plants collected in S.
	France.
<em>Grönda</em>(<em>h</em>)<em>l, Carl Fredrik</em> (1760-1816), Swedish-Finnish physician and naturalist, studied
	at Åbo (1781) and Stockholm (1786-1788), hospital physician in Finland 1789-1790,
	ship's surgeon on two Swedish East India Company's voyages between 1790 and
	1795. Several plants collected on his voyages with the annotations Java [sic, at least
	one specimen], China and Mauritius ("Ile de France"); see SK 5: clxxxi-cclxxxii;
	<em>letters</em> to Thunberg in Uppsala Univ. Libr. see IDC 7646.
<em>Hagen, Karl Gottfried</em> (1749-1829), (TL-2/2: 11-12), some plants collected in the Berlin
	botanical garden.
<em>Hall, Birger Mårten</em> (1741-1814), (see KR p. 258), Swedish physician, MD Uppsala
	1768; government physician in southern Västmanland 1773-1793; some plants from
	Västmanland ("Westmannia").

PAGE: 309
HEADING: THUNBERG

<em>Hartman, Carl Johan</em> (1790-1849), (TL-2/2: 65-67), student of Thunberg; Dr. med.
	Uppsala 1822; some Swedish plants.
<em>Hermann, Paul</em> (1646-1695), (TL-2/2: 171-173), some specimens.
<em>Hildebrand, Jacob Henrik</em> (1742-1759?) and <em>Hildebrand, Claes Henrik</em> (1743-1809), Swedish
	officers in contact with Linnaeus; plants from Spain.
<em>Hornstedt, Claës Fredric</em> (1758-1809), Finnish naturalist; Dr. med. Greifswald 1786; col-
	lections from Lapland, Cape of Good Hope, East Indies (incl. Java). See KR p. 307-
	308, SK 1: 242-243.
<em>Hortus aboensis</em>, Botanical garden of Åbo [Turku] University in Finland. Plants from the
	garden supplied by e.g. Bonsdorff, Forselles, Prytz, Radloff, Sahlberg.
<em>Hortus amstelodamensis</em>, plants from the Amsterdam botanical garden may stem mostly
	from Thunberg's visits to this garden in 1770, 1771 and 1778.
<em>Hortus berolinensis</em>, plants from the Botanical garden of the Berlin Academy of Sciences;
	Thunberg received plants from Hagen (visitor) and Willdenow (director 1794-1812).
<em>Hortus goettingensis</em>, plants from the Göttingen botanical garden may have been provided
	by Karl Theodor Menke (q.v.) who studied there c. 1811.
<em>Hortus gryphicus</em>, plants from the Greifswald botanical garden may have been supplied by
	C.E. Weigel (director 1775-1805) or by several of Thunberg's students.
<em>Hortus hafniensis Georgii</em>, Thunberg collected in the old Amaliegade botanical garden of
	Copenhagen in 1770; the indication Georgii refers to Georg Christian Oeder (1728-
	1791), director 1752-1770, TL-2/3: 803-807.
<em>Hortus hamburgensis</em>, garden of the horticulturist J.N. Buek, q.v.
<em>Hortus hannoveranus</em>, garden of the Herrenhausen palace nr Hannover. Plants from this
	garden come mainly from F. Ehrhart, q.v.
<em>Hortus kewensis</em>, plants simply labelled "ex horto kewensi" as well as material sent by
	Afzelius, Broberg and Dryander (q.v.).
<em>Hortus leidensis</em> Thunberg visited the Leiden botanical garden on 16 and 17 October 1770
	and stated in his <em>Travels</em> that he collected rare plants for his herbarium.
<em>Hortus parisiensis</em>, ... The <em>Jardin des plantes</em>, also called <em>Jardin du Roi</em>, Paris. Several travel-
	lers sent plants to Thunberg collected in the Paris garden such as the gardener
	Broberg and the physician Mellerborg. A number of sheets from the Paris garden
	carry no collector's name; some may have been sent by Antoine-Laurent de Jussieu.
<em>Hortus trianonensis</em>, ... the garden connected with the Trianon at Versailles. A few plants
	in the Thunberg herbarium stem from this garden collected by Linnaean and
	Thunberg students. Thunberg himself visited the garden in July 1770.
<em>Hortus upsaliensis</em> ... Plants from the botanical garden of Uppsala University, collected
	by Thunberg himself and by Broberg, the gardener who served under Linnaeus,
	Linnaeus f. and Thunberg.
<em>Host, Nicolaus Thomas</em> (1761-1834), (TL-2/2: 339-340), a small set of Austrian plants.
<em>Hove, Anton Pantaleon</em> ("Howe", "Awe", "Au"), (<em>fl</em>. 1780S-1820S), Polish-born plant col-
	lector for Kew, on Guinea coast 1785, in India 1787-1788, Crimea 1796 (see
	Desmond p. 324). Plants from the Bombay region (India) in the Thunberg her-
	barium, some labelled "Achmad" (Ahmadabad, Amdabad), or "Sabermathy"
	(Sabermathi River).
<em>Hudson, William</em> (1730-1793), (TL-2/2: 354-356), a number of plants "ex Hudsons
	collect".
<em>Hultgren</em> (no details known to us), plants collected in New Jersey and Pennsylvania).
<em>Jacquin, Nicolaus Joseph von</em> (1727-1817), (TL-2/2: 407-413), Austrian plants collected by
	J. and plants from Austrian gardens.
<em>Kalm, Pehr</em> (1716-1779), (TL-2/2: 487-490), several specimens from N. America.
<em>Koenig, Johan Gerhard</em> (1728-1785), (TL-2/2: 600-601). A number of plants collected in
	Ceylon and India (e.g. "Mallabaria" on some sheets).
<em>Lapeyrouse, Philippe Picot baron de</em> (1744-1818), (TL-2/2: 756-757), a considerable number
	of plants from the Pyrenees and "Cantabria" (Spanish Oviedo, Santander, Vizcaya,
	Guipúzcoa).
<em>Lebeck, H.J.</em> (x-1800), Dutch merchant and botanist, active in India, Ceylon and
	Indonesia (for details see SK 5(4): 61-62), specimens "e Java", "e Mallabaria", "e
	Coromandelia". Unique set.
<em>Ledebour, Carl Friedrich von</em> (1785-1851), (TL-2/2: 805-808), an appreciable number of

PAGE: 310
HEADING: THUNBERG

	specimens labelled Astrakan, Bessarabia, Kamchatka, Livonia, Persia, Siberia. Some
	specimens "ex Ibiria p. Ledebour".
<em>Liljeblad, Samuel</em> (1761-1815), (TL-2/3: 17-18), Swedish and Lapland plants.
<em>Lindroth, Pehr Gustaf</em> (1758-1809), Swedish military surgeon who made natural history
	collections and who undertook a collecting trip to Norway; plants from Lapland ("ex
	alp. Lapp.") in Thunberg herb.
<em>Ljungh, Sven Ingemar</em> (1757-1828), Swedish administrator, studied in Uppsala; County
	treasurer of the Vedb[fix] district in Småland (1780-1793); plants from Småland. – Most
	collections at LD (herb. Acharius).
<em>Lundmark, Johan Daniel</em> (1755-1792), (TL-2/3: 196-197), specimens from Lapland.
<em>Marschall von Bieberstein, Friedrich August</em> (1768-1826), (TL-2/3: 305-306), plants in
	Thunberg herbarium marked "e Tauria", or "e Taurica" designating the Crimea
	(and not the Tabris anc. Tauris) region.
<em>Masson, Francis</em> (1741-1805), (TL-2/3: 361-363), numerous specimens from the Canaries,
	Madeira, Teneriffe, the Azores, St. Helena and the Cape of Good Hope.
<em>Melierborg, Claes Erik</em> (1773-1828), Swedish naval physician in the East India Company;
	student of Thunberg; travelled widely in Europe; in the East Indies 1826-1827; plants
	from his European tours in Thunberg herbarium, Java material in LD and S.
<em>Mencke</em> or <em>Menke, Karl Theodor</em> (1791-1861), plants collected by Mencke or Menke in the
	Göttingen botanical garden. This may have been the German physician Karl
	Theodor Menke who studied at Göttingen.
<em>Meyer</em> ... A few plants labelled "Meyer, Germania". It is difficult to say which Meyer is
	meant (Georg Friedrich Wilhelm, 1782-1856 at Göttingen?).
<em>Miller, Philip</em> (1691-1771), (TL-2/3: 491-499), a few sheets only, possibly received by
	Thunberg through Linnaeus.
<em>Montin, Lars Jonasson</em> (1723-1785), (TL-2/3: 565-566), a few specimens from Sweden;
	some sheets of the Montin herbarium with his handwriting.
<em>Mutis y Bosio, José Célestino Bruno</em> (1732-1808), (TL-2/3: 676-677), a few plants labelled
	"Mexico" (duplicates received from Linnaeus fil.?).
<em>Nyström</em>, unidentified; a small number of plants collected by him at the Cape, in the East
	Indies and in China.
<em>Oldenburg, Franz Pehr</em> (1740-1774), Swedish soldier, traveller, and plant collector who
	accompanied Francis Masson on his first trip in the interior of South Africa; accom-
	panied Thunberg on his trips around Cape Town in 1772; went to Madagascar,
	collected and died there 1774. – Plants from Madagascar in Thunberg herb.; see IH
	2(5): 619.
<em>Oldenland, Henrik Bernard</em> (x-1699), (TL-2/3: 817-818), some specimens from the Cape,
	possibly obtained from the Burman family; see also IH 2(5): 619.
<em>Osbeck, Carl Gustaf</em> (1766-1841), Swedish physician, studied at Lund, collected specimens
	at Cape of Good Hope as ship's surgeon on two Swedish East India Company's
	voyages in 1797-1798 and 1799-1800.
<em>Osbeck, Pehr</em> (1723-1805), (TL-2/3: 851-852), numerous specimens collected at Canton,
	Cape of Good Hope, Java, Ascension. [Pehr O. never landed at the Cape; he saw
	some seaweeds outside the Cape and described <em>Fucus maximus</em> [Ecklonia maxima] from
	this area].
<em>Pallas, Peter Simon</em> (1741-1811), (TL-2/4: 20-27), a considerable number of Pallas speci-
	mens from Siberia (e.g. Dauria, Baikal, Orenburg).
<em>Peck, William Dandridge</em> (1763-1822), (TL-2/4: 142-143), plants from "Massachusetts",
	in part also coming from the White Mountains, New Hampshire.
<em>Pentz, Henrik Christian</em> (1738-1803), Swedish politician who owned a large natural history
	cabinet which was dispersed upon his death. Both the Alströmer and Thunberg her-
	baria have specimens labelled "Pentz China". However, Pentz is not known to have
	visited China; the plants must stem from a different collector.
<em>Pihl, C.F</em>., a Swedish physician who collected at Porto-Bello, Panama; 50 species in SBT,
	some duplicates in Thunberg herb.
<em>Poiret, Jean-Louis-Marie</em>, (1755-1834), (TL-2/4: 319-321), plants from N. Africa.
<em>Pourret</em>, [<em>De Figeac</em>], Pierre André (1754-1818), (TL-2/4: 368-369), some plants from
	Pourret's time at Narbonne as well as from Spain.
<em>Pryss, Ulrik</em> (1767-1791), Swedish physician at Åbo (Turku), who owned a natural
	history collection; plants from Åbo ("Prytz").

PAGE: 311
HEADING: THUNBERG

<em>Radioff, Fredric Wilhelm</em> (1766-1838), (TL-2/4: 546), plants from Åbo (Turku).
<em>Roemer, Johann Jakob</em> (1763-1819), (TL-2/4: 844-848), some plants from Switzerland
	("Römer, Helvetia").
<em>Rohr, Julius Philip Benjamin von</em> (ca. 1737-1793), (TL-2/4: 864-865). Rohr sent his collect-
	ions to Rottbøll and Vahl, who in turn probably sent some of the Rohr material to
	Thunberg. This is difficult to identify since Thunberg annotated such specimens as
	"Ex insulis amer. calid. per Vahl" or "Ex insulae Trinitatis per Vahl".
<em>Rosén, Eberhard</em> (1714-1796), (TL-2/4: 887), plants from S. Sweden labelled "Rosén"
	may stem from Eberhard rather than Nils Rosén (1706-1773).
<em>Rosén, Johan Peter</em> (1788-?), (KR p. 596-597), Swedish botanist and horticulturist,
	curator of a botanic garden in Stockholm after 1825, travelled in Gotland 1816-1818;
	plants from Gotland and Öland in Thunberg herb.
<em>Rothman, Georg</em> (Göran) (1739-1778), (TL-2/4: 925-926), material labelled "Rothman e
	Tripoli" may stem from Georg R., his father Johan Stenson Rothman (TL-2/4: 926-
	927) (Linnaeus's secondary school teacher) or from still another Rothman. The elder
	Rothman is known to have possessed a natural history cabinet. The "e Tripoli" might
	point to a different collector.
<em>Rottler, Johann Peter</em> (1749-1836), (TL-2/4: 933), plants from Tranquebar and the
	Coromandel coast in general.
<em>Roxburgh, William</em> (1751-1815), (TL-2/4: 954-958), a small set of plants from
	Coromandel.
<em>Rudolphi</em>, [<em>Israel</em>] <em>Karl Asmund</em> (1771-1832), (TL-2/4: 974-975), plants from S. France
	(Marseille).
<em>Sahlberg, Carl Reinhold</em> (1779-1860), (TL-2/4: 1057-1058), plants from the Åbo (Turku)
	botanical garden.
<em>Savi, Gaetano</em> (1769-1844), (TL-2/5: 84-87), plants from Italy (e.g. "prope Livorno").
<em>Schleicher, Johann Christoph</em> (1768-1834), (TL-2/5: 213-214), plants from Switzerland (esp.
	Salix).
<em>Schousbou, Peter Kofod Anker</em> (1766-1834), (TL-2/5: 309-310), material from Denmark,
	from the 1791-1793 trip to Spain, Portugal and Morocco, as well as from Morocco
	and adjacent Algeria and Tanger collected in later years.
<em>Schrader, Heinrich Adolph</em> (1767-1836), (TL-2/5: 316-320), cultivated plants from
	Germany.
<em>Schwaegrichen, Christian Friedrich</em> (1775-1853), (TL-2/5: 416-419), plants from the
	Austrian Alps.
<em>Schweigger, August Friedrich</em> (1783-1821), (TL-2/5: 428-430), plants from Austria and the
	Pyrenees ("Schweiger" and "Schweigger").
<em>Scopoli, Joannes Antonius</em> (Giovanni Antonio) (1723-1788), (TL-2/5: 453-456). The
	Scopoli material in the Thunberg herbarium consists of specimens of plants grown in
	the Uppsala Botanic Garden from seed sent by Scopoli to Linnaeus ("cult. in hort.
	Ups. sem. ex Italia Scopoli").
<em>Sibthorp, John</em> (1758-1796), (TL-2/5: 577-580). Thunberg received from J.E. Smith
	plants collected by Sibthorp in Greece.
<em>Smith, James Edward</em> (1759-1828), (TL-2/5: 678-691). Thunberg obtained many plants
	from Smith. These are mostly annotated with the name of the original collector, but
	there are also annotations "p. Smith". A collection from Norfolk Island, collected by
	Ferdinand Bauer, is thus designated; the plants from Greece were collected by J.
	Sibthorp; early collections from Australia are from John White. Smith also sent dup-
	licates from the Linnaean herbarium to Thunberg.
<em>Solander, Daniel</em> [<em>Carlsson</em>] (1733-1782), (TL-2/5: 721-723), many specimens collected by
	Banks and Solander on Cook's first voyage, see under J. Banks for further details.
<em>Sparrman, Anders</em> [Andreas] (1748-1820), (TL-2/5: 773-775), plants from the Cape of
	Good Hope and from Senegal.
<em>Steven, Christian von</em> (1781-1863), (TL-2/5: 911-915), numerous plants from Russia ("ad
	Volgam", "e Caucaso", "e Tauria " [Crimea]) and Siberia (sometimes as "Stephen e
	Siberia").
<em>Swartz, Olof Peter</em> (1760-1818) (TL-2/6: nos. 13.525-13.541) material from Sweden (e.g.
	from Lapland), West Indies (Jamaica, Hispaniola, Montserrat, St. Cristopher [ = St.
	Kitts].

PAGE: 312
HEADING: THUNBERG

<em>Tenore, Michele</em> (1780-1861) (TL-2/6: nos. 13.898-13.946), Italian plants (e.g. from
	Calabria and Napoli).
<em>Thunberg, Carl Peter</em> (1743-1828), see first paragraph of <em>Herbarium and types</em>, above, and
	Juel (1918).
<em>Törner, Samuel</em> (1762-?), Swedish naturalist; studied at Uppsala (i.a. under Thunberg),
	assistant to Dryander in Bank's library 1792-1797; plants from Finland and Sweden.
<em>Turner, Dawson</em> (1775-1858), English botanist, antiquary and banker; some British algae.
	Main collections at K (in deposit at BM).
<em>Vahl, Martin</em> (1749-1804), Danish botanist at Copenhagen; The Thunberg herbarium
	contains many plants collected by Vahl as well as several sets of plants collected by
	others supplied by Vahl. Vahl collections from the Mediterranean (1783-1785) are
	from e.g. Spain, Tunisia, Algeria and Italy. West Indian plants received through
	Vahl are mostly duplicates of collections by Julius von Rohr, q.v.; some of these
	plants may also stem from John Ryan (Trinidad), Hans West (St. Croix), or Martfelt
	(Guadeloupe).
<em>Viborg</em> (Wiborg), <em>Erik Nissen</em> (1759-1822), Danish botanist and veterinarian; professor at
	Copenhagen University and id. Veterinary school; plants labelled "p. Wiborg" "e
	Coromandelia", and "ex India orientalis" were probably collected by Rottler, q.v.
<em>Villars, Dominique</em> (1745-1814), French physician and botanist in the Dauphiné; plants
	from this region ("e Delphinati") and from the Pyrenees.
<em>Wahlberg, Pehr Fredrik</em> (1800-1877), Swedish botanist, student of Thunberg; Dr. phil.
	1824; Dr. med. 1827; professor of materia medica at the Karolinska Institutet, Stock-
	holm 1827-1865; some plants from "Gothoburg".
<em>Wahlenberg, Georg</em> (from 1804: Göran) (1780-1851), Swedish botanist; Dr. med. Uppsala
	1806; professor of botany and medicine ib., succeeding Thunberg 1829; a consi-
	derable number of plants from his travels in Pomerania, Lapland and Northern
	Norway, Switzerland, the Carpathics and Värmland.
<em>Weigel, Christian Ehrenfried</em> (after 1806 von Weigel) (1748-1831), German botanist;
	studied at Göttingen; Dr. med. ib. 1771; professor of botany and chemistry at Gre-
	ifswald 1775-1805; many plants from the Greifswald botanical garden ("Hortus
	gryphicus").
<em>Westin, Lorentz</em> (1787-1846), Swedish consul in Rio de Janeiro who employed G.W.
	Freyreiss (q.v.) in 1815-1818 to collect plants and animals for Swedish institutions;
	numerous plants from Rio de Janeiro and Minas Geraes sent by Westin but mostly
	collected by Freyreiss; some Rio de Janeiro plants actually collected by Westin.
<em>White, John</em> (c. 1756-1832), British naval surgeon, chief surgeon New South Wales 1786,
	sent plants to J.E. Smith, some of which came to Thunberg "p. Smith". The main set
	is in the Smith herbarium (LINN); the Lambert set is at G.
<em>Wickman</em> [Vickman], <em>Daniel</em> (1741-1800), Swedish physician, student of Linnaeus; Dr.
	med. Uppsala 1780; government physician in Filipstad 1792-1800; plants collected in
	Värmland by "Vickman" in Thunberg herb. (see also KR p. 760).
<em>Wikström, Johan Emanuel</em> (1789-1856), Swedish botanist; student of Thunberg (Dr. med.
	1817), curator of the herbarium of the Riksmuseum, Stockholm from 1818; some
	plants from Sweden.
<em>Willdenow, Karl Ludwig</em> (1765-1812), German botanist; Dr. med. Halle 1789; professor of
	botany and director of the botanical garden at Berlin; plants from Prussia ("e
	Borussia") collected by him and other plants without further indication from his
	herbarium.
<em>Withering, William</em> (1741-1799), British physician and botanist; M.D. Edinburgh 1766;
	practiced at Stafford and Birmingham; a small number of specimens from England.
<em>Wurmb, Frederik</em> baron <em>von</em> (x-1781), Dutch colonial administrator; several specimens
	"Von Wurmb Nova Guinea".
<em>Zeyher, Johann Michael</em> (1770-1843), German botanist; director of the garden of the
	grand-duke of Baden at Schwetzingen nr Mannheim (not to be confused with his
	nephew who collected, later, in South Africa); a considerable number of plants re-
	ceived from him, not necessarily collected by him ("per Zeyher") from S. France, E.
	Pyrenees, N. America and Sicily.
<em>Zuccagni, Attilio</em> (1754-1807), Italian botanist; director of the garden of the "Museo di
	fisica e storia naturale" in Firenze; Italian plants. – The original herbarium was at FI
	but was "eliminated" by Parlatore because of insect damage and absence of localities.

PAGE: 313
HEADING: THUNBERG

<sm>PLANTAE</sm> <sm>THUNBERGIANAE</sm>, [H.O. Juel], Ein Verzeichnis der von C.P. Thunberg in
Südafrika, Indien und Japan gesammelten und der in seinen Schriften beschriebenen
oder erwähnten Pflanzen, sowie von den Exemplaren derselben, die im Herbarium
Thunbergianum in Upsala aufbewahrt sind, Uppsala, Leipzig 1918, frontisp. portr.
Thunberg, iii, 462 p., Arb. utg. Vilh. Ekmans Univ.-Fond. Uppsala 21 (biogr. introd.,
list of Th.'s publications, list of publications by others in which Th.'s plants are de-
scribed and an annotated list of taxa (see TL-2/3430).

14.431. <em>Miscellaneous papers regarding Japanese plants</em> written by C.P. Thunberg. Tokyo
(Shokubutsu Bunken Kanko-kai) 1935. (<em>Misc. pap. Jap. pl.</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: 1935, 2 frontisp., p. [i-iv], 1-542, (1)-(20), [1, colo.]. <em>Copies</em>: B, G, MICH, U.

Thurber, George (1821-1890), American botanist and chemist; quartermaster and
commissary on the United States Boundary Commission to settle the boundary between
the United States and Mexico 1850-1853; with the United States Assay Office in New
York 1853-1856; lecturer on botany and materia medica College of Pharmacy, New
York, 1856-1860, 1865-1866; professor of botany and head of the Michigan Agricultural
College 1859-1863; editor of the American Agriculturist 1863-1885; president of the
Torrey Botanical Club succeeding J. Torrey 1873-1880. (<em>Thurb</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: MO and GH; further material at B (mainly destr.), BR, BUF, F,
K, MASS, NA, NY, PH, US. – The set of Boundary Plants at CAS was burnt in 1906.
<em>Library</em> and <em>Manuscripts</em> at GH. <em>Letters</em> to W.G. Farlow at FH, to J. Torrey at NY; other
letters at G, GH.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 382 (b. 2 Sep 1821, d. 2 Apr 1890); BM 5:
2111; Bossert p. 400; CSP 19: 116; DAB 18: 514-515; Ewan ed. 1: 64, 321, ed. 2: 220;
Frank 3 (Anh.): 103; Hortus 3: 1205; IH 1 (ed. 6): 365, (ed. 7): 344; Lenley p. 410, 470
(letter to Torrey); ME 1: 234, 3: 666; Morren ed. 2. p. 56, ed. 10, p. 127; PH 164, 567;
PR 4555; Rehder 2: 403; SIA 220; TL-2/2128, 3203, 9657; see A. Gray, P.K.A. Schous-
boe; Tucker 1: 14, 690; Urban-Berl. 403.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Amer. Agriculturist 49: 284. 1890 (obit., portr.); Bot. Gaz. 15: 126. 1890
	(obit. not.); Bull. Torrey bot. Club 17: 112. 1890 (d.); Garden &amp; Forest 3: 173. 1890
	(obit.); Maine Natural. 6: 171-174. 1926 (information accompanying a reprint of his
	"Notes of an excursion to Mount Katahdin"); USDA Div. Entom., Insect life 3: 4.
	1891 (obit. not.); Who was who Amer. hist. vol. 602. 1967.

Day, M.A., Rhodora 3: 244. 1901.

	dency club).

paedia</em>.

report as a whole is dated 1861.

Thurén, Alfred Fredrik Abraham (1840-?), Finnish botanist. (<em>Thurén</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

Thuret, Gustave Adolphe (1817-1875), French botanist (phycologist) of private
means; studied law in Paris; Lic. droit. 1838, devoting himself to botanical research after
having served for a short time as attaché to the French embassy in Constantinople 1840-
1841; in Rentilly nr Paris until 1847, at Versailles 1847-1852, at Cherbourg 1852-1856;
from 1856-1875 at Cap d'Antibes (Villa Thuret) collaborating with J.B.E. Bornet.
(<em>Thur</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: PC (cryptogamic collections; see Bornet 1912), G (Alpes-
maritimes herbarium; through Burnat); other cryptogams at BR, CGE, FI, KIEL, L
(alg.), M (lich.), MPU (alg.), TCD (lich.), W. – <em>Letters</em> to W.G. Farlow at FH, other
letters at G, UPS-UB.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: AG 6(1): 105; Barnhart 3: 382 (b. 23 Mai 1917, d. 10
Mai 1875); BM 1: 203, 5: 2111; Bossert p. 400; CSP 5: 987-988, 8: 1085, 11: 600, 12:
730, 19: 116; De Toni 1: cxxii-cxxiii; DSB 13: 394-396 (J. Feldmann); Frank 3 (Anh.):
103-104; Herder p. 254; IH 1 (ed. 6): 365, (ed. 7): 344, 2: (files); Jackson p. 156, 157,
159, 452; JW 1: 452; KR p. 716; Lasègue p. 314, 405, 503; Moebius p. 457 [index];
Morren, ed. 2, p. 17; NI 1961-1962; Plesch p. 434; PR 9334-9335, 1015; Rehder 1: 240,
528; Sotheby 753; Stevenson p. 1260; TL-1/1310; TL-2/158, 663, 3125, see E. Burnat;
Tucker 1: 690.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Cat. gén. livr. impr. Bibl. natl. 188: 886-888. 1962; Gard. Chron. ser. 2.
	4: 40-41. 1875 (obit.); Grand Larousse encycl. 10: 322. 1964; J. Bot. 13: 254. 1875
	(d.); J. Bot. 16: 96. 1878. (Villa Thuret becomes Medit. "appanage to the Paris
	Jardin des plantes"); Proc. Linn. Soc. London 1874-5: lxvi-lxix. 1875 (obit.).
Bornet, Éd., Ann. Sci. nat. Bot., ser. 6. 2: 308-360. 1875 (also reprinted, 55 p.) (obit.);
	Bull. Soc. bot. France 59: 297-301. 1876; Mém. Soc. natl. Sci. nat. Cherbourg 20: 5-
	68. 1876 (detailed obit., bibl.).
Bureau, E., Bull. Soc. bot. France 22: 152. 1875 (d.), 22 (bibl.): 45. 1875 (d.), 24 (bibl.):
	236-237. 1878 (Villa Thuret acquired for frs. 200.000 by Thuret's widow from
	Thuret's brother; donated to the state, to be attached to the Muséum d'Hist. nat. and
	the botanical div. of Paris Univ.).
Burnat, É., Bull. Soc. bot. France 30: cxxxii. 1883; Boissiera 5: 24-25. 1945.

	Burnat).

Laundon, J.R., Lichenologist 11: 14. 1979 (lichens A. Michaux in PC-Thuret).

14.442. <em>Études phycologiques</em> ... Analyses d'algues marines par M. Gustave Thuret
publiées par les soins de M. le Dr. Édouard Bornet. Ouvrage accompagné de cinquante
planches gravées d'après les dessins de M. Alfred Riocreux. Paris (G. Masson, ...) 1878.
Fol. (<em>Étud. phycol.</em>).

<em>Authorship</em>: Thuret, upon his death, left 40 plates intended for a comprehensive illus-
	trated work on the sexuality of the algae, a summary of a lifetime of research. Bornet
	supplied the other plates that were still wanting and provided the text, partly on the
	basis of earlier publications and manuscript notes by Thuret, but for the major part
	written by himself. [Jean-Baptiste Édouard Bornet, 1828-1911]. The plates were
	drawn by Alfred Riocreux (1820-1912), and engraved by Picart (see Stafleu 1966).
<em>Publ</em>.: 1-22 Nov 1878 (Nat. Nov. Jan 1879; J. Bot. Jan 1879; BSbF rd 22 Nov 1878), p.
	[i*-v*], [i]-iii, [1]-105, <em>pl. 1-51</em> [sic, t.p. says "cinquante"] (uncol. copp. A. Riocreux
	and E. Bornet). <em>Copies</em>: B-S, BR, FH, G, MO, NY, PH; IDC 1506. – 200 copies
	printed.
<em>Facsimile ed</em>.: 1966, Réimpression (A. Asher &amp; Co.) Amsterdam, p. [i*-v*], [i]-iii, [1]-
	105, <em>pl. 1-51</em> (id.). <em>Copies</em>: B, FAS. – ISBN 90-6123-159-0.
<em>Ref</em>.: Anon., Bull. Soc. bot. France 25 (bibl.): 193-195. 1879.
	Bary, A. de, Bot. Zeit. 37: 31-32. 10 Jan 1879 (rev.).
	Stafleu, F.A., Taxon 15: 324-325. 1966 (rev. reprint ed.).

Thurmann, Jules (1804-1855), Swiss botanist (Alsatian-born) and school teacher;
trained to be an army engineer at Thun, turning to natural history in 1830, especially
dedicating himself to the geology of the Jura; from 1832 teacher of mathematics and
natural history at Porrentruy (Brunntrut), from 1837 as director of the local teacher's
college. (<em>Thurmann</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 382 (b. 5 Nov 1804, d. 25 Jul 1855); BL 2:
567, 569, 723; BM 5: 2112; CSP 5: 988; Herder p. 168; Jackson p. 285; KR p. 716; PR
9336-9337, ed. 1: 10302; Quenstedt p. 429-430; Rehder 5: 849; Tucker 1: 690.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Bot. Not. 1858: 13 (d.); Biol.-Dokum. 18: 9276; Bot. Zeit. 13: 615. 1855
	(d.); Bull. Soc. bot. France 2: 496. 1855 (d.); Cat. gen. livr. impr. Bibl. natl. 188: 917-
	919. 1962; Flora 38: 591. 1855 (obit. not.); [J.M.], Mém. Soc. Émul. Jura. ser. 4. 4:
	159-165. 1889; Österr. bot. W. 5: 319. 1855 (d.).

Thurn, Everard Ferdinand Im (1852-1932), British colonial administrator and col-
lector; MA Oxford, curator of the Museum at Georgetown, British Guiana 1877-1882;
magistrate at Pomeroon 1882-1891, government agent, N.W. District 1891-1899;
colonial secretary in Ceylon 1901; governor of the Fiji Islands 1904-1910; first to make
an ascent of Mt. Roraima (1884); LL.D. Edinburgh Univ. 1911. (<em>Thurn</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: K; other material at BM (315 plants from Roraima), LIV,
NMW, MO, NOT, OXF, P, RNG.

<em>Note</em>: often listed as Im Thurn, E.F.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 2: 230, 3: 382; BL 1: 244, 302; BM 2: 902; CSP
16: 13; Desmond p. 612; IH 2: 300; Morren ed. 10, p. 143; Tucker 1: 361.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Brit. Mus. gen. cat. print. books 111: 56-57. 1962; Bull. misc. Inf. Kew
	1932: 461-462 (d.); Nature 130: 602-603. 1932 (obit.); Orch. Rev. 40: 352. 1932 (d.);
	Science ser. 2. 76: 400. 1932 (d.); The Times 11 Oct 1932; Who's who (London)
	1898-1932; Who was who (London) 3: 690. 1929-1940 (d. 9 Oct 1932).
Kent, D.H. &amp; D.E. Allen, Brit. Irish herb. 258. 1984.
Ridley, H.N., J. Bot. 70: 341-342. 1932 (obit. not.).
Smith, A.C., Fl. vitiensis nova 1: 54. 1979 (coll. Fiji).

PAGE: 339
HEADING: E. THURSTON

W.L.S., Geogr. J. 80(6): 556-557. 1932 (obit.).

<sm>COMPOSITE</sm> <sm>WORKS</sm>: Founded <em>Timehri</em>, Journal of the Royal Agricultural and commercial
Society of British Guiana, 1-5, 1882-1886, for continuation see BM 4: 1745.

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Thurnia</em> J.D. Hooker (1883); <em>Everardia</em> Ridley (1886).

14.447. <em>Among the Indians of Guiana</em> being sketches chiefly anthropologic from the interior
of British Guiana ... London (Kegan Paul, Trench, &amp; Co., ...) 1883. Oct. (<em>Among Ind.

Thurston, Charles Orion (1857-1933), American botanist; AB Dartmouth 1884. (<em>C.

Thurston, Edgar (1855-1935), British botanist and anthropologist; studied medicine at
King's College, London (L.R.C.P. 1877); superintendent of the Government Museum,
Madras 1885-1909; from 1910 in retirement in Cornwall dedicating himself to the local
flora and to horticulture. (<em>E. Thurst.</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: K (Cornwall); duplicates at DPU, LIV, NMW, NOT, OXF,
RNG; Indian marine algae at BM.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 382; BL 2: 217, 231, 232, 723; BM 5: 2112;

Thurston, John Bates (1836-1897), British planter, politician and administrator in the
merchant service 1850-1855; sheep farmer near Sydney ca. 1859-1862; acting consul
Ovalau, Fiji Isl. 1867-1869; colonial secretary Fiji 1874, lieut. governor 1886, governor
and commander-in-chief Fiji and Western Pacific 1887-1897; collected plants on Fiji
between 1863 and 1897 (<em>J. Thurst.</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: K.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 382; Desmond p. 612 (b. 31 Jan 1836, d.

<em>Publ</em>.: 1886, p. [1]-18. (n.v.).

Thury, [Jean] Marc [Antoine] (1822-1905), Swiss naturalist and teacher; teaching at
various private institutions at Nyon, Lausanne, Neuchâtel and Genève 1840-1851; pro-
fessor of botany at the Faculté des Sciences, Genève from 1851-1900 as well as natural
history teacher at the Genève girls high school. (<em>Thury</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: G (2508; part of orig. herb. donated 1943 by Mlle Alice Thury,
daughter of M. Thury; intercalated in general herbarium 1944). – <em>Letters</em> at G.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 382 (b. 18 Apr 1822, d. 17 Jan 1905); BM 5:

ed. 10, p. 110; PR (alph.), ed. 1: 4387; Rehder 5: 849; TL-2/1119-1120.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Cat. gén. livr. impr. Bibl. natl. 1888: 973-974. 1962; Docum. hist. Univ.

Thwaites, George Henry Kendrick (1812-1882), British botanist; accountant in the
city of Bristol while training himself to become a botanist; lecturer in botany at the
School of Pharmacy and the Medical school in Bristol 1847; superintendant Royal
Botanic Gardens at Peradeniya, Ceylon 1849-1880 (from 1857 as director); established

PAGE: 342
HEADING: THWAITES

the algal nature of diatoms (1847), started Cinchona plantations in Ceylon; Dr. phil.
Leopold. 1864. (<em>Thwaites</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Personal herbarium not traced; however, BRISTM still has some
early Thwaites material (recent listing rd by us). The main sets of Thwaites Ceylon
material are at K and PDA. Both herbaria have Thwaites types. The CP (Ceylon
plants) numbers of material distributed by Thwaites were not true collector's numbers;
the material stems from various locations and was not always collected by Thwaites
himself (Wagenitz 1982). Further material of Thwaites (British as well as Ceylonese) is
at A, AWH, B (ferns extant), BHU, BM (1861), BR, BRISTM, CAL, CGE, DO, DPU,
E, FI, G, GH, GOET, GZU, H, LE, LIV (ferns), MH, MO, NMW, NY, OXF, P, PC,
PH, TTN, US, W, WAR, WU. – <em>Letters</em> at BM, G, K.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Backer p. 585; Barnhart 3: 383; BB p. 301; BM 5: 2112,
8: 1308; Bossert p. 401; CSP 5: 989-990, 11: 602, 12: 730, 19: 117; Desmond p. 612 (b. 9
Jul 1812, d. 11 Sep 1882); De Toni 1: cxxiii, 2: cxiv; DNB 56: 361-362 (19: 841-842);
Frank 3 (Anh.): 104; GR p. 383, cat. 72; Hawksworth p. 186; Herder p. 164, 213;
Hortus 3: 1205; IF p. 734; IH 1 (ed. 6): 365, (ed. 7): 344; Jackson p. 396; Lenley p. 410;
LS 26772-26774; Moebius p. 422; Morren ed. 2, p. 38; Nordstedt p. 30; PR 9340-9341;
Rehder 5: 849; RS p. 144-145; SBC p. 133; SIA 7112; SK 4: ccxiv; TL-1/1311; TL-
2/6923, see W. Ferguson, J.D. Hooker; Tucker 1: 690; Urban-Berl. p. 315, 403; Zander
ed. 10, p. 724, ed. 11, p. 826.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Allen, D.A., Handb. guide herb. coll. publ. mus. Liverpool 66. 1935.
Anon., Bonplandia 2: 264. 1854 (bot. gard. will not be abolished), 5: 332, 364. 1857, 6:
	397. 15 Dec 1858 (part 1 <em>Enum</em>. in hands); Bot. Centralbl. 12: 112. 1882 (obit. not.);
	Bot. Not. 1883: 30 (d.); Bot. Zeit. 7: 744. 1849 (app. Ceylon), 23: 312. 1865 (Dr. phil.
	Leopold.), 40: 821. 1882 (d.); Bull. Soc. bot. France 26 (bibl.): 191. 1879 (H. Trimen
	will succeed Thwaites in Ceylon), 29 (bibl.): 141. 1882 (d.); Entom. Mon. Mag. 19:
	142-143. 1882; Flora 47: 603. 1864 (Dr. phil. Leopold.), 51: 349. 1868 (will return to

Thyssen, Paul (1891-1974), German (Preuss.-Rheinland) horticulturist and bryolo-
gist; studied at the Berlin-Dahlem Gartenbauhochschule; on active service in World
War I, assistant horticulturist at Köln 1922, "Gartendirector" ib. 1931. (<em>Thyssen</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: M (bryoph. herb., rd. 1969 and lichens coll. 1940).

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: BFM 59.

	M).

<sm>COMPOSITE</sm> <sm>WORKS</sm>: With L. Laven, <em>Flora des Köln-Bonner Wandergebietes</em>, Wiss. Mitt. Ver.
Natur-Heimatk. 1: 149-268. 1937, ed. 2: in Decheniana 112(1): 1-179. 1959.

Tidestrom, [orig.: Tidestrøm], Ivar [Frederick] (1864-1956), Swedish-born
American botanist; emigrated to the United States 1880; in the U.S. army attached to
the hospital service 1880-1884, 1887-1891; studied engineering at the University of
California 1891-1895, becoming assistant to E.L. Greene; with Greene to Catholic Univ-
ersity, Washington 1895; Dr. phil. ib. 1897; assistant botanist USDA with F.V. Coville
1903, from 1915 detached at the Smithsonian Institution on the grass and sedge collect-
ions; retired from USDA 1934; from 1934-1935 at the botany Dept., Catholic Univ.; in
retirement at St. Petersburg, Florida. (<em>Tidestr</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: US; personal collection at LCU. – Further material at A, C, CI,
DUKE, F, GH, LA, LCU, MICH, MO, NA, OGDF, P, PH, S, UC. – <em>Field notes</em> at US
(SIA).

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 383 (b. 13 Sep 1864, d. 2 Aug 1956); BFM
1609, 1610; BL 1: 196, 321, 2: 282, 723; BM 8: 1309; Bossert p. 401; Ewan ed. 1: 321-
322, ed. 2: 221; Hortus 3: 1205; IF (suppl. 1): 85, (suppl. 3): 218; IH (ed. 7): 344, 2:

PAGE: 344
HEADING: TIDESTROM

(files); KR p. 717; Langman p. 736-737; NW p. 59; TL-2/see M.K. Brandegee, H.L.
Shantz; Tucker 1: 690, 3: 309; Zander ed. 10, p. 724, ed. 11, p. 826.

14.466. <em>Flora of Utah and Nevada</em> ... Washington (Government Printing Office) 1925.

Tidyman, Philipp [Philip] (x-1850), American botanist and palaeontologist of Char-

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

14.470. Dissertatio inauguralis de <em>Oryza sativa</em>. Quam gratiosae Facultatis medicae con-
sensu et auctoritate pro gradu doctoris medicinae et chirurgiae rite legitimeque ob-

<em>Publ</em>.: 24 Jul 1800, p. [1]-28, <em>pl. 1-2</em> (copp.; NY has one of the plates col.). <em>Copies</em>: B-S,
	NY.

Tieghem, Philippe Édouard Léon van (1839-1914), French botanist; at the École
normale supérieure 1858-1861, aggr. ib. 1861; Dr. sci. nat. Paris 1867; "maître de con-
férences" in botany at the École normale supérieure 1864, professor of botany at the
École des Arts et Métiers, at the Muséum d'Histoire naturelle 1879, at the École supéri-
eure for female teachers; also active at the Agronomical Institute; originator of the stelar
concept and of the floral vascular anatomy of the flower. (<em>Tiegh</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: P. – <em>Letters</em> to Malinvaud (20) at P.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Ainsworth p. 348 [index]; Backer p. 663; Barnhart 3:
425 (b. 19 Apr 1839, d. 28 Apr 1914); BJI 1: 57, 2: 183; BM 5: 2113, 8: 1309; Bossert p.
40; CSP 5: 993, 8: 1087-1088, 11: 603-604, 19: 121-122; De Toni 1: cxxvii, 2: cxix, 4:
lvii; DSB 13: 405-406 (A. Nougarède); Frank 3 (Anh.): 104; Hawksworth p. 186; Herder
p. 23, 246, 308; Hortus 3: 1206; Jackson p. 84, 92, 170; Kelly p. 227; Langman p. 737;
LS 26785-26826; Moebius p. 457 (index); Morren ed. 2, p. 21, ed. 10, p. 54, 55; MW p.
497-498; NI 1965, 3: 59; Nordstedt suppl. p. 15; PR 9345, 10644; Rehder 5: 850-851;
Stevenson p. 1260, 1261; TL-2/1303, see C.F. Sauvageau; Tucker 1: 691; Zander ed. 10,
p. 724, 727, ed. 11, p. 829.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Atti r. Ist. Veneto Sci. 73(1): 191-194. 1914 (obit.); Bot. Centralbl. 1/2:
	96. 1880 (vice-pres. Soc. bot. Fr.), 108: 665. 1909 (secr. perp. Acad. Sci.), 113: 144.
	1910 (comm. Lég. Honn.), 126: 32. 1914 (d.).; Bot. Zeit. 37: 710. 1879 (app.
	Muséum, Paris); Bull. Soc. bot. France 26 (bibl.): 89. 1879 (app. Mus. His. nat.);
	Cat. gen. livr. impr. Bibl. natl. 202: 947-955. 1971; CR. Acad. Sci., Paris 62: 568-
	569. 1866 (prix Bordin), 66: 963-970. 1868 (id.); Grand Larousse encycl. 10: 679.
	1964 (portr.); Hedwigia 55: (152). 1914 (d.); Index Amer. bot. lit. 1886-1966, 4: 357,
	417-418. 1969; Index biogr. Acad. Sci., Paris 508. 1954 (functions, activities Acad.);
	J. Bot. 52: 192. 1914; Nat. Nov. 36: 264. 1914 (d.); Österr. bot. Z. 64: 208. 1914 (d.);
	Science ed. 2, 39: 684. 1914.

	1: 394-396. 1916 (obit.); Arch. Mus. natl. Hist. nat. ser. 6. 12: 319-324. 1935 (rôle
	chair organography muséum); La Nature ser. 3. 1: 394-396. 1916 (obit.).

<sm>COMPOSITE</sm> <sm>WORKS</sm>: (1) Editor, <em>Ann. Sci. nat. Bot.</em> ser. 6. 13 (1882). – Ser. 9, 18(5-6)
(1913).
(2) Translated and annotated J. Sachs, <em>Lehrb. bot</em>. (<em>Traité bot</em>.) 1874, see TL-2/9954.

<sm>NAME</sm>: The name Philippe van Tieghem should be alphabetised under T.; the "van" is of
Dutch origin; van Tieghem wrote his name consistently this way ("Ph. van Tieghem");
his grandfather received the French nationality under Napoleon.

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Tieghemella</em> Berlese et G.B. De Toni (1888); <em>Tieghemiomyces</em> R.K. Benjamin
(1959); <em>Vantieghemia</em> O. Kuntze (1891). The derivations for <em>Tieghemella</em> Pierre (1890) and
<em>Tieghemopanax</em> R. Viguier (1905) were not given, but probably honor this author.

sur la structure des Aroidées</em>. 2e thèse. – Propositions ... par la Faculté. Soutenues le [11]

Tilesius von Tilenau, Wilhelm Gottlieb (1769-1857), German (Thuringian)
naturalist and traveller, with J.C. von Hoffmannsegg in Portugal 1796; lecturer Univ.
Leipzig 1801; with A.J. v. Krusenstern on a voyage of circumnavigation as surgeon and
naturalist 1803-1808; from 1808 practicing medicine but also active as a private scientist
in Leipzig, Göttingen, Mühlhausen and Dresden, ultimately private teacher at Müh-
lhausen. (<em>Tilesius</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: LE (Herder 1888 "einige ... Pflanzen"), B (mainly destr.), H
(20 specimens in herb. Steven), H-Ach (lich.); sent also material to G.F.W. Meyer at
Göttingen. – <em>Letters</em> at G, UPS-UB.

Tiling [Tilling], Heinrich Sylvester Theodor (1818-1871), Livonian physician and
botanist; in the service of the Russian-American company of the Ajan factory 1845-
1851; returned to St. Petersburg via Kamtschatka, Sitka, Hawaii and Cape Horn 1851-
1852; practicing physician in Livonia 1852-1866; again in the service of the Russian-
American company as hospital physician in Sitka 1866-1868; collecting in California
and Nevada for various botanical gardens 1868-1871. (<em>Tiling</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: LE (Ajan material, 356 sp.); dupl. B (mainly destr.), MW, OXF,
US, W.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Backer p. 586; Barnhart 3: 384 (b. 31 Dec 1818); BM 5:
2116; Clokie p. 254; Hegi 5(2): 1304; Herder p. 61, 211; Hortus 3: 1205; PR ed. 1:
10321-10322; TR 1419-1421; Tucker 1: 691; Urban-Berl. p. 404.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Bot. Zeit. 22: 92. 1864 (a herbarium of the Flora of Ajan offered for sale
	by a bookseller in Riga).

HEADING: TILLANDZ

Herder, F. von, Bot. Jahrb. 9: 453-454. 1888 (biogr. sketch, coll.).
Hultén, E., Bot. Not. 1940: 301 (coll. at Unalaska 1851; Sitka 1866-1868; coll. LE, US).
Lindemann, F. v., Bull. Soc. natural. Moscou 61(1): 77. 1886 (13 specim. MW).
Lipschitz, S., F. URSS fontes 1860. 1975.

<sm>COMPOSITE</sm> <sm>WORKS</sm>: With E. Regel, <em>Fl. Ajan.</em> 1858, see TL-2/8780.

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Tilingia</em> E. Regel et H. Tiling (1859).

Tillandz (Til-landz), Elias Erici [orig. Tillander] (1640-1693), Swedish physician and
botanist; studied in Åbo and Uppsala; Dr. med. Leiden 1670, later professor of medicine
at Åbo [Finland]. (<em>Tillandz</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Destroyed.

<sm>NOTE</sm>: We are indebted to P. Isoviita for supplying us with the material on which this
entry is based.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Backer p. 586; Barnhart 3: 384 (d. 18 Feb 1693); BM 5:
2116, 8: 1311; (Hollander Hist. p. 12, 65; Dryander 3: 170; Frank 3 (Anh.): 104; Herder
p. 201; Jackson p. 27, 170; KR p. 718-719 (detailed treatment); NI 1966; PR 9350-
9351, 9137, ed. 1: 10088, 10314-10315; Rehder 1: 359; Saelan p. 503; TR 1422-1423.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Bot. Not. 1921: 32 (commemoration).
Carpelan, T., Finsk biogr. handb. 2: 2223-2224. 1903.
Elfving, F., Finsk Tidskr. 90: 27-44. 1921 (life and works).
Eriksson, G., Bot. hist. Sverige 88, 138, 140, 143. 1969.
Fries, R.E., Short hist. bot. Sweden 17. 1950.
Heikinheimo, I., Suomen elämä-kerrasto 768. 1955.
Hintikka, T.J., Aika 14: 181-188. 1920 (Finnish plant names in T.'s Catalogus).
Hirsch, A., ed., Biogr. lex. hervorrag. Ärzte ed. 3. 5: 591. 1962.
Hjelt, O.E.A., Försök att bestämma de af E. Tillandz i hans "Catalogus plantarum"
	upptagna vexter. 1869 (Not. Sällsk. Fauna Fl. fenn. Förh. 10), p. [207]-244. 2 Oct-6
	Nov 1869.
Hulth, J.M., Bref Skrifv. Linné 1(8): 105. 1922.
Krok, Th.O.B.N., Bot. Not. 1919: 165-166 (on a catalogue of Åbo plants).
Mägdefrau, K., Gesch. Bot. 48, 50. 1973.
S-s, H.G., Nordisk familjebok 19: 309. 1933.
Skepparnabb, L., Mem. Soc. Fauna Fl. 15: 179-185. 1940; Elias Tillandz' växtbilder
	och växtnamn, Lovisa 1961, 173 p. (on sources of Icones novae).
Wein, V., Ann. Soc. zool.-bot. fenn. Vanamo 11: 189-411. 1930 (T.'s Catalogus
	plantarum (1683) im Lichte seiner Zeit erklärt und gewürdigt).

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Tillandsia</em> Linnaeus (1753).

14.522. <em>Catalogus plantarum</em> tàm in excultis quàm incultis locis prope Aboam superiori
aestate nasci observatarum, in gratiam philo-botanicorum concinnatus ab Elia Til-
Landz ... D. [ ] Maij 1673. Aboae (excusus â Petro Hansonio) [1673]. Oct. (<em>Cat. pl.</em>).

<em>Ed</em>. [<em>1</em>]: Mai 1693, p. [1-31]. <em>Copies</em>: H-UB, Roy. Libr. Stockholm, Libr. Karol. Inst.
	Stockholm.
<em>Ed</em>. [<em>2</em>]: Mai 1683, p. [1-72]. <em>Copies</em>: H, H-UB, Peterson, Roy. Libr. Stockholm. – <em>Cata-
	logus plantarum</em> quae prope Aboam tarn in excultis, quam incultis locis huc usque
	inventae sunt. In gratiam philo-botanicorum auctior editus. Accessêre praetéreà usit-
	atiora Svetica atq; Finnonica nomina, cum brevi virtutum recensione. Collecta, ab
	Elia Til-Landz ... mense Maij m.dc.lxxxiii. Aboae, (excusus â Johanne L. Wallio,
	...) [1683]. Oct. – See KR p. 718 for further details, as well as the literature cited
	above (<em>biofile</em>), especially Hjelt (1869) and Wein (1930).

Timbal-Lagrave, Pierre Marguérite Édouard (1819-1888), French botanist;
studied pharmacy and chemistry at Toulouse and Montpellier; pharmacien 1re classe
Montpellier; practicing pharmacist; professor at the École de médecine et de pharmacie,
Toulouse. (<em>Timb.-Lagr</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: TL; other material at BR, CGE, E, FI, MPU, MW, P. – <em>Letters</em>
to E. Malinvaud at P; other letters at G.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: AG 2(1): 482, 6(2): 970, 7: 374, 12(2): 512; BL 2: 723-
724 [index]; BM 5: 2116, 8: 1312; Bossert p. 402; Colmeiro 1: ccii; CSP 5: 997-998, 8:
1091-1092, 11: 609, 19: 130-131; Hegi 5(2): 1175; Herder p. 481 [index]; Hortus 3:
1205; IH 1 (ed. 7): 344, 2: (files); Jackson p. 127, 146, 274, 275, 279, 281, 282, 341;
Morren ed. 10, p. 69; PR 344, 9357-9360; Rehder 5: 851-852; TL-2/3319, 10.513, see
C.H. Schultz; Tucker 1: 691, 2: xxxviii, 3: 309.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Bot. Centralbl. 37: 95. 1889 (d.); Cat. gén. livr. impr. Bibl. natl. 189:
	498-508. 1963; Flora 52: 368. 1869 (silver med. French sci. soc); J. Bot., Morot 2:

Timm, Carl Theodor (1824-1907), German (Hamburg) teacher and botanist; head
teacher of the Hessische Privatschule, Hamburg 1857-1872, with the Volksschuldienst
Hamburg 1872-1887; active amateur floristic botanist, with special interest in bryo-
phytes and lichens. (<em>C. Timm</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown (had a herbarium).

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Biol.-Dokum. 18: 9290; BM 5: 2116; Christiansen p. 320
[index]; CSP 11: 609, 19: 132; DTS 6(4): 201; GR p. 144; Tucker 1: 692.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Christiansen, D.N., Schr. naturw. Ver. Schlesw.-Holst. 18: 450-452. 1928
	(biogr., b. 29 Feb 1824, d. 16 Aug 1907).
Fischer-Benzon, R.J.D., <em>in</em> P. Prahl, Fl. Schlesw.-Holst. 2(1): 57-58. 1890.
Koppe, F., Abh. naturw. Ver. Bremen 36: 240, 248-249, 256. 1964.
Volkens, G.L.A., Verh. bot. Ver. Brandenburg 51: (85). 1910.

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Timmia</em> J.F. Gmelin (1791, <em>nom. rej.</em>); <em>Timmia</em> J. Hedwig (1801, <em>nom. cons.</em>);
<em>Timmiella</em> (De Notaris) Limpricht (1888).

Timm, Joachim Christian (1734-1805), German (Pommern) pharmacist and
botanist; from 1760 pharmacist (later also burgomaster) at Malchin (Mecklenburg);
associated with J. Hedwig. (<em>Timm</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown; some lichens at M.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: AG 4: 95; Barnhart 3: 385 (b. 7 Dec 1734, d. 3 Feb

14.564. <em>FLorae megapolitanae prodromus</em> exhibens plantas ducatas megapolitano-suerinensis
