Timm, Rudolph (1859-1936), German (Hamburg) bryologist and zoologist; son of
Carl Theodor Timm; studied at Göttingen and Würzburg; Dr. phil. Würzburg 1883;
high school teacher for natural sciences at the Realschule vor dem Lübecker Tor 1887-
1890; working at Cuxhaven 1890-1892; again at the Hamburg school 1892-1924, from
1906 with the title professor. (<em>R. Timm</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: BREM; other material at B (mainly destr.).

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Biol.-Dokum. 18: 9291; BL 2: 177; BM 5: 2116; Christ-
iansen p. 320 [index]; CSP 19: 132; LS 39940; Nordstedt suppl. p. 15; PH 12; SBC 133;
TL-2/4941; Urban-Berl. p. 315.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Koppe, F., Abh. naturw. Ver. Bremen 36: 240, 248-249, 256. 1964 (bibl.).
Pax, F., Bibl. schles. Bot. 150. 1929.
Verdoorn, F., ed., Chron. bot. 3: 357. 1937; Ann. bryol. 10: 153. 1937 (obit. not.).
Weidner, H., Abh. Verh. naturw. Ver. Hamburg suppl. 9: 193. (b. 2 Jan 1859, d. 26
	Jan 1936).

<sm>COMPOSITE</sm> <sm>WORKS</sm>: (1) Contributed to L. Loeske, <em>Laubm. Eur.</em> 1914, TL-2/4941.
(2) Editor, E. Zacharias, Beobachtungen an Lebermoosen 1928, q.v.

<sm>NOTE</sm>: Wulf Wilhelm Timm (1850-1924) high school teacher in Schleswig and Hamburg
also published several papers on the local flora, see D.N. v. Christiansen, Schr. naturw.
Ver. Schlesw.-Holst. 22(2): 452. 1928.

Tinant, François Auguste (1803-1853), Luxemburg botanist and administrator; cus-
toms officer 1828-1839, subsequently inspector-general of forests. (<em>Tinant</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: LUX; further material (at least 1200) BR.

Tineo</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: In the herbarium of his son V. Tineo at PAL. – <em>Letters</em> at G.

Tineo, Vincenzo (1791-1856), Italian botanist; director of the botanical garden and
professor of botany at Palermo 1815-1836, chancellor of Palermo University 1838.
(<em>Tineo</em>).

(Stev.), HLY, M, MW, P. – Distributed sets of Sicilian plants; W.D.J. Koch at Erlangen
distributed material to subscribers from a total of 175 species (Flora 16: 766. 1833). –
<em>Letters</em> at G.

Tischler, Georg [Friedrich Leopold] (1878-1955), German (East-Prussian) botanist;
studied at Königsberg, München, Bonn 1896-1900; Dr. phil. Bonn 1899; assistant
Botanical Institute Heidelberg 1900-1902, at the Plant-Physiological Institute of the
Landtbrucksakad. Stockholm; habil. and lecturer Heidelberg 1902, in Java (Buitenzorg-
Stipendium), Ceylon and East-Africa 1908-1909; extra-ordinary professor of botany
Heidelberg 1908-1912; professor at the Technical College and director of the Natural
history Museum and Botanical garden Braunschweig 1912-1917; ordinary professor and
director of the Botanical Institute and Garden Stuttgart-Hohenheim 1917-1922; profes-
sor of botany and director of the Botanical Garden at Kiel 1922-1951; outstanding plant
cytologist. (<em>Tischler</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown. – <em>Letters</em> at G.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Backer p. 587; Barnhart 3: 386 (b. 22 Jun 1878); BFM p.
321 [index]; Biol.-Dokum. 18: 9301-9302; BJI 2: 177-178; BM 5: 2117; Bossert p. 402;
Hirsch p. 300; IH (ed. 1): 49; KR p. 719; Langman p. 738; LS 8139, 26848, 39944,
41791, suppl. 27842-27844; TL-2/10.943; Tucker 1: 692.

Tiselius, Gustaf [August] (1833-1904), Swedish botanist and high school teacher; Dr.
phil. Uppsala 1869; with a high school in Stockholm 1868-1903; also teacher at Ultuna
agricultural college 1868-1892; specialist on Potamogeton. (<em>Tiselius</em>).

Tison, [Eugène] Édouard [Augustin] (1842-?), French botanist and physician;
studied medicine at Paris; Dr. med. ib. 1873; lic. sci. nat. 1874, Dr. sci. nat. 1876;
professor of botany at the Université catholique de Paris 1876-1881; in charge of the

Tissière, Pierre Germain (1828-1868), Swiss roman-catholic priest and amateur
botanist; at the Grand St. Bernard monastery 1843-1856 (ordained 1852); vicar of
Vouvry 1857, at Sembrancher 1857-1868; driving force in the Société Murithienne.
(<em>Tissière</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Tissière's herbarium went to Chanoine de la Soie, at Martigny. –
<em>Letters</em> at G.

Tita, Antonius (x-1729), Italian botanist at Padua, travelled and botanised in the

could not be determined.

14.605. <em>Catalogus plantarum</em>, quibus consitus est Patavii amoenissimus hortus illustrissimi,
ac excellentissimi equitis Jo: Francisci Mauroceni veneti senatoris ab Antonio Tita con-

<em>Publ</em>.: 1713, p. [i-xvi], 1-183, iter [1-24], err. [1]. <em>Copies</em>: BR, USDA.

Titford, William Jowit (Jowett] (1784-1823/7?), Jamaica-born British accountant of
London and Master in Chancery, Jamaica; in Jamaica 1805-1807; travelled in North
America and the West Indies 1807-1809; studied with D. Hosack at Columbia College,
New York 1809-1810; returned to England 1810, publishing his Hortus 1810-1812; in
Jamaica 1813-1815; in London 1815-1822, ultimately again in Jamaica. (<em>Titford</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 387; BB p. 301-302; BM 5: 2117; Desmond
p. 613; DU 256; GF p. 78; Jackson p. 354; Langman p. 738; Plesch p. 436; PR 9370, ed.
1: 10334; Rehder 3: 62; SO 798b; Sotheby 757; Tucker 1: 692.

Titius [Tietz], Johann Daniel (1729-1796), German (West-Prussian) botanist and general
natural scientist; Mag. phil. Leipzig 1752; lecturer Univ. Leipzig 1752-1756; professor of
mathematics Univ. Wittenberg 1756-1762, from 1762 id. for physics. (<em>Titius</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown. – <em>Letters</em> to Thomä at UPS-UB.

Titius, Pius [Pio] Vendei (1801-1884), Hungaran botanist and clergyman; Franciscan
priest from Arad; teacher at Löcse (Levoca) 1828, later in Kézdivásárhely; from 1838-
1852 army chaplain; from 1860 living in Pirano (Istria); collected algae in the Adriatic.
(<em>P. Titius</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: W; further material (Dalmatian algae) at B (extant), HAL,
MW, OXF, WRSL. – <em>Letters</em> at G.

xiii; Morren ed. 10, p. 39; Saccardo 1: 164.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Vöröss, L.Zs., Bot. Közlem. 59(3): 141-143. 1973.

<sm>COMPOSITE</sm> <sm>WORKS</sm>: See Georg Frauenfeld (1807-1873), TL-2/1: 873 for a treatment of
algae collected by Titius on the coast of Dalmatia.

Tittmann, Johann August (1774-1840), German (Hannover) physician, botanist and
agronomist; studied pharmacy at Elbingerode and Wernigerode; studied medicine at
Leipzig 1794; "Privatdocent" ib. 1797; Dr. med. 1801; practicing physician at Dresden
1801-1813; in retirement nr Altenburg. (<em>Tittmann</em>).

Tkany, Wilhelm (1792-1863), Moravian botanist; governmental administrator
("Hofconcipist") in Wien 1822-1830, in Brünn (Gubernialsecretär) 1830-1839, Hofsec-
retär Wien 1839, Moravian-Silesian "Gubernialrath" Brünn 1840-1850; supervisor of
the school system in Moravia and Silesia 1850-1855; from 1830 active as amateur bota-
nist. (<em>Tkany</em>).

Tobler, Friedrich (1879-1957), Swiss (Berlin-born) botanist; studied in Berlin, Heidel-
berg and Leipzig; Dr. phil. Berlin 1901 (promotor Schwendener); habil. Univ. Münster
1905, lecturer ib. 1905, extraordinary professor of botany and head of the Botanical
Institute, Münster 1911-1920; travelled in South and East Africa 1912-1913; head of the
Fiber research institute at Sorau 1920-1924; professor of botany and director of the
Botanical Garden of the Technical University of Dresden 1924-1946; in retirement in St.
Gallen (Switzerland) from 1947. (<em>Tobl</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: DR; further material in B (duplicates received from Dresden
after 1943), original collections at DR. <em>Letters</em> at G.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 387 (b. 1 Oct 1897); BFM 2540, 2951-2953;
Biol.-Dokum. 18: 9308-9310; BJI 2: 178; BM 5: 2117; Bossert p. 402; GR 635-636, <em>pl</em>.
[<em>21</em>], cat. p. 72; Hawksworth p. 186; Hirsch p. 301; Hortus 3: 1205; IH (ed. 1): 31, (ed.
2): 48; Kelly p. 228; Kleppa 30, 100; Langman p. 738-739; LS 39947-39950, suppl.
27888-27903; Moebius p. 111, 114; MW p. 498; Plesch p. 436; SBC p. 133; TL-2/see
W.F. Mattick; Tucker 1: 692; Zander ed. 10, p. 724, ed. 11, p. 826.

Tobler, Gertrud [Paula], née Wolff (1877-1948), German (Berlin) botanist; studied
botany at the University of Berlin under Schwendener, Engler, Magnus, Kolkwitz,
Lindau; Dr. phil. Berlin 1905 (with Schwendener); worked with E. Strasburger in Bonn
as a botanical technician 1905-1907; married F. Tobler 1907 (obtaining Swiss
nationality); worked with her husband at Münster, East Africa, Sorau, Dresden and St.
Gallen. (<em>G. Tobl.</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 387 (b. 8 Aug 1877); BFM 2952; Biol.-
Dokum. 18: 9310; BJI 2: 178; GR p. 145; Hirsch p. 301; LS 29212, suppl. 27904-27905.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Schmid, B. &amp; C. Thesing, Biol.-Kalend. 1: 326. 1914.
Tobler, F., Ber. deut. bot. Ges. 68a (Nachrufe): 170-172. 1955 (obit. by her husband;
	bibl., d. 29 Nov 1946).

<sm>COMPOSITE</sm> <sm>WORKS</sm>: <em>Vegetationsbilder von Kilimandscharo</em>, with F. Tobler, <em>in</em> G. Karsten &amp; H.
Schenck, <em>Vegetationsbilder</em> ser. 12, Heft 2-3, <em>pl. 7-18</em>, with text, 1914 (J. Bot. Sep 1914).

Friedrich-Wilhelms-Universität zu Berlin von Gertrud P. Wolff aus Pankow bei Berlin.
Tag der Promotion: 5. August 1905 [Berlin] Oct. (<em>Beitr. Entw.–Gesch. Flechtenapoth.</em>).

Todaro, Agostino (1818-1892), Italian (Sicilian) botanist; studied law and natural
sciences at the University of Palermo; assistant at the Palermo botanical garden 1848-
1856; director id. 1856 (officially 1860)-1892. (<em>Tod</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: PAL; other material at AWH, B (extant), BM, BR, CGE, DBN,
DPU, DS, E, FI, G, G-DC, GE, H, HBG, L, LA, LY, MPU, PH, US (but see exsic-
catae). – <em>Exsiccatae</em>: <em>Flora sicula</em>, nos. 1-1600, 1864-18??, AWH, BM, BP, BR, CGE, FI,

HEADING: TODARO

Gray at GH, other letters at G.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: AG 2(1): 282; Backer p. 662; Barnhart 3: 388 (b. 14 Jan
1818, d. 18 Apr 1892); BM 5: 2118; Bossert p. 402; Clokie p. 255; CSP 6: 2, 8: 1094, 11:

	1972 cite under no. 5 a title not seen by them, which may be identical with this <em>first
	Relazione</em> of 1864.

Tode, Heinrich Julius (1733-1797), German (Mecklenburg) botanist and clergyman;
"Consistorialrath", "Hof- und Domprediger" at Schwerin. (<em>Tode</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Original collection of fungi destroyed.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Ainsworth p. 65, 226, 312, 348; Backer p. 587; Barnhart
3: 388 (b. 31 Mai 1733, d. 30 Dec 1797); BM 5: 2118; Dryander 3: 224, 226, 343, 351,
352, 353; Frank 3 (Anh.): 104; GR p. 50, cat. p. 72; Hawksworth p. 186, 198; Herder p.
246; Kelly p. 228; LS 26866-26878; NI 1970; PR 9386, ed.1: 10350; Stevenson p. 1260.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Ainsworth, G.C., Dict. fungi ed. 6. 584. 1971.
Anon., Bot. Zeit. Regensburg 3: 48. 1804 (mycol. collections dumped in a pool behind
	his house by his family).
Boll, E., Fl. Mecklenburg 173-176. 1860.
Killermann, S., Z. Pilzk. 8-10: 269-271. 1924-1926.
Roemer, J.J., Arch. Bot. 2(1): 115. 1799 (d. 30 Dec 1797; Mecklenburg-Schwerinische
	Consistorialrath, Hof- und Domprediger).

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Mycotodea</em> Kirschstein (1936); <em>Todea</em> Willdenow ex Bernhardi (1801) and the
derived genera names <em>Todeopsis</em> B. Renault (1896), <em>Todisporites</em> R.A. Couper (1958) and
<em>Todites</em> A.C. Seward (1900).

14.672. <em>Fungi mecklenburgenses selecti</em> ... Luneburgi [Lüneburg] (apud Joh. Friedr. Guil.
Lemke) 1790-1791. Qu. (<em>Fung. mecklenb. sel.</em>).

<em>1</em>: 1790 (p. vii: mid.-Mar 1790), p. [i]-viii, [1]-47, [48-49, index; 50, err.], <em>pl. 1-7</em> (uncol.
	copp. auct.). – Fasciculus i. Nova fungorum genera complectens.
<em>2</em>: 1791, p. [i]-viii, [1]-64, [65-66, index; 67, err.], <em>pl. 8-17</em> (id.). – Fasciculus ii. Generum
	novorum appendicem et Sphaeriarum acaulium subordines iii priores complectens.
<em>Copies</em>: B-S, BR, G, MICH, NY, PH, Stevenson, USDA.

Toepffer, Adolph (1853-1931), German (Prussian/Brandenburg) botanist; originally
in charge of a family mill; subsequently travelling in Europe and distributing exsiccatae
ca. 1881-1886; in charge of a pharmacy in Schwerin 1887-1902; in retirement because of
invalidity in München, fully dedicating himself to botany as volunteer in the (then)
Royal Botanical Museum. (<em>Toepff</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: M (especially Salix 1890-1925); other material at E (Germany),
W (Germany) – and Z (Australia). – <em>Exsiccatae</em>: <em>Salicetum exsiccatum</em> fasc. 1-15, nos. 1-772,
1906-1929. Sets at A, BM, GB, GOET, M, MANCH. For text see below. – An early
herbarium was offered for sale in 1886 (Flora 69: 80. 1886). Toepffer offered herbarium
specimens for sale as early as 1882 (Bot. Zeit. 40: 144. 1882). These included H.F.A. von
Eggers, <em>Fl. ind. occ. exsicc.</em> nos. 1-1600, 1881-1885; see under Eggers (TL-2/1: 726). –
<em>Letters</em> at G, GH, UPS-UB.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: AG 12(1): 174; Barnhart 3: 388; Biol.-Dokum. 18: 9316-
9317; BM 5: 2118; Bossert p. 402; CSP 19: 146; DSB 6(4): 202; Hortus 3: 1205; KR p.
719; Morren ed. 10, p. 9; MW p. 498; Rehder 5: 853; TL-2/11.174, see H.F.A. von
Eggers, P.E.E. Sintenis; Tucker 1: 692, 2: xxxviii, 3: 309-310; Urban-Berl. p. 404.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Ascherson, P.F.A., Nachtr. zu L. Schneider's Fl. Magdeb. 72. 1894.
Harz, K., Mitt. Bayer. bot. Ges. 4(12): 203-204. 1932 (obit., portr., b. 16 Aug 1853, d.
	26 Apr 1931).
Lack, H.W. &amp; C.-O. von Sydow, Willdenowia 14: 442. 1984.
Schmid, B. &amp; C. Thesing, Biol. Kalend. 1: 326. 1914.
Wagenitz, G., Index coll. princ. herb. Gott. 166. 1982.

PAGE: 383
HEADING: TOEPFFER

Törner, Samuel (1762-?), Swedish naturalist and librarian; studied in Uppsala with P.
Thunberg; Dr. phil. ib., asst. to J. Dryander in Sir Joseph Banks's library 1792-1797.
(<em>Törner</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Plants from Sweden and Finland in Thunberg herb. UPS. –
Törner compiled a 20 vol. mss. <em>Nomenclator botanicus</em> while in London; this mss. is now in
Uppsala University Library.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 388; Dawson p. 210, 634, 800 ["Toerner"];
KR p. 728.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Marshall, J.B., Bull. Bot. Brit. Mus. (N.H.) 6(1): 1-85. 1978 (the handwriting of
	Joseph Banks, his scientific staff and amanuenses; much information on Törner).

<sm>HANDWRITING</sm>: Bull. Bot. Brit. Mus. (N.H.) 6(1): 19, 56, 57, 58. 1978.

Togashi, Kogo (1895-1952), Japanese mycologist and plant pathologist; Dr. sci.
Hokkaido Univ. 1931; assistant professor Kyoto University 1925; professor of plant pat-
hology Morioka College of Agriculture and Forestry 1926. (<em>Togashi</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown. Some material at IACM.

Tolf, Robert (1849-1903), Swedish botanist and teacher; assistant dyer at Vrigstad
1868-1879; dyer and private teacher at Ingatorp, Småland 1879-1890; assistant for
botany and geology with the Swedish "mosskulturföreningen" (peat reclamation
society) at Jönköping 1890-1895; with Jönköping's seed control station 1895-1903.
(<em>Tolf</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Musci at C, DPU, GB (700), H, LD (600), S. – <em>Exsiccatae</em>: <em>Sveriges
torfbildande växter</em>, utgifna af Svenska Mosskulturföreningen, fasc. 1-2, nos. 1-104, Jönköp-
ing 1900-1901 (see Sayre 1969).

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 389; BM 5: 2120; CSP 19: 151; GR p. 502;
KR p. 719-721 (main bibl., b. 12 Dec 1849, d. 21 Dec 1903); LS 26887-26888, 39954-
39956; SBC P. 133.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Brit. Mus. gen. cat. print. books 239: 753. 1964.
Lindman, S., Sv. män kvinn. 8: I. 1955.
Nilsson, E., Sv. bot. Tidskr. 75(5): 291-294. 1981 (biogr. sketch, portr.).

	1977 (musei at S).
Wittrock, V.B., Acta Horti Berg. 3(2): 74. 1903, 3(3): 56, 74. 1905.

14.685. <em>Traité des végétaux</em> qui composent l'agriculture de l'empire français, ou catalogue

de commerce des frères Tollard, ... avec un exposé rapide des caractères les plus saillans
qui en indiquent les différences, qualités et usages, et notamment des espèces peu con-
nues et dont la naturalisation présente des avantages. Suivi de considérations sur les
semis et les plantations, et de l'indication pour chaque mois des travaux à faire dans les

Tolmachev, Alexsandr Innokent'evich (1903-1979), Russian botanist; with the
Botanical Institute of the Academy of Sciences, Leningrad 1925; director of the Bureau
for the Exploration of the Northern regions at Archangelsk 1934-1942; in Dushaube
(Tadzhik branch of the Academy) 1942-1947; id. Sakhalin Branch 1947-1955, from
1955 again in Leningrad at the Komarov Botanical Institute; specialist on arctic-alpine
research. (<em>Tolm</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: VLA; other material in C, E, LE. – <em>Letters</em> at G.

Tolmie, William Fraser (1812-1886), British botanical collector on the Northwest
coast of America; student of W.J. Hooker; medical officer in Vancouver 1832, later also
associated with the Canadian Geological Survey; first botanist to ascend and to collect
on Mount Rainier (1833). (<em>Tolmie</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: K; other material at E-GL, GH, OXF. – <em>Letters</em> at K.

Tomaschek, Antonín [Anton] (1826-1891), Moravian botanist and high school teach-
er; studied at the University of Olmiiütz; assistant teacher at the state gymnasium of
Pressburg (Bratislava) 1850-1852; at the University of Vienna 1852-1853; assistant
teacher at Görz and Cilly 1854-1856; at the Gymnasium of Lemberg 1856-1863; in
charge of the Institute for Meteorology and Terrestrial Magnetism, Vienna 1863-1865;
again in Lemberg 1865-1870; professor at the gymnasium and at the Technical Univers-
ity of Brünn from 1870. (<em>Tomaschek</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: BRNU.

Tommasini, Muzio Giuseppe Spirito de [Mutius Joseph Spiritus, Ritter von]
(1794-1879), Austro-Hungarian (Trieste-Italian) magistrate and botanist; educated at

PAGE: 390
HEADING: TOMMASINI

Lemberg, Wien and Graz; in administrative functions in Zara, Spalato 1817-1827; dis-
trict commissioner in Cattaro (Kotor) 1827; assessor of the Triest Council 1827-1839,
from 1839-1861 as chairman of the Triest council and (from 1851) mayor ("podesta") of
the town; student of the flora of the Austrian coastal regions and Istria. (<em>Tomm</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: TSM; other material at B (some types; extant), BHU, BR, C,

to D.F.L. von Schlechtendal at HAL; other letters at G and UPS-UB.

Tonduz, Adolphe (1862-1921), Swiss plant collector and botanist; studied at the Tech-
nical School at Lausanne 1876-1881, studied medicine at the University of Lausanne
1881-1885; with the Lausanne Botanical Institute 1885-1889; went to Costa Rica 1889
as collector at the Instituto fisico-geografica nacional founded by H. Pittier 1889-1903;
employed at the Costa Rican Museo Nacional 1903-1920; from 1920-1921 pathologist at
the Agricultural Service of Guatemala. (<em>Tonduz</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: US and CR; other material in A, AMES, B (mainly destr.), BM,
BR (p.p. orig.), C, DPU, F, G (e.g. almost complete set of the Costa Rican coll.), GE,
GH, H-BR, K, KIEL, L, LAU, LE, M, MICH, MO, NY, P, PH, S, Z. – <em>Letters</em> at G.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 390 (b. 18 Sep 1862, d. 17 Dec 1921); BM 5:
2121; IH 2: 689; LS 26903-26904; Rehder 5: 854; SIA 224; TL-2/11.617; Tucker 1: 693;
Urban-Berl. 315, 404.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Beauverd, G., Bull. Soc. bot. Genève ser. 2. 14. 12-13. 1922 (obit.).
Pittier, H., Gazette de Lausanne 24 Feb 1922 (obit.).
Pittier, H. &amp; J. Amann, Ber. Schweiz. bot. Ges. 32: ix-x. 1923 (obit. not; family name
	spelled "Tondu"; names "J.F. Adolphe").
Sayre, G., Mem. New York Bot. Gard. 19(3): 405. 1975 (coll.).

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Tonduzia</em> Pittier (1908); <em>Tonduzia</em> F.L. Stevens (1927).

Tonning, Henrik (Henrich, Heinrich] (1732-1796), Norwegian teacher and botanist;
Dr. med. Uppsala 1768, student of Linnaeus; teacher in Trondhjem and curator with

Tornabene, Francesco [later: Francisco] (1813-1897), Italian (Sicilian) Benedictine
monk (from Montecassino) and botanist; founder and director of the Botanical Garden
at Catania 1847 [1858]-1892; from 1850 also professor of botany at Catania University.
(<em>Tornab</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: CAT; other material at G-DC. – <em>Letters</em> at G.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: AG 5(1): 146; Barnhart 3: 392 (b. 18 Mai 1813, d. 16
Sep 1897); BL 2: 392, 396, 724; BM 5: 2123; Bossert p. 403; CSP 6: 9, 19: 167; De Toni
1: cxxiii, 2: cxv; GR p. 524;, cat. p. 72; Herder p. 73, 124, 283, 353; Jackson p. 103, 187,
322; LS 26923; Morren ed. 2, p. 26, ed. 10, p. 82; PR 9395-9400, ed. 1: 10365-10366;
Quenstedt p. 432; Rehder 5: 854; Saccardo 1: 165, 229, 2: 108; SBC p. 133; Tucker 1:
693, 2: xxxviii.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Bot. Centralbl. 53: 96. 1893 (T. retired; Fausto Novi successor at
	Catania), 74: 256. 1898 (d.); Bot. Jahrb. 25 (Beibl. 60): 54. 1898 (d.); Dizion. encicl.
	ital. 12: 263. 1961; Nat. Nov. 20: 315. 1898 (d.).
Baccarini, P., Boll. Accad. Gioenia ser. 2. 50: 9-12. 1898 (obit., list publ.).

	1892).

	alla fondazione del r. Orto botanica in Catania il 31 Luglio 1858. Catania, 1858, 35
	p. (copy at G; formal date of foundation garden 31 Jul 1838).

Univ. Habana 1890; professor at Habana University and director of the Botanical

Torrend, Camille (1875-1961), French clergyman (S.J.) and mycologist; active in
France, Portugal and Ireland; from 1910 in Brazil (Bahia), ultimately as professor of
botany and phytopathology in the Escola agricola da Baia [Bahia]. (<em>Torrend</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: URM; other material at COI, IACM, INA, NY, PAD, PAV,
SP. – <em>Exsiccatae</em>: <em>Fungi selecti exsiccati</em>, cent. 1-3, 1910-1914, nos. 1-100, 25a, 64a, 101-200,
152b, 176b, 201-300, 201a, 236a. Sets at BPI, FH, S, URM. – See J. Stevenson, Beih.
Nova Hedw. 36: 466-469. 1971 (full details; refs. to texts and commentaries). Centuries
1 and 2 were published each in 4 series. – <em>Letters</em> to W.G. Farlow at FH; other letters at
G.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 392; BM 5: 2125; IH 1 (ed. 7): 344; Kelly p.
228; LS 3357, 26929-26932, 39960-39978, suppl. 27984-27992; MW p. 500; Stevenson p.
1260.

Fournier, P., Voy. déc. mission. natural. franç. 2: 206-212. 1932 (biogr. details, list

Torrey, John (1796-1873), American botanist and chemist; studied medicine at the
College of Physicians and Surgeons, New York (M.D. 1818), practicing physician New
York 1818-1822; professor of chemistry at the United States Military Academy, West
Point 1824-1827, id. at New York College of physicians and surgeons 1827-1855, trustee
id. 1856-1873, id. concurrently at Princeton 1830-1855; United States Assayer, U.S.
Mint, New York 1853-1873; first president of the Torrey botanical Club. (<em>Torr</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: NY (incl. library mss. and corr.); other material distributed by
Torrey (incl. that of other collectors): AWH, B (Bridel), BR, BUF, C, DBN, DPU,
DWC, E, E-GL, FI, G, GH, H, K, KIEL, L, LE, LZ (destr.), M, MASS, MICH, MO,
MSC, NYS, OXF, P-JU, PH, UPS, US, W, WECO. Torrey correspondence at NY (see
Lenley); Torrey letters (widely scattered) also at G, GH (ca. 375), PH and US. Copies
of letters from W.S. Sullivant to Torrey at FH.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: AG 5(1): 376; Backer p. 589; Barnhart 3: 392 (b. 15 Aug
1796, d. 10 Mar 1873); BL 1: 200, 321; BM 2: 617, 711, 5: 2125-2126; Bossert p. 404;
Clokie p. 255; CSP 6: 10, 8: 1103, 11: 625, 12: 738, 19: 169; DAB 18: 596-598
(Barnhart); DSB 13: 432-433 (A.H. Dupree); Ewan ed. 1: 322-323, 357, ed. 2: 222;
Frank 3 (Anh.): 105; GR p. 197, cat. 72; Herder p. 481 [index]; Hortus 3: 1205; IF p.
734; IH 1 (ed. 2): 88, (ed. 3): m, (ed. 6): 365, (ed. 7): 344, 2: (files); Jackson p. 355,
356, 361, 364; Langman p. 742; Lasègue p. 585 (index); Lenley p. 411-412, 470-471 and
cat. Torrey corr.; LS 26934-26937; ME 1: 234, 3: 666-667 [index]; NI 1971-1973; PH
538 [index]; PR 1947, 2681-2682, 3040, 4555, 5348, 8536, 9401-9420, ed. 1: 2061, 5933,
9485, 10368-10376; Rehder 5: 854-855; RS p. 145; SIA [index]; SK 4: ccxiv; SO 509;
Sotheby 758; Stevenson p. 1260; TL-1/342, 1313-1321; TL-2/see indexes; Tucker 1: 14,

14.755. <em>Monograph of North American Cyperaceae</em> ... to which is appended a monograph of

	Lyc. nat. Hist. 3: [239]-448, [449-451]. 1836. – <em>Rhynchosporeae</em> revised "entirely" by
	Asa Gray, whose <em>Monograph ... of Rhynchospora</em> was published ib. 3: 191-220, 221-238.
	1836, thus immediately preceding Torrey's paper. See TL-2/2120 and C. Gilly,
	Rhodora 43: 333-335. 1941.

14.757. <em>A fora of North America</em>: containing abridged descriptions of all the known indi-
genous and naturalized plants growing north of Mexico; arranged according to the
natural system ... New-York (Wiley &amp; Putnam), London (Wiley &amp; Putnam, ...), Paris
(Bossange &amp; Co. ...) 1838-1843. Oct. 2 vols. (<em>Fl. N. Amer</em>.).

<em>Co-author</em>: Asa Gray (1810-1888), see TL-2/1: 983-993.
<em>Publ</em>.: 2 vols., in 7 parts 1838-1843; vol. 1 completed, vol. 2 issued without title-page but
	with dated covers. <em>Copies</em>: BR, G, HH, M, MICH, Teyler, US(3), USDA; IDC 5771.
	<em>Preface</em>: Jun 1840, p. [i]-xiv, [xv] (dates on p. [vi]).
	<em>1</em>(<em>1</em>): Jul 1838, cover-t.p., p. [1]-184.
	<em>1</em>(<em>2</em>): Oct 1938, cover-t.p., p. 185-360.
	<em>1</em>(<em>3</em>): Jun 1840, cover-t.p., p. 361-544.
	<em>1</em>(<em>4</em>): Jun 1840, p. 545-711.
	<em>2</em>(<em>1</em>): Mai 1841, cover-t.p., p. [1]-184.
	<em>2</em>(<em>2</em>): Apr 1842, cover-t.p., p. 185-392.
	<em>2</em>(<em>3</em>): Feb 1843, cover-t.p., p. 393-504, [i-ii, index issued later! Present in one of the US
	copies].
<em>Facsimile ed</em>.: 1969, New York and London (Hafner Publishing Company) 1969, 2 vols.
	Introduction by Joseph Ewan. <em>Copies</em>: B, FAS, HH. – Classica botanica americana
	vol. 4.
<em>1</em>: 1969, p. [ii*-iv*], [i]-xviii introd. Ewan, [i]-xiv, [xv], cover-t.p., fasc. 1, p. [1]-184,
	cover-t.p., fasc. 2, inside cover notice, p. 185-360, cover-t.p., fasc. 3, p. 361-544,
	cover-t.p., fasc. 4, p. 545-711.
	<em>2</em>: 1969, p. [ii*-iv*], [i]-xviii introd. Ewan, cover-t.p., fasc. 1, p. [1]-184, cover-t.p.,
	fasc. 2, p. 185-392, cover-t.p., fasc. 3, p. 393-504, p. [i-ii, index]. – This index to
	vol. 2, 2 printed pages, was evidently issued later.
<em>Notes</em>: (1) Tucker (1921) mentions reprints of portions of vol. 1 which differ slightly from
	the original.
	(2) Several taxa must be attributed to Nuttall as is explained by Torrey and Gray in
	the preface: p. ix: "To Mr Nuttall we are indebted for a nearly complete suite of
	the plants collected during his recent journey across the Rocky Mountains to
	Oregon and California, accompanied with manuscript descriptions of the new
	genera and species; ..." On p. xiv (note) "When the dash is omitted after the
	character of the species, the description is derived from the author whose name
	immediately follows; when the dash is inserted, we are alone responsible for the
	description".
	(3) For the use of infrageneric categories in this work see Brizicky (1969): most sub-
	divisions of genera are sections.
	(4) See ME 3: 426 for contemporary reviews.

PAGE: 406
HEADING: TORREY

	(5) Five of the seven herbaria used by T. &amp; G. for the <em>Flora</em> are now at PH: T. Nuttall
	(early), L.D. von Schweinitz, B.S Barton, H. Muhlenberg and the Academy herb.
	itself. For full details see Mears (1980).
<em>Ref</em>.: Brandegee, T.S., Zoe 4: 369-372. 1894.
	Brizicky, G., Taxon 18: 653. 1969.
	Coville, F., Proc. Biol. Soc. Washington 13: 109-121. 1899.
	Ewan, J., Editor's introduction to facsimile reprint 1969, p. i-xviii, see also <em>in</em> Current
	topics in plant science 155-160. 1969 and Southw. Louisiana J. 7: 21. 1967.
	Gray, A., <em>in</em> G. Thurber, Bull. Torrey bot. Club 4: 33-34. 1873. See also Amer. J. Sci.
	ser. 3. 24: 321-331. 1882.
	Greene, E.L., Pittonia 1: 238-245. 1889.
	Jackson, B.D., J. Bot. 31: 297-299. 1893.
	Mears, J.A., Proc. Acad. nat. Sci. Philadelphia 132: 228-238. 1980 (relevance of col-
	lections PH to the <em>Flora</em>).
	Preston, H.W., Rhodora 8: 232-233. 1906 (2 editions!).
	Stafleu, F.A., Taxon 18: 715-717. 1969 (rev. facs. ed.).
	Tucker, E.M., J. Arnold Arb. 2: 183-184. 1921 (dates).
	Wagenitz, G., Bot. Jahrb. 89 (Lit.): 36. 1969 (rev. facs. ed.).

14.758. <em>A flora of the state of New York</em>, comprising full descriptions of all the indigenous
and naturalized plants hitherto discovered in the state; with remarks on their econom-
ical and medicinal properties ... Albany (Carroll and Cook, ...) 1843, 2 vols. Qu. (<em>Fl.
New York</em>).

<em>1</em>: 1843 (p. ix: Dec 1842), engraved t.p. [of series: Natural History of New York ...], p.
	[i*-iii*], [i]-xii, [1]-484, <em>pl. 1-72</em> (numbers not always present on plates; col. liths.).
<em>2</em>: 1843, engraved t.p. [id.], p. [i-iii], [1]-572, <em>pl. 73-75, 75a, 76-127, 128/129, 130-144, 144a,
	145-161</em> (col. liths.).

Torrey, Ray Ethan (1887-1956), American botanist; B.S. Massachusetts Agricultural
College [later: Massachusetts State Coll. Amherst] 1912, M.A. Harvard 1916; Dr. phil.
ib., student of E.C. Jeffrey, 1918, assistant professor of biology at Grove City College,
Pa., 1912-1915, instructor in botany, Wesleyan University 1918-1919; professor of
botany at Massachusetts State Coll. [later University of Massachusetts, Amherst] 1919-
1956. (<em>R.E. Torr</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Ainsworth p. 340; Barnhart 3: 393 (b. 15 Dec 1887, d. 16
Jan 1956); Hirsch p. 302; IH 1 (ed. 2): 15, (ed. 3): 16; Tucker 3: 310.

Anon., Amer. men sci. eds. 3-8, 1921-1949; Index Amer. bot. lit. 1886-1966, 4: 368.
	1969; The New York Times 17 Jan 1956, p. L-33; Wesleyan Univ. Bull. 65 (12(2)):
	40. 1918 (instr. bot. Wesl. Univ.); Who's who New England 3: 1266. 1938.
Francis, R., Forum, Mass. State Coll., Amherst, 107(2): 160-164. 1947.
Tippo, O., University of Massachusetts index 1956 (typewritten copy of obit. at MO, 3
	p.; "spent the rest of his life [i.e. 1919-1956] ... indeed, rarely if ever, leaving the
	environs of Amherst").

Torssell, Gustaf (1811-1849), Swedish printer and botanist; studied in Uppsala from

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: UPS; further material in WRSL.

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: The etymology of <em>Torsellia</em> E.M. Fries (1849) could not be determined.

Totten, Henry Roland (1892-1974), American botanist; A.B. Univ. N. Carol. 1913,
M.A. ib. 1914, Dr. phil. ib. 1923; from 1913-1963 with the Dept. of Botany, Univ. N.
Carol., Chapel Hill, ultimately as professor of botany; from 1963 emeritus professor of
botany ib., LL.D. Atlantic Christian College 1957. (<em>Totten</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: NCU; other material at WCUH. – Manuscripts at NCU.

Toula, Franz (1845-1920), Austrian mineralogist and geologist; studied at the
Technische Hochschule, Wien, as well as at the University; assistant with C.G.F. von
Hochstetter 1869-1872; teacher at the Gumpendorfer Realschule 1872; Dr. phil. Univ.
Rostock 1873; habil. Techn. Univ. Wien 1877; lecturer in palaeontology ib. 1877-1880,
in geology of Austria and Hungary 1880-1881; extraordinary (1881) and ordinary
(1884) professor of mineralogy and geology until 1917. (<em>Toula</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Andrews p. 340; Barnhart 3: 393; BM 5: 2126-2127; CSP
8: 1104, 11: 626-627, 19: 172-173; Ewan ed. 2: 222; Herder p. 36; Quenstedt p. 433; SIA
7177.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Cat. gén. livr. impr. Bibl. natl. 192: 288-292. 1965; Who's who sci. int.
	1912-1914.
Degener, H.A.L., Wer ist's ed. 5. 1484-1485. 1911, ed. 6. 1637-1638. 1912 (b. 20 Dec
	1845).

Poggendorff, J.C., Biogr.-lit. Handw.-Buch 3: 1361. 1883, 4: 1516-1517. 1904, 5: 1265.
	1922, 6: 2680. 1940 (b. 20 Dec 1845, d. 3 Jan 1920).

	naturw. Kenntn. Wien 60: 13-23. 1920 (obit.).

	(list publ. in "Schriften").

	[index]. 1901.

Toumey, James William (1865-1932), United States forestry botanist; studied at
Michigan Agricultural College; B.A. 1889, M.S. 1896; Dr. Sci. Syracuse 1920; instructor
in botany Mich. Agr. Coll. 1890-1891; curator of botany State College and Experiment
Station, Tucson, Arizona 1891-1898; superintendent of tree planting U.S.D.A. 1899-
1900; asst. prof. forestry Yale 1901-1903, professor and director of the Marsh Botanical
Garden, Yale 1903-1910; Moris K. Jesup professor of silviculture Forest School, Yale
1910-1932. (<em>Toumey</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: US. – Further material at A, ARIZ, DS, GH, MO, MSC,
WECO. – <em>Field notes</em> and other archival material at US (SIA); letters to Farlow at FH.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 393 (b. 17 Apr 1865, d. 6 Mai 1932); Bossert

Tourlet, Ernest Henry (1843-1907), French pharmacist and botanist; studied phar-
macy in Paris 1865-1868; succeeded his father in the pharmacy at Chinon (Indre-et-
Loire); active floristic botanist, archeologist and numismatist. (<em>Tourlet</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Owned a considerable herbarium. Some material in E.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 394 (b. 4 Aug 1843, d. 29 Jul 1907); BL 2:
167, 724; BM 5: 2128; CSP 8: 1104; Morren ed. 10, p. 62; Tucker 1: 695.

	Bibl. natl. 192: 553-555. 1965.
Lutz, L., Bull. Soc. bot. France 54: 703-705. 1907 (obit., bibl.), also in E.H. Tourlet (ed.
	J. Ivolas) <em>Cat. pl. vasc. Indre-et-Loire</em> 1908, p. v-viii, portr.
Tourlet, E.H., Docum. hist. bot. Touraine 89-91 (on his father, Louis René Henri
	Tourlet b. 1809), 102, 105-106 (on himself) 1905.

14.778. <em>Documents pour servir à l'histoire de la botanique en Touraine</em> ... Tours (Librairie
Péricat ...) 1905. Oct. (<em>Doc. hist. bot. Touraine</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: 1905 (Nat. Nov. Jun(1) 1906), p. [1]-106, [107, cont.; 108, colo.]. <em>Copies</em>: G(2),
	USDA. – Preprinted or reprinted from Bull. Soc. pharm. Indre-et-Loire 1-2: 247-...,
275-..., 303. ..., 313-..., 361-... 1905 (Journal n.v.).

14.779. <em>Catalogue raisonné des plantes vasculaires</em> du département <em>d'Indre-et-Loire</em> par E.-H.
Tourlet ... publié par les soins de J. Ivolas ... Paris (Paul Klincksieck ...) Tours
(Théophile Tridon ... 1908. Oct. (<em>Cat. pl. vasc. Indre-et-Loire</em>).

<em>Editor</em>: Pierre Louis Jean Ivolas (1842-1908).
<em>Publ</em>.: Apr-Jun 1908 (p. x: 1 Mar 1908; BSbF rd séance 20 Jun 1908), p. [i-iv], portr.,
	[v]-xxiii, [1]-621, [623, colo.]. <em>Copies</em>: B, B-S, BR, G, HH, NY, USDA. – <em>Nécrologie</em> by
	L. Lutz on p. [v]-viii.
<em>Preliminary publ</em>.: Bull. Soc. bot. France 51(5): 222-237. Jun, 279-287. Aug 1904. "Plantes
	introduites, naturalisées ou adventices ...", reprinted as <em>Tableau de la flore adventice du
	département d'Indre-et-Loire</em>, Paris 1904, 26 p. – See BL 2: 167 for further details.

PAGE: 412
HEADING: TOURLET

<em>Ref</em>.: Cuisinier-Reclus, M., Bot. Centralbl. 110: 447-448. 27 Apr 1909 (rev.).
	Malinvaud, E., Bull. Soc. bot. France 55 (bibl.): 487-489. 11 Aug 1908.

Tournefort, Joseph Pitton de (1656-1708), French botanist; botanised in S.E. France
with Charles Plumier 1678; studied with Pierre Magnol in Montpellier 1679-1680; trav-
elled in the Eastern Pyrenees and Spain 1681; took medical degree in Montpellier 1682;
at Aix 1682-1683; assistant to Guy Fagon at the Jardin du Roi, Paris 1683-1708, from
1693 replacing Fagon; professor of botany ib. 1708; travelled in S. France (1685, 1686),
England (1687), Eastern Pyrenees and Spain 1687; in the Provence 1688 (Dr. med.
Faculté d'Orange), in Spain and Portugal 1688-1689; Lic. méd. Faculté de Médecine,
Paris 1695; Dr. med. ib. 1696; travelled in the Levant 1700-1702; professor at the
Collège Royal 1706. (<em>Tourn</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: P (herbier historique), kept separately, 6963 species. Tournefort
left the herbarium to the French state for the use of the "Messieurs de l'Académie
Royale des Sciences ..." It was kept at the Jardin du Roi. When this institution became
the Muséum d'Histoire naturelle one of the original articles of foundation stipulated that
the Tournefort herbarium had to be kept separate, in the order and with the nom-
enclature of the author. The manuscript catalogue mentions no collectors; most speci-
mens were collected by Tournefort himself; there may be some specimens sent or collec-
ted by his correspondents, e.g. by Petiver. The herbarium is available as IDC microfiche
no. 6208 (with index). – An important set of Tournefort plants is at B-W, see Wagenitz
(1962). Tournefort material at BM included in the Sloane herbarium (see Dandy 1958,
p. 220), in the general herbarium ("Banksian herbarium", Levant 1702 and other
material). The Sherard herbarium (OXF) contains also a considerable set of Tournefort
specimens. Small numbers of Tournefort plants are at FI, H (herb. Steven), P-JU, PH.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: AG 2(1): 711, 5(1): 196, 248, 6(2): 358; Ainsworth p.
310, 348; Backer p. 590; Barnhart 3: 394 (b. 5 Jun 1656, d. 28 Dec 1708); BM 5: 2128,
8: 1320; Bossert p. 404; Bret. p. 123; Clokie p. 255; Colmeiro 1: ccii; Dryander [see
index]; DSB 13: 442-444 (J.F. Leroy); Frank 3 (Anh.): 104-105; GR p. 344-345;
Hawksworth p. 186; Hegi 6(1): 222, 231, 4(3): 1177, 5(3): 2131, 6(1): 53, 6(2): 631;
Henrey 2: 744, 3: 1432-1433; Herder p. 481; Hortus 3: 1205; HU 392, 419, 450; IH 1
(ed. 2): 94, (ed. 3): 119, (ed. 6): 365 (ed. 7): 344; Jackson p. 30, 31, 289; KR p. 722;
Krempelh. 2: 3; Lasègue p. 586; LS 26949-26954; Moebius p. 457; MW p. 500; NI
1966-1979, 3: 65; Plesch p. 437-438; PR 603, 2179, 6923, 6992, 7380, 7436, 7440, 9423-
9429, 9662, 10.000, ed. 1: 2494, 5896, 6622, 7736, 7818, 8276, 8380, 8384, 8623, 10384-
10388, 10627, 10698; Rehder 5: 855; SO 763; Sotheby 759-762; Stevenson p. 1260; TL-
1/284, 457, 1322-1323; TL-2/see indexes; TR 1427-1428; Tucker 1: 695, 3: 310; Urban-
Berl. p. 404.

<sm>MANUSCRIPTS</sm>: The original drawings by Claude Aubriet for the <em>Elémens</em> and the <em>Institut-
iones</em>, as well as proof sheets, are at the <em>Muséum national d'histoire naturelle</em>, Paris. Aubriet's
plates for the Corollarium are also at this institution; they were later published by
Desfontaines in the Ann. Mus. nat. For a full discussion of Tournefort's manuscripts see
Duprat (1957). A copy of the "Catalogue des plantes ... d'Espagne et de Portugal" is at
BM (Banksian mss. 82).

<sm>MAIN</sm> <sm>GENERAL</sm> <sm>TREATMENT</sm>: G. Becker et al., Tournefort, Paris 1957, 323 p. (most as-
pects; no bibl.); for bibliography see e.g. Dryander. – Reproductions of title-pages: see
Burdet et al. (1985).

<sm>COMPOSITE</sm> <sm>WORKS</sm>: (1) See P. Hermann, <em>Schola botanica</em> 1689, TL-2/2685. – The <em>Schola
botanica</em> by Tournefort occupies p. 1-300; the <em>Paradisi baiavi prodromus</em> by Hermann p.
301-389. The "Edente in lucem S.W.A." may refer to William Sherard (see HU 382
and Jackson (1874)). <em>Copies</em>: BR, HU, NY, U.
(2) For Tournefort's <em>Materia medica</em>, London 1708 and the <em>Traité de la matière medicale</em>,
Paris 1717, see HU 419 and J.F. Bréchot &amp; M. Guédès (1975).

<sm>HANDWRITING</sm>: J.E. Dandy, The Sloane herbarium 1958, facsimile no. 72. Clokie p. 279.

Linnaeus (1753); <em>Tournefortiopsis</em> Rusby (1907); (journal): <em>Pittonia</em>, a series of papers
relating to botany and botanists, Berkeley, California. Vol. 1-5. 1887-1905.

	vignet 86 mm wide rather than 90 mm; text reset; plates on post 1742 paper. <em>Copies</em>:

<em>English version</em>: [1716-] 1719-1730, <em>133</em> and <em>134 pl. Copies</em>: G, K, PH, USDA. – "<em>The
	compleat herbal</em>: or, the botanical institutions of Mr. Tournefort, chief botanist to the
	late French King. Carefully translated [probably by John Martyn] from the original
	Latin. With large additions from Ray, Gerarde, Parkinson, and others, the most
	celebrated moderns. To which are added, two alphabetical indexes; one, containing
	the names; the other, the physical vertues and uses of the several plants. Illustrated
	with about five hundred copper plates, containing above four thousand different
	figures, all curiously engraven. A work highly instructive, and of general use ...
	London ((printed for R. Bomvicke, ...) 1719. Qu. [vol. 2: (printed for R. Walthoe,
	...) 1730. – Collation given by Henrey 3: no. 1432, based on copy at K. – Copies
	vary.

	22, 22-49, 50/51, 52, 53, 65-71, 71-80, 80-83, 84/85, 86-143).
	<em>2</em>: 1728-1730 (id.), p.[ii], 649 [i.e. 629], [ii], <em>134 pl</em>. (nos. 144-277).

Tournon, Dominique Jérôme (1758-post 1827), French physician and botanist; Dr.

PAGE: 416
HEADING: TOURNON

med. Toulouse 1788; director of the Jardin des plantes and professor of botany at the
Medical School at Toulouse. (<em>Tournon</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown. – <em>Letters</em> at UPS-UB.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: BM 5: 2128; Plesch p. 438; PR 9430, ed. 1: 10389;
Rehder 1: 407; Tucker 1: 695.

Tourret, Eugène Gilbert (1881-1914), French bryologist and teacher; studied at the
teacher's college of Moulins 1898-1901; teacher at Saint-Ennemond, Paray-le-Frésil and
La Ferbé-Hauterive; died while on active service in 1914. (<em>Tourr</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: CLF; other material at B (mainly destr.).

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 394; Urban-Berl. p. 315.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Rev. bryol. 48(3): 44. 1921 (publ.).
Bois, D., Bull. Soc. bot. France 62: 2. 1915 (obit.).
Brun, A., Gilbert Tourret (1881-1914). Un botaniste bourbonnais, Clermont 1932 (n.v.,
	fide Bull. Soc. bot. France 80: 686. 1933).
Lassimonne, Rev. sci. Bourbonnais 1923(3): 85-86 (biogr. sketch), 1928: 21.
Loiseau, J.E., Monde des Plantes 1971 (369): 7 (herb. at CLF).
Sayre, G., Bryologist 80: 519. 1977.

Toussaint, Anatole (1863-1943), French clergyman and botanist in Normandy; priest
at Bois-Jérôme. (<em>Toussaint</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: P (10.000), PC (musci); some duplicates in DBN.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 394; BL 1: 161, 321, 2: 147, 186, 204, 724;
BM 5: 2128; CSP 19: 176; Rehder 1: 535; Tucker 1: 695.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Bull. Acad. Géogr. Bot. 9: ii, 17. 1900, 11: 15. 1902, 13: 14. 1904; Cat.
	gén. livr. impr. Bibl. natl. 192: 911. 1965.

<sm>NOTE</sm>: Toussaint, clergyman, is often referred to simply as Abbé Toussaint; not to be
confused with the Chanoine [François] Toussaint, 1882-1964, who published on e.g. the
flora of Malmédy; see J. de Walque and R. Houart, Le Chanoine Toussaint, sa vie et
son oeuvre, Malmédy 1964 (Folklore Stavclot-Malmédy-Saint Vith 28, 1964, 68 p.).

Townsend, Frederick (1822-1905), British landowner and county squire, M.A.
Trinity Coll., Cambridge 1855; actively engaged in floristic botany associated with C.C.
Babington and W.W. Newbould, resided in Wickham, Hampshire 1865-1874; from
1874 on the family residence, Honington Hall, Warwickshire. (<em>Townsend</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: SLBI (5000); other material at C, CGE, K, NMW, OXF, WAR.

630-631, 12: 739, 19: 180; Desmond p. 615 (b. 5 Dec 1822, d. 16 Dec 1905); Herder p.
315; Jackson p. 253; Rehder 1: 403-534; Tucker 1: 695.

Townsend, John Kirk (1809-1851), American naturalist, especially interested in or-
nithology; collected plants on a journey with Th. Nuttall west of the Mississippi river;
travelled also in the Sandwich Islands and South America; in charge of the Ornitholog-
ical Department of the Smithsonian Institution and a member of the Philadelphia
Academy of Sciences. (<em>J.K. Townsend</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: PH and US. – Manuscript material at PH.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 395; BM 5: 2129; DAB 18: 617-618; Ewan

Tucker 1: 695.

HEADING: TRABUT

Townson, William (1850-1926), British-born New Zealand pharmaceutical chemist
and plant collector. (<em>Townson</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 395; BL 1: 85, 321; Desmond p. 615 (d. 11
Aug 1926).

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Aston, B.C., Trans. Proc. New Zealand Inst. 58(1-2): 186-188. 1927 (obit.,
	portr.).
Cheeseman, T.F., Manual New Zealand Fl. xxx, xxxiv. 1906.

<sm>NOTE</sm>: (1) Published <em>On the vegetation of the Westport district</em>, Trans. Proc. New Zealand
Inst. 39: 380-433, <em>pl. 14, 14a.</em> Jun 1907. See BL 1: 85.
(2) Robert Townson published <em>Travels in Hungary</em> with a short account of Vienna in the
year 1793 ... London (printed for G.G. and J. Robinson, ...) 1797. Qu. (<em>Trav.
Hungary</em>), which has a list of plants (some with descriptions) on p. 477-494. Also in
French: <em>Voyage en Hongrie</em>, Paris, an vii, 3 vols. (repr. An xi, 1803).

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Townsonia</em> Cheeseman (1906).

Trabut, Louis [Charles] (1853-1929), French botanist (Savoie-born, then part of
Sardinia and Piedmont); studied medicine at the Faculté de Médecine, Algiers 1873;
Dr. med. ib. 1878, Lic. Sci. nat. ib. 1879; practicing physician at Algiers 1879-1880;
professor of natural history at the École de Médecine et de Pharmacie, 1880-1923 and
physician at the Mustapha hospital 1880-1905; collaborated with J.A. Battandier on the
flora of Algeria 1876-1922; from 1892 also director of the Service botanique of Algeria
working on applied botany. (<em>Trab</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: AL. – Other material in B (mainly destr.), G, GOET, H, MPU,
MO, P, PAD, PC. – Sayre (1977) notes that the originals of the bryophytes are no
longer at AL; this herbarium informed us in 1964 that Trabut's spermatophytes and
bryophytes were still present.– <em>Letters</em> to F. Renauld and E. Malinvaud at P; other letters
at G.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: AG 3: 513-514; Barnhart 3: 396 (b. 12 Jul 1853, d. 23
Apr 1929); BJI 2: 178; BL 1: 17, 18, 20, 321; BM 1: 110, 5: 2130, 8: 1321; Bossert p. 405;
CSP 11: 631, 12: 739, 19: 181-182; GR p. 353; Hegi 5(1): 593; IH 1 (ed. 2): 14, (ed. 3):
15, (ed. 6): 365, (ed. 7): 344; Kelly p. 228; Langman p. 743; LS 26962-26973a, 40000-
40009, suppl. 28011-28013; Morren ed. 10, p. 112; MW p. 500-501; NI 2: 183; Rehder
5: 885-886; SBC p. 133; Stevenson p. 1260; TL-1/47-50; TL-2/352-356, 3437, 11051, see
J.A. Battandier; Tucker 1: 696, 780, 2: xxxviii, 3: 311; Urban-Berl. p. 404; Zander ed.
10, p. 725, ed. 11, p. 718, 827.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Bot. Centralbl. 1/2: 766. 1880 (app. prof. nat. hist. Algiers), 113: 304.
	1910 (Légion d'honneur); Bull. Soc. bot. France 27 (bibl.): 46. 1880 (app. Algiers),
	41 (bibl.): 528. 1894 (app. Officier de l'Instruction publique), 57: 160. 1910 (École de
	Médecine becomes Faculté de Médecine; chair kept as professor); Cat. gén. livr. impr.
	Bibl. natl. 193: 99-104. 1966; Hedwigia 70: (74). 1930 (d.).; Index biogr. Acad. Sci.,
	Paris 494-495. 1954.; J. Bot. 67: 184. 1929 (d.); Österr. bot. Z. 79(1): 96. 1930.

HEADING: TRABUT

	illesia 2: 187-189. 1930 (obit.); Progr. Connaiss. bot. Algérie 137-145, <em>pl. 8.</em> 172, 181,

Trachsel, Kaspar [Caspar] (1788-1832), Swiss botanist and physician at Rüggisberg
(Riggisberg) nr Bern; Dr. med. Univ. Bern. (<em>Trachsel</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Owned a herbarium of the Canton of Bern, location unknown. –

library Bern.

Tracy, Clarissa, née Tucker (1818-1905), American botanist; married Horace Tracy
1844, widowed 1848; operated private schools at Honesdale 1851-1856 and Neenah,
Wisc. 1856-1859; matron in charge of domestic operations and teacher at Ripon
College, Wisc., retired 1893. (<em>Cl. Tracy</em>).

Tracy, Cyrus Mason (1824-1891), American botanist and civil engineer; some time
professor of materia medica Massachusetts College of Pharmacy; writer on the flora of
Essex Co., Mass., father of the composer Georg Lowell Tracy.

Tracy, Joseph Prince (1879-1953), American abstractor of land titles at Eureka,
Calif., amateur botanist and plant collector; studied at the University of California,
Eureka, A.B. ib. 1903; accountant and landsurveyor with the Belcher Abstract and Title
Company 1904-1953. (<em>J.P. Tracy</em>).

Tracy, Samuel Mills (1847-1920), American botanist and agronomist; MS Mich.
Agric. Coll. 1873; professor of botany, Missouri State Univ. 1877-1887; associated with
USDA in various functions; director of the USDA Experimental Station, Starkville,
Miss., 1887-1897; special agent 1897-1914; agronomist from 1914. (<em>Tracy</em>).

PAGE: 426
HEADING: TRACY

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: TAES (private herb.); important sets at F, MO (4393), MSC
and NY. Further material at A, B (mainly destr.), BM (1513), BPI, CM, CU, CUP, E,
F, GH, IA, LSU, MICH, MIN, MISSA, MO, NEB, NYS, PENN, PH, PUR, SMU,
TEX, US, VT. – <em>Exsiccatae</em>: <em>Plants of the Gulf States</em>, collected and distributed by S.M.
Tracy; irregular series; over 9000 specimens distributed (see Stevenson 1971). – <em>Library</em>
at TAES; <em>field notes</em> at US; <em>letters</em> to W.G. Farlow at FH; other letters at G, NY, PH, SIA.

Tradescant, John (1608-1662), British naturalist, traveller, collector and gardener; in
Virginia 1637 collecting material for his father's museum at South Lambeth; from 1638
gardener to Queen Henrietta Maria; continued the management and further develop-
ment of his father's garden and museum. (<em>Tradescant Jr</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: The collections of the Tradescants came into the hands of
Ashmole in 1674 and went to Oxford University (Ashmolean Museum) (see MacGregor
et al., 1983).

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: AG 2(2): 405; Backer p. 591; Barnhart 3: 397; BB p. 303;
BM 5: 2130, 8: 1321; Bossert p. 405; Dawson p. 616; DNB 19: 1072-1074; Dryander 3:

<sm>NOTE</sm>: For John Tradescant senior (1570/75-1638), father of John T. (b. 1608) see Ewan,

PAGE: 428
HEADING: TRADESCANT

DSB, Desmond p. 616, and M. Allan, The Tradescants 1964. Many of the references
under Tradescant junior actually deal to some extent with both father and son. Tradesc-
ant Sr. was the first western European botanist to visit Russia, see G.S. Boulger, J. Bot.
33: 33-38. 1895 and J. Hamel, Tradescant der Ältere 1618 in Rusland, St.
Petersburg/Leipzig 1847.

Trafvenfelt, Eric Carl (1774-1835), Swedish physician and botanist; Dr. med.
Uppsala 1797; ultimately "medicinalråd" at Stockholm, from 1801 with the title profes-
sor. (<em>Trafv</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Had a natural history cabinet. See Löwegren (1952) (mentions
no plants).

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 397; BM 5: 2130; Hortus 3: 1205; KR p. 723

Trail (sometime Traill), James William Helenus (1851-1919), British botanist; MA
Aberdeen 1870, MB 1876, MD 1879; assistant at the medical faculty, Univ. Aberdeen
1870-1873; on a South American exploring expedition 1873-1875; professor of botany,
Univ. Aberdeen 1877-1919; director of the Cruickshank Botanic Garden 1898-1919; co-
founder of the Aberdeen Working Men's Natural History Society 1886. (<em>Trail</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: ABD; other material at BH (photo's of palm types), BM (palms
Amaz., Brit. pl.), E, GH, GL, K (British and Amaz. coll.), NMW, NY. – <em>Letters</em> to W.G.
Farlow at FH.

405; CSP 8: 1106, 11: 631, 12: 739, 19: 182-183; Desmond p. 616-617 (b. 4 Mar 1851, d.
18 Sep 1919); Hawksworth p. 186; IH 1 (ed. 6): 365, (ed. 7): 344; Kelly p. 228; Kleppa
p. 81, 111; LS 25850, 26989-27018, 40010-40012; Morren ed. 10, p. 78; Rehder 5: 856;
Stevenson p. 1260; TL-2/6783, 13.087.

Traill, Catherine Parr (née Strickland) (1802-1899), British naturalist and writer;
married Thomas Traill 1832; emigrated to Canada 1832; resident in Lakefield,
Ashburnham and Rice Lake, Ontario. (<em>C. Traill</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Destroyed by fire (Desmond); some material at CAN and QK. –
A volume "Grasses from Stony Lake" at DAO (see Dore 1966).

Trana, Erik Andreas (1847-1933), Swedish botanist, egyptologist and judge; Dr. phil.
Uppsala 1872; Exam. jur. ib. 1876; with the Uppsala Court of Appeal 1876; from 1877-
	1917 in Göteborg in various judiciary functions. (<em>Trana</em>).

Transeau, Edgar Nelson (1875-1960), American botanist (phycologist); B.A.
Franklin and Marshall College, Lancaster, Pa. 1897; Dr. phil. Univ. Michigan 1904;
professor of biology, Alma College 1904-1906; with Carnegie Inst. Exp. Sta. Cold
Spring Harbor, Long Island 1906-1907; professor of botany East Illinois Teachers Coll.,
Charleston, Ill. 1907-1915; professor of plant physiology and ecology Ohio State Univ.,
Columbus, Ohio 1915-1946; professor emeritus ib. 1946. (<em>Transeau</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: OS (incl. types algae), ALMA. – <em>Letters</em> to W.G. Farlow at FH;

Tranzschel [Transhel], Woldemar [Andrejevich] (1868-1942), Russian botanist; as-
sistant Forestry Institute St. Petersburg; assistant for syst. bot. at the University of
Warsaw 1898; curator at the department of cryptogams of the St. Petersburg Botanical
Museum 1900, professor at the Institute for applied Zoology and Phytopathology,
Leningrad. (<em>Tranzschel</em>).

Trappen, Johannes [Jan] Everhardus van der (<em>fl</em>. 1834-1849), Dutch botanist and
physician; studied medicine at Utrecht University; Dr. med. Utrecht 1843; practicing
physician at Naaldwijk (Westland, Holland). (<em>Trappen</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: L (through D.J. Coster). – On the mss. <em>Flora westlandica</em> see
Jansen &amp; Wachter (1941) and H. Kleijn (1943). For a description of the original her-
barium, collections and plates with illustrations of fungi see Allg. Konst- Letterb.
1853(2): 190; a set of illustrations of fungi is in the University Library of Amsterdam.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: BL 2: 428, 440, 724; BM 5: 2132; Herder p. 77; Jackson
p. 325; JW 3: 372, 4: 410, 5: 253-254; NI 3: 65; PR 4822, 9435-9436, ed. 1: 5358, 10400-
10401; Rehder 5: 856; TL-1/608; TL-2/2007, 3874; Tucker 1: 696.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Brit. Mus. gen. cat. print. books 240: 913-914. 1964.
Jansen, P. &amp; W.H. Wachter, Ned. kruidk. Arch. 51: 431-434. 1941 (on his herbarium
	and other collections and a mss. Flora westlandica).
Kleijn, H., Ned. kruidk. Arch. 52: 258-287. 1943 (descr. mycological plates).
Trappen, J.E. van der, Allg. Konst- Letterb. 1853(2): 190-191 (herbarium for sale; to be
	sold by auction Nov 1853; list of species new for the Westland region).

<em>Algemeen Register</em> to <em>vols. 1-8</em>, Utrecht 1844 (preface), p. [i]-xcvi. <em>Copy</em>: U.

14.874. <em>Specimen historico-medicum de Coffea</em>, quod ex auctoritate rectoris magnifici Cornelii
Adriani Bergsma, ... amplissimique Senatus Academicis consensu et nobilissimae Facul-
tatis medicae decreto, pro gradu doctoratus, summisque in medicina honoribus ac privi-

submittit Johannes Everhardus van der Trappen haganus [of the Hague, 's Graven-

PAGE: 436
HEADING: TRAPPEN

<em>Publ</em>.: 22 Dec 1843, p. [i-vi], [1]-152 (137-140: "Sententiae", theses]. <em>Copies</em>: HH, NY,
	U.
<em>Note</em>: Cornelis Adriaan Bergsma (1798-1859) was professor of botany at the University of
	Utrecht from 1835-1859, preceding the real founder of Utrecht plant systematics,
	F.A.W. Miquel, q.v. Bergsma was "rector magnificus" (chairman of the Senate) in
	1843 when his student van der Trappen took his degree.

14.875. <em>Bijdrage tot de kennis aan Neêrlana</em>"<em>s flora</em>; ... te 's Gravenhage (by A. Kloots &amp;
Comp. ...) [1852]. Oct. (in fours). (<em>Bijdr. Neêrl.fl</em>.).

<em>Publ</em>.: 1852 (p. iv; Jan 1852), p. [i-iv], [1]-52. <em>Copies</em>: AMD-UB, KNAW. List of plants
	in the "Westland" (S.W. Holland).

Trattinnick, Leopold (1764-1849), Austrian botanist of private means in Wien, dedi-
cating himself almost exclusively to natural-history; Austrian "Landschafts-
Phytograph" (title), curator of the united k.k. Hof-Naturaliencabinete 1809-1835.
(<em>Tratt</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: W. – Mss. also at W.–One specimen in H (Steven); plants identified by
him at OXF. Trattinnick sold sets of wax models of fungi in 1804-1808; sets at M and W. –
<em>Letters</em> by Trattinnick to C.H. Mertens at HU; other letters at G, UPS-UB; mss. <em>Über das
Nationalisieren der Gewächse</em> at UPS-UB.

<sm>NAME</sm>: Trattinnick used this spelling of his name on the title page of almost all his
publications seen by us; Pritzel and some other sources use "Trattinick", Wurzbach
"Trattinnik".

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: ADB 38: 498-499; Ainsworth p. 65, 312, 313, 348;
Backer p. 662; Barnhart 3: 398 (b. 26 Mai 1764, d. 14 Jan 1849); Biol.-Dokum. 18:
9345; Bossert p. 405; Clokie p. 256; CSP 6: 23; Dryander 3: 646, 648, 654; DTS 1: 305;
DU 307-308; Frank 3 (Anh.): 105; GF p. 78; Hortus 3: 1205; Jackson p. 114, 142, 163,
192, 263, 264, 422; Kelly p. 229; LS 27038-27041; MW p. 501; NI 1982-1992; see
indexes; Plesch p. 439-440; PR 9437-9451, 8267, ed. 1: 9200, 10402-10423; Rehder 5:
857; RS p. 145; Sotheby 767-770; Stevenson p. 1260; TL-1/1324-1325; TL-2/3932;
10.876, 11.091, 11.643; Tucker 1: 697, 3: 311; WU 46: 281-285; Zander ed. 10, p. 725,
ed. 11, p. 827.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Bot. Zeit. 7: 344. 1849 (d.); Brit. Mus. gen. cat. print. books 240: 928-
	929. 1964; Flora 15: 401, 402 (coll.), 19: 126. 1836 (retirement), 32: 480. 1849 (d.);
	Österr. bot. W. 1: 20. 1851 (herb. T. offered to government by widow at 400
	fl.C.M.); Portraiten-Galerie berühmter Aerzte und Naturforscher des Österr. Kaiser-
	thumes no. 30. 1838 (portr.).
Beck, G., Bot. Centralbl. 33: 249. 1888 (first Tratt. herb. donated 1808), 34: 87 (app. T.
	as "20 Gustos'" W), 87 (retirem. 1 Dec 1835), 151 (T. coll. at W 12.000); <em>in</em> Fritsch,
	K. et al., Bot. Anst. Wiens 55, 57. 1894 (herb. 1808; state of coll. W 1835).

Jessen, K.F.W., Bot. Gegenw. Vorz. 309, 394. 1864.

	UPS-UB).

Potonié, H., Österr. bot. Z. 31: 318. 1881 (cites T. in Flora 4: 717-727. 1821; early
	Statement of phylogenetic concept of "improvement" of plants in the course of
	thousands of years).
Schmid, G., Goethe u.d. Naturw. 259, 592. 1940.
Trattinnick, L., Jahrb. Gewächsk. 1(2): 169-185. 1819 (800 plates of plants for sale; list).
Wittrock, V.B., Acta Horti Berg. 3(2): 86, 186. 1903.

	editio nova. Oesterreichs Schwämme in einer Auswahl durch vierzig Abbildungen
	und Beobachtungen beleuchtet. ... Wien (In Carl Gerold's Buchhandlung) 1830. Qu.
	– p. [1]-202 and <em>pl. 1-18</em> are a reissue of the original text and plates; p. 203-210 and <em>pl.
	19-20</em> are new.

14.879. <em>Thesaurus botanicus</em> ... Viennae [Wien] (typis Antonii Strauss) [1805-] 1819. Fol. (<em>Thes. bot</em>.).

<em>Publ</em>.: 1805-1819 (p. iv: 21 Jan 1819; in 20 fasc. of 4 plates each, of which the first five
	were available in 1805: 1 and 2 were listed as available at the Easter "Messe" 1805
	(Bot. Zeit. Regensb. no. 1 by 15 Mai 1805, no. 2 by 15 Jun 1805); fasc. 5 was
	available at the Michaelis "Messe" [late Sep] 1805; see also Rycoft (1965); we have
	seen no fascicle covers), p. [1]-13, [14, expl. pl.], <em>pl. 1-80</em> (copp. handcol., some stip-
	ple; mainly by Strenzel, others by Buchberger, Frister, Kniesech, Malknecht, Reine-
	lli, Joh. Schmid. – Originals extant, cf. NI 1992). <em>Copies</em>: G, HH, NY. USDA. – <em>Note</em>:
	the plates are of high quality, with careful and precise colouring. An extensive
	review, listing all plates is given in Flora 3(2): 722-731. 14 Dec 1820. <em>pl. 80, Tigridia
	pavonia</em>: "Finis coronat opus!" Publication started in 1805, the majority was published
	much later, illustrating the "Napoleonic pause" in book production, characteristic for
	the period. Some of the plates are from Andrews, Bot. Repos. (e.g. <em>11</em> = Andrews <em>pl.
	103</em>; <em>12</em>= Andrews <em>pl. 110</em>).
<em>Ref</em>.: Rycroft, H.B., J.S. Afr. Bot. 31: 89-93, <em>pl. 17.</em> 1965.

PAGE: 438
HEADING: TRATTINNICK

14.880. <em>Die essbaren Schwämme des Oesterreichischen Kaiserstaates</em> ... Wien und Triest (in
Geistingers Buchhandlung) 1809. Oct. (<em>Essb. Schwämme</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: 1809 (p. x: 6 Dec 1808), p. [i]-cxxiii, [1]-174, <em>30 pl</em>. (A-I, K-V, X-Z, AA-FF, col.
	copp.). <em>Copy</em>: Stevenson.
<em>Neue Ausgabe</em>: 1830 (p. 189: 15 Apr 1830), p. [i]-cxxiii, [1]-189, <em>30 pl</em>. (id.). <em>Copies</em>: FH,
	MICH, Stevenson. – Reissue of orig. text and plates with new text, p. 175-189,
	added. A separate leaflet with instructions to the binders (copy MICH) indicates
	that the book came out in five parts.

14.881. <em>Plan</em> eines botanischen Universalwerkes, welches unter dem Titel <em>Archiv der
Gewächskunde</em>, und in besonderen Unterabtheilungen unter eben so vielen besondern
Titeln erscheinet: Zum Gebrauche der Ärzte, Wundärzte, Veterinären, Apotheker,
Gärtner, Forstbeamten, Landwirthe, Reisenden, Fabrikanten, Künstler, Färber,
Erzieher, Statistiker und aller derjenigen, denen an der Kenntniss der Pflanzen etwas
gelegen ist. Wien (Auf Kosten des Herausgebers) 1811. Qu. (<em>Plan, Arch. Gewächsk</em>.).

<em>Publ</em>.: 1811 (p. 16: 28 Aug 1811), p. [1]-16. <em>Copy</em>: B-S (inf. W.H. Lack).

14.882. <em>Archiv der Gewächskunde</em> ... Wien (Auf Kosten der Herausgebers) [1811-] 1812-
1818. 5 Hefte. Qu. (<em>Arch. Gewächst</em>.).

<em>Publ</em>.: published in two editions: with uncoloured plates and with coloured plates. The
	uncoloured editions came out first. The plates themselves are not numbered but cor-
	respond with numbered texts; numbered texts are accompanied by two plates, here
	indicated as bis-numbers. We saw an insufficient number of copies and give our
	annotations of two copies. Most notes on this work mention that copies vary greatly in
	composition.
<em>Uncoloured edition</em>: copy G in 5 Lieferungen, of which 1 and 2 supposedly made up the
	first volume ("Band"), with a volume t.p. dated 1812; nos. 3 and 4 were presumably
	meant to constitute vol. 2, with a volume t.p. Wien 1814 (the copy has a cover of
	Lieferung 4). Lief. 5 is separate, and provided with a cover dated 1818. A copy at
	NSUB has 4 Lief. with <em>59, 58, 53</em> and <em>57 pl</em>. The copy at HH (2 Lief.) has 54 and 58 pl.
	<em>Preface material to vol. 1</em>: p. [i]-xxiv, p. xxiv dated 15 Mar 1812, t.p. 1812. Presumably
	issued with the second Lieferung [Heft].
	<em>Lieferung 1</em> (no cover seen), publ. Sep 1811 (available at Michaelis Messe 1811), p.
	[1]-28, <em>pl. 1-50</em> with second plates for nos. <em>7, 8, 9, 10, 12, 13</em>, 27, <em>39</em>. [Most sources list
	59 plates, rather than the 58 listed here].
<em>Lieferung 2</em> (no cover seen) 1812, p. 29-64, [9]-16, <em>pl. 51-100</em> with second plates for nos.
	<em>67, 68, 80, 86, 89, 90, 92</em>.
	<em>Preface material</em> for vol. 2. 1814, p. [i]-vi (p. vi: 22 Aug 1814), issued with Lieferung 4.
	<em>Lieferung 3</em> (no cover seen), 1813 or 1814, p. [i-iv], 65-128, [1]-7, <em>pl. 101-150</em> with <em>second
	plates</em> for <em>nos. 102, 104, 108</em>.
	<em>Lieferung 4</em>: 1814, cover p. [i-ii] (p. ii: 22 Aug 1814), p. [9]-12, 129-148, <em>pl. 151-200</em>
	with <em>second plates</em> for <em>nos. 176, 177, 181, 182, 189, 190</em>.
	<em>Lieferung</em> 5: 1818, cover, p. [i-iv], [15]-16, <em>pl. 201-250</em>, with <em>second plates</em> for <em>nos. 201, 202,
	203, 205, 206, 207, 208, 209, 210, 214, 215, 220, 229, 239, 242, 243, 245</em> and <em>third</em> plates
	for <em>243</em> and <em>245</em>.
<em>Coloured edition</em>: <em>copies</em>: B-S (analysis below by W. Lack), M (text only of vols. 1, 3, 4).
	Four volumes with half titles "Archiv der Gewächskunde" and main titles <em>Ausgemahlte
	Tafeln aus dem Archiv der Gewächskunde</em>, ... Erster [-Vierter] Band.
	<em>1</em>: t.p. 1813, publication of coloured plates started 1 Oct 1812, well after the publicat-
	ion of the coloured edition had begun, p. [i, in], frontisp., [3]-34, [35-56], <em>117</em>
	unnumbered col. copp., p. 12: 15 Hornung [Feb] 1813, p. 16: 16 Feb 1813.
	<em>2</em>: t.p. 1813 (p. 6: 15 Jul 1813), p. [1]-24, [25-44], <em>123 pl</em>. id.
	<em>3</em>: t.p. 1814 (p. 10: 15 Feb 1814), p. [1]-61, [63-82], <em>176 pl</em>. id.
	<em>4</em>: t.p. 1814 (p. 6: 30 Sep 1814), p. [1]-42, [43-62], <em>122 pl</em>. id.
<em>Note</em>(<em>1</em>): Trattinick published a list of 800 copper engravings which had been prepared
	for this work in Jahrb. Gewächsk. 1(2): 169-185. 1819. The uncoloured engravings
	were available separately. They probably constitute the total body of plates which he
	had planned to publish in the Arch. Gewächsk. which remained unfinished.
<em>Note 2</em>: an undated pamphlet at G, gives a report on the progress of e.g. the <em>Archiv</em>. The
	text ends abruptly: <em>Ausführlicher Bericht</em> über den Fortgang und die Veranlassung eini-

PAGE: 439
HEADING: TRATTINNICK

	ger unvermeidlich gewordenen Neuerungen in der Herausgabe folgenden Werke, als
	des <em>Archivs der Gewächskunde</em>, der <em>Flora des österreichischen Kaiserthümes</em>, und der <em>Auswahl</em>
	vorzüglich schöner, seltener, berühmter und sonst sehr merkwürdiger <em>Gartenpflanzen</em> in
	getreuen Abbildungen, nebst Erläuterungen über ihre Charakteristik, Verwandts-
	chaft, Classification, Geschichte, Anwendung, Cultur und ästhetischen Ansichten von
	Leopold Trattinnick. Wien (Gedruckt bey Anton Strauss) <em>Copy Auswahl</em> at M has
	<em>Hefte</em> nos. 1, 7, 8, 9, 10, 11, 16, 17, 1814-1817.
<em>Note 3</em>: Artists copper plates: I. Strenzel (mainly), Fricke, Hawatschek, Hohlaus
	(Hollaus), Kazinger, Reinelli, F.
<em>Note 4</em>: The frontispieces to the four volumes of the coloured editions (<em>Ausgemahlte Tafeln</em>
	...) are portraits of L. Trattinnick (1), C. Linnaeus (2), G.L. de Buffon (3), F.G.
	Dietrich (4).
<em>Note 5</em>: the text was also issued separately as <em>Observ. bot</em>. see below.

14.883. <em>Observationes botanicae</em> tabularum rei herbariae illustrantes: ... Viennae [Wien]
(Sumptibus editoris), 4 fasc. 1811-1815. Qu. (<em>Observ. bot</em>.).

<em>1</em>: 1811 (date filled in by hand, 1811 on copies HU, M, NSUB, 1812 on copy B-S),
	cover-t.p., p. [1]-28. – (Text <em>Arch. Gewächsk</em>., see above).
<em>2</em>: 1812 (filled in by hand), p. 29-64. – (Id.).
<em>3</em>: 1812 (id.), p. 65-128. – (Id.).
<em>4</em>: 1815 (date copy M; copy NSUB: 1816), p. 129-148.
<em>5</em>: n.v.
<em>Copies</em>: B-S(1), HU (1-3), M (1-4), NSUB (1-4).

14.884. <em>Flora des österreichischen Kaiserthumes</em> ... Wien (Auf Kosten des Herausgebers ...)
1816-1820 [-1822]. Qu. (<em>Fl. österr. Kaiserth</em>.).

<em>1</em>: 1816 (t.p.; p. xiv: 4 Oct 1816; published in 10 parts the contents and dates of which
	are unknown to us, possibly between 1814-1816), p. [i-ii], portr. C. Clusius, p. [iii]-
	xiv, [1]-143. – <em>Plates 1-100</em> belong to this volume.
<em>2</em>: 1820 (t.p.; p. vi: 24 Oct 1819; in 10 parts, publ. 1816-1819), portr. F.X. von Wulfen,
	p. [i]-vi, [1]-82. – <em>Plates 101-200</em> belong to this volume. Vols. 1-2 came out in altog-
	ether 22 parts (Hefte).
[<em>3</em>, incomplete; Hefte 23-24, fide PR, no t.p.]: 1822, p. [1]-16, index p. v-x. Plates 206-
	220 were issued with these parts.
<em>Plates</em> (bound separately in both copies seen by us): <em>1a, 1b, 2-6, 7a, 7b, 8, 9a, 9b, 10-13, 14a-,
14b, 15-31, 32a, 32b, 33-40, 41a, 41b, 42, 43a, 43b, 44a, 44b, 45-51, 52a, 52b, 53-67, 68a, 68b, 69-
82, 83a, 83b, 84-89, 90a, 90b, 91-123, 124a, 124b, 125-139, 140a, 140b, 141a, 141b, 42-154, 155a,
155b, 156-162, 163a, 163b, 164-179, 180a, 180b, 182-209, 210a, 210b, 211-220</em>, uncol. copp.
[taken from <em>Arch. Gewächsk</em>.]. – Copies with coloured engr. exist, see e.g. Junk, Catalogus
215 (no 318). 1979 and Sotheby 769.
<em>Copies</em>: <em>M</em>, MO, NY, USDA; IDC 5773.

14.885. <em>Oesterreichischer Blumenkranz</em>. ... Wien (Auf Kosten des Herausgebers ...) 1819.
Duod. (<em>Oesterr. Blumenkr</em>.).

<em>Publ</em>.: 1819 (p. xvi: 26 Mai 1819; Flora 7 Mar and 14 Mai 1820), p. i]-xxiv, [1]-240.
	<em>Copy</em>: G. – Poems by T. on ca. 200 sp. of plants. – On <em>Clypeola Jonthlaspi</em> e.g. "... Klein
	sind die Blumen, die Früchte gross; Das ist gewöhnlich des Weisen Loos! So lang er
	lebt, muss der verkannte schmachten; Die Nachwelt erst weiss sein Verdienst zu
	achten ..."
<em>Reissue</em>: 21-27 Jun 1840, as <em>Calliope und Flora</em> oder poetische Unterhaltungen in den
	Gefilden der blühenden Natur. Wien 1840. Duod. (n.v.; ann. Hinrichs, Börsenbl.
	deut. Buchh. 7: 1444. 21-27 Jun 1840).

14.886. <em>Botanisches Taschenbuch</em> oder Conservatorium, aller Resultate, Ideen und Ansich-
ten aus dem ganzen Umfange der Gewächskunde ... Erster Jahrgang. Wien (bey Carl
Schaumburg und Comp.) 1821. Duod. (<em>Bot. Tachenb</em>.).

<em>Publ</em>.: 1821, portr. Trattinick, p. [i]-xii, [1]-347, [348, err.]. <em>Copy</em>: B-S. – Only volume
	published.
<em>Ref</em>.: Anon., Flora 4(2): 711-716. 7 Dec 1821 (rev.: main reason for publication lies "in

PAGE: 440
HEADING: TRATTINNICK

der unendlichen Vermehrung der bot. Literatur und der Zerstreuung der wichtigsten
Aufsätze ..."

14.887. <em>Rosacearum monographia</em> ... Vindobonae [Wien] (apud J.G. Heubner) 1823-1824,
4 vols. Oct. (<em>Rosac. monogr</em>.).

<em>Alternative title</em>: <em>Synodus botanica</em> omnes familias, genera et species plantarum illustrans pars
	1-4. The Synodus was to grow into an overall review of the plant kingdom; only 4
	parts, dealing with the Rosaceae, were published.
<em>1</em>: 1823 (prospectus dated 31 Mai 1823; Flora 14 Mai 1823: will be printed; Flora 28
	Dec 1823, 1 and 2 publ., 14 Jan 1824 rev.), p. [ii-iii], [1-4, prospectus], [v]-xxii,
	[xxiii], [1]-86, [87, h.t.] and lvs. 1-136. – The "leaves" are printed on one side. BR
	copy has in addition a prospectus p. [1-4].
<em>2</em>: 1823 (p. 16: 22 Jul 1823; Flora 28 Dec 1823, publ.), p. [ii]-xxvi, [xxvii], lvs. 1-234, p.
	[1]-16. – The 16 p. constitute a "Besondere Beilage": "Berichtigung von Hrn. Dr.
	Steudels Bedenklichkeiten".
<em>3</em>: 1823 (p. xvi: ii Cal. 8 Sep 1823), p. [i]-xvi, lvs. 1-171.
<em>4</em>: Feb 1824 (p. xxiii: 19 Oct 1823; Flora 14 Oct 1824 publ., rev. Mar 1825; letter J.F.
	Jacquin to DC, Genève, 29 Feb 1824 "vient de publier"), p. [i]-xxiii, lvs. 1-163, [1,
	Anmerkung].
<em>Copies</em>: B-S, BR, G (has in addition a handwritten index, p. [i], 1-26), HH, L, MICH,
	NY, USDA; IDC 7381.
<em>Original announcement</em> by author: Flora 5(2): 37-43. 1822 (see also prospectus included in
	vol. 1). Planned to be an overall monographic treatment of all plants ("dass es ewig
	das Hauptwerk der Botanik bleiben muss ..."). The printing of the text on one side
	was meant to enable the owner to use them e.g. as herbarium labels. Conceived as a
	common enterprise of all botanists.
<em>Comment</em> by E.G. von Steudel: ist eine Verbindung der Botaniker zu einer gemeinschaftli-
	chen Bearbeitung eines <em>Systema Vegetabilium</em> nöthig und möglich?, Denkschr. Bot. Ges.
	Regensburg 2: 1-20. 1822, Isis (Oken) 1823: col. 1230-1240.
<em>Reply by Trattinick, Synodus 2</em>: Beilage p. [1]-16. 1823, see above under vol. 2.
<em>Further comment Steudel</em>: Einige Worte zur Erwiederung der Antwort des Herrn Custos
	Trattinnick auf die gegen die Ausführbarkeit des <em>Synodus botanica</em> erhobenen
	Bedenklichkeiten, Flora 7(1), Beil. 1: 75-81. 1824.
<em>Ref</em>.: Anon., Flora 7(1): 27-32. 14 Jan 1824 (rev. 1, 2), 8(1), Beil. 1: 63-64 before 21 Mai
	1824 (rev. 3, 4).
	Seits, T.A., Rosen 1825, see TL-2/11.643. Based on Synodus.

14.888. <em>Genera nova plantarum</em> iconibus observationibusque illustrata ... Viennae [Wien]
(sumptibus editoris) 1824, 2 fasc. Qu. (<em>Gen. nov. pl</em>.).

<em>1</em>: 17 Jul 1825 (just published, fide letter to J.E. Fürst of that date, see WU 46: 284;
	Flora rev. 28 Dec 1825), cover-t.p., <em>14 pl</em>. with text sign. 1-3 (uncol. copp. Strenzel).
<em>2</em>: 1825 (p. ii: 30 Jun 1825), cover-t.p., p. [i-ii], <em>10 pl</em>. with text sign. 1-3 (id.).
<em>Copies</em>: B, G, HH, NY, U, USDA. – Discontinued; the text on the cover of fasc. 1 states
	that 10 fasc. will constitute a volume of 100 pl.
<em>Ref</em>.: Anon., Flora 8(2): 759-765. 28 Dec 1825 (rev. fasc. 1), Linnaea 1(1): 123-124. Jan
	1862 (rev. 1-2).
	Trattinnick, L., Flora 8(1): 380-384. 1825 (description of project).

14.889. <em>Neue Arten von Pelargonien</em> deutschen Ursprunges. Als Beytrag zu Rob. Sweet's
Geraniaceen mit Abbildungen und Beschreibungen. Herausgegeben von einigen deut-
schen Gartenfreunden der Text von Leop. Trattinick. Wien (auf Kosten der
Herausgeber ...) 1825-1834, 6 vols. Oct. (<em>Neu. Pelargonien</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: 1825-1834 in parts. <em>Copies</em>: G, HH, NY (orig. covers). The analysis below is that of
	the NY copy. Artists Fr. Blaschek, Parger, Seiler.
	<em>1</em> (<em>preface material</em>): 1826, p. [i*], [i]-xvi. – T.p. has "Trattinick" [the copy at G has: p.
	[i*-iii*], [i]-xvi, [xvii-xviii, cont.].
	<em>1</em>(<em>1</em>): Jul 1825, cover, <em>pl. 1-4</em> with text (col. copp.). Date on cover. – All covers have
	"Trattinnick".
	(<em>2</em>): Aug 1825, cover, <em>pl. 5-8</em> with text.
	(<em>3</em>): Sep 1825, cover, <em>pl</em>. 9-<em>12</em> with text.

14.890. <em>Auswahl merkwürdiger Pilze</em>. Herausgegeben von Leopold Trattinnick. Wien (Im
Verlage von Rudolf Sammer) 1851. (<em>Ausw. merkw. Pilze</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: <em>Jan</em> 1851 (ÖbW 30 Jan and 27 Feb 1851; selection of plates from T.'s estate), p.
	[i-ii], <em>pl. 1-16</em> (col. copp.). <em>Copies</em>: FH, Stevenson, USDA. – Plates also used in <em>Fungi
	austriaci</em> (1805).
<em>Ref</em>.: Anon., Österr. bot. W. 1: 70-71. 1851 (lists plates; Sammer took plates from
	"Nachlass" (estate)).

14.891. <em>Botanisches Album</em>, oder: Sammlung ausgewählter, naturgetreuer Abbildungen,
der merkwürdigsten Pflanzen, Blumen, Früchte, Bäume, Sträucher u.s.w. nebst deren
Benennung. Zusammengetragen aus Leop. Trattinnick's (Weiland Custos im k.k.

PAGE: 442
HEADING: TRATTINNIGK

Naturalien-Kabinet) sämmtlichen botanischen Werken. Mit 150 Kupfertafeln. Wien
(bei R. Sammer, Buchhändler) [ca. 1850-1851]. (<em>Bot. Album</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: ca. 1850-1851 (a selection of plates from Trattinick's estate, published by the
	book-seller R. Sammer who also published the <em>Ausw. merkw. Pilze</em> 1851; Trattinick is
	referred to as "Weiland Custos", (the late curator); he died 1849), p. [i], <em>150 pl.
	Copies</em>: B-S (148 pl.), BM, HH. – See also Sotheby 770.

Traub, Hamilton Paul (1890-1983), American botanist and plant breeder of German
descent; on active service in World War I 1917-1919; Dr. phil. Univ. Minnesota 1927;
chief division of horticulture, Texas Agr. Exp. Station at Bryan, Texas 1928-1930, at
Austin, Texas 1930-1931; horticulturist at Gainesville, Florida 1932; with USDA at
Orlando, Florida 1933-1940, with USDA Beltsville 1940-1952; in retirement at Arcadia
and La Jolla, California continuing his work on Amaryllidaceae until 1983; founder of
the American Amaryllis Society and American Plant Life Society. (<em>Traub</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: MO (formerly TRA); some types also in US. – Traub left most of
his estate to the University of Minnesota.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 398 (b. 18 Jun 1890); Bossert p. 405; Hirsch
p. 303; Hortus 3: 1205; IH 1 (ed. 2): 17, (ed. 3): 137, (ed. 4): 153, (ed. 5): 164, (ed. 6):
244, (ed. 7): 142; Langman p. 743; MW suppl. p. 366-367; PH 450; Roon p. 115.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Amer. men sci. eds. 5-10, 1933-1961; Index Amer. bot. lit. 1886-1966, 4:
	375. 1969; Taxon 2: 35. 1953 (retirement), 33: 552. 1984 (herb. TRA to MO); Amer.
	men Sci. eds. 5-9, 1933-1955; The Tribune, San Diego 16 Jul 1983 (obit., d. 14 Jul
	1983).
Beauchamp, R.M., Herbertia 40: 1-25. 1984 (main biogr., bibl., portraits.).
Bullock, A.A., Bibl. S. Afr. bot. 118. 1978.

<sm>NOTE</sm>: Traub's main publications fall outside our period. They include <em>The Amaryllis
manual</em> 1958 (Taxon 7: 209. 1958), <em>The phyla of organisms</em> 1962 (ib. 11: 206. 1962), <em>The
genera of Amaryllidaceae</em> 1963 (ib. 14: 109. 1965), <em>Lineagics</em> 1964 (ib. 14: 202-203. 1965); <em>An
introduction to Herbert's</em> "<em>Amaryllidaceae</em>, etc." 1837 and related works, 1970, 94 p. Traub
was also longtime editor of <em>Plant Life</em>. He published a summary of the great battle on the
typification of <em>Amaryllis Belladonna</em> L. in Taxon 32(3): 253-267. Mai 1983 (see also
Taxon 3: 102-111. 1954).

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Traubia</em> H.N. Moldenke (1963).

Traunfellner, Aloys (1782-1840), Austrian pharmacist and botanist; practicing
pharmacist in Klagenfurt from 1801; collected in Dalmatia (1806) and Istria.
(<em>Traunfellner</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: KL; further material in GOET, MW. – Owned also a large
mineralogical and numismatic collection. – List of duplicates in Flora 1: 616-621. 20 Dec
1818. – <em>Letters</em> at G, UPS-UB.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 398 (b. 27 Sep 1782, d. 13 Oct 1840); IH 1
(ed. 6): 365, (ed. 7): 344.

Dolezal, H., Friedrich Welwitsch 25, 93. 1974.
Graf, R., Flora 24(1): 57-62. 1841 (obit.), see also Carinthia 2(32): 121. 1908.
