(2) F. Hofmeister, <em>Vergl. Unters. Krypt.</em> 1851, partial French translation by L.R. Tulasne
in Ann. Sci. nat., Bot. ser. 3. 18: 172-192, <em>pl. 8-9.</em> 1852, see TL-2/2921.
(3) With A. de Saint-Hilaire, <em>Revue de la flore du Brésil méridional</em> 1842, see TL-2/10.052.

Tullberg, Sven Axel Teodor (1852-1886), Swedish geologist and botanist; Dr. phil.
Lund 1880; lecturer in geology at Lund; with the Swedish geological survey 1879-1886.
(<em>Tullberg</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: LD (3000); further material in GB (200).

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 408; BM 5: 2149-2150; Bossert p. 408; CSP
11: 657, 12: 743, 19: 229; Kleppa p. 214; KR p. 725 (b. 27 Feb 1852, d. 15 Dec 1886;
bibl.); Quenstedt p. 437.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Bot. Not. 1873: 65, 1876: 136, 1887: 46 (obit. not.), 1933: 14, 37, 76;
	Förh. Geol. Fören. Stockholm 8(7): 526-528. 1886 (obit., bibl.).
K.A.G., Nordisk familjebok 19: 756. 1933.
Kurck, C., Bot. Not. 1933: 40-43. 1933 (portr., Skåne botanist).
Verdoorn, F., ed., Chron. bot. 2: 22. 1936.
Wittrock, V.B., Acta Horti Berg. 3(2): 74. 1903, 3(3): 57. 1905 (on portr.).
Zittel, K.A. von, Hist. geol. paleont. 447. 1901.

<sm>COMPOSITE WORKS</sm>: Contributed <em>Ranunculus</em> subg. <em>Batrachium</em> and <em>Rosa</em> to F.W.C. Are-
schoug, Skånes Flora, ed. 2, 1881, p. 179-181 and 298-301. – For geological works see
e.g. CSP.

<sm>NOTE</sm>: For Tycho Fredrik Hugo Tullberg 1842-1920, professor of zoology at Uppsala
1882-1907, who published e.g. on Linnaeus, see KR p. 725-726.

Tully, William (1785-1859), American botanist and philosopher; studied at Yale and
Philadelphia; practicing physician in Enfield, Conn. 1811; Dr. med. Yale 1819; as-
sociated with Thomas Minor at Middleton, Conn. 1819-1824; president of the Vermont
Medical College, Castleton 1824-1830; in private practice at Albany New York 1826-
1829 continuing his lectures at Castleton; professor of materia medica and therapeutics
Yale 1829-1841; in retirement at Springfield, Mass. (<em>Tully</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown. – <em>Letter</em> to Gray at GH.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 408 (b. 18 Nov 1785, d. 28 Feb 1859); DAB
19: 51-52; Lenley p. 471; LS 27450-27451; ME 1: 236, 3: 669; Rehder 3: 243.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Allibone, S.A., Crit. dict. Engl. lit. 3: 2472. 1880. Anon., Who was who Amer.
	Hist. vo. 612. 1967 (b. 18 Nov 1785, d. 28 Feb 1859).
Bronson, H., Ann. med. Soc. County Albany 1806-1851: 317-320. 1864 (obit.).
Dexter, F.B., Biogr. sketch grad. Yale College 6: 68-73. 1912 (biogr., bibl.).
Drake, F.S., Dict. Amer. Biogr. suppl. 926. 1872.
Kelly, H.A., Cycl. Amer. med. biogr. 460. 1912.
Mead, K.C., Johns Jopkins Hosp. Bull. 27: 79-85. 1916; Abstr. in H.A. Kelly and W.L.
	Burrage, Amer. med. biogr. 1166-1167. 1920.
Rogers, D.P., Brief hist. mycol. N. Amer. ed. 2. 8. 1981.
Smith, C.H., <em>in</em> Universities and their sons. 4: 219. 1900 (biogr. sketch).

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Tullia</em> Leavenworth (1831).

15.316. <em>Catalogue of the phenogamous plants and ferns</em> growing without cultivation, within
five miles of <em>Yale College</em>, Ct. Extracted from the appendix to Mr. E. Baldwin's History of
Yale College. New Haven (Hezekiah Howe) 1831. Qu. (<em>Cat. pl. Yale Coll.</em>).

PAGE: 536
HEADING: TULLY

<em>Authorship</em>: Eli Ives (1779-1861), Melines Conklin Leavenworth (1796-1862) and W.
	Tully.
<em>Publ</em>.: 1831, p. [i], [1]-38. <em>Copy</em>: USDA. – Reprinted from Ebenezer Baldwin, Annals of
	Yale College 1831: 264-302 (see McVaugh 1947 and C.B. Graves et al. <em>Cat. fl. pl. ferns
	Connecticut</em> 1910, p. 11).
<em>Ref</em>.: McVaugh, R., Field &amp; Laboratory 15(2): 57-70. 1947.

Tunmann, Otto (1867-1919), German (Posen-born) pharmacologist and botanist;
studied at Leipzig and Erlangen; Dr. phil. Bern 1900 as a student of Tschirch; pharma-
cist at Schöneck, Vogtland; assistant with Tschirch in Bern; habil. ib. 1908; professor of
forensic chemistry, phytomicrochemistry and microchemical toxicology Bern 1913; ordi-
nary professor of pharmacology Wien 1919. (<em>Tunmann</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 408 (b. 13 Aug 1867, d. 11 Sep 1919); Biol.-
Dokum. 18: 9415; BM 5: 2151, 8: 1332; LS 40147-40148, suppl. 28197-28198; Rehder 1:
135; Tucker 3: 314.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Pabisch, H., Ber. deut. bot. Ges. 37: (77)-(84). 1919 (obit., portr.).

Tuomikoski, Risto Kalevi (1911-x), Finnish botanist and entomologist; associate pro-
fessor of botany at Helsinki University 1947-1961; professor of biotaxonomy 1961-1974.
(<em>Tuom</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: H (12.535); further material (Newfoundland bryoph.) at
CANM, NFLD (Hepatics publ. Arch. Soc. Vanamo 9 (Suppl.)): 3-29. 1955; Musci, id.
Ann. bot. fenn. 10: 217-264. 1973). – <em>Letters</em> at G.

Turconi, Malusio (1879-1929), Italian mycologist at the Laboratorio crittogamico di
Pavia from 1899. (<em>Turconi</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: PAV.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 408; Bossert p. 408; GR p. 524-525, 541;

	bibl.).

Turczaninow, Nicolai Stepanowitsch [von] (1796-1863) [n.s. 1864], Russian bota-
nist and administrator; civil servant in the departments of justice and finances 1814-
1828; on a government mission to Irkutsk 1828 (from 1832 in the service of the
Academy of Sciences)-1835; civil servant in Krasnoyarsk 1835-1837; president of the

PAGE: 538
HEADING: TURCZANINOW

civil council of the Jenisei government 1835-1845; actively collecting in these areas and
bringing together a large herbarium; in retirement at Taganrog 1845-1847 and
Charkow 1847-1863; botanical explorer of the Baikal and Dahurical region 1828-1835
and the Jenisei region 1835-1845. (<em>Turcz</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: KW (formerly at CW); large collections also in LE; other
material at A, AWH, B (mainly destr.), BR, C, CN, CORD, CW, E, FI, G, G-DC,
GOET, H (1000), K, KAZ, KIEL, LY, M, MANCH, MO, MW, O, OXF, P, PH,
PRC, TU, U, US, W. – <em>Letters</em> to A.P. de Candolle at G, to A. Gray at GH, to
Hohenacker, Lehmann and Steudel at UPS-UB.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 408 (d. 26 Dec 1863 [n.s.] Jan 1864); BM 5:
2151; Bret. p. 352-354, 1091; Clokie p. 257; Herder p. 214; Hortus 3: 1205; HR; IF p.
734; IH 1 (ed. 2): 40, (ed. 3): 46, 82, 88, (ed. 6): 365, (ed. 7): 344; Jackson p. 392;
Langman p. 748; Lasègue p. 586 [index]; MW p. 505-506, suppl. 371; PR 9559, ed. 1:
10528; Ratzeburg p. 495-496; Rehder 5: 864; RS p. 145; TL-2/see indexes; TR 1513-
1525 (bibl.); Tucker 1: 704-705; Zander ed. 10, p. 726, ed. 11, p. 828.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Amer. J. Sci. ser. 2. 41: 263. 1866 (d.); Bonplandia 9: 92. 1861; Bot.
	Zeit. 19: 88. 1861 (herb. Robert Brown bought by T. (relates possibly to a set of
	Brown's plants; evidently not to "the herbarium"; Brown's herb. was sold in parts
	after his death, see TL-2/1: 364); Bull. Soc. bot. France 11 (bibl.): 191. 1864 (d.);
	Flora 40: 464. 1857 (Demidoff prize for <em>Fl. baik. dah</em>.). 47: 284. 1864 (obit. not.);
	Österr. bot. Z. 14: 196-197. 1864 (obit. not.).
Bernardi, L., Musées de Genève 79: 7-13. 1967 (portr., vivid sketch of T.'s life and
	works; visit to herb. at KW).

Burdet, H.M., Candollea 34: 171-172. 1979 (curr. vit., location colls., handwriting).

	Turcz.); Bot. Zeit. 2: 816. 1844 (id.).

	disabled).

Wagenitz, G., Index coll. princ. herb. Gott. 167-168. 1982.

<sm>NOTE</sm>: The <em>Index specierum plantarum circa urbem Ircutiam</em>, in Dahuria et ad lacum Baical <em>in
Siberia lectarum</em>, quas Societas Caesarea naturae scrutatorum Mosquensi pro mutua com-
municatione offert, <em>in</em> Bull. Soc. Natural. Moscou 10(1): 56-62. 1837, must also be
attributed to Turczaninow, fide Lipschitz (1964).

(1924) probably honors this author but no derivation was given.

15.334. <em>Flora baicalensi-dahurica</em> seu descriptio plantarum in regionibus cis- et transbaical-
ensibus atque in Dahuria sponte nascentium ... Mosquae (Typis A. Semen), 1842-1856

<em>Publ</em>.: Original publication took place in parts in the <em>Bulletin de la Société impériale des
	Naturalistes de Moscou</em>. It was subsequenty reprinted with separate pagination in two
	volumes, the first dated "1842-1845" and the second "1856" (in two parts). The
	appendix with Roman page numbers (i-lxi) was added to the second volume in 1857.
	When reprinting the articles in book-form the type was shifted and the concordance
	between the pagination in the <em>Bulletin</em> and the book is therefore involved.
<em>1</em>: "1842-1845" (see table below), p. [1]-544.
<em>2</em>(<em>1</em>): 1856, p. [i-ii], [1]-374.
<em>2</em>(<em>2</em>): 1856, p. [i-ii], [1]-436.
<em>Appendix</em>: 1857, p. [i]-lxi.
<em>Copies</em>: BR (vol. 1), G, H (vol. 2), HH, PH; IDC 5266.
<em>Facsimile ed</em>.: 1969, Amsterdam (A. Asher &amp; Co.). <em>Copies</em>: B, FAS, MO. – ISBN 90-6123-
	170-1.

Turesson, Göte Wilhelm (1892-1970), Swedish botanist; in the United States 1912-
1915, studied at the University of Washington, Seattle, B.Sc. ib. 1914, M.Sc. 1915;
assistant with the botanical departments of Washington University; returned to Sweden
1915, studied at Lund, Lic. sci. ib. 1921; Dr. phil. 1922, specializing in genecology;
lecturer Lund 1922-1927; chief plant breeder at the Weibullsholm Plant Breeding
Institute, Karlskrona 1927-1931; research "docent" at Lund University 1931-1935; pro-
fessor of systematic botany and genetics at the Agricultural College of Sweden, Uppsala
1935-1959; in retirement at Lund. (<em>Turesson</em>).

PAGE: 542
HEADING: TURESSON

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: LD; other material at GB, GH, UPS.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 408; BJI 2: 180; BL 2: 541, 725; BM 8: 1332;
Bossert p. 408; Hirsch p. 305; KR p. 726 (b. 6 Apr 1892); LS suppl. 28238-28341; MW
p. 506; NW p. 60.

	sorship), 1939: 411 (memb. K. Fysiogr. Sällsk.), 110(2): 290. 1957 (dr. h.c.), 111(3):

HEADING: TURNER

Turner, Dawson (1775-1858), British banker and botanist; studied at Pembroke
College, Cambridge 1793-1794; from 1796-1850 with the Yarmouth bank; from 1850-
1853 in London and Barnes; from 1853 in Old Brompton. (<em>Turn</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: K and BM; other specimens at B-Willd., BRISTM, CGE, E, FH
(Taylor), H, LINN, LIV, OXF, UPS, YRK (see further Kent &amp; Allen 1984).

<sm>MANUSCRIPTS</sm> and <sm>DRAWINGS</sm>: K (memoranda, drawings of algae, mss. Fl. Norfolciensis),
BM (e.g.: 29 sheets with illustrations of the Muscologiae hibernicae spicilegium;
Turner's copy of his Fuci with additional drawings). For further particulars see Dawson
(1958). – The Turner correspondence is at Trinity College Cambridge (82 vols.); fur-
ther <em>letters</em> at BM, G, GH, HU, LINN, UPS-UB, Liverpool and Norwich public lib-
raries. (See also Bridson 1980). <em>Library</em> sold by auction (1853, 1859).

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 409; BB p. 306; BM 1: 203, 463, 5: 2153, 8:
1332; Bossert p. 409; Clokie p. 257; CSP 6: 67; Dawson p. 834, suppl. p. 64-69; Desmond
p. 622 (b. 18 Oct 1775, d. 20 Jun 1858); De Toni 1: cxxv; DNB 19: 1261-1262, (57: 334)
(G.S. Boulger); Frank 3 (Anh.): 107; GR p. 384, cat. p. 72; Hawksworth p. 186; Henrey
2: 135; Herder p. 171, 236, 254, 260, 267; Jackson p. 153, 157, 229, 243, 247; Kelly p.
231; Lasègue p. 327, 328, 434, 503, 544; Lenley p. 416; LS 3408, 27457-27462; Moebius
p. 66, 86; MW p. 506; NI 2011-2012; Plesch p. 442; PR 1016, 4225, 7416, 9563-9568,
10006, 10320, ed. 1: 1141, 4164, 8567, 10534-10537, 10990, 11290; Sayre p. 22, 25, 26;
SBC p. 133; Sotheby 774; TL-1/1339-1341a, see E. Rudge; TL-2/see indexes; Tucker 1:
703; Urban-Berl. p. 269, 291, 315, 405, 415.

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Dawsonia</em> R. Brown (1809); <em>Dawsonia</em> Palisot de Beauvois ex J.V.F.
Lamouroux (1824, <em>nom. rej</em>.); <em>Turnerella</em> Fr. Schmitz (1896) also very likely honors
Dawson Turner. <em>Turnera</em> Linnaeus (1753) was named for William Turner (1508?-1568),
English clergyman and herbalist, considered by some to be the "Father of English
botany".

15.367. <em>Fuci</em> sive plantarum fucorum generi a botanicis ascriptarum icones descriptiones
et historia ... Fuci; or, colored figures and descriptions of the plants referred by botanists
to the genus Fucus ... London (printed by J. M'Creery, ...) 1807-1819, 4 vols. Qu. (<em>Fuci</em>).

<em>1</em>: 1 Sep 1807-1 Jun 1808 (first fascicle available to Goodenough by 21 Sep 1807; see also
	Price (1984): fasc. 10: 1 Jun 1808), p. [i, iii], [1]-164, [1]-2, <em>pl. 1-71</em> (col. copp. W.J.
	Hooker).
<em>2</em>: 1808-1809 (in fascicles), p. [i], [1]-162, [1-2], <em>pl. 72-134</em> (id.).
<em>3</em>: 1809-1811 (in fascicles), p. [i], [1]-148, [1-2], <em>pl. 135-196</em> (id.).
<em>4</em>: 1811-1819 ("possibly"; Price 1984; in fascicles), p. [i, iii], [1]-153, [1-2], [1-7], <em>pl. 197-
	258</em> (id.).
<em>Copies</em>: FH, G, H-UB, MO, NY; IDC 6438. – Published in fascicles, details of which are
	lacking; a large paper edition, 25 copies, were issued. See J.H. Price (1982) on the
	complexity of publication of e.g. the <em>Fuci</em>. We know of no copy in original wrappers (if
	any). A further paper on the Fuci by Price was announced by him in 1984.

Turner, Edward Phillips (1865-1937), British-born New Zealand botanist; came to
New Zealand 1870, later at school in Tasmania and studying in England; again in New
Zealand 1884; surveyor 1887; surveying Tasmanian silver fields 1891, with the Govern-
ment Survey Dept. Auckland, N.Z. 1894-1907; inspector of scenic reserves N.Y. 1907,

PAGE: 547
HEADING: F.TURNER

secretary of the R. Commission on Forestry 1913; in charge of the forest branch of the
Lands Dept. 1918; Director of Forestry 1920-1931; in retirement at Hamilton (<em>E. Turn</em>.).

Turpin, Pierre Jean François (1775-1840), French botanist and botanical artist;
from 1794-1802 in Haiti, Tortuga and the United States; from 1802 in France active as
botanist and illustrator. (<em>Turpin</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: P, PC. – For plants collected with P.A. Poiteau in the Antilles see
also under that author. Other material e.g. in LE, NEU, PH. – Drawings e.g. in the
Lindley Library, London (25), Bibl. centr. Mus. Hist. Nat., Paris.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Ainsworth p. 154, 212, 315, 348; Backer p. 602; Barnhart

695; Jackson p. 77, 116, 276; Langman p. 748-750; Lasègue p. 489, 505, 541, 554; LS
27465-27473; Moebius p. 82, 102, 152, 203, 427; NI 2014-2016; see index; Nordstedt p.

Rehder 5: 865; RS p. 145; SO 815; TL-1/see indexes; TL-2/see indexes; Tucker 1: 704,

<sm>COMPOSITE WORKS</sm>: (1) Co-author, P.A. Poiteau, <em>Fl. paris</em>. 1808-1813, TL-2/8122.
(2) Author and artist of the <em>Iconographie végétale</em>, of J.L.M. Poiret, <em>Leçons fl</em>. 1819-1820,
vol. 3, see TL-2/8115. – The "letter" in vol. 1 of the octavo edition (6 p.) [quarto ed. 4
p.] of vol. 1 is addressed to the publisher, C.L.F. Pancoucke, and written by Turpin. –
See also G. Schmid 1960, no. 1700. – Other copies of the octavo edition seen at MO,
PH. – For the <em>Flore médicale</em> and the <em>Leçons de Flore</em> in which Turpin provided the plates,
see TL-2/1091 and 8115 (includes Turpin's <em>Essai d'une iconographie élémentaire et philo-
sophique des végétaux</em> of 1820, which constitutes the first edition of the <em>Iconographie végétale</em>.
(3) See H.L. Duhamel du Monceau, <em>Traité arbr. fruit</em>., 1807-1835, TL2/1548, nouvelle
edition augmentée ... par A. Poiteau et P. Turpin; <em>also</em>: <em>Choix des arbres fruitiers</em> de
Duhamel du Monceau. Nouvelle édition. Augmentée d'un grand nombre de fruits, par

15.388. <em>Oeuvres d'histoire naturelle de Goethe</em>, comprenant divers mémoires d'anatomie com-

PAGE: 551
HEADING: TURRA

parée, de botanique et de géologie traduits et annotés par Ch. Fr. Martins, ... <em>Atlas</em>
contenant deux planches d'anatomie comparée, trois de botanique et deux de géologie,
accompagnées d'une explication raisonnée et d'une esquisse d'organographie végétale
par P.-J.-F. Turpin, ... Paris (Abraham Cherbuliez et Compagnie, ...); Genéve (même
Maison de commerce) 1837. Fol. 

<em>Authorship</em>: Charles Frédéric Martins (1806-1889); botanical part: PJ.F. Turpin.
<em>Publ</em>.: 1837, p. [i-ii], [1]-69, [70], <em>pl. 1-5, 6/7</em>, (all pl. by Turpin; <em>pl. 3-5</em> botanical). <em>Copy</em>:
	G.
<em>Reprint of botanical part</em>: described by M. Guédès (1972): <em>Esquisse d'organographie végétale</em>,
	fondée sur le principe d'unité de composition organique et d'évolution rayonnante ou
	centrifuge pour servir à prouver l'identité des organes appendiculaires des végétaux et
	la métamorphose des plantes de <em>Goethe</em>, par P.-J.-F. Turpin, ... Paris (id.) 1837.
	Contains botanical text [col. 5-70] and <em>pl. 3-5. Copy</em>: P (not seen by us).
<em>Text of main work</em>: 1837, p. [i*-iii*], [i]-viii, [1]-468. <em>Copy</em>: G. – Text by Goethe/Martins.
<em>Ref</em>.: Guèdès, M., J. Soc. Bibl. nat. Hist. 6(3): 175-176. 1972.

Turquet, Jean (<em>fl</em>. 1910), French botanist; Dr. phil. Paris 1910; Dr. med. Paris; on the
staff of the colonial laboratory of the Muséum d'Histoire naturelle, Paris; member of the
French antarctic expedition (Mission Charcot). (<em>Turquet</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

Turra, Antonio (1730-1796), Italian botanist, mineralogist and practicing physician at
Vicenza. (<em>Turra</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Formerly in the Museo civico, Vicenza; destroyed during World
War II; some material in LINN. – <em>Letters</em> at G.

Turrill, William Bertram (1890-1961), British botanist; assistant with G.C. Druce at
Oxford 1906-1909; temporary assistant Herbarium Royal Botanic Gardens, Kew 1909,
permanent assistant ("botanist") 1914; B.Sc. London 1915, (M.Sc. 1922, D.Sc. 1928),
on active service with the Royal Army medical Corps in Macedonia 1916-1918; from
1916 again with Kew, lecturing at the Chelsea Polytechnic 1918-1939; in Oxford 1939-
1945 in charge of part of the Kew library and herbarium transferred to the New
Bodleian Library; keeper of the herbarium and library at Kew 1946-1957; in retirement
1957-1961, still working at Kew; leading authority on the flora of the Balkan Peninsula.
(<em>Turrill</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: K; further material ABD, NMW, NOT, OXF; <em>letters</em> at G; corre-
spondence received at K.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 410 (b. 14 Jun 1890); BFM 3271; Biol.-
Dokum. 18: 9420; BJI 2: 180; BL 1: 108, 246, 322, 2: 224, 303, 312, 725; BM 8: 1333;
Bossert p. 409; Clokie p. 257; Desmond p. 624 (d. 15 Dec 1961); DNB 1961-1970: 1026-
1027 (P.J. Coote); GR p. 417-418; Hortus 3: 1205; IH 1 (ed. 1): 49, (ed. 2): 66, (ed. 3):
81, 2: 505; MW p. 506, suppl. 371-372; Plesch p. 443; Roon p. 116; Sotheby 776; TL-

Tussac, François Richard chevalier de (1751-1837), French colonial botanist; at
Martinique 1786, subsequently in Haiti until 1802, at Jamaica 1802; returned to France
late 1802, director of the Jardin botanique, Angers, while resident in Paris. (<em>Tussac</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Only relatively few specimens collected by Tussac are known to
be extant. What comes probably nearest to the main set (perhaps including types) is the
one obtained by Desvaux and now at P in the herbier-général. In 1807 Tussac gave a
number of specimens to A.L. de Jussieu (P-JU), other specimens are at G (through A.P.
de Candolle) and FI. Tussac's 2000 drawings, made on Martinique, were burned on 5
Feb 1802, but the herbaria and manuscripts were saved. Nothing is known of the pre-
sent location of the manuscripts.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: AG 3: 895; Barnhart 3: 410; BM 5: 2155; CSP 6: 73; DU
312 (details on plates); Frank 3 (Anh.): 107; Herder p. 237; Hortus 3: 1205; Jackson p.
369; Lasègue p. 489, 505, 536; NI 2017; Plesch p. 443; PR 9586, ed. 1: 10560; Rehder 1:
335, 5: 865; SO add. 787d; Sotheby 777; TL-1/1342; TL-2/1293, 1410; Tucker 3: 314;
Zander ed. 10, p. 726.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Biogr. hommes vivants 5: 475. 1819; Brit. Mus. gen. cat. print. books
	242: 734. 1964; Cat. gén. livr. impr. Bibl. natl. 196: 406-408. 1967.
Candolle, A.P. ed, Mém. souvenirs 181, 182. 1862.

	Tussac dont nous possédons l'herbier" sic).

<em>Publ</em>.: The history of the publication of this book is not quite clear because the contents
	of the fascicles are unknown, and since there are differences between the numbers of
	pages and plates listed in the <em>Bibliographie de la France</em> and those actually present in the
	volumes. The dates of receipt by the Académie are in general in agreement with the
	BF dates. In the list below the dates for fasc. 1-2 of vol. 1 are those from the JGLF,
	fasc. 3-4 from C.R. Acad. Sci., the others from BF. In the absence of convincing
information no attempt is made here to suggest the contents of the parts.

ner" subsequently "sub-foreman" at Kew 1888-1891; assistant superintendent botanical
and forestry department Hongkong 1901, superintendent 1910-1920. (<em>Tutcher</em>).

Tutin, Thomas Gaskell (1908-x), British botanist; studied at Cambridge 1927-1931;
collected in Southern Spain and Spanish Marocco 1931 and British Guiana 1932; at the
Marine Biological Station Plymouth 1933-1937; to lake Titicaca 1937; lecturer at King's
College, London 1937-1939, collected in S. Peru and N. Bolivia 1938; assistant lecturer
at Manchester 1939-1944; lecturer-in-charge of the Botany Dept. Leicester University
College; professor of botany at Leicester University 1947-1973 (from 1967-1973 occupy-
ing the chair of taxonomy). (<em>Tutin</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: LTR; other material at BM (orig., Brit. Guiana 1933; dupl. of
other mat.), CGE (orig. Madeira and Azores 1929, dupl. of other mat.), DPU, K, MO,
NMW, U (Brit. Guiana), US (Brit. Guiana).

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 410; BFM p. 322 [index]; Biol.-Dokum. 18:
9421; BL 1: 87, 322, 2: 216, 725; Bossert p. 409; Hortus 3: 1205; IH 1 (ed. 7): 344; Roon
p. 116; Zander ed. 10, p. 726, ed. 11, p. 828.

	1978, p. ix-xviii (tribute, biogr. sketch, bibl.).

Tuzson, János (1870-1943), Hungarian (Transylvanian-born) systematic botanist; Dr.
phil. Kolozsvár (Cluj) 1898; professor of systematic botany at the Institute for systematic
botany and plant geography of the University of Budapest 1914, from 1928 also director
of its botanical garden. (<em>Tuzson</em>).

Tweedie, John ["James"] (1775-1862), British (Scottish) gardener at Eglinton Castle,
Ayrshire and Royal Botanic Garden, Edinburgh; to Buenos Aires, Argentina 1825, trav-
elled and collected up the Uruguay river in Argentina, Uruguay, Rio Grande do Sul,
Santa Catharina, Rio de Janeiro (1832), in the Tucuman region (1835) at the Serra de
Tandil (1837). (<em>Tweedie</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: K; further material at BM, CGE, E-GL, FI, LE, MO, OXF,
TCD, U, W. – <em>Letters</em> at K.

487; PR alph.

(<em>Tweedy</em>).

Twiss, Wilfred Charles (1868-?), American botanist; A.M. Univ. Calif. 1910; Dr.
phil. Columbia Univ.; teacher chiefly in city schools near Los Angeles 1895-1911, from

Tyler, Ansel Augustus (1869-1922), American botanist; AB Lafayette 1892; Dr. phil.
Columbia Univ. 1897; assistant in biology Lafayette Univ. 1894-1897; graduate student
Columbia 1894-1897; instructor in biology Union College 1897-1898, id. Syracuse Univ.
1898-1899; associate professor of biology Univ. Arizona 1899-1900; professor science,
Bellevue College, Omaha 1900-1916 (from 1911 as dean); head of the department of
biology at Millikin University, Deca- tur 1916-1922. (<em>Tyler</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: NY; some further material in YU.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 412 (b. 7 Mar 1869, d. 31 Mar 1922);

	1901-1902; Who was who 5: 736. 1969-1973.
Ward, H.B., Science ser. 2. 56: 37. 1922 (obit., d. 31 Mar 1922).

Tyson, William (1851-1920), Jamaica-born (British parents) South African teacher
and plant collector; studied at Leeds; to S. Africa ca. 1874, teacher at various schools in
S. Africa 1874-1888; with the South African Department of forestry, Kimberley, 1888-
1893; librarian and editor with the Agricultural Department 1893-1904; ultimately, in
retirement at Port Alfred. (<em>Tyson</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: BOL (coll. marine algae), PRE (phan.); further material at B
(mainly destr.), BM, E, FI, GRA, K, MO, NH, PRE, SAM, STE.
<em>Exsiccatae</em>: <em>South African marine algae</em>, fasc. 1-2, 1909-1910, nos. 1-100. Sets A, B (mainly
destr.), BR, DBN, FH, GRA, MANCH, NY, PC, PRE. – Algae also distributed with
<em>Herbarium normale austro-africanum</em>.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: BB p. 308; Desmond p. 625 (b. Mar 1851, d. 13 Apr
1920); Urban-Berl. p. 405.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Bull. misc. Inf. Kew 1920: 176 (obit.).
Bayer, A.W., S. Afr. J. Sci. 67: 407. 1971.

scriptae a patre F. Bernardino ab Ucria ... moderante Francesco Carta. Romae 1959.
Oct. (<em>Pl. Linn.</em>).

<em>Editor</em>: Francesco Carta.
<em>Publ</em>.: 1959 (p. 69: 10 Mai 1959), p. [1-2], portr. (of Ucria) 3-69. <em>Copy</em>: MO.
<em>Original publication</em>: in <em>Muova raccolta di opuscoli di autori Siciliani</em> 6, 1788 (n.v.), and <em>in</em> J.J.
	Roemer, Ark. Bot. 1(1): 67-70. 1796.

Uechtritz, Maximilian [Max] Friedrich Sigismund Freiherr von (1785-1851),
German (Silesian) soldier and "Privatgelehrter" especially interested in botany and
entomology; sometime cavalry captain ("Rittmeister") in the Austrian army; stationed
in Moravia ca. 1805; resident in Breslau; (father of Rudolf von Uechtritz). (<em>Uechtr</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: WRSL; further material in B (extant).

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: BM 5: 2160; Biol.-Dokum. 18: 9429 (list 11 publ.); CSP
6: 79; Futak-Domin p. 619; Herder p. 62; Klástersky p. 190; PR 9595, ed. 1: 10568; WU
48: 222.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Ilg, W., Hoppea 42: 345. 1984 (member Regensb. bot. Ges. 1816).
Pax, F., Bibl. schles. Bot. 7, 41, 72, 105, 111, 142, 149, 1929.
Schmid, G., Chamisso als Naturforscher 263. 1942.

15.419. <em>Kleine Reisen eines Naturforschers</em>, ... Motto: Reisen ist ein zwiefaches Leben. J.G.
Richter. Breslau (Bei Johann Friedrich Korn, dem Altern) 1820. Oct. (<em>Kleine Reis.
Naturf</em>.).

<em>Publ</em>.: 1820, p. [i]-x, [1]-354. <em>Copies</em>: BM, LE (n.v.).
<em>Ref</em>.: Opravil, E., Prír. Cas. Stezský 22(4): 571-579. 1961 (list of taxa).

Uechtritz, Rudolf [Karl] [Carl] Friedrich von (1838-1886), German (Silesian)
botanist at Breslau; studied at the Magdalenaeum (1849-1857), Matthias-Gymnasium
(1858) and University of Breslau (1858-1863); student of Goeppert, Cohn and Koerber;
"Privatgelehrter", especially dedicated to systematic botany and the floristics of Silesia;
travelled frequently in Central Europe between 1855-1861; founder of the Schlesische

PAGE: 563
HEADING: UECHTRITZ

botanische Tausch-Verein; curator of the botanical collections of the Schlesische
Gesellschaft für vaterländische Cultur. (<em>R. Uechtr</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: WRSL (main herb. orig. in Schles. Provinzialherbar, Schles.
Ges. vaterl. Cultur, Breslau/Wroclaw). – Adolf Engler bought Uechtritz's herbarium
(which included that of his father Max v. U.) privately from the estate and donated it to
the University of Breslau, a touching gesture towards the memory of a man who had
stimulated his earliest botanical interests. Uechtritz's library, manuscripts and corre-
spondence went also to Breslau University. – Other Uechtritz material at AK, AWH, B
(extant), BP, BR, C, E, F, G, GB, GOET, LE, M (lich.), MANCH, MW, PR, W. –
Uechtritz founded the <em>Schlesische botanische Tauschverein</em> in 1862; this Society published
lists of duplicates available for exchange ("General-Doubletten Verzeichniss ..."). –
<em>Letters</em> to D.F.L. von Schlechtendal at HAL, to K. Keck and A. Kerner at UPS-UB, G.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: ADB 39: 126-127 (E. Wunschmann); AG 1: 275, 12(1):
170, 12(2): 730; Backer p. 603; Barnhart 3: 413; BJI 1: 58-59; Bossert p. 410; CSP 6: 79-
80, 8: 1133, 11: 664, 12: 745, 19: 249; DTS 1: 309-311, xxiii-xxiv; Futak-Domin p. 619-
620; Hegi 4(1): 202, 6(2): 1316; Herder p. 482 [index]; Kanitz p. 285; Klásterský p. 190;
Maiwald p. 123, 238; MW p. 507; Rehder 5: 866; Saccardo 2: 110; TL-2/1770; Tucker
1: 706, 2: xxxviii; WU 48: 222; Urban-Berl. 272, 405; Zander ed. 10, p. 726, ed. 11 p.
828.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Bot. Jahrb., 8(2): (Beibl. 17): I. 1886 (Engler has bought herbarium,
	will donate it to Breslau); Leopoldina 22: 217. 1886; Magy. nov. Lap. 10: 173-175.
	1886 (obit., bibl.); Nat. Nov. 8: 278. 1886 (d.); Österr. bot. Z. 18: 302. 1868 (U. is ill
	and is forced for the time being to interrupt his correspondence and scientific
	activity); Verh. bot. Ges. Brandenburg 28: xlii. 1887.
Ascherson, P., Ber. deut. bot. Ges. 5: xxxviii-xli. 1887 (detailed obit., b. 31 Dec 1838, d.
	21 Nov 1886).
Berdowski, W. et al., Katalog Zbior. Zieln. Inst. bot. Univ. Wroclaw 5: 8, 6: 81. 1974,
	8(2): 6. 1981 (herb. M. et R. v. U. in WRSL).
Engler, A., Bot. Centralbl. 28: 380-381. 1886 (obit.); Bot. Zeit. 44: 854-855. 1866;
	Schles. Zeit. 23 Nov 1886, Jahresber. schles. Ges. vaterl. Cult. 64: 185-191. 1886
	(obit., bibl. A. Kanitz).
Lack, H.W. &amp; C.-O. von Sydow, Willdenowia 14: 443. 1984.
Lack, H.W. &amp; D. Wagner, Willdenowia 14: 432. 1984 (material at B in herb.
	Ullepitsch).
Oborny, A., Verh. naturf. Ver. Brünn 21(2): 11, 17, 22. 1882.
Pax, F., Schlesiens Pflanzenwelt 13, 14. 1915 (portr.); Bibl. schles. Bot. 7, 21, 24, 33, 41-
	42, 44, 47, 56, 69, 72, 83, 105, 111, 116, 140, 149. 1929.
Schönach, H., Jahresber. k.k. Real-Ober-Gymn. Feldkirch 44. 1882.
Stein, B., Breslauer Zeit. 22 Nov 1886; Österr. bot. Z. 37: 28-29. 1887 (obit., notes on
	circle of young botanists at Breslau, e.g. A. Engler, Hausknecht, Heidenreich, Sade-
	beck, Stein).
Szymkiewicz, D., Bibl. Fl. Polsk. 138. 1925.
Uechtritz, R.v., Öster. bot. Z. 37: 228-232, 283-287. 1887 ("Mein wissenschaftliches
	Streben und Schaffen", autobiogr. with introduction by Ernst Jünger; portr.).
Wimmer, F., Fl. Schles. 154. 1844.
Wittrock, V.B., Acta Horti Berg. 3(2): 145. 1903, 3(3): 155. <em>pl. 126.</em> 1905 (portr.).

<sm>COMPOSITE WORKS</sm>: Collaborator, E. Fiek, <em>Flora von Schlesien</em> 1881, TL-2/1770.

<sm>HANDWRITING</sm>: Candollea 34: 173-174. 1979.

15.423. <em>Die Vegetationslinien der schlesischen Flora</em> von R. von Uechtritz. Separat-Abdruck

	to be cited from E. Fiek, <em>Fl. Schlesien</em> 1881, <em>Einleitung</em>.
<em>Note</em>(<em>1</em>): v. Uechtritz's contribution to the <em>Flora</em> is called "wesentlich" (essential) by Fiek,
	in his introduction. Apart from the <em>Vegetationslinien</em>, v.Ue. contributed "Die Hieracia
	accipitrina" Schlesiens" (also reprinted, 8 p., p. 277-285) and many notes as well as
	new taxa (mostly formae) throughout the text.
<em>Note</em>(<em>2</em>): Additional copies seen of Fiek, <em>Fl. Schlesien</em> 1881, TL-2/1770: B-S, BR, HH, NY.
	 – Additional reviews: Freyn (Prag), Bot. Centralbl. 8: 138-142. 1881, Anon., Flora
	64: 574-576. 1881. The book was mentioned as published by Bot. Centralbl. 25-27
	Jul 1882, by Bot. Zeit. 29 Jul 1881.
<em>Ref</em>.: Freyn (Prag), Bot. Centralbl. 8: 142-146. 1881 (rev.).

Ugolini, Ugolino (1856-1942), Italian botanist; studied natural sciences at Padova
University; habil. ib. 1881; private teacher and journalist at Milano 1882-1883; profes-
sor of natural history at the Istituto Tecnico provinciale, Padova 1883-1894; id. R.
Istituto Tecnico, Brescia 1894-1918; id. at Bologna and Padova 1918-1919; finally again
at Brescia. (<em>Ugolini</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: PAD. – <em>Letters</em> at G.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 413 (b. 12 Mai 1856); BFM 1112; BL: 370,
725; Bossert p. 410; CSP 19: 250; DTS 1: 311; LS 27597; Rehder 1: 430; Saccardo 1:
167, cron. p. xxxv.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Comm. Ateneo Brescia, Indici 1808-1907, p. 187-188. 1908 (list of publ.
	in journal).
Giacomini, V., Nuov. Giorn. bot. ital. ser. 2. 51: 88-104. 1944 (obit., d. 23 Oct 1942).

Uhlworm, Oskar (1849-1929), German (Thüringen) librarian and botanical editor;
librarian of the University Library of Leipzig 1880; director of the Murhard Library,
Kassel, 1881-1901; head-librarian at the Royal Library Berlin 1901-1915 (from 1903
with professor's title) and in charge of the Deutsches Bureau für internationale Biblio-
graphie). (<em>Uhlworm</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown. – <em>Letters</em> to W.G. Farlow and Roland Thaxter at FH,
other letters at G.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 414 (b. 4 Aug 1849, d. 13 Mar 1929); BM 5:
2161; Herder p. 23; Jackson p. 89; Morren ed. 10, p. 10; Rehder 1: 112; TL-2/see F.G.
Kohl; Tucker 1: 706.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Centralbl. Bakteriol. Abth. 2. 77(25-26): [i]-ii, portr. 1929 (obit.);
	Hedwigia 42: (162). 1903 (prof. title), 53: (96). 1912 (Geh. Regierungsrath); Nat.
	Nov. 23: 344. 1901 (to Berlin), 25: 299. 1903 (prof. title), 37: 196. 1915 (retires from
	Bureau); Österr. bot. Z. 22: 407. 1872 (in charge of Leipziger botanischer Taus-
	chverein), 31: 102. 1881 (Kassel), 51: 319. 1901 (to Berlin), 62: 199. 1912 (Geh.
	Regierungsrat), 78: 360. 1929 (d.).

Pascher, A., Beih. Bot. Centralbl. 45(2)(Heft 3): [vi-vii, facing p. 397]. 1928 (obit. not.,
	portr.).
Schmid, B. &amp; C. Thesing, Biol.-Kalend. 1: 328. 1914.
Stephenson, H.H., Who's who in science international 1914: 273.

<sm>COMPOSITE WORKS</sm>: (1) Founder and editor, <em>Botanisches Centralblatt</em> ... vol. 1-88, 1880-
1901.
(2) Founder and editor of <em>Beihefte, Botanisches Centralblatt</em>, vols. 1-45, 1891-1929 ('40-'45
with A. Pascher).
(3) Founder and editor of <em>Bibliotheca botanica</em>, Hefte 1-13. 1886-1889.

Uilkens, Theodorus Frederik (1812-1891), Dutch protestant minister, botanist and
horticulturist; studied theology at Groningen; minister at Wehe and Zuurdijk 1836-
1890. (<em>Uilkens</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: NNBW 10: 1068-1069 (bibl., b. 25 Apr 1825, d. 12 Jun
1891; author Wumkes).

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Brit. Mus. gen. cat. print. books 243: 159. 1964; Groningen, Tijdschr.
	Volkstaal gesch. volksleven 1: 60-61. 1916 (on Museum Uilkens, Wehe, now de-
	stroyed; no bot. coll.).

<sm>NOTE</sm>: Uilken's father, Jacobus Albertus Uilkens (1772-1825), Dr. phil. Groningen 1795,
protestant minister at Lellens (1797-1799) and Eenrum (1799-1815), professor of rural
economy at Groningen 1815-1821, was the author of e.g. <em>Redevoeringen over de volmaakt-
heden van den Schepper in zijne schepselen beschouwd</em>, Groningen 1801-1822, 4 vols. on which
see e.g. Wumkes, NNBW 10: 1067-1068, H.C. van Hall, <em>Redevoer. plantenrijk</em> 1837, TL-
2/2287, F.A.W. Miquel, <em>Beschouw. delfst</em>. 1855, TL-2/6110 and F.A. Stafleu, Wentia 16:
7-8. 1966.

15.435. <em>Handboek voor den Nederlandschen Tuinbouw</em> ... te Groningen (bij J. Oomkens, J.
Zoon) 1848. Oct. (<em>Handb. Ned. Tuinb</em>.).

<em>Publ</em>.: 1848 (p. iv: Sep 1848), p. [i]-xx, [1]-380. <em>Copy</em>: U-UB.

PAGE: 568
HEADING: UITTIEN

Uittien, Hendrik (1898-1944), Dutch botanist; studied biology in Utrecht; assistant for
systematic botany at the University of Utrecht 1921-1923, curator 1923-1926; Dr. phil.
ib. 1929 (student of F.A.F.W. Went); lecturer at the College of Colonial Agriculture
(Middelbare Koloniale Landbouwschool) Deventer 1926-1933 and 1937-1941; assistant
again in Utrecht 1933-1937, from 1936-1937 lecturer (privaat-docent) in the history of
botany; from 1941-1944 actively engaged in the underground movement against the
German occupation; executed 1944. (<em>Uittien</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: U. – <em>Letters</em> at G, library at U.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Backer p. 603; Barnhart 3: 414 (d. 10 Aug 1944); BJI 2:
181; MW p. 507; SK 4: no. 111.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Isis 43(1): 56. 1952 (obit.).
Lanjouw, J., <em>in</em> H. Uittien, De volksnamen van onze planten 1946, p. iii-vi (biogr. note
	in preface; portr.; Ned. kruidk. Arch. 56: 59-68, portr. 1949 (obit., bibl., b. 26 Sep
	1898); Biologia 2 (Chron. bot. 12(4-6)): 202-204. 1951.
Lowden, R.M., Taxon, Index pers. names vols. 1-30. 750. 1984.
Pol, D. v.d., NRC-Handelsblad (Rotterdam) 29 Jan 1983, Bijvoegsel p. 5 (on U.'s share
	in the resistance movement 1940-1945).
Swart, J.J., Vakbl. Biol. 25: 77-78. 1945 (obit.).
Verdoorn, F., ed., Chron. bot. 1: 363, 380. 1935, 2: 28, 34, 35, 237, 394. 1936, 3: 27,
	206. 1937, 4: 82, 86, 399, 541. 1938, 5: 555 [index]. 1939, 6: 308. 1941; Man. pteridol.
	565, 580. 1938.

<em>Note</em>: Uittien, in a note to Frans Verdoorn, 13 July 1939, on the discovery of this part of
	the Aublet herbarium, proposed to publish a news flash in Chronica botanica: "Theft
	of type herbarium elucidated after 170 years. A report on a week of herbarium hunt-
	ing by taxi over 1300 km ... Was Jean Jacques Rousseau a kleptomaniac? With juicy
	details on the love life of Rousseau and the maîtresse of Pétain".

Ujhelyi, József (1910-1979), Hungaran botanist; studied natural history, geography
and chemistry at the Pázmány Péter University, Budapest 1930-1934; Dr. phil. (plant
taxonomy, geography and mineralogy) ib. 1937; assistant at the Department of plant
taxonomy of the P.P. University 1937-1942; first assistant 1942-1947, honorary professor
1945-1955; director of the Botanical Department of the Hungarian Natural History
Museum 1945-1950; with the National Center of Museums and Monuments 1950-1952;
again associated with the Hungarian Natural History Museum from 1952. (<em>Ujhelyi</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: BP.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: PFC 3(2): XVU.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Kováts, D., Ann. hist.-nat. Mus. natl. Hung. 72: 5-9. 1980 (b. 4 Mai 1910, d. 3
	Mai 1979; obit., portr., bibl.).

Ulander, Axel Petrus (1874-?), Swedish botanist and agronomist; Fil. kand. Uppsala
1898, student at Göttingen 1903-1905; Dr. phil. ib. 1905; assistant with the Svenska
Utsädesföringen at Luleå 1906-1913; later teacher at the Luleå seminarium. (<em>Ulander</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: GR p. 502-503; KR p. 729 (b. 8 Apr 1874); LS 27498,
40162.

15.463. <em>Untersuchungen über die Kohlenhydrate der Flechten</em>. Inaugural-Dissertation zur Erlan-
gung der Doktorwürde der Hohen Philosophischen Fakultät der Georg-Augusts-
Unversität zu Göttingen ... Göttingen (Druck der Dieterich'schen Univ.-Buchdruckerei
(W.Fr. Kaestner)). 1905. Oct. (<em>Unters. Kohlenhydr. Flecht</em>.).

<em>Publ</em>.: 1905 (intr.: oral exam. 2 Aug 1905), p. [1]-59, [60, Lebenslauf). <em>Copies</em>: LC, MO,
	NSUB, US.

Ulbrich, [Oskar] Eberhard (1879-1952), German (Berlin) botanist; studied natural
sciences at the University of Berlin 1899-1905; Dr. phil. ib. 1905, student of A. Engler;
free-lance assistant at the Botanical Museum and Herbarium, Berlin 1902-1905 (1903-
1904 with L. Kny at the Agric. College); assistant 1905-1908, tenured assistant 1908-
1920; curator 1920-1926, professor from 1926; in charge of the Department of fungi from
1938. (<em>Ulbr</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: B (partly extant). – Ulbrich introduced the use of a colour
scheme to indicate geographical regions on herbarium specimens and fascicles (1911, see
below); see also his contribution to Abderhalden (under Composite works) for his
numerous innovations introduced into herbarium practice. – <em>Letters</em> at G.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 414; BFM 2690, 2691, 3332; BJI 2: 181; BM
8: 1338; Bossert p. 410; DTS 6(4): 202-203; GR p. 146; Hawksworth p. 186; Hirsch p.
306-307; IH 1 (ed. 1): 10; KR p. 729; Langman p. 750-751; LS suppl. 28264-28279;

PAGE: 572
HEADING: ULBRICH

MW p. 507; Stevenson p. 1261; TL-2/1711, 4558; Tucker 1: 706, 3: 315; Urban-Berl.
405; Zander ed. 10, p. 726, ed. 11, p. 828; Zep-Tim p. 109.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Index Amer. bot. lit. 1886-1966, 4: 397. 1969; Kürschners Deut.
	Gelehrt.-Kal. 1950: 2135; Nat. Nov. 22: 201. 1920 (app. curator); Notizbl. Berlin-
	Dahlem 7: 334. 1917 (Verdienstkreuz Kriegshilfe).
Kohlmeyer, J., Willdenowia 3(1): 64-66. 1962 (mycol. coll. only partly extant).
Kumerloeve, H., Naturw. Rundschau 6: 350. 1953 (obit.).
Lowden, R.M., Taxon, Index pers. names vols. 1-30. 750. 1985.
Meyer, D.E., Ber. deut. bot. Ges. 68a: 317-319. 1957 (obit.).
Mildbraed, J., Willdenowia 1(1): 39-40. 1953 (obit. not.), 1(2): 154-174. 1954 (b. 17
	Sep 1879, d. 4 Nov 1952, obit., portr., bibl. of 209 nos. excl. reviews and notices in
	daily journals); Taxon 2: 21-22. 1953 (obit.).
Rosenthal, M., Von ... Eberhard Ulbrich ... veröffentlichte wissenschaftliche Arbeiten
	grösseren Umfanges, Berlin 1954 (75 major works; total number of papers known ca.
	400; typescrypt at B).
Verdoorn, F., ed., Chron. bot. 1: 133, 155. 1935, 6: 308. 1941.

1924.

Benützung einiger Vorarbeiten Prof. Dr. E. Ulbrichs".

(7) <em>Pflanzenwelt, in</em> H.W. Conwentz, ed., <em>Das Plagefenn bei Chorin</em>, Beitr. Naturdenkmalpfl.

15.472. <em>Ordnung grösserer, systematischer Herbarien</em> mit Berücksichtigung der geographischen
Verbreitung. (Methode des Königl. botanischen Museums zu Dahlem bei Berlin) ...
[Extrait des Actes du iiime Congrès international de Botanique Bruxelles 1910. Tome ii
(Avril 1911). Bruxelles (Albert de Boeck ...)]. 

<em>Publ</em>.: Apr 1911, p. [i-ii], [43]-49, 16 charts, 1 map. <em>Copy</em>: G. – Reprinted and to be cited
	from Act. Congr. int. Bot., Bruxelles 1910: [43]-49, 16 charts, map. 1911.
<em>Berichtigungen und Nachträge</em>: 29 Jun 1911, p. [1-2]. <em>Copy</em>: G.
<em>Note</em>: A major characteristic of Ulbrich's system of labelling herbarium specimens was
	the geographical colour code: white for the non-Mediterranean Euro-Siberian area;
	red for North America etc. Ulbrich explains that this code has a mnemotechnic basis:
	"Diese acht Grundfarben prägen sich dem Gedächtnis leicht ein, zumal, wenn wir
	uns mnemotechnischen Hilfsmittels bedienen, dass die Farben in Beziehung bringt zu
	den Bewohnern oder den bekannten Eigenschaften der betreffenden Länder. So kann
	uns die weisse Farbe an die weisse Rasse (Europa-Siberien), die gelbe an die gelbe
	Rasse (China-Japan), die braune an die Neger u.s.w. (Afrika-Arabien), die rote an
	die Rothäute (Nordamerika) erinnern. Die blaue Grundfarbe kann uns erinnern an
	die blaue Farbe des Himmels und Meers in Mittelmeergebiete, die grüne an die
	üppige Fülle des monsunalen Tropenwaldes". No association is mentioned for "rosa"
	(pink) (C. &amp; S. Amer) and violet (Austral., N. Zeal., Oceania), even though as-
	sociations with pink and purple are not difficult to find.

chern ... Leipzig (Wilhelm Engelmann 1912]. Oct.

<em>Publ</em>.: 31 Mar 1935, p. [355]-369. <em>Copy</em>: B. – Reprinted and to be cited from Notizbl.

15.510. <em>Essbar oder giftig?</em> Ein Ratgeber für Pilzsammler ... Berlin (Verlag der Grünen

<em>Publ</em>.: 1937 (Nat. Nov. Feb 1938), p. [1]-87, [88]. <em>Copy</em>: B.
<em>Ed. 3</em>: 1944 (n.v.).

15.511. <em>Die floristische Stellung der Mark</em> ... Brandenburgische Jahrbücher ... 1941. Oct. 

<em>Publ</em>.: 1941, p. [1]-80. <em>Copy</em>: B. – Issued as Brandenb. Jahrb. 16, 1941.

Ule, Ernst Heinrich Georg (1854-1915), German (Prussian) botanist and botanical
explorer of the Amazonas and the Brazilian highlands; studied at the Proskau horticul-
tural college 1874-1876; gardener in Halle and Berlin 1876-1879; prepared himself for
the qualification to attend a University 1879-1880; inactive because of illness 1880-1883;
to Brazil 1883, private teacher and collector in Santa Catharina 1883-1891; to Rio de
Janeiro as travelling naturalist with the National Museum 1891, collected in Southern
and Central Brazil, assistant-director 1895-1900, in 1898-1899 working on his collections
in Brazil; independent explorer from 1900; in the Amazonian region on a privately
sponsored caoutchouc expedition 1900-1903, in Bahia 1906-1907, again in the
Amazonas region 1908-1932; in Berlin from 1912; assistant at the Botanical Museum
Berlin 1913-1914. (<em>Ule</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: B (some material still extant), BAS, BM, BP, BR, C, CORD,
DPU, E, F, FH, G, GOET, H, HBG (impt. set, up to no. 7575; for fungi see Friederich-
sen 1973), K, KBG (destr.), L, LE, M, MG, MIN, NY, P, PH, PR, R, U, US (659), W,
WRSL. – See Urban 1909 (full details). – <em>Letters</em> to W.G. Farlow at FH, to K. Keck at
UPS-UB; other letters at G.
<em>Exsiccatae</em>: (1) <em>Bryotheca brasiliensis</em> nos. 1-298, 1891-1905 (for list see Hedwigia 38: [57]-
[58]. 1899; nos. 241-298, see ib. 44: [90]-[91]. 1905; edited by V.F. Brotherus, identifi-
cations by Brotherus, Karl Müller (Halle), Carl Warnstorf. – Sets at BM, E, FH,
GOET, H, KIEL, MANCH, OXF, PC, S, W. – See Sayre 1971.
(2) <em>Mycotheca brasiliensis</em> cent. 1, Berlin (1905) and Appendix, nos. 1-36, Berlin (1905),
for list see Hedwigia 44: [88]-[89]. 1905. – Sets at B (extant), BPI, BRU, FH, GOET,
ILL, KIEL, LIL, NY, PAD, SI. – For details see Stevenson (1971).
(3) <em>Herbarium brasiliense</em>: irregular sets of Brazilian material were offered for sale by Ule
(e.g. 445 cryp. bought 1899 by BM; many coll. in FH), see Bot. Jahrb. 32, Beibl. nr. 72
for details.
(4) Ule contributed to W. Zopf &amp; Sydow, <em>Mycotheca marchica</em>.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Backer p. 662; Barnhart 3: 414; BJI 1: 59, 2: 181-182;
Bossert p. 410; Clokie p. 258; CSP 19: 253-254; Hortus 3: 1205; IH 1 (ed. 6): 365, (ed.
7): 344; Langman p. 751; LS 27499-27502, suppl. 28280; Rehder 5: 867; Stevenson p.
1261; Tucker 1: 706; Urban-Berl. p. 269, 283, 291, 315, 405; Zander ed. 10, p. 726, ed.
11, p. 828; Zep-Tim p. 109-110.

<em>Ref</em>.: Lakon (Hohenheim), Bot. Centralbl. 131: 227. 7 Mar 1916 (rev.).

Uline, Edwin Burton (1867-1933), American teacher and botanist; studied at Wabash
College 1888-1891, at Indiana Univ. 1891-1893, AM 1893, instructor ib. 1892-1893;
instructor in botany Lake Forest Univ. 1893-1895; at the University of Leipzig 1895, at
Berlin Univ. 1896-1898; Dr. phil. Berlin 1897, student of A. Engler; assistant curator
Field Museum 1899; id. Gray Herbarium 1900; superintendent of schools Mankato,
Minn. 1899-1904, High School of Commerce, New York 1904-1906, principal of public
schools in Brooklyn 1906-1930. (<em>Uline</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: North American and Canadian material at CAN, F. – <em>Letters</em> at
G.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Backer p. 662; Barnhart 3: 414 (b. 20 Sep 1867, d. 10
Mai 1933; curr. vit.); BJI 1: 59; CSP 19: 255 (bibl.); Langman p. 751; MW p. 507;
Rehder 2: 189, 582; Tucker 3: 315.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Bot. Centralbl. 56: 320. 1893 (app. Lake For. Coll.); Bot. Jahrb. 18
	(Beibl. 43): 47. 1893 (curator of the herbarium at Lake Forest University under J.M.
	Coulter); Index Amer. bot. lit. 1886-1966, 4: 399. 1969; The New York Times 3 Jun
	1933 (obit.).
Uline, E.B., Monogr. Dioscor. p. [46]. 1897 (curr. vit.).

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Brayulinea</em> J.K. Small (1903, also honors W.L. Bray (1865-1953), a worker on
the Amaranthaceae).

15.534. <em>A preliminary synopsis of the North American species of Amaranthus</em> ... From the Botan-
ical Gazette ... [1894]. 

<em>Co-authors</em>: William L. Bray (1865-1953).
[<em>1</em>]: 16 Jul and 15 Aug 1894, p. [267]-272, 313-320. – Reprinted and to be cited from
	Bot. Gaz. 19: [267]-272, 313-320. 1894.

Ulke, Titus (1866-1961), American patent attorney, chemist, botanist and mineralog-
ist; B.S. Columbia College, Washington D.C. 1885; studied at the Mining Academy,
Freiberg in Sachsen, ME George Washington University 1889; Dr. phil. (bot.) Catholic
Univ. Amer. 1934; U.S. examiner of patents 1906-1918, patent attorney 1918-1932.
(<em>Ulke</em>).

Ullepitsch, Joseph (1827-1896), Austrian mining and financial administrator and
naturalist at Wiliczka, Szwoszowice, in the Schemnitz region (Rhonitz, Kremnitz, then
in Hungary) 1850-1856; Laibach 1856-1857, Klagenfurt 1857-1866; Praha 1866-1867,
Linz 1867-1872, and Triest 1873-1880; in retirement at Rohrbach, Poysdorf, Gnezda
and, ultimately Wilfersdorf. (<em>Ullep</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: B (greater part see Lack &amp; Wagner (1984), WU. – Other
material at BUC, C, E, G, GOET, K, KL, LI, MANCH, OXF, WRSL, WU. – <em>Letters</em>
to K. Keck at UPS-UB.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: AG 4: 400, 12(1): 129; Barnhart 3: 414 (b. 27 Mar 1827,
d. 16 Dec 1896); Clokie p. 258; CSP 19: 255; Futak-Domin p. 622; Hegi 6(2): 1210.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Allg. bot. Z. 5: 184. 1899 (herb. to WU); Bot. Centralbl. 69: 192. 1897
	(d.), 80: 173. 1899 (Fürst J. Liechtenstein has bought U.'s herbarium and donated it

	310. 1899 (herb. to WU).

Ullgren, Olof Matthias (1785-1819), Swedish botanist, historian and librarian; Dr.
phil. Uppsala 1806, lecturer in Swedish history and employee at Uppsala University
Library. (<em>Ullgren</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

Uloth, Wilhelm [Ludwig Heinrich] (1833-1895), German (Hessen) botanist and
pharmacist; studied pharmacy in Treysa; worked with C. v. Nägeli in Zürich 1856;
studied at the University of Marburg 1857-1859; Dr. phil. ib. 1859; in charge of a
chemical-pharmaceutical factory at Bad Nauheim 1860; in charge of the Nauheim phar-
macy 1868; id. at Friedberg 1878-1879; teacher at Colleges in Friedberg (1879) and
Bensheim (1880), specialist for pharmacy at the Darmstadt ministery 1881; professor of
pharmacognosy at the Darmstadt Technical University from 1884. (<em>Uloth</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Location not known (Ann. bryol. 9: 153); some lichens at B
(mainly destr.), M and WRSL.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: AG 4: 270; Barnhart 3: 415 (b. 13 Mar 1833, d. 23 Jan

1895); Biol.-Dokum. 18: 9462-9463; CSP 6: 82, 8: 1135, 11: 667; GR p. 51 (orig. info.),
cat. p. 72; LS 27507-27509; Rehder 5: 867; Urban-Berl. p. 315.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Dann, G.E., Apoth.-Zeit. 41(85): 1175. 1926 (biogr. sketch).
Ludwig, W., Hess. florist. Briefe 13(148): 13-20. 1964 (biogr., bibl.; sec. refs.).

Unamuno Yrigoyen, Luis M. (1873-1943), Spanish clergyman (O.S.A.) and botanist;
Dr. phil. Madrid 1906; professor of natural history at the college of the PP. Augustinos
de Lianes, Oviedo; from 1927 in Madrid ultimately as director of the Mycological
laboratory of the Jardin botanico, and professor of botany. (<em>Unamuno</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: MA. – Further material at H (fungi).

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Bossert p. 411; Hirsch p. 307; IH 2 (files); LS suppl.

	109. 1949 (Pugillus fungorum ... a cl. P. Unamuno collect.).
Verdoorn, F., ed., Chron. bot. 1: 244, 253. 1935, 4: 276. 1938.

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Unamunoa</em> Urries (1942).

<sm>NOTE</sm>: Unamuno was a prolific author of whom we treat here only a small number of
publications. A good set of his mycological papers between 1920 and 1940 is at the
Stevenson Library (BPI).

Unanue, José Hipólito (1755-1853), Peruvian writer, physician and mathematician;
professor of medicine at the Escuela de medicina of Lima; founder of the Escuela de
Medicina of San Fernando; active in the movement of Peruvian independence (cosigna-
tory manifesto 1812); in various government functions, ultimately as prime minister.
(<em>Unanue</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

Underwood, Lucien Marcus (1853-1907), American botanist; Dr. phil. Syracuse
Univ. 1879 (LL.D. 1906), instructor in biology and geology, Syracuse University 1883-
1886; professor id. 1886-1891; professor of botany De Pauw Univ. 1891-1895; professor
of biology Alabama Polytechnic Institute 1895-1896; professor of botany at Columbia
College 1896-1907; chairman of the board of scientific directors New York Botanical
Garden 1901-1907. (<em>Underw</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: NY. – Other material at ALU, BM, C, DBN, DPU, DUKE, E,
F, FH, G, GH, K, L, LIV, LIVU, MAINE, MICH, NY, NYS, OS, P, PH, TENN, US
(Jamaica 447, Puerto Rico 1003) YU. – <em>Manuscripts</em> and <em>letters</em>: NY; other letters at FH,
G, GH. (Manuscript <em>A list of the Anthocerotaceae</em> 20 Apr 1907, 7 p. typescript, is at NY).
<em>Exsiccatae</em> (1): <em>Indiana flora, parasitic fungi</em>, series 1, nos. 1-100. Dec 1894. Greencastle,
Indiana. Sets: BPI, DPU, F, FH, MSC, NCU, NY, PUR (20 sets issued) (see Stevenson
1971 and Underwood, Proc. Indiana Acad. Sci. 1893: 16. 1894: 144-156. 1895).
(2) With Orator Fuller Cook (1867-1949), <em>A century of illustrative fungi</em>, octavo volume (21
page intr. text, 100 specimens mounted 2-3 per page); cent. 1, nos. 1-100, Sep 1889,
Syracuse, New York. Sets at BPI, BRU, COLO, CUP, DPU, FH, ISC, MASS, MICH,
NY, NYS, PAC, TRTC, WELC (see Stevenson 1971, J.E. Humphrey and P. Sydow
(1891). Text issued separately as <em>Generic synopses of the Basidiomycetes and Myxomycetes</em>
(1889).
(3) With Orator Fuller Cook (1867-1949), <em>Hepaticae americanae</em>, decades 1-20, 1887-1899,

PAGE: 588
HEADING: UNDERWOOD

nos. 1-200. Sets at: B (mainly destr.), CM, FH, NY, NYS, PH, WELC. – For dates see
Barnhart (1908), nos. 25, 31, 35, 37, 42, 48, 49, 65, 93, 121) and Sayre (1971).

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Backer p. 662; Barnhart 3: 416 (b. 26 Oct 1853, d. 10
Nov 1907); BJI 1: 59; BL 1: 145, 176, 225, 322; BM 2: 501, 5: 2164, 8: 1339; Bossert p.

(ed. 7): 344, 2: 175; Kelly p. 231; Lenley p. 416-417; LS 27516-27546f, 40170-40177;
Morren ed. 2, p. 508, ed. 10, p. 128; NW p. 60; PH 26, 164, 209, 906; SBC p. 134; SIA

Zander ed. 10, p. 726, ed. 11, p. 828.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Amer. men sci. ed. I. 328. 1906; Bot. Centralbl. 47: 223. 1891 (from
	Syracuse to De Pauw), 64: 319. 1895 (from DePauw to Alabama), 67: 128. 1896

	fortune); Natl. Cycl. Amer. biogr. 12: 238. 1904; Nat. Nov. 18: 334. 1896 (succeeds
	N.L. Britton as prof. bot. Columbia College); Rev. bryol. 35: 16. 1908 ("a été une des
	victimes du désastre financier de New York. Ayant perdu sa fortune, il s'est, d'après
	les journaux, coupé la gorge, après avoir essayé de tuer sa femme et sa fille"); Science
	26: 726. 1907 (suicide), 27: 858. 1908 (obit. not.), 29: 733. 1909 (memorial tablet);
	Torreya 7: 244. 1908 (d.), 9: 132. 1909 (fern herb. NY to be called "The Underwood
	fern herbarium"); Who's who Amer. 1-4, 1895-1907; Who was who Amer. 1: 1264.
	1968.
Barnhart, J.H., Bull. Torrey bot. Club 35(1): 17-38. 1908 (bibl. 212 entries).
Britton, E.G., J. New York Bot. Gard. 9: 23. 1908 (Hepatics purchased from U. before
	his death); Columbia Univ. Quart. 1907 (Dec): 67-69 (obit., portr.).
Britton, N.L., Bull. Torrey bot. Club 35: 39-40. 1908 (relation to NY).
Brown, J.H., ed., Lamb's biogr. dict. U.S. 7: 410. 1903.
Clute, W.N., Fern Bull. 15: 67-68. 1907.

Elliott, C.A., Biogr. dict. Amer. Sci. 258. 1979.

	resolutions).

Frodin, D.G., Guide standard floras world D-1. 1984.

Haynes, C.C., Bryologist 11: 41-44. 1098 (obit., portr., bibl. 32 nos. of bryol. publ.).
Howe, M.A., Bull. Torrey bot. Club 35(1): 13-16. 1908 (memor. trib.; "Fifty years
	hence, perhaps, it will be generally conceded that he rendered a notable service to
	botanical science in insisting upon the importance of nomenclatural types of genera
	and species. ...").
Humphrey, J.E., Bot. Centralbl. 41: 86. 1890 (rev. Cent. ill. fung.).

	directors NYBG comm. U).
Lowden, R.M., Taxon, Index pers. names vols. 1-30. 751. 1985.
Markle, M.S., Proc. Indiana Acad. Sci. 76: 145. 1967 (cites Underwood: "There has
	been a seeming fear ... that anything short of cytology [substitute "molecular bio-
	logy"] was undignified in a botanical laboratory").
Murrill, W.A., J. New York bot. Gard. 15: 224. 1914 (U.'s fungi, 17.000 specim. pur-
	chased by NY, Jul 1914).

<sm>COMPOSITE WORKS</sm>: (1) Originator, with N.L. Britton, of the <em>North American Flora</em>, as-
sociate editor for the first five parts.
(2) Editor, <em>Bull. Torrey bot. Club</em> 16-24. Jan 1889-Dec 1897.
(3) Editor, <em>Memoirs Torrey bot. Club</em> 6 (p.p.) and 7-12, 1898-1902.
(4) <em>Hepaticae, in</em> A. Gray, <em>Manual</em>, ed. 6. 702-732, <em>pl. 22-25.</em> 1890.
(5) <em>Pteridophyta, in</em> J.M. Coulter, <em>Botany of western Texas</em>, Contr. U.S. natl. Herb. 2: 557-
568. 10 Mai 1894.
(6) With Franklin Sumner Earle, <em>Treatment of some fungous diseases</em>, Bull. Alabama Agr.
Expt. Sta. 69(4): 243-272. Feb 1896.
(7) <em>Pteridophyta, in</em> N.L. Britton and A. Brown, Ill. fl. n. U.S. 1: 1-48. Aug 1896.
(8) [Entries on botany of ferns <em>Acrostichum-Dryopteris</em>] in L.H. Bailey &amp; W. Miller, Cycl.
Amer. Hort. 1, 14 Feb 1900 (for detailed list see Barnhart no. 132), <em>id. Gleichenia-Mohria</em>,
in 2, 18 Jul 1900 (Barnhart 135), <em>id. Nephrodum-Pteris</em>, in 3, 23 Apr 1901 (Barnhart 143),
<em>id. Schizaea-Woodwardia</em>, in 4, 26 Feb 1902 (Barnhart 154).
(9) <em>Pteridophyta, in</em> N.L. Britton, <em>Man. fl. n. states</em> 1901, p. 1-29, 1901, see TL-2/779. – Also
in ed. 2, 1905.
(10) <em>Fungi, edible and poisonous, in</em> A.H. Buck, <em>Reference handbook of the medical sciences</em> ed. 2.
4: 275-286. 1902.
(11) <em>Ferns and fern-allies</em>, in <em>Encyclopedia americana</em> 7: [308-312]. [1904].
(12) <em>Flowerless plants or cryptogams, in</em> W. Miller, <em>A synopsis of the vegetable kingdom</em> p. 77-80,
<em>in</em> L.H. Bailey &amp; W. Miller, <em>Cycl. Amer. hort</em>. ed. 4. 1, 27 Mar 1906.
(13) <em>Pteridophyta, in</em> P.A. Rydberg, <em>Fl. Colorado</em> 1906 (TL-2/9861), p. 1-6.
(14) <em>Pteridophyta, in</em> Th. Morong, H.H. Rusby et al., <em>List of Pteridophyta and Spermatophyta</em>
growing without cultivation in Northeastern North America, Mem. Torrey bot. Club 5:
9-17. 4 Dec 1893. – See TL-2/6342.
(15) NAF, with R.C. Benedict, <em>Pteridophyta</em> 16(1). I. 6 Nov 1909, <em>Ophioglossales</em> 16(1): 1.
6 Nov 1909 and <em>Ophioglossaceae</em> 16(1): 3-13. 6 Nov 1909; <em>Marattiales</em> and <em>Marattiaceae</em>,
16(1): 15-23. 6 Nov 1909; with W.R. Maxon <em>Filicales</em>, 16(1): 25. 6 Nov 1909.
(16) Identification of <em>Hepaticae, in</em> E.L. Rand and J.H. Redfield, <em>Flora of Mount Desert
Island, Maine</em>, Cambridge 1894, TL-2/8623.

<sm>MAIN BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm>: see Barnhart 1908, here referred to as "Barnhart" (212 nos., in-
cludes an analytical index).

American species ... Bloomington, Ill. 1881. (<em>Native ferns</em>).

	MO, US.

15.562. Vol. ix. Part i. <em>Systematic botany of North America. Hepaticae</em>. By Lucien Marcus
Underwood. (Issued January 1895). Oct. (<em>Syst. bot. N. Amer., Hepat</em>.).

<em>Publ</em>.: Jan 1895, cover-t.p., p. [1]-7. <em>Copies</em>: BR, FAS, FH, G, NY(4), USDA. – Actually
	a prospectus for a new project, <em>The systematic botany of North America</em>, undertaken by
	Underwood and N.L. Britton in association with G.F. Atkinson, J.M. Coulter, F.V.
	Coville, E.L. Greene, B.D. Halsted and A. Hollick and described on p. 2-4 of the
	cover. Underwood's sample treatment is limited to <em>Riccia</em>. The composite work started
	only 10 years later, under the title <em>North American Flora</em>, see TL-/781.
<em>Announcement</em>: <em>The proposed new systematic botany of North America</em> ... Proc. Indian Acad. Sci.
	1894: 133. Oct. 1895.

15.578. <em>The genus Riella</em>, with descriptions of new species from North America and the

<em>Co-author</em>: Marshall Avery Howe (1867-1936), TL-2/2: 347-348.

Unger, Franz [Joseph Andreas Nicolaus] (1800-1870), Austrian botanist; Dr. med.
Wien 1827; practicing physician at Stockerau 1828-1830; forensic physician at Kitzbüh-
el; professor of botany and zoology at the Johanneum, Graz 1835-1849; professor of
plant anatomy and physiology Univ. Wien 1849-1866; in retirement at Graz 1866-1870.
(<em>Unger</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: GJO; other material in BR, GZU, M, PC, REG (fungi), W
(Cyprus, Greece). – <em>Letters</em> to D.F.L. von Schlechtendal at HAL; other letters at G,
UPS-UB.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: AG 5(2): 169, 12(2): 654; Ainsworth p. 21, 154, 314;
Andrews p. 341-342; Backer p. 604; Barnhart 3: 416 (b. 30 Nov 1800, d. 13 Feb 1870);
BM 2: 530, 1019, 5: 2164-2165, 8: 1339; Bossert p. 411; CSP 6: 84-87, 8: 1137-1138, 12:
747; De Toni 1: cxxv-cxxvi, 2: cxvi; DSB 13: 542-543 (R. Olby); DTS 1: 311-312, xxiv,
6(4): 203; Frank 3 (Anh.): 107-108; GR p. 461; Hawksworth p. 186; Herder p. 482
(index); Hortus 3: 1206; Jackson [see index]; KR p. 730-731; Lasègue p. 524; LS 27547-
27564; Maiwald p. 246; Moebius 457 [index]; NI 2024-2029; PR 2702, 9601-9629, ed.
1: 2999. 6585, 7307, 10579-10593; Quenstedt p. 438-439; Ratzeburg p. 496-498; Rehder
5: 868-869; RS p. 146; Saccardo 2: 110; SBC p. 134; SO 3465; Stevenson p. 1261; TL-

1/794. 1343-1344; TL-2/1674, 1680, 1686, 1725, 2838, 3524, 3891, 5520, 6535, 11.949,

documentation, bibl., detailed information on cause of death).

Anon., Almanach Akad. Wiss. Wien 1: 43, 265-270. 1851 (bibl.), 4: 155, 20: 40 (d. 13

	267 (returns from Greece). 1860, 9: 90-91. 1861 ("New Holland in Europe"), 10: 13.
	1862 (with Kotschy to Cyprus); Bot. Zeit. 14: 174-175 (attacked by ultramontane
	factions; accused of blasphemy and pantheism, seducer of the youth, on one level with
	Vogt and Moleschott, pamphlet "Isispriester und Philister"; protest of U.'s students
	against this attack, rehabilitation by state; possibility of transfer to München), 808
	(portr. and biogr. in Illustr. Zeit.). 1856, 20: 48. 1862 (with Kotschy to Cyprus), 22:
	120. 1864 (biogr. in Bot. Zeit.), 25: 352. 1867 (Hofrath), 28: 128 (d.; murdered?), 296

Unger, Michael (<em>fl</em>. 1806), German (Prussian) physician and botanist; Dr. phil. Halle

<em>Publ</em>.: 25 Jan 1806, p. [1]-34, [1]. <em>Copy</em>: B-S.

Ungern-Sternberg, Franz (x-1885), Baltic-German (Estonia born) physician and
botanist; Dr. med. Dorpat 1866; practicing physician in Torino (Italy). (<em>Ungern-Sternb</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: TO. – <em>Letters</em> at G.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Backer p. 604; Barnhart 3: 416 (d. 12 Aug 1885); BM 5:
2165; Bossert p. 411; CSP 12: 747, 19: 261; Herder p. 299; MW p. 508; PR 9632 (d. 24
Jan 1868, err.); Rehder 2: 187; Saccardo 1: 167; TR 1526-1527.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Bot Zeit. 44: 31. 1886 (d. 12 Aug 1885); Nat. Nov. 7: 248. 1885 (d.);
	Österr. bot. Z. 35: 445. 1885 (d.).
Burnat, E., Bull. Soc. bot. France 30: cxxxii. 1893 (herb. with him in Torino); Boissiera
	5: 91. 1941.
Kanitz, A., Magy. növen. Lap. 9: 139. 1885 (obit. not.).
Lucante, A., Rev. de Bot. 4: 333. 1886 (d.).
Mattirolo, O., Studie veget. Piemonte, 2: xcv, cii. 1929 (herb. at TO).
Reichenbach, H.G., Bot. Centralbl. 24: 159. 1885 (d. 12 Aug 1885); J. Bot. 23: 385.
	1885 (obit. not.).

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Ungernia</em> Bunge (1875).

<sm>NOTE</sm>: Pritzel and others cite the date of death as 24 Jan 1868; this is erroneous: [Peter
Georg] Franz Ungern-Sternberg, soldier in the Russian cavalry, later painter, died on
that day, 12 Jan 1868 o.s. (24 n.s.) in Dorpat.

15.634. <em>Versuch einer Systematik der Salicornieen</em>. Eine mit Bewilligung der Hochverordneten

PAGE: 603
HEADING: UNWIN

Medicinischen Facultät der kaiserlichen Universität zu Dorpat zur Erlangung der
Würde eines Doctors der Medicin verfasste und zur öffentlichen Vertheidigung bestim-

Karow, ...) 1866. Oct. (<em>Vers. Syst. Salicorn.</em>).

Unverricht, Carl (1809-1883), German (Silesian) teacher and botanist; studied at the
Evangelical teacher's seminary at Breslau 1830-1833, assistant teacher at Böhmischdorf
nr. Brieg 1833-1834; teacher at Königshütte (Upper Silesia) 1834-1835; studied at the
University of Breslau 1835-1836; teacher at Fürstenstein 1836-1842; teacher at the com-
mercial college Bonn 1843, studied again in Breslau 1846, teacher in Hermannstadt
1847-1848, 1851; director of the evangelical school in Broos (Sachsenstadt, Szásváros in
Siebenbürgen) 1881, private teacher ib. 1854; active as "Privatgelehrter" in Laurahütte
(Preuss. Oberschles.) from 1861. (<em>Unverricht</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 416 (b. 22 Jan 1809, d. Mar 1883); BM 5:
2180; CSP 6: 88; Jackson p. 53; Kanitz p. 163 (no. 269); Morren ed. 10, p. 15; PR 9636,
ed. 1: 380; WU 49: 107-110 (detailed biogr., bibl.).

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Kanitz, A., Magy. növen. Lap. 7: 120. 1883 (obit. not.).
Pax, F., Bibl. schles. Bot. 83. 1929.
Simonkai, L., Enum. fl. transsilv. xxxiv. 1886.

Unwin, Arthur Harold (1878-?), German (British?) forester; Dr. oec. pub. München;

Upham, Warren (1850-1934), American geologist, librarian, archeologist and
botanist; A.B. Dartmouth Coll. 1871; with the geological survey of New Hampshire
1874-1878, with the geological survey of Minnesota 1879-1885, the United States Geo-
logical Survey 1893-1895; secretary and librarian of the Minnesota Historical Society
1895-1914, archeologist to this Society 1914-1933. (<em>Upham</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

Uphof, Johannes Cornells Theodoras (1886-x), Dutch botanist; studied at the
College of horticulture, Frederiksoord and the University of Amsterdam; emigrated to
the United States 1912; curator of the botanical garden at East Lansing (Michigan
Agricultural College); asst. professor of botany at the State University of Arizona 1913-
1919; in the Netherlands with the Nederlandsche Elitezaad Maatschappij 1919-1922;
professor of botany Rollins College, Orlando, Florida 1922-1941; economic botanist
Board Economic Warfare 1941-1943; at Tampa, Florida from 1945. (<em>Uphof</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown. Some material at C, PH. – <em>Letters</em> at NY.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 417 (b. 11 Jun 1886); BFM 2542, 2667,
2956; BJI 2: 182; Bossert p. 411; Hirsch p. 307; Hortus 3: 1206; JW 1: 449; Langman p.
751-752; Lenley p. 418; LS 41808, suppl. 28308-28314; Plesch p. 445; TL-2/1711, see F.
Shreve.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Amer. men Sci. eds. 4-9, 1927-1955; Index Amer. bot. lit. 1886-1966, 4:
	403-405. 1969; Österr. bot. Z. 71: 288. 1922 (app. Orlando).

Urban, Ignatz (1848-1931), German (Westphalian/Prussian) botanist; studied in Bonn
1866 and at the University of Berlin 1866-1869, 1872-1873; student of A. Braun, P.
Ascherson, L. Kny; military service 1869-1870; on active service in the Franco-Prussian
war 1870-1871 (Reserve officer, Kaiser Alexander Garde-Grenadierregiment); Dr. phil.
Berlin 1873; teacher at the Pädagogium, Lichterfelde (Berlin) 1873-1878; assistant at the
Botanical Garden, Berlin 1878-1883, curator ("Kustos") ib. 1883-1889; second director
and titular professor 1889-1913; Geheimer Regierungsrath 1903; in "retirement" re-
maining at the Botanical Garden and Museum Berlin-Dahlem, fully dedicating himself
to plant systematics, especially the study of the flora of the West Indies; historian of the
Berlin Botanical Garden and Museum and initiator of its move to Berlin-Dahlem.
(<em>Urb</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: B (mainly destr.). – Urban collected outside Germany only
during the Franco-Prussian war and few German collections made by him were distri-
buted. The West-Indian collections distributed by him stem from other collectors (e.g.
C.W.L. Krug). – Sayre (1977) mentions bryophytes from him in H-BR; a series of
<em>Medicago</em> collected (in part) and determined by him is at BP. Urban's private her-
barium (at B) consisted of his Brazilian herbarium (collections by others, but containing
Urban types), the German herbarium (the French collections and the important
Medicago coll. (see Urban-Berl.). <em>Letters</em> at FH, G, GH, HU, NY, UPS-UB, US.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: AG 2(2): 91; Backer p. 605; Barnhart 3:, 417 (b. 7 Jan
1848, d. 7 Jan 1931); BJI 1: 59-60, 2: 182-183; BL 1: 322 (index), 2: 200, 725; BM 5:
2183, 8: 1350; Bossert p. 411; CSP 8: 1138, 11: 669-670, 12: 747-748, 19: 266; DTS 1:
313; Frank 3 (Anh.): 108; Hegi 6(1): 242; Herder p. 482 (indexes); Hirsch p. 307;
Hortus 3: 1206; IF p. 735; IH 2: 390; Jackson p. 109, 136; Langman p. 752; Lenley p.
418; Morren ed. 10, p. 6; MW p. 509; NI (alph.) 2248; Rehder 5: 870; RS p. 146; SIA
see index; SK 1: cix, cxviii; TL-1/803; TL-2/see indexes; Tucker 1: 711-712, 3: 319;
Urban-Berl. p. 283, 406; Zander ed. 10, p. 726, ed. 11, p. 828-829; Zep-Tim p. 110-111.

	Urban "sprach ... davon, wie er in seinem Leben vom Glück begünstigt gewesen sei,
	als Gymnasiast, Student, Soldat, Lehrer und Forscher ..."; Bot. Centralbl. 39: 208.

(4) Editor, with E. Koehne &amp; F. Dietrich, <em>Verh. bot. Ver. Brandenburg</em> 26, 1885.
(5) Editor, with P. Graebner, <em>Festschrift zur Feier des 70. Geburtstages des Herrn Prof. Dr.
Paul Ascherson</em>, Leipzig 1904, 568 p.

Boiss. ser. 2. 3: 1114-1125. 1903.

Urban ... Berolini [Berlin] [from vol. 2: Lipsiae] (fratres Borntraeger), Parisiis (Paul
Klincksieck), Londini (Williams &amp; Norgate) 1898-1928, 9 vols. Oct. (<em>Symb. antill.</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: 1898-1925, published in fascicles, see below. Composite work; for authors see
	tables below. <em>Copies</em>: B, BR, FH, G, HH, MO, NY, U, US, USDA (orig. covers).

	Botanik. These issues are provided with the date of printing on the last page of each

	consisting of several issues) are given in the journal volumes. It may be assumed that

Urbina y Altamirano, Manuel (1843-1906), Mexican botanist; studied at the Escuela
nacional de Medecina, Mexico; medical and pharmaceutical examinations 1864; pract-
icing physician and active in various medical and scientific functions; professor of botany
at the Museo nacional from 1881, from 1889 also zoology; also connected with the
Instituto médico nacional. (<em>Urbino</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: MEXU (1158).

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 417 (b. 7 Sep 1843, d. 19 Jul 1906); BL 1:

Tucker 1: 712.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Castaneda, A.M., La flora del estado de Jalisco 118. 1933.

Uribe-Uribe, [Antonio] Lorenzo (1900-1980), Colombian clergyman (S.J.) and
botanist; entered the company of Jesus 1916, studied in Bogotá, Oña (Spain) and Val-
kenburg (Netherlands); ordained 1930; studied natural sciences in Fribourg (Switzer-
land), Braga and Roma; Dr. phil. theol. Univ. Gregor. 1935; professor of philosophy
and natural sciences at the Universidad Javeriana, Bogotá 1935; professor of botany at
the Instituto de Ciencias Naturales 1952, director of the institute 1953-1958; curator
1958-1980; editor of Mutisia and Caldasia. (<em>Uribe</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: BOG; other material at F, NY, PSO, US, WAG.

<sm>NOTE</sm>: Nearly all botanical publications fall outside our period; see Anon. (1982). Uribe's
father Joaquin Antonio Uribe (1858-1935) was also an active botanist, whose collections
are at BOG (see Rev. Acad. Colomb. Ci. nat. 10(40): 288-289 (by E.P. Arbelaez) and
289-290 (by M. Posada) 1958; further material at MEDEL.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Bossert p. 411 (b. 20 Jan 1901); IH 1 (ed. 6): 30.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Caldasia 13(64): 483-486. 1982 (obit., portr., bibl.); Index Amer. bot.
	lit. 1886-1966. 4: 408. 1969.
Frodin, D.G., Guide standard floras world no. 323. 1984.
Pinto, P., Flora de Colombia 1: ix. 1983.
Verdoorn, F., ed., Chron. bot. 7: 117. 1943.

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Uribea</em> Dugand et Romero (1962).

15.705. <em>Flora de Antioquia</em> por Joaquin Antonio Uribe ampliada y editada por Lorenzo
Uribo Uribe S.J. Medellin (Imp. Deptol.) 1940. Oct. (<em>Fl. Antioquia</em>).

Ursprung, Alfred (1876-1952), Swiss botanist; Dr. phil. Basel 1900; in Berlin with
Schwendener 1900-1902; assistant at the University of Fribourg (Switzerland) 1902-
1903, extraordinary professor of botany ib. 1903, regular professor 1907. (<em>Ursprung</em>).

Usteri, Alfred (1869-?), Swiss botanist and horticulturist in Zürich and Dornach
(Reinach); in the Philippines 1903-1904; Dr. phil. Basel 1905; sometime (ca. 1906)
professor at the São Paulo Polytechnic; author of a number of anthropological publicat-
ions; ultimately at Reinach nr. Basel. (<em>A. Usteri</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: material in B (mainly destr.), BR, C, DPU, K, M, NY, PH, SP,
W (Melastom.), Z (see also SK 1: 536). <em>Letters</em> at FH, G.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Backer p. 606; Barnhart 3: 418; BL 1: 243, 322; Biol.-
Dokum. 18: 9499; BM 5: 2185; CSP 19: 272; Hortus 3: 1206; IF suppl. 2: 39; IH 2:
(files); Langman p. 754; LS 27574; MW p. 509; Plesch p. 445; Rehder 5: 871; SK 1:
536, 8: xcix; Tucker 1: 712, 2: xxxviii, 3: 319 (no. 1); Urban-Berl. p. 406.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Brit. Mus. gen. cat. print. books 245: 421. 1964; Cat. gén. livr. impr.
	Bibl. natl. Paris, Auteurs 197: 810. 1967.
Frodin, D.G., Guide standard floras world no. 366. 1984.
Quisumbing, E., Philipp. geogr. J. 8: 35. 1964.
<em>Note</em>: In his later years the author published several papers on the relationship between
	botany (especially plant taxonomy) and anthroposophy. ("Eine höchst gewagte
	Verknüpfung der Pflanzensystematik mit dem Planetensystem und der mystischen
	Siebenzahl" ÖbZ 1 Mai 1923) such as <em>Versuch eines System der Phanerogamen im Einklang
	anthroposophischer Weltanschauung</em>, Stuttgart 1922, 63 p., <em>Versuch einer geisteswissenschaftli-
	chen Einführung in die Botanik</em>, Zürich 1923, 69 p., <em>Die Familien der Blütenpflanzen nach
	geisteswissenschaftlichen Gesichtspunkten geordnet</em>".

15.709. <em>Führer durch die Quaianlagen in Zürich</em> ... Zürich (Verlag und Druck von Meyer &amp;
Hendess) 1898. Oct. (<em>Führer Quaianl. Zürich</em>).

<em>Preface</em> and some contributions by: C. Schröter, appendices by E. Künzli and A.
	Badoux.
<em>Publ</em>.: 1898, p. [1]-131, 2 maps. <em>Copy</em>: G.
