Usteri, Paul (1768-1831), Swiss journalist, politician, physician and botanist; Dr. med.
Göttingen 1788; founder with J.J. Roemer of the first German-language botanical jour-
nal 1787; teacher at the Zürich medical institute 1789-1798; after the French revolution
heavily engaged in Swiss politics, president of the Helvetian legislative council of 1801,
in various public functions at Zürich, ultimately as burgomaster, from 1808-1831.
(<em>Usteri</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Usteri described few, if any, new taxa. He was an amateur with
wide interests and promoted botany through the publication of the results of others. No
herbarium is known to have been made by him.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: ADB 39: 399-408 (W. Oechsli); AG 3: 234; Backer p.
606; Barnhart 3: 418; BM 5: 2185; Bossert p. 412; Dryander 3: 1292; Herder p. 22, 23;
Hortus 3: 1206; LS 10072; Maiwald p. 139; PR 395, 2224, 4549, 6576, 7706, 9647,
10680, ed. 1: 10609-10610 and p. 544; Rehder 1: 263; TL-1/1098, 1299, 1345-2346; TL-
2/1442, 1645, 1718, 3468.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Ber. Verh. naturf. Ges. Zürich 1832: 1-54, 105-106 (bibl.) (commem.
	address); Brit. Mus. gen. cat. print. books 245: 423-424. 1964; Cat. gén. livr. impr.
	Bibl. natl. Paris Auteurs 197: 813-817. 1967; Dict. sci. méd., Biogr. méd. 7: 382. 1825;
	Flora 14: 304. 1831 (d.); Neu. nekrol. Deutschen g(1)(1831): 316-318. 1833; Schweiz.
	Lexik. 7: 742. 1984 (b. 14 Feb 1768, d. 9 Apr 1831).
Attinger, V. et al., eds., Dict. hist. biogr. Suisse 6: 786 (no. 19). 1932.
Bossart, P., Schweiz. Ärzte als Naturf. 19. Jahrh. 12: 15-16. 1979 (further biogr. refs.).
Candolle, A.P. de, Mém. souvenirs 294. 1862.
Dihle, H., Sudhoff, Arch. 25: 349-381. 1932.
Guggenbühl, G., Bürgermeister Paul Usteri, 2 vols., Aarau 1924-1931; also: Paul Usteri,
	<em>in</em> Grosse Schweizer (ed. M. Hürlimann), 396, 430-433. s.d.
Hirsch, A., ed, Biogr. Lex. hervorrag. Ärzte ed. 3. 5: 684. 1962.
Locher-Balber, Act. Soc. helvét. Sci. nat. 17: 162-174. 1832 (obit.).
Lowden, R.M., Taxon, Index pers. names vols. 1-30. 753. 1984.
Manitz, K., Wiss. Z. Fr.-Schill. Univ. Jena mat. nat. R. 31(2): 261. 1982 (Ann. Bot. St.
	2).
M-d.j. [Michaud junior], <em>in</em> Michaud, Biogr. univers. 42: 390. 1854ff.
Oechsli, W. &amp; C. Schröter, Paul Usteri, Zürich 1917, 48 p., reprinted from Viertel-
	jahrsschr. naturf. Ges. Zürich 62: 1-48, <em>pl. I.</em> 1917 (Schröter, p. 31-48, U.'s signi-
	ficance for the natural sciences; "Das Leitmotiv ... war das Bestreben die wissen-
	schaftlichen Arbeiten Anderer der Allgemeinheit zugänglich zu machen ..."); Neue
	Zürcher Zeitung 1895 (nos. 312, 317, 324); Neujahrssblatt Zentralbibl. Zürich
	1917(2): 1-59 (corr. U. with nat. scientists and physicians).
Oechsli, W. &amp; C. Schröter, Viertelj.-Schr. naturf. Ges. Zürich 62: 1-48. 1917.
Rübel, E., Gesch. naturf. Ges. Zürich 64. 1947.
Rudio, F., Vierteljahrsschr. naturf. Ges. Zürich 41: 75-78. 1896 (Festschrift naturf. Ges.
	Zürich 1746-1896, part 1).
Schröter, C., Verh. Schweiz. naturf. Ges. 99: 3, 12, 24. 1918.
Stafleu, F.A., <em>in</em> C.L. L'Héritier, Sertum anglicum, facs. ed. 1963, introd. p. xviii-xix;
	Taxon 12: 82. 1963 (on <em>Delectus</em>).
Wittrock, V.B., Acta Horti Berg. 3(2): 153. 1903.

<sm>COMPOSITE WORKS</sm>: (1) With J.J. Roemer editor of <em>Magazin für die Botanik</em> 1787-1791, see
TL-2/9400. – Continued by Usteri as <em>Ann. Bot.</em>, see below.

PAGE: 624
HEADING: USTERI

(2) A.L. Jussieu, <em>Genera plantarum</em>, Zürich edition, 1791, edited, with annotations, by
Usteri, see TL-2/3468.
(3) With J.J. Roemer, editor of an octavo edition of J. Dickson, <em>Fasc. pl. crypt. brit.</em>, 1785-
1790, Zürich TL-2/1442 and composite works (2) sub J.J. Roemer.
(4) Editor, <em>Delectus opusculorum botanicorum</em>, Argentorati [Strasbourg] 1790-1793. Oct. 2
vols. of reprints of papers published by other authors. See TL-1/1345 and D.E. Johnson,
Huntia 6(1): 96. 1985.

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Usteria</em> Cavanilles (1793). The derivation of <em>Usteria</em> Medicus (1790) was not
given and those for <em>Usteria</em> Batista et Maia (1962) or <em>Usteria</em> Willdenow (1790) could not
be determined.

Vaarama, [Otto] Antero (1912-1975), Finnish botanist (bryologist); studied biology
at the University of Helsinki; Dr. phil. ib. 1938; teacher of natural sciences and plant
conservation at the Horticultural College of Lepaa 1939-1945; chief assistant at the
State Horticultural Institution Piikkiö 1945-1955; professor of botany at the University
of Turku 1955-1975; pioneer of bryophyte cytology. (<em>Vaar</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: H, TUR; further material at OXF.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Collander p. 536-538.

Vahl, Jens Laurentius Moestue (1796-1854), Danish botanist, plant collector and
librarian; travelled in Sweden, Germany, Austria and France 1822-1826; in Greenland
with V.A. Graah's expedition 1828-1829; engaged in botanical and meteorological work
ib. 1829-1836; with a French expedition to Spitsbergen 1838-1839; from 1840 connected
with the Botanical Museum, Copenhagen, from 1842-1850 as librarian; Dr. phil.
Rostock 1842; son of M. Vahl. (<em>J. Vahl</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: C; other material at B (extant in B-Willd.), BAF, BM, CAS, F,
FR, GOET, H (bryo., lich.), M, MANCH, PH. – <em>Manuscripts</em> and <em>letters</em>: (see Chris-
tensen 1924, p. 198).

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 419 (b. 27 Nov 1796, d. 12 Nov 1854); BM
5: 2187; Christiansen p. 321 [index]; Kleppa p. 290; KR p. 731; Lasègue see index; PR
2409, 6744, 9648, ed. 1: 2724, 6576, 7601, 8629; Rehder 1: 354; TL-1/933; TL-2/7001,
see E.F. Nolte, J.F. Schouw; Urban-Berl. p. 269, 316, 406.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Bonplandia 6: 340. 1858 (cognomen Leopoldina Vahl pat.); Bot. Not.
	1840: 211, 1842: 211, 1854: 159 (d.), 1855: 160 (d.); Brit. Mus. gen. cat. print. books
	245: 681. 1964; Cat. Gén. livr. impr. Bibl. natl. 198: 143. 1968.
Buchheim, G., Huntia 3(3): 166. 1979 (contr. <em>Fl. dan.</em>).
Christensen, C., Dansk. Bot. hist. 1: 244-245, 311, 313. 1924, 2: 197-198. 1924 (bibl.);
	Dansk biogr. Leks. 25: 3-4. 1943.
Dahl, O., Nyt. Mag. Nat.-vid. Oslo 69: 36-42. 1934.
Fischer-Benzon, R. von, <em>in</em> P. Prahl, Krit. Fl. Schlesw. Holst. 2: 58. 1889.
Jørgensen, C.A. et al., Biol. Skr. Dan. Vid. Selsk. 9(4): 5. 1958 (expl. Greenland).
J.V., Bot. Zeit. 12: 876. 1854 (obit.).
Lind, J., Farmac. Tid. 1915: 29-30 (biogr.).
Rydberg, A., Augustana Library publ. 6: 22. 1907.
Warming, E., Bot. Tisskr. 12: 182-183. 1881 (curr. vit., bibl.).

<sm>COMPOSITE WORKS</sm>: Contributed to G.C. Oeder, <em>Fl. dan.</em> text and supervision of plates in
fasc. 39-42, 1840-1849, co-editor fasc. 40. For details see Buchheim (1979) and TL-
2/7002.

<sm>HANDWRITING</sm>: Christensen, C., Dansk. Bot. Hist. 1: 245. 1924.

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Mostuea</em> Didrichsen (1853); <em>Vahlodea</em> E.M. Fries (1842).

Vahl, Martin (1749-1804), Norwegian-born Danish botanist; studied botany at

PAGE: 629
HEADING: VAHL

Copenhagen under Zoëga 1766-1767; in Norway 1767-1769; studied in Uppsala under
Linnaeus 1769-1774; from 1774 in Copenhagen, associated with the Botanical Garden,
lecturer 1779-1782; travelled in Europe 1783-1785; professor of botany 1786; travelled
in Norway 1786, 1787-1788, in the Netherlands and France 1799-1800; full professor at
Copenhagen University 1801-1804. (<em>Vahl</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: C; acquired by the Danish king in 1805 and given by him to the
Botanical Institute. Vahl's <em>Symbolae botanicae</em> are based on the Forsskål material at C; the
<em>Eclogae</em> in the first instance on the collections (at C) by Julius von Rohr and others. –
Herbarium available on microfiche (IDC 2201). – Other material at B-W (Vahl types
based on J. v. Rohr coll.), BM, CGE, E, FR, G-DC, GOET, H-SOL (bryo.), H-Steven,
LD, M, P, UPS (Thunberg). – <em>Letters</em> at G.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: AG 2(1): 278, 5(2): 32; Backer p. 607; Barnhart 3: 419
(b. 10 Oct 1749, d. 24 Nov 1804); BM 5: 2187; Bossert p. 412; CSP 6: 93-94; Dawson p.

Vahl, Martin [II] (1869-1946), Danish geographer and botanist; cand. theol. 1895;
cand. mag. 1900; teacher at Copenhagen gymnasium 1900-1921; professor of geography
at the University of Copenhagen 1921-1939; visited Madeira 1901-1902 and 1921-1922.
(<em>M. Vahl</em> II).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: C.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 419 (b. 15 Mar 1869); Biol.-Dokum. 18:
9504; BJI 2: 183; BL 1: 90, 322, 2:544, 726; BM 5: 2187; Kleppa p. 68, 238; Tucker 3:
320.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Kraks Blaa Bog 1911-1938; 1969: 144.
Christensen, C., Danske bot. Litt. 1880-1911, p. 231-232. 1913, 1912-1939, p. 105-106.
	1940.
Fox Maule, A., Bot. Tidsskr. 69: 190. 1974.
Hansen, A., Dansk bot. Ark. 21(1): 71. 1963 (d. 11 Jul 1946); Bocagiana 51: 12. 1980
	(Madeira).
Nielsen, N., <em>in</em> Festskr. Københ. Univ. 145-151. 1946 (d. 11 Jul 1946).

<sm>COMPOSITE WORKS</sm>: With E. Warming, q.v., <em>Oecology of plants</em>, Oxford 1909, xi, 422 p.

	B, USDA. – Autoreferat, Bot. Centralbl. 96: 77-78. 25 Jul 1904.

Vail, Anna Murray (1863-1955), American botanist; received private instruction in
Europe, student under N.L. Britton, librarian New York Botanical Garden 1900-1907;
living in Paris 1951. (<em>Vail</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: NY. – Further material in PH. – <em>Manuscripts, field notes</em> and <em>letters</em>
received at NY. Other letters at G.

p. 754; Lenley p. 418-421; PH 567; Rehder 5: 872; TL-2/781, 5163, 5164, see J.K.
Small; Tucker 1: 713, 2: xxxviii, 3: 320.

Vailionis, Liudas (1886-1939), Lithuanian botanist; studied at gymnasia in Lodz and
Krakau (Poland) and at the University of Krakau, graduated 1913; assistant at the
Agricultural Experiment Station Potzk 1913-1914; high school teacher in Poland 1914-
1918; returned to the then independent Lithuania 1919 (still occupied by Polish troops),
in the underground army 1919-1920; lector in botany at the Lithuanian University,
Kaunas 1920, "docent" and in charge of the Institute of plant anatomy and physiology
1922; e.o. professor at botany 1938; died 1939 just before the renewed loss of Lithuanian
independence; mainly active as a phycologist. (<em>Vailionis</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

PAGE: 634
HEADING: VAILIONIS

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 419 (b. 13 Jan 1886, d. 27 Feb 1939);
Bossert p. 413.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Dagys, J., Ber. deut. bot. Ges. 57: (235)-(258). 1940 (obit., potr., bibl.).
VanLandingham, S.L., Catal. Diat. 7: 4235. 1978.
Verdoorn, F., ed., Chron. bot. 2: 227, 393. 1936, 3: 199. 1937, 4: 282. 1939, 6: 238, 431.
	1941.

15.744. <em>Medžiagos žiupsnys</em> Lietuvos dumbli[fix]u augmenijai pažinti ... Atspausdinta iš
gamtos moksl[fix]u ... Kosmos 1930 m. Oct. 

<em>Publ</em>.: 1930, p. [351]-358. <em>Copy</em>: FAS. – Reprinted and to be cited from Kosmos
	(Kaunas) 1930: 351-358. – <em>Phialediscus</em> nov. gen.

Vaillant, Léon [Louis] (1834-1914), French zoologist; M.D. Paris 1861; aggr. hist.
nat. 1863; Dr. sci. 1865, Prix Savigny 1867; lecturer in Montpellier 1867; with the
zoological laboratory of the École des Hautes-Études, Paris 1869; professor of herpe-
tology and ichthyology at the Muséum d'Histoire naturelle, Paris 1874-1910. (<em>L. Vaill.</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Botanical material not known.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 419; BM 5: 2187; De Toni 2: cxvi; DSB 13:
551-553 (D.B. Weiner; biogr., bibl.; b. 11 Nov 1834, d. 27 Nov 1914); GR p. 354; Kelly
p. 231; LS 27598; MW p. 510; NI alph.; PR 9653; Quenstedt p. 439.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Brit. Mus. gen. cat. print, books 245: 703-704. 1915; Cat. gén. livr.
	impr. Bibl. natl. 198: 237-245. 1968; Science ser. 2. 41: 61. 1915 (d.); Grand Larousse
	encycl. 10: 642. 1964; Qui êtes-vous 1908: 472.
Nissen, C., Zool. Buchill. 414. 1969.
Roule, L., Arch. Mus. Hist. nat. ser. 6. 4: 1-14. 1929 (biogr., bibl., portr.).

<sm>NOTE</sm>: (1) Auguste Nicolas Vaillant (1793-1858) ("Commandant Vaillant") was in com-
mand of the voyage of the <em>Bonite</em>, the botanical results of which were published by C.
Gaudichaud-Beaupré, <em>Voy. Bonite, Bot.</em> 1841-1866, see TL-2/1968.
(2) François Le Vaillant (1753-1824), Suriname-born French traveller, naturalist and
painter, mainly interested in ornithology; explorer of South Africa; collected and
painted also several plants, is dealt with in detail by M. Gunn and L.E. Codd, Bot. expl.
S. Afr. 224-226. 1981, and by Forbes, François Le Vaillant, traveller in S. Africa 2 vols.
1973 (see 1: 31-100 and 2: 43-81).

15.745. <em>De la fécondation dans les cryptogames</em>. Thèse présentée au concours d'agrégation
(section d'histoire naturelle) et soutenue à la faculté de médecine de Paris ... Paris (F.
Savy, ...) 1863. Oct. (<em>Fécond. crypt.</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: 1863 (Flora 28 Oct 1863), p. [i-iii], [1]-134, [135, cont.], <em>pl. 1-2</em> (uncol. liths.
	auth.). <em>Copies</em>: B, BR, G, HH, NY, PH.
<em>Commercial issue</em> 1863, p. [1]-134, <em>pl. 1-2. Copies</em>: B, FH. – "De ... cryptogames par Léon
	Vaillant ..." Paris (id.) 1863. Oct.
<em>Ref</em>.: Fournier, É., Bull. Soc. bot. France 10: 233-235. Nov 1863 (rev.).
	Stiz. (Stizenberger), Hedwigia 2(18): 179-180. Nov 1863 (rev.).

Vaillant, Sébastien (1669-1722), French botanist, practicing physician at Évreux
1688; army surgeon 1690, surgeon at Neuilly 1692; studied botany with Tournefort;
secretary to Guy Fagon; curator of the living collections of the Jardin du Roi 1700;
"sous-démonstrateur" 1708; substitute for Antoine de Jussieu in 1716 delivering the
lecture on the stamens as the male organ of the flower. (<em>Vaill</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: P, PC, P-JU. – Other material in BM and BM-Sloane (see
Dandy 1958), FI, OXF. – Left to the Cabinet du Roi; became the basis of the Herbier
général of P in 1793; most plants are from France; other collections were probably
present but cannot be listed because of the dissolution of the herbarium in 1793. –

PAGE: 635
HEADING: VAILLANT

<em>Manuscripts</em> at P; <em>letters</em> to Petiver at BM, to Sherard at Roy. Soc. London; other letters
at G.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: AG 1: 350, 4: 38, 12(1): 214; Ainsworth p. 48, 50, 225,
250, 299, 310, 348; Backer p. 607; Barnhart 3: 419 (b. 26 Mai 1669); Blunt p. 256
[index]; BM 5: 2188; Bossert p. 413; Clokie p. 258; De Toni 1: cxxvi; Dryander 3: 34,
44, 141, 218, 386; DSB 13: 553-554 (P. Jovet, J. Mallet; d. 20 Mai 1722); Futak-Domin
p. 108; GR p. 299, <em>pl</em>. [<em>31</em>]; Hawksworth p. 186; Hegi 4(1): 49, 6(1): 227, 477, 6(1):
1222; Herder p. 85, 124, 176, 425; Hortus 3: 1206; IH 1 (ed. 6): 365, (ed. 7): 344;

<sm>HANDWRITING</sm>: Dandy, J.E., Sloane herb. facs. 82. 1958; see also J. Soc. Bibl. nat. hist. 4:
195. 1963.

<sm>NOTE</sm>: Vaillant, <em>Établissement de nouveaux caractères</em> de trois familles ou classes de plantes à
fleurs composées; Sçavoir, des Cynarocephales, des Corymbifères, et des Cichoracées,
Paris 1718-1721, Mém. Acad. Sci., Paris 1718: 143-191, 1719: 277-318, 1720: 277-339,
1721: 174-224 was translated into German and published (after 1753 sic) in W.B.A. von
Steinwehr, Der kön. Akad. Wiss. Paris Anat. Chym. Bot. Abh. [Breslau] 5: 143-194,
333-388, 545-613, 697-750. 1754, 6: 131-174. 1756 (?). The standing of this republication
of a great many pre-Linnaean names is in this case that of a straightforward republicat-
ion, and not an effective publication under ICBN for which a contemporary author took
responsibility. Vaillant's <em>Remarques sur la méthode de M. Tournefort</em>, Hist. Acad. R. Sci.
1722: 243-264. 1724 was also translated in this German series 6: 175-197. 1756(?).

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Valantia</em> Linnaeus (1753).

15.746. <em>Sermo de structura florum</em>, horum differentia, usuque partium eos constituetium,
habitus in ipsis auspiciis demonstrationis publicae stirpium in Horto Regio Parisino, X°.
Junii 1717. Et constitutio trium novorum generum plantarum, Araliastri, Sherardiae,
Boerhaaviae, cum descriptione duarum plantarum novarum generi postremo inscrip-
tarum, per Sebastianum Vaillant, demonstratorem plantarum Horti Regii Parisiensis ...
Lugduni Batavorum (apud Petrum van der Aa, ...) 1718. Qu. (<em>Sermo struct. fl.</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: 1718, p. [ii-iii], [1]-55, [56, err.]. <em>Copies</em>: B-S, BR, G, M, PH; IDC 7329. – Alter-
	native title on p. [ii]: <em>Discours sur la structure des fleurs</em>, leur difference et l'usage de leurs
	parties; prononcé a l'ouverture du Jardin Royal de Paris, le Xe, jour du mois de juin
	1717 et l'établissement de trois nouveaux genres de plantes ... à Leide (Chez Pierre
	van der Aa ...). – See Rousseau (1970) for biological significance of this treatise.
<em>1727 issue</em>: 1727, p. [ii-iii], [1]-55, [56]. <em>Copy</em>: B-S. – See Guédès (1983).
<em>1728 issue</em>: 1728, p. [ii-iii], p. [1]-55, [56]. <em>Copy</em>: G.
<em>Ref</em>.: Guédès, M., Arch. nat. Hist. 11(2): 195-197. 1983 (on the three issues).
	Ramsbottom, J., J. Soc. Bibl. nat. Hist. 4: 194-196. 1963 (list of corrections of text of
	his Discours; had been printed without his supervision).

15.747. Sebastiani Vaillant, ... <em>Botanicon parisiense</em>. Operis majoris prodituri <em>prodromus</em>.

	son, ... 1743. – Burdet nr. 491.

15.748. <em>Botanicon parisiense</em> ou dénombrement par ordre alphabétique des plantes, qui se
trouvent aux environs de Paris compris dans la carte de la prevoté &amp; de l'élection de la
dite ville par le sieur Danet Gendre année mdccxxii. Avec plusieurs descriptions des
plantes, leurs synonymes, le tems de fleurir &amp; de grainer et une critique des auteurs de
botanique par feu monsieur Sebastien Vaillant, ... enriché de plus de trois cents figures,
dessinées par le sieur Claude Aubriet, peintre du Cabinet du Roy. à Leide [Leiden] &amp; à
Amsterdam (chez Jean &amp; Herman Verbeek et Balthazar Lakeman) 1727. Fol. (<em>Bot.
paris.</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: 1727, p. [i*], portr., [iii], map, [v*-xxxvi*], i-xii, [xiii-xvi], 1-205, [49, indexes,
	expl. pl.], pl. 1-33 (uncol. copp. J. Wandelaar after Aubriet). <em>Copies</em>: B, BR, FH, G,
	HU, MICH, NY, PH, U, USDA; IDC 8323. For an analytical collation see HU
470, with many annotations; for the importance and history of the work see Rousseau
(1970, p. 209-212) and Tjaden (1976). See also Burdet no. 401.
<em>Updated text</em> (Linnaean nomenclature): F.V. Mérat, <em>Rev.fl. paris.</em> 1843 (TL-2/5837); a
	further concordance with modern nomenclature is given by J.N.E. Germain de Saint-
	Pierre, Guide bot. 1852 (TL-2/1998), p. 169-172.

Vainio, Edvard August (until 1877: Lang; until 1919: Wainio) (1853-1929), Finnish

PAGE: 637
HEADING: VAINIO

lichenologist; studied at the University of Helsinki 1870; Dr. phil. ib. 1880; honorary
lecturer for botany ib. 1880; travelled in Europe 1884-1885, 1889-1890, 1898; in W.
Siberia 1880, in Brazil 1885; in various modest functions, mostly as teacher in natural
sciences between 1874 and 1891; censor at the [Russian] press service in Helsinki 1891-
1917; assistant professor and curator of the cryptogamic herbarium of Turku University
1922-1929. (<em>Vain</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: TUR (incl. 34.800 lich.); further important sets in FH (350 type
dupl.) and H; other material in BR (antarct.), C (trop.), JYV, M (N. Eur.), PC (ex
herb. Havaas), STE-VB (S. Afr. types), UPS, ZT. – <em>Lichenes brasilienses exsiccati</em> (circa
600 nos. 1891-1892), BM, FH, K, KIEL, M, PC, TUR, UPS (see Sayre 1969).
<em>Herbarium lichenum Fenniae</em> (orig. ed. J.P. Norrlin), nos. 451-807 curavit E.A. Wainio,
Helsinfors 1921, see under J.P. Norrlin. – <em>Manuscripts</em> and library: Turku Univ. Libr. –
<em>Correspondence</em>: Vainio family, in part Turku Univ. Libr.

<sm>NOTE</sm>: Information for the entry on Vainio was received from P. Isoviita, R. Alava and
T. Ahti.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 419 (b. 5 Aug 1853, d. 14 Mai 1929); BM 5:

p. 135; LS suppl. 28349-28369; Morren ed. 10, p. 97; Rehder 5: 897; Saelan p. 251, 513-
517, 577; SBC p. 134; TL-2/10.227, 10.710, 10.891; Urban-Berl. p. 316.

PAGE: 643
HEADING: VALCKENIER

Sayre, G., Bryologist 80: 519. 1977 (mosses CGE?).

15.786. <em>On the anatomy and development of the sporogonium of mosses</em> ... Extracted from the
Linnean Society's Journal-Botany [1887]. 

<em>Publ</em>.: 12 Mar 1888 (in journal; Nat. Nov. Apr(2) 1888), p. [i, recto of 262], 262-285, <em>pl.
	9-12. Copies</em>: B, NY. – Reprinted and to be cited from J. Linn. Soc, London 24: 262-
	285, <em>pl. 9-12.</em> 1888.

Valckenier Suringar, Jan (1864-1932), Dutch botanist (plant systematist, dendrolo-
gist, nomenclaturist); son of W.F.R. Suringar; Dr. phil. Leiden 1898; unofficial
caretaker-director of the Leiden Rijksherbarum 1896-1899; teacher at the State agricul-
tural, horticultural and forestry school at Wageningen 1899; from 1900 also director of
the Wageningen botanical garden; from 1918, with the foundation of the Agricultural
University (Landbouwhogeschool) at Wageningen, professor of dendrology until 1924;
in retirement still actively publishing on dendrology and botanical nomenclature.
(<em>Valck.-Suring.</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: WAG. – A large collection of herbarium material, containing
e.g. collections by Bourdeau (Spain) and Kotschy (Mediterranean) was offered for sale
by V. in AbZ 8, Mai 1902.

<sm>NOTE</sm>: Baptized Suringar, added his mother's surname to his father's name early in life
thus accepting "Valckenier Suringar" as his surname. All publications appeared under
the name Valckenier Suringar. Often cited under Suringar, but this is contrary to his
own wishes as well as to the legal status of his name. – The spelling Valkenier Suringar is
incorrect.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 420 (b. 24 Dec 1864, d. 17 Oct 1932); Biol.-
Dokum. 18: 9505-9506; BM 5: 2050; BJI 2: 174; BM 5: 2050; Bossert p. 413; CSP 18:
1038 (Suringar); Hirsch p. 308; Hortus 3: 1205 ("Suring."); JW 1: 449, 452, 2: 202, 3:
373, 4: 411-412, 5: 254; MW p. 510; SK 4: cxxix; SO 575b, 1506a, 2959; Tucker 1: 714,
3: 320; Zander ed. 10, p. 722, ed. 11, p. 824.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Hedwigia 73: (83)-(84). 1933 (d.); Wie is dat? ed. I. 263-264. 1931, ed.
	2. 317. 1932.
Höfker, H., Mitt. deut. dendrol. Ges. 45: xxv-xxvi. 1933 (obit.).
Hummelinck, P. ("P.H."), Succulenta 14(12): 290-292. 1932 (obit., portr., list of
	Melocactus publ.).
Jeswiet, J. et al., Gedenkboek J. Valckenier Suringar 24 December 1864-17 October
	1932. Wageningen (Gedrukt door H. Veenman &amp; Zonen) 1942, 272 p., 36 pl. (biogr.
	notes; description of herb., nomenclatural activities, etc.; no bibl. (except of Melocac-
	tus publ.)).
Lütjeharms, W.J., Gesch. Mykol. 33ff, 231. 1936.
Renkema, H.W., Jaarb. Nederl. dendrol. Vereen. 10: 23-32. 1934 (obit., bibl.).
Urban, I., Symb. ant. 5: 12. 1904.
Valckenier Suringar, J., Nieuwe theologische studies 10(6): 161-170. Jun 1927 (Lin-
	naeus' beschouwing der natuur en van het doel der [van den] mensch; deals with L.'s
	ideas about man).
Veendorp, H. &amp; L.G.M. Baas-Becking, Hort. acad. lugd.-bot. 167, 168, 171. 1938.
Verdoorn, F., ed., Chron. bot. 1: 221, 22. 1935, 2: 232. 1936.

<sm>COMPOSITE WORKS</sm>: (1) Parts 2 and 3 of W.F.R. Suringar, <em>Ill. Melocactus</em>, 1903-1905; see
under W.F.R. Suringar.
(2) <em>De planten in het zandverstuivingsterrein bij Kootwijk</em> en hunne groeiwijze, <em>in</em> P. Tesch et
al., <em>De zandverstuivingen bij Kootwijk</em> in woord en beeld, p. 40-70. Utrecht 1926.
(3) <em>Cyperaceae, in</em> Nova Guinea 8 (Bot.)(4): 695-713 [714 err.], <em>pl. 113-118.</em> 1912.

<sm>MEMORIAL VOLUME</sm>: Gedenkboek J. Valckenier Suringar 24 December 1864-17 October
1932, H. Veenman &amp; Zonen, Wageningen. 1942, 272 p. Contains e.g. autobiographical
notes and notes on his herbarium by J.G.B. Beumée and several tributes to his work as a

PAGE: 644
HEADING: VALCKENIER

dendrologist (H. Höfker) and nomenclaturist (P. den Ouden) and notes on his last work
by J. Jeswiet.

15.795. <em>Het Arboretum</em> der Rijks Hoogere Land,- Tuin- en Boschbouwschool <em>te Wageningen</em>
(thans Landbouwhogeschool). Kort overzicht van het wezen en de geschiedenis der
dendrologie, van de literatuur en de herkomst onzer houtgewassen, en van de gesch-
iedenis der nomenclatuur; gevolgd door een lijst van de in het Rijks Arboretum voorko-
mende houtgewassen, met hunne benamingen volgens de in 1905 herziene wetten der
botanische nomenclatuur, met de voornaamste synoniemen, de geografische verspreid-
ing, en verdere gegevens, ... Wageningen (H. Veenman) 1910. Oct. (<em>Arbor. Wageningen</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: 1910, cover-t.p., frontisp., p. [119]-212, [213], <em>2 pl. Copies</em>: HH, U. – Preprint or
	reprint from Meded. Rijks Hoogere L.-, T.- en B.-bouwschool 3, 1910. – Contains a
	concise history of dendrology, plant introductions and nomenclature.

15.815. <em>De internationale nomenclatuurcongressen</em> in Augustus 1930. Overzicht der voorstellen
en besluiten. Overdruk uit het Jaarboek 1930 der Nederlandsche Dendrologische

	Jaarb. Ned. Dendrol. Ver. 1930: 44-76. – Important informal account of the pro-

	formation not apparent from the official documents. Account of Briquet's policy and
	tactics. Continuation in <em>Nomenclatuur</em> 1931, see below.

Valente, Antonio (<em>fl</em>. 1803), Italian physician and botanist in Rome. (<em>Valente</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: BM 5: 2189; Jackson p. 437; LS 27602; PR 9659, ed. 1:
10624; Rehder 1: 61; Saccardo 1: 168; SO 783a.

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Valentiana</em> Rafinesque (1814) honors George Annesley, 2nd Earl of Mountnor-
ris, Viscount Valentia (1769-1844), English botanist and traveller to India and the
Middle East.

15.821. <em>Recensio plantarum</em> villa atque <em>horto</em> praesertim botanico <em>Francisci Caetani</em> ...
Romae (Typis Caetani ...) 1803. Oct. (<em>Recens. pl. hort. Caetani</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: 1803, p. [i-iv], portr., v-xviii, [xix], 1-167, [168, colo.]. <em>copies</em>: B-S, G.

Valenti-Serini, Francesco (1795-1872), Italian physician and botanist, practicing at
Siena. (<em>Valenti</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: SIAC. – According to Tassi (1905) Valenti deposited his collect-
ions with the Accademia dei Fisiocritici in Siena; other material was given to the
Accademia di Medicina di Torino and to the municipality of Siena.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: BM 5: 2189; Jackson p. 316; Kelly p. 231; LS 27603; NI
2034; PR 9660; Saccardo 1: 168.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Tassi, Fl., Bull. Lab. Orto bot. 7: 6, 31, 44. 1905.

15.822. <em>Dei funghi sospetti e velenosi del territorio senese</em> ... Torino (Litografia Giordana e
Salussolia) 1868. Qu. (<em>Fung. sosp. velen. senese</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: 1868 (Flora 30 Sep 1868), p. [i]-xx, 1-35, <em>pl. 1-56</em> (col. liths.). <em>Copies</em>: FH,
	Stevenson.
<em>Ref</em>.: Anon., J. Bot. 7: 207-211. Jul 1869 (rev.).

Valet, [August] Friedrich (1811-1889), German (Swabian) pharmacist and botanist;
studied pharmacy in the Gmelin pharmacy in Ulm (Langenau), pharm. state exam.
Tübingen 1837; in charge of several Swabian pharmacies; ultimately owner of the
Schussenried pharmacy 1845-1876. (<em>Valet</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: TUB and HOH; further material in E.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: BM 5: 2190; PR 9667, ed. 1: 10637; Quenstedt p. 440.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Fraas, O., Jahresb. Ver. vaterl. Naturk. Württemberg 46: 29-31. 1890 (obit.).
Hein, W.H. &amp; M.D. Schwarz 2: 704. 1978 (curr. vit., biogr. refs., b. 23 Oct 1811, d. 26
	Sep 1889).
Künkele, S., Jahresh. Ges. Nat. Württemberg 125: 151, 152. 1970.
Lehmann, E., Schwäbische Apotheker 38, 51-52, 82-84, 95, 96, 97, 102, 131-132, 138.
	1951.
Martens, G. von &amp; C.A. Kemmler, Fl. Württemb. ed. 2. 782. 1865.

PAGE: 649
HEADING: VALETON

15.823. <em>Uebersicht der in der Umgegend von Ulm wildwachsenden phanerogamischen Pflanzen</em>,
nebst Angabe der Standorte und Blüthezeit ... Ulm (Druck und Verlag von Ernst
Nübling) 1847. Oct. (<em>Übers. Ulm phan. Pfl.</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: 1-15 Dec 1847 (Hinrichs 15-18 Dec 1847), p. [1]-111. <em>Copies</em>: B-S, M.

Valeton, Theodoric (1855-1929), Dutch botanist educated at the University of Gron-
ingen; assistant at the botanical laboratory circa 1879-1885; Dr. phil. 1886; high school
teacher at Groningen 1885-1889; bacteriologist at the Java Sugar Experiment Station,
Pasuruan, E.Java 1889-1892, working on the Sereh disease of Sugar-cane; from 1892-
1913 scientist at the Buitenzorg Botanic Garden, ultimately as head of the herbarium; in
retirement in Holland from 1913 but again in Buitenzorg 1915-1919 to study the Zin-
giberaceae, and from 1919 in the Netherlands working at the Leiden Rijksherbarium.
(<em>Val</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: BO; further material in B (mainly destr.), P, U. – <em>Letters</em> at G.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Biol.-Dokum. 18: 9509; BJI 2: 183; BL 1: 112, 121, 322;
BM 2: 1016, 5: 2190; CSP 19: 281; Hirsch p. 308; Hortus 3: 1206; IH 2: 379; JW 2: 202,
3: 373; LS suppl. 28372; Morren ed. 10, p. 90; MW p. 510; Rehder 5: 873; SK 1: 537
(curr. vit., coll.), 5: xxviii, ccc, 8: xcix; TL-2/595, 3862, 3867, 6216, see Joh. Jac. Smith;
Tucker 1: 713; Urban-Berl. p. 406; Zander ed. 10, p. 726, ed. 11, p. 829.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Allg. bot. Z. 19: 96. 1913 (retired early June as head of the Buitenzorg
	herbarium; address in Apeldoorn).
Frodin, D.G., Guide standard floras world no. 918. 1984.
Lowden, R.M., Taxon, Index pers. names vols. 1-30. 735.
Sirks, M.J., Indisch natuuronderzoek 208, 212. 1915.
Smith, J.J., Bull. Jard. bot. Buitenzorg ser. 3. 11: 1-11, <em>pl. I.</em> 1930 (obit., portr., bibl.).

<sm>COMPOSITE WORKS</sm>: (1) Co-author, for the botanical text, of S.H. Koorders, <em>Bijdr. boom-
soort. Java</em>, see TL-2/3862; the <em>Atlas Baumart. Java</em> (TL-2/3867), illustrating the <em>Bijdragen</em>,
was edited by Koorders. See also J.W. Moll, <em>Mikrogr. Holz.</em> 1906-1936, TL-2/6216.
(2) <em>Balanophoraceae, in</em> C.E.A. Wichmann, ed., Nova Guinea 8(5): 919-921, <em>pl. 161.</em> Dec
1913.
(3) <em>Zingiberaceae, in</em> id. 8(5): 923-988, <em>pl. 162-179.</em> Dec 1913.
(4) <em>Rubiaceae, in</em> id. 8(3): 437-5129) <em>pl. 71-74.</em> 1911, 8(4): 755-775, <em>pl. 125-129.</em> 1912
(printed Mar 1912)(Nachträge, printed Mar 1912); 14(2): 229-274, <em>pl. 20-30.</em> Dec 1925
(Neue Nachträge; printed Dec 1925; preprint publ. Dec 1925; Vakbl. Biol. noted Jul
1926).
(5) For a list of the treatments in <em>Icones bogorienses</em> see the bibliography by J.J. Smith
(1930).
(6) <em>Rubiaceae, in</em> H. Winkler, <em>Beiträge zur Flora und Pflanzengeographie von Borneo</em>, Bot.
Jahrb. 44: 542-571. 1910, id. II, 48: 110-117. 1912.
(7) <em>Rubiaceae, in</em> L.S. Gibbs, <em>A contribution to the phyto geography and flora of the Arfak
Mountains</em> 180-182, 220-221. 1917.
(8) <em>Zingiberaceae, in</em> E.D. Merrill, An interpretation of Rumphius's <em>Herbarium amboinense</em>
151-165. 1917.
(9) <em>Die Rubiaceae von Papuasien, Cinchonoideae, in</em> Lauterbach, <em>Beiträge zur Flora von
Papuasien</em>, Bot. Jahrb. 60: 1-104, 1926, id. <em>Coffeideae, in</em> id. 61: 31-163. 1927.

<sm>NOTE</sm>: Théodore Valeton Jr., (1881-1961/1962), Dr. phil. Amsterdam 1907, wrote a
thesis <em>Bijdrage tot de kennis van de kieming der rijst</em>, Amsterdam (J.H. de Bussy) 1907 (p. [i-
vii], [1]-88, theses [1-3, loose], <em>copies</em>: B, U), went to Java in 1908 and was director of the
Buitenzorg School of Agriculture 1924-1934; in retirement in the Netherlands (SK 1:
517, 8: xcix). Theodoric V., occasionally referred to himself in print as "Th. Valeton
sen." or "Sr."

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Valetonia</em> T. Durand (1888); <em>Valetoniella</em> F. von Höhnel (1909).

Islands-born British botanical artist; married Rupert Vallentin 23 Mar 1904; to

founder and first director of the Observatoire du Mont-Blanc, Chamonix; also active in
the Société botanique de France. (<em>Vallot</em>).

question dans les catalogues et les flores de cette province, p. [1]-51 (<em>copy</em>: NY), re-
printed from C.R. Acad. Dijon 1827: 112-160, which has some floristic notes and a
superficial account of the history of botany of Bourgogne.

Valmont de Bomare, Jacques Christophe (1731-1807), French naturalist and
mineralogist, popularizer of natural history; lectured at the Jardin des Plantes 1756-
1788; head of the cabinet of physics and natural history of the Prince de Condé at
Chantilly 1769; professor of natural history at the École centrale, Rue Saint-Antoine,
Paris 1796-1806; assistant headmaster Lycée Charlemagne 1806-1807. (<em>Valmont</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

1907); BM 5: 2192; DSB 13: 565-566 (J.G. Burke); Herder p. 89; PR ed. 1: 10649;
Tucker 3: 321.

	biogr. Acad. Sci. Paris 504. 1954.

Poggendorff, J.C., Biogr.-Lit. Handw.-Buch 2: 1169-1170. 1863.

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Bomarea</em> Mirbel (1802).

15.850. <em>Dictionnaire raisonné universel d'histoire naturelle</em>: contenant l'histoire des animaux,

Van Bambeke, Charles Eugène Marie (1829-1918), Belgian physician and botanist;
Dr. med. Univ. Gent 1857; practicing physician in Gent 1857, also physician for the
poor 1857-1863 and surgeon at various hospitals until 1880; assistant for comparative
anatomy at the University, e.o. professor 1871-1876; regular professor at the Faculty of
medicine 1876-1899, especially interested in mycology from ca. 1880-1918. (<em>Van
Bambeke</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown. – <em>Letters</em> at G.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 421 (b. 6 Feb 1829, d. 14 Mai 1918); Bossert
p. 414; CSP 7: 83, 12: 46, 13: 272-273 (Bambeeke); LS 1630-1652; TL-2/11.173.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Cat. gén. livr. impr. Bibl. natl., Auteurs 200: 95-97. 1971; Bibl. natl.,
	Dict. Écriv. belg. 1830-1880, 4: 10-11. 1910 (bibl.); Nat. Biogr. bibl. Acad. R. Sci.
	Belg. ed. 4. 129-135. 1897, ed. 5: 864-871. 1909.
C.V., Bull. Soc. Méd. Gand 1899 [8 p., reprint] (tributes 70th birthday).
Hirsch, A. et al., Biogr. Lex. hervorrag. Ärzte ed. 3. 5. 700. 1962.
Leboucq, H., Bibl. natl. Belg. [p. 137-144]; Univ. Gand, Ch. Van Bambeke, Gand 1921,
	17 p..

<sm>COMPOSITE WORKS</sm>: Co-author, C. Schröter et al., <em>Prop. lois. nom. bot.</em> 1904, TL-2/11.173.

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Bambekea</em> Cogniaux (1916).

Van Bastelaer, Désiré Alexandre [Henri] (1823-1907), Belgian botanist, pharma-
cist, archeologist and author on folklore; Dr. sci. nat. 1847; pharmacist at Charleroi
1847-1878, from 1883 in Bruxelles. (<em>Van Bastelaer</em>).

Vandamme, Henri (1803-?), French pharmacist and botanist at Hazebrouck in N.W.
France. (<em>Vandamme</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

HEADING: VANDAS

15.862. <em>Flore de l'arrondissement d'Hazebrouck</em> (Département du Nord). Ouvrage contenant
les notions élémentaires sur les organes des végétaux, les noms latins, français et flam-
ands, avec la description des caractères, le lieu propre, le temps de la floraison et
l'indication des vertus de toutes les plantes qui croissent naturellement dans le pays ou
que l'on y cultive communément, pour l'usage de la médecine et de l'économie domest-
ique. Travail disposé selon le système de Linné, avec la concordance des familles
naturelles de Jussieu ... à Paris (Chez J.-B. Baillière, ...) à Lille (chez Béghin, ...), à
Douai (chez la veuve Le Male, ...) à Hazebrouck (chez l'auteur) 1850. Oct. (in 4-s). (<em>Fl. Hazebrouck</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: 1850, p. [i]-viii, [3]-202. <em>Copies</em>: BR, G, HH, NY.
<em>Appendice</em>: 1854 (BSbF after 23 Jul 1854; p. 206: 1 Aug 1853), p. [203]-267. <em>Copies</em>: HH,
	MO. – Paris (J.-B. Baillière, ... Labé, ...) Hazebrouck (l'Auteur, ...) 1854. Oct.
<em>Ed. 4</em>: 1864 (n.v.).

Vandas, Karel (1861-1923), Bohemian botanist; assistant with Celakovsky at the Nat-
ional Museum, Praha; high school teacher at Praha 1892, id. at Kolin 1894; professor
for the encyclopaedia of agriculture and forestry at the Czech Technical School, Brünn
1902; rector of this school 1913; travelled and collected on the Balkan peninsula; died in
Serbian Macedonia 1923. (<em>Vandas</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: PR (Balkan herb.), BRNU; further material in BP, BRNM, GB,
K, PL, W. – <em>Lettes</em> to Halácsy at UPS-UB.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: AG 6(2): 792; Backer p. 663; Barnhart 3: 477 (b. 21 Oct
1861, d. 15 Sep 1923); Biol.-Dokum. 9512; BJI 1: 60; BM 5: 2192; CSP 19: 286; Hortus
3: 1200; IH 1 (ed. 6): 365, (ed. 7): 345; Klásterský p. 192 (curr. vit.); Rehder 1: 448,
450; Tucker 1: 715; Zander ed. 10, p. 727, ed. 11, p. 829.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Allg. bot. Z. 18: 208. 1902 (app. Brünn); Bot. Centralbl. 59: 320. 1894
	(prof. Gymn. Kolin); Hedwigia 53: (170). 1913 (rector Techn. College Brünn), 56:
	(80). 1915 (prisoner of war Montenegro; free again); Österr. bot. Z. 42: 295. 1892

15.867. <em>Reliquiae Formánekianae</em>. Enumeratio critica plantarum vascularium, quas
itineribus in Haemo peninsula et Asia minore (Bithynia) factis collegit Dr. Ed. [Eduard]
Formánek [x-1900], professor Gymnasii brunensis bohemici ... Brunae [Brno] (typis

	sp. nov. 9: 524-534. 1911.

Vandelli, Domingo [Domenico] (1735-1816), Italian physician and botanist; Dr. phil.
Univ. Padua; to Portugal 1764 or 1765; founded the Ajuda botanical garden in Lisboa
1766-1768; professor of chemistry and natural history at the University of Coimbra;
founder and first director of the Coimbra botanical garden (1773-1791), later in similar
functions in Lisboa; during the French occupation of Portugal in exile 1810-1815, part
of the time in London. (<em>Vand</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Said to be at the <em>École polytechnique de Lisbonne</em> by Alph. de
Candolle (now LISU). Some Vandelli specimens are at LINN and P. – <em>Letters</em> at BM, G.
	– The Banks corrspondence does not reveal an exchange of specimens.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Backer p. 608-609; Barnhart 3: 422 (b. 8 Jul 1735, d. 27
Jun 1816); BM 5: 2192; Colmeiro 1: cciii; CSP 6: 108; Dawson p. 841-842; De Toni 1:
cxxvi; Dryander 3: 82, 94, 146, 190, 262, 430, 590; Hegi 4(2): 586; Herder p. 29, 68,
177. 283; Hortus 3: 1206; KR p. 732; Langman p. 474, 505; Lasègue p. 474, 505; LS
27614-27615, 40.203; PR 3602, 9678-9683, ed. 1: 3913, 10651-10656; Quenstedt p. 440;
Rehder 5: 874; RS p. 146; Saccardo 1: 169, 2: 111; SO 34, 725, 731a, 2465-2467, 2878;
TL-1/1351-1352; TL-2/2285; Tucker 1: 715, 3: 321; Zander ed. 10, p. 727, ed. 11, p.
829.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon. Brit. Mus. gen. cat. print, books 246: 274-275. 1964; Cat. gén. livr. impr.
	Bibl. natl. 200: 529. 1971; Enc. Dic. Int., Rio de Janeiro. New York 20: 11808. 1933
	[?]; Grande encicl. portug. brasil. 34: 109-110. 1945.

	Atti Mem. Accad. Padova 16: 71-85. 1900 (influence on teaching at Padua; b. 8 Jul
	1735; biogr. sketch), see also Bot. Centralbl. 88: 257-258. 1901.
Verdoorn, F., ed., Chron. bot. 1: 15. 1935.

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Vandellia</em> P. Browne ex Linnaeus (1767) probably commemorates Vandelli,

Vandendries, René François Prosper (1874-1952); studied natural sciences at the
University of Louvain (Leuven); Dr. sci. nat. ib. 1897, student of J.B. Carnoy; high
school teacher at the Athenaeum of Chimay, later idem at the Royal Athenaeum
Antwerp, ultimately at a Lyceum for girls in Brussels; at the same time continuing his
work at the Laboratory of Cytology at Louvain; from 1939 in retirement and "Inspec-
teur honoraire" of the school system; in Portugal 1950. (<em>Vandendries</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: BR. – <em>Letters</em> at G.

suppl. 28403-28421.

Van der Byl [Bijl], Paul Andries (1888-1939), South African botanist (mycologist,
phytopathologist); M.A. Victoria College Stellenbosch 1913; Dr. Sci. Cape Town 1915;
teacher in Bethlehem O.F.S.; with the Division of Plant Pathology, Pretoria from ca.
1915-1918; in charge of the Botanic Station and National Herbarium, Durban 1918-
1921; professor of phytopathology at the Agricultural Faculty of Stellenbosch University
1921-1928; principal of the Stellenbosch-Elsenburg Agricultural College 1928-1939.
(<em>Van der Byl</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: STEU (formerly STE-VB; separate unit in STEU) (fungi and
lichens). – Other material in K.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: BJI 2: 24; GR p. 798; IH 1 (ed. 7): 274 (herb. at
STEU).

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Bull. misc. Inf. Kew 1921: 253 (app. Stellenbosch).
Bullock, A.A., Bibl. S. Afr. bot. 120. 1978.
Doidge, E., Bothalia 5: 1023-1025. 1950 (bibl.).
Gunn, M. &amp; L.E. Codd, Bot. Expl. S. Africa 354-355. 1981 (b. 25 Mai 1888, d. 25 Jul
	1939).
Lloyd, C.G., Mycol. notes 74: 1333. 1925.
Louw, A.J., Dict. S. Afr. Biogr. 2: 770. 1972.

<sm>NOTE</sm>: Van der Byl stems from a family which spelled its name Van der Bijl; he himself,
however, used the anglicised spelling Van der Byl at least from 1923 onward on all his
publications.

Van Dersal, William Richard (1907-x), American botanist and conservationist; B.A.
Reed Coll. Portland Ore., 1929; MS Univ. Pittsburgh 1931, ib. Dr. phil. 1936; graduate
assistant in botany Pittsburgh 1929-1934; with the U.S. Soil Conservation Service as
forester 1938, biologist 1936-1942, principal admin, officer from 1942-1948; chief operat-
ions Pacific 1948-1953, administrator for management 1954-1972, consultant 1972-1974;
dean Management College, Nat. grad. Univ. from 1974. (<em>Van Dersal</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Some material at CM, PENN.

Vanderyst, Hyacinthe Julien Robert (1860-1934), Belgian agronomical engineer,
botanist and missionary; studied agronomy at Louvain [Leuven] 1883-1885; agronomist
with the ministry of agriculture 1884, state agronomist 1885-1890; secular missionary in
the Belgian Congo 1890-1891 setting up a missionary post at Banane; assistant inspector
for agriculture in the Belgian department of agriculture 1893, from 1898-1902 inspector;
studied theology in Rome 1902-1906, ordained at Louvain as a Missionary of Scheut
(Congr. Immac. Cord. Mariae); in Congo 1906-1909 as auxiliary priest with Jesuit
missionaries at Kisantu; further similar stays in Congo 1909-1912, 1913-1919, 1920-1923
and 1924-1928 combining his scientific studies and collecting with his missionary work.
(<em>Vanderyst</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: BR, K. – Further material at B (mainly destr.), K.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: BJI 2: 183; Kelly p. 232; LS 27617-27626, 40207, suppl.
28445; Urban-Berl. p. 283.

De Wildeman, E., Inst. R. Colon. belg., Bull. Séanc. 6(1): 27-46. 1935 (obit., bibl.).
Verdoorn, F., ed., Chron. bot. 2: 81. 1936.

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Vanderystia</em> De Wildeman (1926); <em>Vanderystiella</em> P. Hennings (1908).

Van Eseltine, Glen Parker (1888-1938), American botanist; AB Syracuse 1913, Aid,
U.S. Natl. Herb. 1913-1915; assistant Office for seed and plant introduction USDA
1915-1919, assistant botanist 1919-1922; teacher North High School, Syracuse 1922-
1926; associate horticulturist N.Y. Experiment Station, Geneva 1927. (<em>Van Eselt</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: SYR (but see IH ed. 7, p. 279) and US. – <em>Letters</em> at G.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 423 (b. 21 Oct 1888); BM 8: 1356; Bossert p.
414; Hortus 3: 1206; Langman p. 758; MW p. 510; Tucker 3: 321; Zander ed. 10, p.
727, ed. 11, p. 829.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Amer. men sci. ed. 3: 702. 1921, ed. 4: 1008. 1927, ed. 5: 1144. 1933, ed.
	6: 1459. 1938; Index Amer. bot. lit. 1886-1966. 4: 414. 1969.
Verdoorn, F., ed., Chron. bot. 3: 303. 1937, 4: 452, 571. 1938, 5: 98, 514. 1939.

15.899. <em>The allies of Selaginella rupestris</em> in the Southeastern United States ... Washington
(Government Printing Office) 1918. Oct. 

<em>Publ</em>.: 14 Oct 1918, p. [i]-v, 159-172, <em>pl. 13-21</em>, vii. <em>Copies</em>: B-S, G, NY, U, US. – Issued
	and to be cited as Contr. U.S. Natl. Herb. 20(5): [i]-v, 159-172, <em>pl. 15-21</em>, vii. 1918.

15.900. <em>A preliminary study of the Unicorn plants</em> (Martyniaceae) ... Geneva (N.Y.) (pub-
lished by the [N.Y. State agr. Exp.] Station ...) 1929. Oct. 

<em>Publ</em>.: Mar 1929, p. [1]-41. <em>Copies</em>: G, HH, NY, US. – Issued as Techn. Bull. no. 149,
	N.Y. State agr. Exp. Sta.

15.901. <em>The taxonomic status of the cultivated apple</em> ... [Reprinted from the Proceedings of
the American Society for Horticultural Science, 1930]. Oct. 

<em>Publ</em>.: 1930, p. [i, recto of 430], 430-434. <em>Copies</em>: G, US. – Reprinted and to be cited from
	Proc. Amer. Soc. hort. Soc. 1930: 430-434.

15.902. <em>Variation in</em> the Lima bean, <em>Phaseolus lunatus</em> L., as illustrated by its synonymy ...
Geneva N.Y. (published by the [N.Y. State Agric. Exp.] Station ...) 1931. Oct.

	Station.

<em>Publ</em>.: Feb 1933, p. [1]-22. <em>Copy</em>: US. – Issued as Techn. Bull. N.Y. State Agr. Expt. Sta.
	208. 1933.

Van Geel, Pierre Corneille (1796-1836), Belgian clergyman, botanist and polemical
publicist; ordained 1815; with Drapiez founder of a "horticultural establishment" at
Bruxelles [later Jardin botanique de l'État, Jardin national de botanique de Belgique];
later residing in The Hague and Paris.

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 423 (b. 8 Oct 1796, d. Mar 1838); BM 2:

PAGE: 665
HEADING: VAN HAESENDONCK

647; GF p. 57, 79, 85; Jackson p. 116; Langman p. 312; MW suppl. p. 74; NI 2386
(alph., see Sertum botanicum); PR 10566.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Bibl. natl. Dict. écriv. belg. 4: 148. 1910; Cat. gén. livr. impr. Bibl. natl.
	756. 1971.
Coninckx, H., <em>in</em> Biogr. natl. Acad. r. Belg. 26: 407-409. 1938 (refers the Sertum to
	Drapiez).
Crépin, F., Guide bot. belg. 481. 1878.

15.904. <em>Sertum botanicum</em>. Collection choisie de plantes remarquables par leur utilité, leur
élégance, leur éclat ou leur nouveauté; consistant en six cents planches ... accompagnées
d'un texte particulier pour chaque plante (encyclographie du règne végétal) ... par une
société de botanistes et dirigée par P.C. van Geel. Bruxelles [1827-] 1828-1832 [-1836], 4
vols. Fol. (<em>Sert. bot.</em>).

<em>Authorship</em>: Van Geel was certainly the editor and possibly the author of the <em>Sertum</em>. H.
	Coninckx (1938) suggests that Pierre Auguste Joseph Drapiez (1778-1856) may have
	been responsible for the text.
<em>Publ</em>.: 1827-1836 probably in 100 livraisons of 6 plates each. Fasc. 1 and 2 were pub-
	lished in Apr 1827 (Rev. Bibl. Pays Bas 6: 139). The six hundred (or 594?) plates are
	unnumbered hand-coloured lithographs by G. Severeyns, who also supplied the one
	uncoloured plate. T.T. Barnard (in lit. 28 Oct 1972) informs us that he consulted the
	copies at BM, K and LINN; in each copy the plates are in a different order (K:
	Linnaean system; BM alphabetic by genera, LINN taxonomically). The prospectus
	issued by the publisher (copies BR, G, K) states that the fascicles will consist of 6
	plates and 3-4 sheets of text, 600 plates to be published in 3 years. We saw additional
	copies at BR and G. – A number of new taxa was described in this work and their
	dating poses a problem (see e.g. T.T. Barnard, J.S. Afr. Bot. suppl. 10: 46). – Many
	plates are probably pirated (Blunt, GF), the text, however, contains original
	elements.
<em>Reissue</em>: <em>Flore des Serres et Jardins de Paris</em>, Paris 1834; see NI 2255.
<em>Note</em>: The text of the <em>Encyclographie du règne végétal</em>, Bruxelles 1833-1838; NI 2241 is
	sometimes also attributed to Van Geel; the editor was probably Drapiez.

Van Geert, Auguste [August] (1888-1938), Belgian horticulturist at Gent, specialist
on Azaleas. (<em>Van Geert</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Hortus 3: 1206; Zander ed. 10, p. 727, ed. 11, p. 829.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Cat. gen. livr. impr. Bibl. natl. 201: 758. 1971.
O.K., Rev. Hortic. belg. étrang. 12: 280. 1886 (obit. not.).

<sm>COMPOSITE WORKS</sm>: Co-editor, <em>Revue de l'horticulture belge et étrangère</em>, ... 1 (-27), 1875(-
1900), Gand (Gent).

15.905. <em>Iconographie des Azalées de l'Inde</em>. Recueil mensuel comprenant la figure et la
description des meilleures variétés tant anciennes que nouvelles ... Gand [Gent] (chez
l'éditeur) [1881-1882]. †. Qu. (<em>Iconogr. Azal. Inde</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: 1 Oct 1881-Sep 1882, in 12 dated parts, p. [1]-81, [83-84], <em>pl. 1-36</em> (chromoliths P.
	Stroobant). <em>Copies</em>: BR, G, HH.
German transl.: Gent 1883 (n.v.).
<em>English ed</em>.: Oct 1881-Sep 1882, in 12 dated parts, p. [i], [1]-81, <em>pl. 1-31</em> (id.). – <em>Copy</em>:
	HH. – <em>Iconography of Indian Azaleas</em> comprising figures and descriptions of the best
	varieties old and new by Auguste van Geert, with the assistance of the principal
	horticulturists and amateurs of these plants. Translated by Thomas Moore, junior, of
	Chelsea. Ghent [Gent] (Adolphe Hoste ... Auguste Van Geert ...) 1882. Qu. †.

Van Haesendonck, [Gérard] Constant (1810-1881), Belgian physician and botanist;

PAGE: 666
HEADING: VAN HAESENDONCK

studied at Antwerp; became gynaecologist and pharmacist at the St. Elisabeth hospital,
also practicing physician at Tongerloo. (<em>Van Haesend</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: BR. – Further material at LG. <em>Exsiccatae</em>: <em>Herbier médical belge</em>, 4
fasc. (200 nos.). 1863. Sets at BR and LG. Some further material in Thielens &amp; de Vos,
Kickxia belgica, e.g. BR, GOET and in AWH.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 423 (b. 23 Sep 1810, d. 4 Jul 1881); BL 2:
36, 726.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Bibl. natl., Dict. écriv. belg. 4: 151. 1910 (bibl.).
Crépin, F., Manuel fl. belg. Belgique Ixix. 1860; Guide bot. Belgique 481. 1878.
De Wildeman, E., Biogr. natl. belg. 26: 418-422. 1936-1938 (biogr., bibl.).
Evens, F.M.J.C., Gesch. algol. Belg. 190-191. 1944.

Van Heurck, Henri Ferdinand (1838-1909), Belgian botanist, microscopist and in-
dustrialist at Antwerp; autodidactic botanist, in charge of his family's colour-factory and
chemical firm 1869-1896; "director-professor" of the Antwerp botanical garden 1877-
1909. (<em>Van Heurck</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: AWH; diatoms types mainly at AWH, but also at B (mainly lost)
and in the <em>Types du Synopsis</em>, see below. Van Heurck herbarium material (distributed by
him) in BR, MANCH, OS. The core of the Van Heurck herbarium is the F.W. Sieber-
Carl Reichenbach herbarium, acquired by him in 1867; for details see e.g. Martinis
(1870), Frison (1963, p. 38-41) and Verleyen (1942). – <em>Exsiccatae</em>: (<em>1</em>) <em>Types du Synopsis
des Diatomées de Belgique</em>, nos. 1-550, 1882-1885 (text determ., notes diagn. by A.
Grunov). Sets at B (mainly destr.), BM, FH, PH, W.
(2) <em>Herbier des plantes rares ou critiques de Belgique</em> (with Arthur Martinis), 1866-1870, fasc.
1-8 (50 nos./fasc). Sets at BR, LG, OXF. – See notice Bot. Zeit. 24: 324. 1866. – <em>Letters</em>
at G.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 424 (b. 28 Aug 1838, d. 13 Mar 1909); BL 2:
35, 36, 726; Bossert p. 414; Clokie p. 183; CSP 3: 340, 10: 220, 12: 331, 15: 818-819; De
Toni 1: cxxvi-cxxvii, 2: cxvi-cxviii, cxxix, 4: lvi-lvii; Herder p. 482 [index]; IH 1 (ed. 6):
365, (ed. 7): 345; Jackson p. 204, 220, 272; Morren ed. 2, p. 15, ed. 10, p. 44; MW p.
510; NI 868, 868n, na; PR 4037-4040; Rehder 5: 389-390; SK 1: cxxvii; TL-2/11.173,
11.204, see F.W. Sieber, A.F. Spring; Urban-Berl. p. 356.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Allg. bot. Z. 15: 80. 1909 (d.); Bibl. natl., Dict. Écriv. belg. 4: 162-163.
	1910; Bot. Centralbl. 1-2: 156-157. 1880 (herb.), 110: 400. 1909 (d.); Bot. Zeit. 25:
	343. 1867 (offers plants for exchange; 150.000 duplicates from his herbarium

	126, [127-128], <em>pl. 1-13. Copies</em>: B, BR, NY, PH.

Vanhöffen, Ernst (1858-1918), German (East-Prussian) zoologist, botanist (algologist)
and explorer of Greenland; studied at the University of Königsberg 1878-1886; state
teacher's examination ib. 1886; assistant at the Zoological Institute, Königsberg 1886-
1890 (in Naples 1889-1890); Dr. phil. ib. 1888; professor of zoology at the University of
Kiel 1890-1906. (<em>Vanhöffen</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: B (mainly destr.); further material in C, KIEL.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 424 (b. 15 Nov 1858); Biol.-Dokum. 18:
9513-9514; BM 5: 2193, 8: 1356-1357; De Toni 4: lvii; LS 27634; Urban-Berl. p. 262,
269, 283, 291, 316, 406.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Brit. Mus. gen. cat. print. books 246: 385. 1964; Cat. gén. livr. impr.
	Bibl. natl. 201: 1056-1057. 1971.
Lohmann, H., Mitt. Zool. Mus. Berlin 9(1): 71-90. 1918 (obit., bibl.).
Prescott, G.W., Bibl. Desmid. univ. 520. 1984.
Schmid, B. &amp; C. Thesing, Biol.-Kalend. 1: 329. 1914.
VanLandingham, S.L., Cat. Diat. 4: 2379. 1971, 6: 3599. 1978, 7: 4236. 1978.
Wittrock, V.B., Acta Horti Berg. 3(3): 155. 1905.

<sm>COMPOSITE WORKS</sm>: <em>Grönlands Pflanzenwelt</em> in Erich von Drygalski, Grönland-Expedition
der Gesellschaft für Erdkunde zu Berlin 1891-1892, 2(1): [i], [323]-380, <em>pl. 7-8.</em> 1897.

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Vanhoeffenia</em> Wille (1924); <em>Vanhoeffenus</em> Heiden et Kolbe (1928).

PAGE: 670
HEADING: VANHOFFEN

15.919. <em>Botanische Ergebnisse</em> der von der Gesellschaft für Erdkunde zu Berlin unter

Sammlungen bearbeitet. A. <em>Kryptogamen</em> ... Stuttgart (Verlag von Erwin Nägele) 1897.
Qu. (<em>Bot. Erg. Grönlandexped., Krypt.</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: 1897 (p. vii: Feb 1897; Hedwigia Jul-Oct 1897), p. [i*], [i]-vii, [1]-75, <em>1 pl</em>. –
	Issued as Bibl. bot. 42(A), 1897. Vorwort (p. v-vii) and <em>Grönländische Peridineen und

<em>Phanerogams</em> 1899, in 42(B), p. [1]-105, <em>pl. 1-5, Samenpflanzen</em> (Phanerogamen) aus dem

<em>Ref</em>.: Karsten, Bot. Zeit. 55(2): 363-364. 1 Dec 1897 (rev.).

Van Hoorebeke, Charles Joseph (1790-1821), Belgian pharmacist and botanist at
Gent (Gand). (<em>Van Hoorebeke</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 424 (b. 14 Sep 1790, d. 25 Jul 1821).

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Crépin, F., Guide bot. Belgique 483. 1878.

15.920. <em>Mémoire sur les Orobanches</em> (en Thiois) Hongers Smeer-Kruyd, Brem-Raep,
Priemen, pour servir d'instruction à la culture du trèfle dans les communes où
l'Orobanche nuit à sa culture ... à Gand [Gent] (Chez P.F. de Goesin-Verhaeght ...)
1818. (<em>Mém. Orobanche</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: Jan 1818, p. [i-iv], [1]-22. <em>Copies</em>: BR, NY.

Van Houtte, Louis Benoît (1810-1876), Belgian horticulturist; studied at the École
centrale du Commerce, Paris, in Clermont-Ferrand 1826-1828; civil servant in Brussels
1830; travelled in Brazil, Guatemala, Honduras and the Cape Verde Islands collecting
living plants 1834-1835; with the Brussels botanical garden 1836-1838; from 1839 at
Gendbrugge as private commercial horticulturist; setting up a horticultural school and
functioning longtime as burgomaster. (<em>Van Houtte</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: AG 4: 558; Backer p. 609; Barnhart 3: 424 (b. 1 Jul
1910, d. 9 Mai 1876); Bossert p. 414; GF p. 84; Herder p. 151, 367; Hortus 3: 1206;
Morren, ed. 2, p. 16, ed. 10, p. 45; MW p. 510-511, suppl. p. 378; NI 2254; PR 5203,
7167, ed. 1: 5745, 10660; Rehder 5: 408-409; Sotheby 445; TL-2/see A.C. Lemaire,
P.L.V. Lemoine, M.J.F. Scheidweiler; Tucker 1: 11; Zander ed. 10, p. 727, ed. 11, p.
829.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Bonplandia 1(3): 23-24. 1853 (on genesis of <em>Fl. Serres</em>; first volume
	originally publ. in 500 copies, later 1500; first volumes twice reprinted); Bull. Soc.
	bot. France 23: 239. 1876 (d.); Centenaire de la naissance de Louis Van Houtte, notes
	biographiques et souvenirs; programme des fêtes jubilaires, Gand [Gent] 1910. 73 p.;
	Gard. Chron. 1876: 635, 655, 1935: 55-56; Grote Winkler Prins 10: 841. 1951.
Buyssens, A., Louis van Houtte, Gand [Gent] 1913. 30 p.
Guilmot, G. et al., <em>in</em> L. Van Houtte, Fl. Serres Jard. Eur. 22: i-xliv. 1877 (biogr., portr.,
	tributes, monument), 23: i-xi. 1880 (on monument).
Haegeman, J., Tuberous Begonias 211. 1979.
Leroy, J.F., et al., Bot. franç. Amér. nord 31, 125, 260. 1957.
Pynaert, Ch., Biogr. natl. Acad. r. Belg. 26: 432-433. 1936-1938.
Regel, E., Gartenflora 25: 262-266. 1876 (obit., portr.).
Rodigas, É., Rev. hort. belg. étrang. 2: 123-130. 1876 (obit.).
St.R., Gartenflora 59: 375-376. 1910 (Van Houtte commem.).

<sm>COMPOSITE WORKS</sm>: (1) Founder, with Ch. Morren, of <em>L'Horticulteur belge</em> 1839.
(2) <em>Seed catalogues</em> Établissement horticole L. Van Houtte 1839-1896, available on IDC
7479.

PAGE: 671
HEADING: VAN HOUTTE

(3) With G. Planchon, <em>La Victoria regia</em> 1850-1851, TL-2/8009.

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Houttea</em> Decaisne (1848); <em>Vanhouttea</em> Lemaire (1845).

15.921. <em>Flore des serres</em> et des jardins de l'Europe, ou descriptions et figures des plantes les
plus rares et les plus méritantes, nouvellement introduites sur le continent ou en
Angleterre, et extraites notamment des Botanical Magazine, Botanical Register,
Paxton's Magazine of Botany, etc., etc., etc; ouvrage publié en allemand, en français et
en anglais, enrichi de notices historiques, scientifiques, étymologiques, synonymiques,
horticulturales, etc., et rédigé par M.Ch. Lemaire, ... M. Scheidweiler, ... M.L. Van
Houtte, horticulteur, ancien botaniste-voyageur, ancien rédacteur principal de
l'Horticulteur belge, collaborateur de l'Horticulteur universel, ex-directeur du Jardin
botanique de Bruxelles, etc. ... Tome premier [-xxiii] à Gand [Gent] (chez Louis Van
Houtte, éditeur) 1845 [-1880]. Qu. (<em>Fl. Serres</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: 23 volumes, 1845-1880. <em>Copies</em>: BR, HH, NY, U. – General editor Louis Van
	Houtte; collaborators for the text listed (as "rédacteurs") on the title-pages ... We
	were fortunate in receiving from L. Garay an analysis of the 23 volumes, providing
	contents and dates, based on a copy at Harvard and on notices in the contemporary
	literature. The indications "out ..." refer to data obtained from various horticultural
	journals; the term "issued" reflects actual publication on that date; "out" means:
	"published by ..."

Vaniot, Eugène (x-1913), French clergyman (S.J.) and botanist in Le Mans. (<em>Vaniot</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: In private hands (see Kent &amp; Allen 1984).

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Vaniotia</em> Léveillé (1903).

Van Schaack, George Booth (1903-1983), American botanist and botanical librarian;
Dr. math. Harvard 1935; instructor mathematics, Harvard 1929-1935; with Equitable
Life Assurance Soc. 1935-1936; instructor mathematics Rochester 1936-1938, Michigan
State College 1938-1940; assistant prof. ib. 1940-1943; became interested in botany
(grasses) when U.S. Navy lieutenant in the Aleutian Islands during World War II;
teacher in mathematics in St. Louis 1946-1960; from 1954 on the library committee of
the Missouri Botanical Garden, from 1958-1968 librarian in charge ib.; librarian
Morton Arboretum, Lisle, Illinois 1968; in retirement at the University of Oregon,
ultimately in Florida. (<em>Van Schaack</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: US; duplicates E, GH, ILL, K, LE, MO, WIS. Correspondence
at Hunt Institute, Pittsburgh.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Bossert p. 414; IH 1 (ed. 5): 161, (ed. 6): 365, (ed. 7):
345; Roon p. 117; SIA 227, 7231 (HI 107).

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Amer. men Sci. eds. 6-10, 1938-1955; Bull. Hunt Inst. Bot. Docum.
	4(2): 3. 1982 (archives at HU); Missouri Bot. Gard. Bull. 71(6): 10. 1983.

PAGE: 676
HEADING: VAN SCHAACK

Eisendrath, E., The many sides of George van Schaack, [unidentified] p. 8-13 (on his
work at MO).

Vareschi, Volkmar (1906-x), Austrian botanist; Dr. phil. Innsbruck 1931; assistant at
the Geobot. Forschungsinst. Rübel, Zürich 1931-1935; in 1936 with the Arbeitsgemeins-
chaft für Raumforschung, München; assistant 1937, lecturer for botany 1939 at the
University of München; with the Sven Hedin Institut 1940-1941; with a Seed Station at
Radstadt, Salzburg 1945-1946; lecturer Innsbruck 1947-1949; emigrated to Venezuela
1950; with the Universidad Central de Caracas from 1951, professor 1953; nationalized
Venezuelan citizen 1956; explored the Venezuelan Amazonas 1958-1973. (<em>Vareschi</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: VEN; other material at DPU, H, MO; lichens at M.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Biol.-Dokum. 18: 9515; BJI 2: 183; GR p. 442-443 (b. 25
Mai 1906), <em>pl</em>. [<em>23</em>]; IF suppl. 4: 347; IH 1 (ed. 1): 23, (ed. 2): 38, (ed. 3): 44, (ed. 4): 47,
(ed. 5): 42, (ed. 6): 54; Roon p. 117.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Index amer. bot. lit. 1886-1966. 4: 418. 1969
Frodin, D.G., Guide standard floras world no. 616. 1984.

	180. 1938, 6: 309. 1941.

15.923. <em>Der Berg blüht</em>. Erleben und Deutung alpiner Pflanzen in Wort und Bild ...
München (Verlag F. Bruckmann) [1978]. Oct. (<em>Berg blüht</em>).

<em>English</em>: <em>Mountains in flower</em>, London (L. Drummond) 1939, 1947, New York (The

Vasey, George (1822-1893), English-born American botanist, especially agrostologist;
came with his parents to the United States 1823; Dr. med. Pittsfield, Mass. 1847; pract-
icing physician in northern Illinois 1848-1868; with J.W. Powell on exploring expedit-
ions to Colorado 1868 and 1869; in charge of the Museum of the State Normal Univers-
ity of Illinois, Bloomington 1869-1872; from 1872-1893 botanist at the United States
Department of Agriculture and curator of the United States National Herbarium.
(<em>Vasey</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: US; other material in BRU, CINC, CLM, DPU, DS, E, F, FH,
ILL, ILLS, K, KNOX, KU, MASS, MSC, NA, NMC, NY, NYS, PENN, PH, POM,
WELC, WECO, WS. – <em>Field notes</em>: US. – <em>Letters</em>: G, GH, US.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Backer p. 610; Barnhart 3: 427 (b. 23 Feb 1822, d. 4
Mar 1893); BJI 1: 60; BL 1: 136, 152, 322; BM 5: 2193; CSP 8: 1144, 12: 751, 19: 300-
301; DAB 19: 229-230 (W.R. Maxon); Desmond p. 627; Ewan ed. 1: 326-327, 357, ed.
2: 227; Herder p. 27, 278; Hortus 3: 1206; IH 1 (ed. 6): 365, (ed. 7): 345, 2: 649, 706;
Jackson p. 360; Langman p. 771-772; Lenley p. 422, 471; LS 27645, 40216; ME 1: 236-
237, 3: 670; Morren ed. 10, p. 116; NI 2040-2041; NW p. 60; PH 132, 164, 906; Rehder
5: 875; TL-2/6664; Tucker 1: 715, 2: xxxix, 3: 321.

15.928. <em>A descriptive catalogue of the grasses of the United States</em>, including especially the grass
collections at the New Orleans exposition made by the U.S. Department of Agriculture,
and the state exhibits of grasses, with notes on such species as are more or less employed

Vatke, [George Carl] Wilhelm (1849-1889), German (Berlin) botanist; studied at the
University of Berlin as student of A. Braun; assistant at the Berlin Botanical Garden
1876-1879; from 1879 privately active, exclusively with botany, visiting various Euro-
pean herbaria, assembling a considerable herbarium and library; mostly working at
Berlin. (<em>Vatke</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: JE; other material at GOET, K (ex herb.), W. – <em>Letters</em> to E. v.
Halácsy and K. Keck at UPS-UB.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: AG 6(2): 454; Barnhart 3: 427 (b. 12 Aug 1849, d. 6 Apr
1889); Biol.-Dokum. 18: 9519; BJI 1: 60; BM 5: 2196; Bossert p. 415; CSP 8: 1144, 11:
682, 12: 751, 19: 303; DTS 1: 314, 6(4): 64; Herder p. 482 [index]; Hortus 3: 1206; IH 1
(ed. 6): 365, (ed. 7): 345; Morren ed. 11, p. 7; MW p. 512; Rehder 5: 875; RS p. 146;
Zander ed. 10, p. 727, ed. 11, p. 829; Zep-Tim. p. 111.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Nat. Nov. 11: 133. 1889 (d.).
Ascherson, P.F.A., <em>in</em> Nachtrag zu L. Schneider's <em>Flora von Magdeburg</em> 1894, p. 72.
Hoffmann, O., Ber. deut. bot. Ges. 7: (21)-(24). 1889 (obit.).
Lack, H.W. &amp; C.-O. von Sydow, Willdenowia 14: 443. 1984.
Magnus, P.W., Ann. Bot. 3: 493-494. 1890 (bibl.).
Volkens, G.L.A., Verh. bot. Ver. Brandenburg 51: (85). 1910.

<sm>COMPOSITE WORKS</sm>: Author of part 6 of the series <em>Reliquiae rutenbergianae</em>, Feb 1885, see
TL-2/4: 1008, Abh. naturw. Ver. Bremen 9(2): 115-138.

<sm>HANDWRITING</sm>: <em>in</em> G. Wagenitz, <em>Index coll. princ. Herb. Gott.</em> 212. 1982.

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Vatkea</em> O. Hoffmann (1880).

Vátova, Aristocle (1897-x), Italian botanist; Dr. phil. Torino 1924, later at the
Institute for marine biology at Rovigno d'Istria. (<em>Vàtova</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown. – Issued a set of <em>Algae adriaticae exsiccatae</em>, fasc. 1, nos.

Vaucher, Jean Pierre Etienne (1763-1841), Swiss clergyman and botanist; Dr. theol.
1787, ordained 1787; in charge of a private school until 1828; pastor of St. Gervais at
Genève 1795-1821; honorary professor of botany Genève 1802; professor of ecclesiastical
history at the Theological Faculty 1808-1841. (<em>Vauch</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: G. – <em>Letters</em> at G.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Ainsworth p. 117; Barnhart 3: 427 (b. 27 Apr 1763, d. 5
Jan 1841); CSP 6: 113; De Toni 1: cxxvii, 2: cxviii; DSB 13: 595-596 (D.M. Simpkins);
Frank 3 (Anh.): 108; Herder p. 170, 225, 268, 316; Jackson p. 139, 150, 155, 226;
Lasègue p. 545; Moebius p. 457 [index]; MW p. 512; NI 2042-2044; Plesch p. 447; PR
1502, 9704-9710, ed. 1: 10680-10686; Sotheby 787; TL-1/1353.

Vaupel, Friedrich Karl Johann (1876-1927), German (Prussian/Rhenisch Palat-
inate) botanist; followed a military career 1893-1895, pensioned off because of invalidity
1895; studied medicine and natural sciences in Berlin, Heidelberg and München; in
Mexico and the West Indies 1899-1910; Dr. phil. München 1903 as student of K. v.
Goebel; travelled in India, Australia and the Samoa Islands 1903-1907; assistant at the
Botanical Museum Berlin-Dahlem 1908, curator ib. 1921, professor's title 1926; on
active service as training officer 1914-1918; specialist on Cactaceae. (<em>Vaup</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: B (partly extant, incl. ferns and alcohol material, see Leuenber-
ger 1979); other material in DPU, K, M, MO, P, US, W.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 428 (b. 23 Mai 1876, d. 4 Mai 1927); Biol.-
Dokum. 18: 9521; BJI 2: 182; Hortus 3: 1206; Langman p. 772-773; SK 1: 538; TL-
2/1711, 11.386, 11.388, see R.L.A.M. Guerke, K. Schumann; Tucker 1: 716, 3: 322;
Urban-Berl. 406; Zander ed. 10, p. 727, ed. 11, p. 830; Zep-Tim p. 112.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Gard. Chron. ser. 3. 81: 442. 1927 (d.); Index Amer. bot. lit. 1886-1966.
	4: 421-422. 1969; Notizbl. Berlin-Dahlem 6: 321. 1915 (active service, lieutenant), 7:
	334. 1917 (Eisernes Kreuz II. Kl., "für Kriegshilfe"), 10: 122-123. 1927 (obit.);
	Österr. bot. Z. 76(2): 168. 1927 (d.).
Fiedler, M., Kakteen und andere Sukkulenten 23(12): 319-325. 1972.
Knobloch, I.W., Phytologia Mem. 6: 99. 1983 (coll. Mexico).
König, G., Z. Sukkulentenk. 1927(3): 42-44 (obit., portr.).
Leuenberger, B.E., Willdenowia 8: 625-635. 1978 (85 types of Cactaceae extant at B in
	alcohol coll., incl. Vaupel types); see also Cact. Suc. mex. 23: 88-92. 1978.
Ulbrich, E., Verh. bot. Ver. Brandenburg 70(1): 31-35. 1928 (obit., bibl.).
Urban, I., Symb. ant. 5: 15. 1904 (Vaupel, Mexicanische und West-indische Kakteen,
	<em>in</em> Monatschr. Kakteenk. 12: 10-45, 50-62, 75-78, 90-96. 1902).
Vaupel, F., Bot. Jahrb. 44 (Beibl. 102): 47-58, <em>pl. 1-3.</em> 9 Aug 1910, repr. in Ber. Zusam-
	menk. Frei. Ver. Pflanzengeogr. Syst. Bot. 1910: 47-58, <em>pl. 1-3.</em>

<sm>COMPOSITE WORKS</sm>: (1) Founder and editor, <em>Zeitschrift für Sukkulentenkunde</em>, Berlin, vols. 1-
3, 1923-1928.
(2) With K. Schumann and R.A.L.M. Guerke, <em>Blühende Kakteen</em>, see under K. Schum-
ann (contribution 1900-1921).
(3) <em>Cactaceae</em> in EP, <em>Nat. Pflanzenfam.</em> ed. 2: 21: 594-561. Dec 1925.
(4) <em>Cactaceae</em> in EP <em>Nat. Pflanzenfam.</em> ed. I. Nachtr. 4: 1914.
(5) Entries on <em>Cactaceae, in</em> Graebner &amp; Lange, <em>Ill. Gartenbaulexikon</em> ed. 4. vol. I. 1925.
(6) With M. Gürke, <em>Borraginaceae, in</em> J. Mildbread, ed., <em>Wiss. Ergebn. deut. Zentr</em>.-<em>Afr. Exp.</em>
1907-1908, 2: 279-281. 1911.
(7) <em>Borraginaceae, in</em> R. Pilger, <em>Plantae Uleanae</em> novae vel minus cognitae, Notizbl. Berlin-
Dahlem 6(56): 181-187. 15 Mai, 1914.
(8) Editor, <em>Monatschrift für Kakteenkunde</em> 21-30. 1911-1920.

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Vaupelia</em> A. Brand (1914, <em>nom. cons.</em>).

15.947. <em>Beiträge zur Kenntniss einiger Bryophyten</em>. Inauguraldissertation zur Erlangung der

Maximilians-Universität zu München vorgelegt ... München (Druck von Val. Höfling,

<em>Publ</em>.: 1903 (before 22 Jul 1903, as preprint; Nat. Nov. Dec(1) 1904), p. [1]-29, [1, vita].

	[1]-40. <em>Copies</em>: B, HH. – First part previously published in Monatschr. Kakteenk. 23:

Vaupell, Christian Theodor (1821-1862), Danish botanist and high school teacher;
Cand. theol. 1847; Dr. phil. Copenhagen 1859; lecturer ("privatdocent") at Copenha-
gen University 1860-1862. (<em>Vaupell</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: C.

Vauquelin, Louis Nicolas (1763-1829), French chemist and pharmacist; studied at
Rouen and Paris; pharmacist at a hospital in Melun 1793; inspector of mines and
assistant professor of chemistry at the École polytechnique, Paris 1794; later professor of
chemistry at the Collège de France and at the Muséum d'Histoire naturelle and from
1811 at the Faculté des Sciences. (<em>Vauquelin</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

Vautier, Simone (1908-1971), Swiss botanist; assistant in a private laboratory for med-
ical analyses 1930-1940; studied botany at Genève 1940-1943 with Chodat, Hochreut-
iner and Becherer; scientist at the Conservatoire botanique 1943-1970; Dr. sci. nat.
Genève 1949. (<em>Vautier</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: G (Acquired 1971). – <em>Letters</em> at G.

Vavilov, Nikolay Ivanovich (1887-1943), Russian botanist, agronomist, geneticist
and phytogeographer; studied at the Moscow Agricultural Institute 1906-1911, reserach
assistant ib. 1911-1912; with the Bureau of Applied Botany and the Bureau of Myco-
logy, St. Petersburg 1912-1913; studied at the University of Cambridge and the John
Innes Institution 1913-1914; teacher at Moscow University 1914-1916; explored Iran
and Pamir 1916-1917; professor of genetics at the Voronezh Agricultural Institute and
id. of agronomy at Saratov University 1917-1920; head of the department of applied
botany Petrograd 1920-1924; in charge of the All Union Institute of applied botany
(later id. of plant breeding, VIR) 1924, set up the All Union Lenin Academy of Agricul-
tural Sciences, 1929-1935; travelled widely 1929-1940, collecting economic plants.
(<em>Vavilov</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: WIR.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 428 (b. 26 Nov 1887, d. 2 Aug 1942); BFM
2983; Biol.-Dokum. 18: 9521; BM 8: 1359; Bossert p. 416; DSB 15: 505-513 (extensive
list sec. lit.; bibl., b. 25 Nov 1887, d. 26 Jan 1943); IH 1 (ed. 1): 71, (ed. 2): 89, (ed. 6):
365, (ed. 7): 345; Langman p. 773; Lenley p. 422; LS suppl. 28553-28556; MW p. 512-
513, suppl. 383-384; TL-2/see M. Lagasca, E.N. Sinskaya; Zander ed. 10, p. 727, ed. 11,
p. 830.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Great Soviet Encyclopaedia ed. 3. 4: 540-541. 1974 (d. 26 Jan 1943); J.
	Heredity 37: 15. 1946 (question of V.'s death), 47(1): portr. facing p. 47. 1956
	("scientific resuscitation").
Bachteev, F.Ch. (Bakhteyev, F.Kh.), Der Züchter 128(4): 161-166. 1958 (biogr. sketch,
	d. 2 Aug 1942); Quart. Rev. Biol. 35(2): 115-119. 1960 (id. 1, Bot. Zhurn. 53(4): 544-
	545. 1968, Theoret. Appl. Genet., Berlin 38: 79-84. 1968; Int. Org. Plant Biosyst.,
	Newsletter 3: 1-4. 1970 (Vavilov and biosystematics); Izv. Akad. Nauk SSSR, Biol. 1:
	119-131. 1980.

Vayredra y Vila, Estanislao (1848-1901), Spanish (Catalonian) botanist and
pharmacist at Olot, Gerona, Barcelona and Sagaro. (<em>Vayr</em>.).

Veesenmeyer, Karl Gustav (1814-1901), German physician, traveller and botanist;
studied theology at Tübingen 1833-1834, 1836-1837; vicar on the Schwäbische Alp
1838; studied medicine at Heidelberg 1840-1842; Dr. med. ib. 1842; private physician to
Sir Mervin Stuart in Ireland 1842-1844; id. with the Chowanski family from 1845 in
Germany and Russia; state medical examination Kasan 1847; with Claus on an expedit-
ion around the Caspian Sea 1852; professor of medicine in Ulm 1853-1885, from 1866
also municipal librarian. (<em>Veesenm</em>.).

Veitch, Harry James (1840-1924), British horticulturist; second son of James Veitch
(1815-1869), from 1858 with the Chelsea nurseries of James Veitch, main promoter of
the Chelsea flower shows; leading spirit and most enterprising member of the Veitch
family in the firm "James Veitch &amp; Sons"; knighted 1912. (<em>H.J. Veitch</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: K (general herb. rd. 1884); other material in BM, E.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: AG 3: 909; Barnhart 3: 429 (b. 29 Jun 1840, d. 6 Jul
1924); BB p. 310; BM 5: 2199; Bossert p. 416; CSP 19: 310; Desmond p. 628 (further sec.
refs.); DNB 1922-1930: 368-369 (868-869) (A.W. Hill); Hortus 3: 1196, 1206; Morren
ed. 10, p. 73; MW p. 513; Rehder 5: 876; SK 1: 538; TL-2/11.979, see T. Lobb; Tucker
1: 716, 2: xxxix; Zander ed. 10, p. 672, ed. 11, p. 766.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Bot. Soc. Exch. Club Brit. Isl. Rep. 7(3): 545-546. 1925; Brit. Mus. gen.
	cat. print. books 247: 154-155. 1964 (James Veitch and son); Hedwigia 65: (195).
	1925 (d.); Gard Chron. 1899(1): 40 (portr.), 1910(1): 72-73 (port.), 1912(1): 365-366,
	1914(2): 19-20, 1921(2): 192, 1925(1): 67, 1964(2): 139-140; Nature 114: 95-96. 1924;
	The Times 7 Jul 1924 ("A great pioneer gardener"; see also J. Bot. 62: 253. 1924);
	Who's who 1914-1924; Who was who 1916-1928: 1070.
Bunyard, E.A., Proc. Linn. Soc. 136: 83-84. 1929.
Curtis, C.H., J.R. Hort. Soc. 73: 242-247, 284-290. 1948.

	house of Veitch", excellent concise account, genealogy, list of collectors).

W.D., Bull. misc. Inf. Kew 1914: 88 (present. Conifer cones).

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Veitchia</em> Lindley (1861, <em>nom. rej.</em>); <em>Veitchia</em> H. Wendland (1868, <em>nom. cons.</em>)
commemorate James Veitch (1815-1869).

<sm>THE HOUSE OF VEITCH</sm>: John Veitch (1752-1839) was the original founder of the Veitch

PAGE: 689
HEADING: H. J. VEITCH

firm: he started a nursery at Budlake which was in existence in 1800. John and his son
James (1792-1863) purchased land at Mount Radford in Exeter and thus founded the
Exeter nursery of which James took charge in 1837. James was joined in the firm by his
son James junior (1815-1869) and James Veitch &amp; Son became a widely known es-
tablishment. A nursery in Chelsea was purchased in 1853; James Sr. remained in Exeter
and James Jr. took charge of the Chelsea (London) nursery. The two nurseries became
different firms in 1863 on the death of James Sr. The Exeter firm came in the hands of
Robert Toswill Veitch (1823-1885), younger brother of James Jr.; the latter took charge
of the Chelsea firm with the assistance of his three sons and traded as James Veitch &amp;
Sons. John Gould Veitch (1839-1870), well-known for his collecting in the Far East, and
Harry James Veitch (1840-1906) were admitted to partnership in 1865; the third son,
Arthur Veitch (1844-1880) was, apparently, less active in the firm. Harry James and
John Gould took charge of the firm on their father's death in 1869; John Gould died
1870 and Harry James V. continued alone. His two nephews James Herbert Veitch and
John Gould Veitch II (sons of John Gould I) were taken in the business. The firm closed
down (as a family enterprise) with the retirement of H.J. Veitch in 1914. Harry James
Veitch can be regarded as the leading spirit from 1865 onwards and we therefore treat
books issued by "James Veitch and Sons" under his name. For a concise and infor-
mative history see K.A.P. Fuller and J.M. Langdon (1973); see also James H. Veitch,
<em>Hortus Veitchii</em> (1906), treated below.

15.970. <em>A manual of the Coniferae</em>, containing a general review of the order; a synopsis of
the hardy kinds cultivated in Great Britain; their place and use in horticulture, etc., etc.
... Chelsea, S.W. [London] (James Veitch &amp; Sons, ...) 1881. Oct. (<em>Man. Conif.</em>).

Veitch, James Herbert (1868-1907), British horticulturist and collector; son of John
Gould Veitch (1839-1870), worked in the Chelsea nursery of the Veitch family from
1885; travelled around the world 1891-1893; managing director of James Veitch &amp; Sons
Ltd. 1898; sent E.H. Wilson to Tibet and China for plant collecting. (<em>J.H. Veitch</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: K; further material in BM.

2199; Bossert p. 416; Bret. p. 767; Desmond p. 628-629 (b. 1 Mai 1868); DNB suppl.
1901-1911: 555 (G.S. Boulger); MW p. 513; Plesch p. 448; Rehder 5: 877; SK 1: 538-
539, cix; Sotheby 788; TL-2/11.977; Tucker 1: 716-717; Zander ed. 11, p. 830.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Gard. Chron. 1907(2): 360, 160(20): 12-13. 1966; Nature 77: 86-87.
	1907.

Velazquez, Gregorio Tiongson (1901-x), Philippine botanist (algologist); M.Sc.
Univ. Philippines 1931; Dr. phil. Univ. Michigan 1939; with the University of the
Philippines in various ranks 1923-1941; assistant professor of botany ib. 1945, associate
prof. 1951, full professor 1958-1967. (<em>Velazquez</em>).

HEADING: VELENOVSKY
